In 1979, Chogha Zanbil became the first Iranian site to be inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List.
If  you look at google maps you will see that there are many historical palaces and houses around it with different distances from the main temple, but unfortunately there isn't any pavements to reach them.

Name: Persepolis
short_description: Founded by Darius I in 518 B.C., Persepolis was the capital of the Achaemenid Empire. It was built on an immense half-artificial, half-natural terrace, where the king of kings created an impressive palace complex inspired by Mesopotamian models. The importance and quality of the monumental ruins make it a unique archaeological site.
formatted_address: Fars Province, Marvdasht, Persepolis street, Iran

reviews.text:
Persepolis, near Shiraz in Iran, is a historic city that served as the Achaemenid Empire's ceremonial capital. This remarkable archeological site, dating back to the fifth century BCE, provides insight into the majesty and sophistication of one of the world's first major civilizations.

Persepolis, built on a large terrace cut into a mountain, was designed by Darius the Great as a great capital to represent his empire's unity and variety. The name Persepolis comes from the Greek words "Persis," meaning Persia, and "polis," meaning city. In Persian, it is known as "Takht-e Jamshid," which translates to "Throne of Jamshid," after a mythical Persian ruler.

Persepolis' architecture is a masterpiece of engineering and craftsmanship. The gigantic stone columns, complex carvings, and monumental staircases showcase the Achaemenid architects' skill and ingenuity. Some of the most significant aspects of Persepolis are:

The Apadana Palace, located in the middle of Persepolis, served as a large hall for royal gatherings and events. Its massive columns and elaborate reliefs showing topics from around the empire are especially striking.
Treasury: This structure was used to house the royal treasury. Its robust structure and concealed entry indicate that it was intended to preserve important belongings.
The Gate of All Nations is a massive entrance embellished with reliefs portraying representatives from various regions of the empire, signifying the Achaemenid realm's unity.
Hall of Hundred Columns: This massive hall, with its 100 towering columns, was utilized for royal feasts and festivities.

Alexander the Great destroyed Persepolis in 330 BCE, yet the remains have remained for centuries. European visitors rediscovered the monument in the 17th century, and it has subsequently been designated a UNESCO World Heritage site. Today, travelers from all over the world flock to admire the historic city's grandeur and beauty.

Persepolis: A Testament to Achaemenid Grandeur

Persepolis, an ancient ceremonial capital of the Achaemenid Empire, stands as a testament to the power and splendor of one of history's greatest empires. Located in the Fars province of Iran, this UNESCO World Heritage Site offers a glimpse into the past, showcasing the architectural and artistic brilliance of the Persian Empire.

Why You Should Visit:

1. Achaemenid Architecture: The monumental structures, intricate carvings, and grand staircases are a testament to the architectural prowess of the Achaemenid era.
2. Bas-reliefs: The stunning bas-reliefs depicting the Persian kings, their armies, and tribute-bearing subjects provide valuable insights into the history and culture of the empire.
3. Apadana Palace: This grand hall, with its towering columns and intricate carvings, was used for royal receptions and celebrations.
4. Treasury of Darius: Explore the Treasury of Darius, a massive structure that once housed the imperial treasury.
5. Cultural Significance: Immerse yourself in the rich history and culture of ancient Persia.

Tips for Your Visit:

1. Best Time to Visit: The spring and autumn months are the ideal time to visit Persepolis, as the weather is pleasant.
2. Guided Tour: Consider hiring a knowledgeable guide to gain a deeper understanding of the site's history and significance.
3. Comfortable Footwear: Wear comfortable footwear, as the site involves walking on uneven terrain.
4. Sun Protection: Protect yourself from the sun by wearing a hat, sunglasses, and sunscreen.
5. Respectful Behavior: Adhere to the site's rules and regulations, and avoid touching or damaging the ancient structures.

reviews.author_name: -Rebecca's Crazy journey- REBE CHANNEL (旅するレベッカ)
reviews.text:
I'm really glad I went.
It seems to be free for locals, but foreigners were up to 3.5 million rials. I was still impressed by the breathtaking megaliths.
There are several water points on site where cold water is available. Toilets were located in the car park and near the entrance.
I went in August and it felt quite hot as there was nothing to block the sun. I heard we don't need to wear skirf here but I needed something to protect my head from sunshine.

The car park is quite large, but only a few cars were parked there, so it felt a bit run down and lonely.

Drone is forbidden here. I was flying my drone and was forced to delete all the footage.
Are you interested in history? Definitly Visit their and enjoy the vast Persia Empire. I wish more of the palace and art works preserved.

This should be on the bucket list of anyone with and an interest in history, especially that of Alexander or the Near East.

The area is very well maintained with clean restrooms, coffee shops and restaurants a respectful distance from the main site.

Instead of the palace of an “oriental potentate”, you find elegant simplicity and grandeur hewn from stone. A must visit.

Name: Meidan Emam, Esfahan
short_description: Built by Shah Abbas I the Great at the beginning of the 17th century, and bordered on all sides by monumental buildings linked by a series of two-storeyed arcades, the site is known for the Royal Mosque, the Mosque of Sheykh Lotfollah, the magnificent Portico of Qaysariyyeh and the 15th-century Timurid palace. They are an impressive testimony to the level of social and cultural life in Persia during the Safavid era.
formatted_address: Isfahan, Isfahan Province Isfahan ضلع جنوبی, میدان, No. No, Iran

reviews.text:
Shah Abbasi Mosque is a breathtaking architectural marvel that boasts intricate designs and stunning craftsmanship. The mosque's serene atmosphere and historical significance make it a must-visit for anyone interested in experiencing the rich culture and beauty of Islamic architecture. With its peaceful ambiance and spiritual vibe, visiting Shah Abbasi Mosque is a truly enlightening and fulfilling experience.

The intricate details of the design are truly awe-inspiring, the serene atmosphere inside the mosque provided a sense of tranquility and spirituality.

This building is the most important historical mosque of Isfahan and one of the mosques in Naqsh Jahan Square, which was built during the Safavid era and is considered one of the important buildings of Islamic architecture in Iran. This building is considered a masterpiece of architecture, tiling and carpentry of the 11th century. The Shah Mosque was registered as one of Iran's national monuments on January 15, 1310 with registration number 107, and along with Naqsh Jahan Square, it was registered as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

reviews.author_name: -Rebecca's Crazy journey- REBE CHANNEL (旅するレベッカ)
reviews.text:
Entry fee is 2.5M rial for foreigners.
But it's worth it. When I visited here , there were no people (Monday afternoon), so I could see around as much as I wanted.

The mosque is so huge, you should have a wide lens camera. Tripod is prohibited but I could use it. There's a toilet and free water inside.

The Shah Mosque, also known as the Imam Mosque, is a stunning architectural masterpiece located in Isfahan, Iran. It was built during the Safavid dynasty in the early 17th century under the rule of Shah Abbas I. The mosque is a prime example of Persian-Islamic architecture and is considered one of the most beautiful mosques in the world.

The Shah Mosque is renowned for its intricate tile work, calligraphy, and geometric designs that adorn its facade and interior. The mosque's iconic blue tiles, minarets, and majestic dome create a striking visual impression that captivates visitors.

One of the most notable features of the Shah Mosque is its grand entrance portal, which is adorned with intricate tile work and calligraphy. The prayer hall inside the mosque is equally impressive, with its soaring dome, ornate mihrab (prayer niche), and exquisite tile work that create a sense of awe and serenity.

The Shah Mosque is not only a place of worship but also a cultural and historical landmark that showcases the artistic and architectural achievements of the Safavid era. Visitors to Isfahan often visit the Shah Mosque to admire its beauty, learn about its history, and experience the spiritual ambiance of this magnificent architectural gem.

Shah Mosque in Isfahan is a masterpiece of Persian architecture, renowned for its stunning blue-tiled dome, intricate mosaics, and grand entrance. A UNESCO World Heritage site, it embodies the artistic and cultural brilliance of the Safavid era, offering visitors a serene and awe-inspiring experience.

Name: Rock Drawings in Valcamonica
short_description: Valcamonica, situated in the Lombardy plain, has one of the world's greatest collections of prehistoric petroglyphs – more than 140,000 symbols and figures carved in the rock over a period of 8,000 years and depicting themes connected with agriculture, navigation, war and magic.

reviews.text: This is a must see especially for children. This historical park holds rocks engravings up to 7000 years old and it's a window on the otigins of our civilization. The place is visited in particular by schools and the guides are prepared to explain things to 7-8 years old children. They sell also books and guides that explain everything at various levels from children to passionate adults. The ticket price includes also the entrance to the museum that is at the nearby town and can be visited even on a different day

Very beatiful location with several rock escarvations of the bronze an iron period. This site is quite unique within Europe. The guides are really friendly and able to answer your questions. We visited the place with three kids between 5-7 years who also liked it. Be aware that the parking space at the chirch is rather small. From the parking it is a 15 minute walk to the site.
Nice trail with many old drawings on the Rocks. Some of them are poorly visible but other are very clear. You can imagine why and how people did it 4.000 years ago.

Rock carvings barely legible at best. You'll spend an hour or two, looking at nicely informative plaques and trying and failing to locate the original rock art on the rocks indicated, as not only aren't the carvings visually enhanced in any way, but there are no pointers nor markets of any kind to even show where to look.
Astonishingly lonely an peaceful place for a top archeological site. Greatly preserved engravings allows you to connect with people from 5000 years ago. Sit on the rock, enjoy the sun.

Name: Natural and Culturo-Historical Region of Kotor
short_description: In the Middle Ages, this natural harbour on the Adriatic coast in Montenegro was an important artistic and commercial centre with its own famous schools of masonry and iconography. A large number of the monuments (including four Romanesque churches and the town walls) were seriously damaged by the 1979 earthquake but the town has been restored, largely with UNESCO’s help.

reviews.text:
This walk was a real highlight for me.

There are many hairpins close together which means you get high quick. There is always a view the whole way up, whether that is of the fortress, the bay, town and water or the surrounding mountains.

I loved this hike.

It took about 1 hour to get to the top. Going early in the morning means you have the trail all to yourself.

There are 2 buildings on the way up which sell drinks etc. I wish I'd come with money to support it!

If you don't make it to the top, I can tell you that you don't need to get to the top. The views are in fact better about 15-20 mins before the top anyway!!
Amazing but dabgerous hike if you have wrong shoes, would not reccomend in the dark.

Amazing walk. Definitely need some kind of fitness level to walk all the way up in a summer time. As heat hits you hard. Some steps pretty narrow and steep. You can get a drink on a way from private seller but without  toilet not sure how good of the idea this would be. We spend around 2h, definitely have been happy to reach the top and enjoy the view. Although I have enjoyed all way up and down. It was €8pp and it was worth it.

It was too hot 36 degrees and was around 12.45 afternoon when I started to walk up but it was worth it. Nice physical activity and amazing view. And yes it feels like stairs will never end but until reach. 😅
Great hike and incredible views. The path is not to rigorous but by 8am the guards are charging hikers even if you are coming down and only want to exit

Name: Sagarmatha National Park
short_description: Sagarmatha is an exceptional area with dramatic mountains, glaciers and deep valleys, dominated by Mount Everest, the highest peak in the world (8,848 m). Several rare species, such as the snow leopard and the lesser panda, are found in the park. The presence of the Sherpas, with their unique culture, adds further interest to this site.

reviews.text:
Sagarmatha National Park is a once-in-a-lifetime destination that every nature lover and adventure seeker must experience! 🌄✨ Home to the world’s highest peak, Mount Everest, this park offers some of the most spectacular landscapes and breathtaking views you will ever encounter. From snow-capped mountains to lush forests, Sagarmatha truly showcases the beauty and grandeur of the Himalayas.

Trekking through the park is an unforgettable experience. The trails take you through Sherpa villages, ancient monasteries, and pristine valleys, all while offering incredible views of Everest, Lhotse, and Nuptse. The park is a UNESCO World Heritage site, and its significance as a sanctuary for wildlife, including snow leopards, red pandas, and a wide range of bird species, makes it even more special.

The atmosphere in Sagarmatha National Park is tranquil and awe-inspiring, with the sheer majesty of the mountains creating a humbling experience. Whether you're trekking to Everest Base Camp or simply soaking in the beauty from one of the viewpoints, this park will leave you with memories to last a lifetime.

Highly recommended for trekkers, nature lovers, and anyone seeking to experience the pure splendor of Nepal’s Himalayan region! 🏔️🌲🌟

This large national park in Northern Nepal is home to three of the six tallest mountains on the planet, including Mount Everest. There are a variety of different hiking trails through the park, ranging from balmy, temperate zones teeming with plant and animal life to frigid, alpine regions devoid of plant and animal life (except people and yaks passing through).

The scenery may be varied, but the majority of it is stunningly beautiful. Absolutely would recommend visiting here. It is easily one of my favorite places I've ever visited.

Views that will stay with me until the day I die.

I've been to my share of national parks and this is the most majestic place I have ever been.

Walking among the giants, crossing blue glacial rivers, awe inspiring swing bridges, beautiful forests!

I did the Everest Basecamp trek and loved walking through here.

Lots of accomodation and trail is very well kept.

Do be warned that October is a busy time of year to go, however the weather is ideal!
Trekking to the Everest Base Camp is a dream of every adventure enthusiasts, with breathtaking trails ,captivating landscapes and heartwarming  people .

Home to Mt. Everest and some of the highest mountain peaks of Himalaya, any trek to Sagarmatha National Park is a lifetime experience ,Attratcts travelers and trekkers from across the globe.The view of nature will forever be  in your mind.The trek trail is beautifully maintained,lots of tea houses, amazing people and all facilities are available on the way including Helicopter service if required.Highly recommended for visit at least once, Trek is tough and one needs to take some preparations both physically and mentally but the trip will be absolutely worth it.

Name: Kathmandu Valley
short_description: The cultural heritage of the Kathmandu Valley is illustrated by seven groups of monuments and buildings which display the full range of historic and artistic achievements for which the Kathmandu Valley is world famous. The seven include the Durbar Squares of Hanuman Dhoka (Kathmandu), Patan and Bhaktapur, the Buddhist stupas of Swayambhu and Bauddhanath and the Hindu temples of Pashupati and Changu Narayan.

reviews.text:
Kathmandu Valley is a breathtaking blend of history, culture, and natural beauty! 🏰🕌 Nestled in the heart of Nepal, this valley is home to UNESCO World Heritage Sites, including Pashupatinath Temple, Boudhanath Stupa, Swayambhunath (Monkey Temple), and the ancient Durbar Squares of Kathmandu, Bhaktapur, and Patan. Each place is a treasure trove of stunning architecture, rich traditions, and deep spiritual significance.

Beyond history, the valley offers vibrant local markets, delicious Nepali cuisine, and warm hospitality. The mix of Hindu and Buddhist heritage, along with breathtaking mountain views, makes Kathmandu Valley a must-visit destination. Whether you're an adventure seeker, a culture lover, or simply looking for a peaceful getaway, this place has something for everyone!

Highly recommended for an unforgettable experience in Nepal! 🌄✨

charming valley of ancient towns, intricate temples, and royal palaces, the Kathmandu Valley has been inhabited since 300 BC. For centuries, the valley has been a place of pilgrimage for both Buddhists and Hindus. Absorbed into the Nepalese Gorkha kingdom in the 12th century, the Kathmandu Valley has nonetheless managed to preserve its many historical structures into the twenty-first century, through wars and natural disasters. Because of its well-preserved architecture and strong cultural traditions, the entire valley was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Kathmandu Valley is a cultural and historical treasure trove that leaves every visitor in awe. This UNESCO World Heritage Site is home to a rich blend of ancient architecture, vibrant traditions, and breathtaking landscapes. The valley boasts iconic landmarks like Kathmandu Durbar Square, Swayambhunath (Monkey Temple), Pashupatinath Temple, and the serene Boudhanath Stupa, each offering a unique glimpse into Nepal’s deep-rooted heritage.

The valley is also surrounded by lush hills and dotted with quaint villages, making it an ideal destination for both cultural exploration and short hikes. The hospitality of the locals adds warmth to the experience, and the bustling markets are perfect for picking up traditional handicrafts and souvenirs.

Whether you’re a history enthusiast, a spiritual seeker, or simply someone looking to soak in the beauty of Nepal, Kathmandu Valley offers an unforgettable experience. A must-visit destination for anyone traveling to Nepal!

The "City of Temples" and beautiful people. Love this town. It is still very well preserved and many ancient temples. The faces of Kathmandu (pictures here) left me a deep impression of this beautiful place. Every face has a story, and everyone is so friendly and beautiful in this wonderful city.

A charming valley of ancient towns, intricate temples, and royal palaces, the Kathmandu Valley has been inhabited since 300 BC. For centuries, the valley has been a place of pilgrimage for both Buddhists and Hindus. Absorbed into the Nepalese Gorkha kingdom in the 12th century, the Kathmandu Valley has nonetheless managed to preserve its many historical structures into the twenty-first century, through wars and natural disasters. Because of its well-preserved architecture and strong cultural traditions, the entire valley was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Name: Urnes Stave Church
short_description: The wooden church of Urnes (the stavkirke) stands in the natural setting of Sogn og Fjordane. It was built in the 12th and 13th centuries and is an outstanding example of traditional Scandinavian wooden architecture. It brings together traces of Celtic art, Viking traditions and Romanesque spatial structures.

reviews.text: Absolutely gorgeous church with its wood carvings. The access to the churchyard and the church itself requires a ticket to a guided tour (130kfor an adult, but OK this includes the guide). The best carvings are on the external northern wall, but the interiors are lovely as well. The guides are very nice. The guided tours start every 30 min or so. There is a small parking space close to the church, or a much bigger place 700m away on the road.

Worth visiting.

I would recommend to park your car before the ferry and take it on foot to save some money if you're not going to the waterfall on the same island next.

You'll be able to get inside the church / on the close territory only with guide. Guide was a very helpful woman who answered all our questions and told a lot about history and details. A little pricey but not regretting at all

Stunning stave church and Ornes is a stunning little place as well! We accessed it via ferry and had a great boat ride. The church itself has a beautiful location within a small fjord and we decided to walk up to it. If you need some refreshments, there’s also a cafe opposite as well as a little museum.

We were really surprised and loved our visit here. It’s a bit difficult and expensive to get there (110kr pp + 160 kr for the ferry - this is a van and 2 ppl), but definitely worth it if you have the time. Hearing the stories from the guide and being able to ask questions was the highlight of our visit, eventhough we normally never like guided tours. The church and its history is really interesting and it’s really nice that everything is told by a local.

An incredible living historical monument. This church has magic in the bones and is very much in use today. We visited in mid April 2023, a bit overcast with a late Spring start. The views are beautiful as it sits on top of a hill. There is a small visitor center and we had a guided tour. You are free to walk all around the graves and sit on the pews in the church. Just beautiful.

Name: Bryggen
short_description: Bryggen, the old wharf of Bergen, is a reminder of the town’s importance as part of the Hanseatic League’s trading empire from the 14th to the mid-16th century. Many fires, the last in 1955, have ravaged the characteristic wooden houses of Bryggen. Its rebuilding has traditionally followed old patterns and methods, thus leaving its main structure preserved, which is a relic of an ancient wooden urban structure once common in Northern Europe. Today, some 62 buildings remain of this former townscape.

reviews.text: Absolutely gorgeous as you'd expect. The shops are all for tourists, so definitely worth stopping over when you want to buy some souvenirs or winter wear.

What a fantastic and lovely area, so much history, it’s amazing listening to the history of the place that is hasn’t been totally raised to the ground. Considering surrounded by forests and all the wooden buildings, which are beautiful. Plenty of coffee shops and restaurants. A must have is the local smoked salmon sandwiches. A trip on the Hop on Hop Off bus  is recommended.

Bryggen in Bergen is a must-visit historical landmark and a UNESCO World Heritage site. This iconic waterfront district features beautifully preserved wooden buildings that date back to the Hanseatic era, offering a glimpse into Norway’s rich maritime history. Visitors can explore charming narrow alleyways, unique local shops, art galleries, and cozy cafés. The area also has museums that showcase Bryggen’s fascinating past. Whether you’re interested in history, shopping for handmade crafts, or simply enjoying the scenic harbor views, Bryggen offers a truly authentic Bergen experience.

Bryggen means "dock" in Norwegian and is the most beautiful part of the city of Bergen. Around 1350 German merchants of the Hanseatic League established here their headquarters to carry out their trades: in particular they exchanged wheat for stockfish. Nowadays it hosts mainly shops and restaurants and it's really cool to walk through its narrow alleys.
Went there twice during my stay in Bergen, has nice vibes to it and great photography opportunities ✨️

Name:
Auschwitz Birkenau
German Nazi Concentration and Extermination Camp (1940-1945)
short_description: The fortified walls, barbed wire, platforms, barracks, gallows, gas chambers and cremation ovens show the conditions within which the Nazi genocide took place in the former concentration and extermination camp of Auschwitz-Birkenau, the largest in the Third Reich. According to historical investigations, 1.5 million people, among them a great number of Jews, were systematically starved, tortured and murdered in this camp, the symbol of humanity's cruelty to its fellow human beings in the 20th century.

Name: Stari Ras and Sopoćani
short_description: On the outskirts of Stari Ras, the first capital of Serbia, there is an impressive group of medieval monuments consisting of fortresses, churches and monasteries. The monastery at Sopoćani is a reminder of the contacts between Western civilization and the Byzantine world.

reviews.text: Not an easy place to reach (at least the most common navigators are misleading, we had to ask for directions to local ppl) but it's worth a visit if you emd up in the Novi Pazar area, along with the surrounding monasteries which are all included into the UNESCO list

There are some ruins here but it is not much. There is a gravel road going up from the main road signed with Gradina. But do not try to go to the end by car. You will probably get stuck on a ramp up with loose rocks (on the way back; it is a downramp when driving in). It will work with a 4WD but not with a normal car.
An interesting historical place with a beautiful view that you have to visit if you come to our town.
Beautiful to climb but very dirty due to unproper cleaning from the munucipality!
Amazing view, hard to reach through the forest by car, not well maintained which is very sad for a world heritage

Name: Ancient City of Damascus
short_description: Founded in the 3rd millennium B.C., Damascus is one of the oldest cities in the Middle East. In the Middle Ages, it was the centre of a flourishing craft industry, specializing in swords and lace. The city has some 125 monuments from different periods of its history – one of the most spectacular is the 8th-century Great Mosque of the Umayyads, built on the site of an Assyrian sanctuary.

Name: Medina of Tunis
short_description: Under the Almohads and the Hafsids, from the 12th to the 16th century, Tunis was considered one of the greatest and wealthiest cities in the Islamic world. Some 700 monuments, including palaces, mosques, mausoleums, madrasas and fountains, testify to this remarkable past.

Name: Archaeological Site of Carthage
short_description: Carthage was founded in the 9th century B.C. on the Gulf of Tunis. From the 6th century onwards, it developed into a great trading empire covering much of the Mediterranean and was home to a brilliant civilization. In the course of the long Punic wars, Carthage occupied territories belonging to Rome, which finally destroyed its rival in 146 B.C. A second – Roman – Carthage was then established on the ruins of the first.
formatted_address: 88 Rte de La Goulette, Site archéologique de Carthage, Tunisia

reviews.text: An amazing experience seeing the ruins of ancient Carthage.  Doing the bike tour would be my recommendation,  as it is a huge site with lots of ground to cover.

The museum was unfortunately closed due to renovations, but the rest was freely accessible. The area is quite small, but still fascinating. Sure, it's just ruins, but I find it hard not to be moved when you're staring at signs of life from hundreds of years ago.
Out of all the sites, this one contains more signs. Maps, info on what these places used to be. I'd say 1h-1h30 should be enough to take it all in.

I love coming to this place as they are many things to see. It is a historical place to visit. And it’s located on top of the hills, the Cathedral was amazing. The entrance ticket that you are, paying will also include all the other historical place within the Carthage area. It’s a great place to visit where you can bring your friends and family.

A great site to visit, our Gate 1 Travel tour was there in early March so the weather was perfect - sunny but nice and cool!  Photos are of Brysa Hill, site of the ancient acropolis, and the Antonine Baths. This is definitely a must see site!
The place is interesting but considering that are ruins. The museum (October 2024) is closed

Name: Amphitheatre of El Jem
short_description: The impressive ruins of the largest colosseum in North Africa, a huge amphitheatre which could hold up to 35,000 spectators, are found in the small village of El Jem. This 3rd-century monument illustrates the grandeur and extent of Imperial Rome.

reviews.text: Incredible place! Much preferred El Jem to the Rome Colosseum. It was peaceful to walk around as it wasn't busy. There's a cafe inside, so it was nice to stop and cool down. The entry ticket also gives you entry to the museum down the road. The tickets were super cheap.

A spectacular place!
No crowds, you can go freely around the amphitheatre, go down into the dungeon and climb up to the upper levels.
It was 100% worth the time to go all the way from Tunis to see this amazing structure.
Don't miss the gift shop on your way out, prices are fixed and very affordable.

A really well preserved Roman amphitheater. While its capacity of 35000 was less than Romes 50000, this one is better preserved. You are also able to access all parts, unlike Rome. It’s a little bit of a trek from Sousse, but it’s well worth the trip.

Let me start by saying that El Jem is a gem. This UNESCO site is strikingly amazing and fairly intact.
The site is picturesque and fairly well maintained with continuous work being carried out. I love the fact that you get incredible views from the upper levels. Unlike Rome, the arena floor is still in tact. You can also go down to the basement. This place is incredible.
The sun piercing through the coves is beautiful. If you can help it, go early on a sunny morning or just before sunset.
The grounds on the outside needs a bit of care but do venture there if you want to take pictures of the site from different angles.
I spent over 2 hours here!
Your ticket will also get you into the El Jem museum which I would recommend visiting.
You can park in the nearby streets if driving. You can also get to El Jem by train or louage (public transport).
There are toilet facilities and security at the site.

Gorgeous place to visit. The UNESCO World Heritage Site Amphitheater of El Jem which is the third largest of its type in the world, meets all expectations. A must see while in Tunisia. Quite impressive

Name: Ngorongoro Conservation Area
short_description: The Ngorongoro Conservation Area spans vast expanses of highland plains, savanna, savanna woodlands and forests. Established in 1959 as a multiple land use area, with wildlife coexisting with semi-nomadic Maasai pastoralists practicing traditional livestock grazing, it includes the spectacular Ngorongoro Crater, the world’s largest caldera. The property has global importance for biodiversity conservation due to the presence of globally threatened species, the density of wildlife inhabiting the area, and the annual migration of wildebeest, zebra, gazelles and other animals into the northern plains. Extensive archaeological research has also yielded a long sequence of evidence of human evolution and human-environment dynamics, including early hominid footprints dating back 3.6 million years.

reviews.text: Must visit when in Tanzania.Amazing game drive and lot of wildlife to see.Great experience.Easier to see lot of animals without trying to find them,it’s packed with animals.
Probably one of the best Safari parks in Tanzania! Not only astonishing wildlife, but also a wonder of nature!! A must visit

Absolutely hard to believe the quantity of animals in the crater. You stand at the top and it appears empty, but once you enter it’s jam packed with animals for miles and miles. Wear long sleeves and long pants - I got bitten repeatedly by unknown bugs which made me pretty sick

I am a Korean living in Dar es Salaam. Before visiting here, I had seen many wildlife during a game drive in Mikumi National Park. So I did not expect this place to be much different from Mikumi National Park. However, my thoughts changed immediately after arriving here and being overwhelmed by the sight of nature. The great many wildlife, unique scenery, and well-managed facilities in harmony with nature were all very impressive. The time I visited here was very impressive and enjoyable.
Really conserved , hills and ridges and the crater. It's a long journey within the conservation area with the most enjoyable favorite view of NgoroNgoro Crater somewhere

Name: Grand Canyon National Park
short_description: Carved out by the Colorado River, the Grand Canyon (nearly 1,500 m deep) is the most spectacular gorge in the world. Located in the state of Arizona, it cuts across the Grand Canyon National Park. Its horizontal strata retrace the geological history of the past 2 billion years. There are also prehistoric traces of human adaptation to a particularly harsh environment.

reviews.text:
The Grand Canyon is undoubtedly one of the most stunning places I've ever seen in the United States. It's a sight that truly has to be experienced in person—no picture can ever fully capture its grandeur.

-Mr.S Travel Quest

I'm embarking on an epic solo adventure from the bustling streets of New York to the breathtaking landscapes of Arizona! Along the way, I'll be exploring countless states and soaking in the beauty of the open road, all while traveling with my most trusted companion: my rugged 2018 Jeep Wrangler JL ( 2600 Miles one side). It’s going to be an unforgettable journey filled with discovery and exploration!

Visiting the Grand Canyon State (Arizona ) is absolutely at the top of my bucket list! It’s a breathtaking marvel of nature and one of the world’s wonders. I can hardly contain my excitement at the thought of standing in awe before its vastness and stunning beauty. I’ll be grateful to God for the chance to witness such an incredible sight firsthand!

Bucket list check! Still want to come to more parts of the canyon though! But this was amazing! So beautiful! The views are breathtaking!! And the air is so fresh!! This felt like such a soul reset. I will spend more time here!!

An amazing national park that is one of the wonders of the United States. It's facilities are accessible for both outdoorsy backpackers and visitors who prefer to simply look over vistas. When hiking through the canyon there are breathtaking views no matter where you look. Lots of unique and interesting wildlife along with beautiful, clean water bodies and falls. There is so much more I could say but I'll let you experience it for yourself because it would be a crime to spoil this heaven of a national park

Everyone should see this once in their life. Even those with limited mobility can visit stunning views near the Visitor Center. Even pictures don’t do the in life view justice. It’s worth the traffic going in and out of the popular South Rim spots .

Name: Everglades National Park
short_description: This site at the southern tip of Florida has been called 'a river of grass flowing imperceptibly from the hinterland into the sea'. The exceptional variety of its water habitats has made it a sanctuary for a large number of birds and reptiles, as well as for threatened species such as the manatee.

reviews.text: Amazing! Within the first 2 min we saw our first gator! We saw quite a few throughout the park after that. This park is filled with lots of great board walks and walking trails. Plan to spend a whole day here . Lots of wildlife and plant life to see. I will be going back one day! The price you pay for entry is totally worth it. If you love the outdoors add this national park to your list.

Went in January.  I was surprised by how great of an experience it was compared to my first trip 15+ years ago. Luckily my fiance and I had no encounters with vultures, and we went on a cool sunny day. Thank you to all the rangers for doing a great job maintaining the trails and buildings.

Highly recommend for nature lovers! Beautiful landscapes to hike and explore, with incredible wildlife. We were able to spot most of the wildlife and enjoy birdwatching. Such a peaceful place to spend the day, and the ticket being valid for a 7 days makes it easy to explore the entire park.

Not my favorite National Park, but worth the stop. Glad the speed limit is 55 mph because the drive through is fairly boring, not the stunning mountain views of other parks. I did enjoy the two hikes that we did, but the paddle from Flamingo was pretty bland.
Visited the park on a field trip with 5th graders. Had a great experience and Ranger Maggie was very informative and knowledgeable.  She worked great with kids and made the tour amazing.

Name: Independence Hall
short_description: The Declaration of Independence (1776) and the Constitution of the United States (1787) were both signed in this building in Philadelphia. The universal principles of freedom and democracy set forth in these documents are of fundamental importance to American history and have also had a profound impact on law-makers around the world.
formatted_address: Independence Hall, 520 Chestnut St, Philadelphia, PA 19106, USA

Name: Natural and Cultural Heritage of the Ohrid region
short_description: A superlative natural phenomenon, Lake Ohrid provides a refuge for numerous endemic species of freshwater fauna and flora dating from the Tertiary period. Situated on the shores of the lake, the town of Ohrid is one of the oldest human settlements in Europe. Built mainly between the 7th and 19th centuries, it has the oldest Slav monastery (St Pantelejmon) and more than 800 Byzantine-style icons dating from the 11th to the end of the 14th century. In the shallow waters near the shores of the lake, three sites testify to the presence of prehistoric pile dwellings, and the small Lin Peninsula is the site of the remains of an Early Christian church founded in the middle of the 6th century.

reviews.text: Simply Stunning.........As our guide said if you come to Macedonia and dont visit Lake Ohrid, then you might as well skip Skopje, we would have to agree this was the highlight of our visit to the Balkans.

It is an amazing lake, not less than Como Lake or others in Eurpe countries. Try to take a tour at Sunset Time, you will have a wonderful time then take some time in walking with a lot of local restaurants along the beach. The tour is cheap and the food in the restaurant are nice and cheap also.
Perfect place for deep thinkers with a good boat trip.  You can see many beautiful views from it

It’s a pearl of the region. Scenic views, awesome nature. This is the deepest and the oldest lake on Balkans. During our stay the weather changed every hour from heavy rain to sunny weather and than again rain… You can rent a boat and see it’s nature from the water.

The atmosphere of Lake Ohrid is truly enchanting. Its crystal-clear waters, combined with the surrounding mountains and historic structures, create a serene and captivating landscape. The natural beauty and historical richness of the area make a visit unforgettable. Especially at sunset, the colors reflected on the lake create a stunning visual spectacle. Lake Ohrid is an ideal place to relax and enjoy nature.

Name: Białowieża Forest
short_description: The Białowieża Forest World Heritage site, on the border between Poland and Belarus, is an immense range of primary forest including both conifers and broadleaved trees covering a total area of 141,885 hectares. Situated on the watershed of the Baltic Sea and Black Sea, this transboundary property is exceptional for the opportunities it offers for biodiversity conservation. It is home to the largest population of the property’s iconic species, the European bison.

reviews.text: Beautiful and well preserved forest, definitly worth visiting with a guide to have all info about the trees and Flora around you. Better Luck to find animals outside of the strict protected area, in the forest, we spotted beautiful bisons and wolves !

Dreams come true...

Like never before this is amazing view guys must visit

Belovezhskaya Pushcha was protected under Decision No. 657 of the Council of People's Commissars of the Soviet Union, 9 October 1944; Order No. 2252-P of the USSR Council of Ministers, 9 August 1957; and Decree No. 352 of the Byelorussian SSR Council of Ministers, 16 September 1991.

In December 1991, the belaveza accord , the decision to dissolve the ussr, were signed at a meeting in the Belarusian part of the reserve by the leaders of Ukraine , Russia and Belarus

Thankful
4/5, still looking for real bisons.
trekking, relaxing and more...
This place is just Magical. I can't wait to go back

Name: Kluane / Wrangell-St. Elias / Glacier Bay / Tatshenshini-Alsek
short_description: These parks comprise an impressive complex of glaciers and high peaks on both sides of the border between Canada (Yukon Territory and British Columbia) and the United States (Alaska). The spectacular natural landscapes are home to many grizzly bears, caribou and Dall's sheep. The site contains the largest non-polar icefield in the world.

reviews.text: Absolutely stunning park, and the largest in the U.S. Staying in McCarthy allowed us to make the most of our experience here, as it took two full days to do the root glacier hike, the kenicott mill tour, flightseeing, and hike to the toe of the glacier. Very friendly locals and incredible scenery.

This is the largest national park 🌲 in the US! At 13.2 million acres, it is the size of Yellowstone, Yosemite, and Switzerland COMBINED. There is plenty to do and see here, but you should be prepared for an adventure, as a lot of the sights and hikes are hard to get to, but are well worth it.
Had a blast!  Gorgeous weather and saw the northern lights!  The park & preserve is huge and stunning.  McCarthy and Kennecott were fun and rich in history.

Absolutely beautiful park. We drove along the McCarty Road and went out to see Kennicott. It’s a bumpy ride and rough road from Chitina to McCarthy but it was worth the trip.

Kennicott is grand and had some rich history. McCarthy was a cute little town full of kind people. We ate at The Potato and loved it.

It’s an absolute massive area and park and we saw only a sliver, but it was beautiful in July. Lots of fireweed and other wild flowers.

The glaciers are massive as well. We hiked out toward Root Glacier from Kennicott.

If you’re considering a trip, do it!

Beautiful but the drive in was 3 hours & out 3 hours due to the road filled with giant potholes. Could not drive over 10-20 mph at the cost of ruining a vehicle. Would be nice if the state paid to pave the road.

Name: Al Qal'a of Beni Hammad
short_description: In a mountainous site of extraordinary beauty, the ruins of the first capital of the Hammadid emirs, founded in 1007 and demolished in 1152, provide an authentic picture of a fortified Muslim city. The mosque, whose prayer room has 13 aisles with eight bays, is one of the largest in Algeria.

reviews.text:
Much to be said, yet, the place is relatively far from the city of Msila, if you wish to catch the bus to Maadid, where this fort is located, you better be there early (7AM ) since few lines go through this region, I had to take a cab.
I advise you to start first by the museum then you move to the fort, 20mn on foot.
It s worth it !

wonderful place.  You get a strange feeling through the arid nature of its terrain.  Honestly, I had a feeling as if the place was so full of memories that I could imagine the traces of a person not far away as if it was just a few hours ago.  Feeling crazy too
A nice place for history lovers

Beni Hammad Fort, also called Al Qal'a of Beni Hammad (Arabic: قلعة بني حماد‎) is a fortified palatine city in Algeria. Now in ruins, in the 11th century, it served as the first capital of the Hammadid dynasty. It is in the Hodna Mountains northeast of M'Sila, at an elevation of 1,418 metres (4,652 ft), and receives abundant water from the surrounding mountains. Beni Hammad Fort is near the town of Maadid (aka Maadhid), about 225 kilometres (140 mi) southeast of Algiers, in the Maghreb.

In 1980, it was inscribed as a World Heritage Site by UNESCO, and described as "an authentic picture of a fortified Muslim city".

The town includes a 7-kilometre (4 mi) long line of walls. Inside the walls are four residential complexes, and the largest mosque built in Algeria after that of Mansurah. It is similar in design to the Grand Mosque of Kairouan, with a tall minaret, 20 metres (66 ft).

Excavations have brought to light numerous terracotta, jewels, coins and ceramics testifying to the high level of civilization under the Hammadid dynasty. Also among the artifacts discovered are several decorative fountains using the lion as a motif. The remains of the emir's palace, known as Dal al-Bahr, include three separate residences separated by gardens and pavilions.
The fortress was built in 1007 by Hammad ibn Buluggin, the son of Buluggin ibn Ziri, the founder of Algiers. The city became the capital of the Hammadid Berbers, and sustained a siege from the Zirid in 1017. In 1090 it was abandoned under the menace of the Banu Hilal, and was partly destroyed by the Almohads in 1152.

The Al Qal'a of Beni Hammad is an archeological site in Algeria, which was the first capital of the Hammadid empire. It was founded in 1007 and destroyed in 1152. The Qal'a (Fortress) is located at more than 1,000m altitude. The town includes a 7 km-long line of walls. Inside the walls are four residential complexes, and the second largest mosque in Algeria. The remains of the emir's palace, known as Dal al-Bahr, include three separate residences separated by gardens and pavilions. Excavations have brought to light numerous terracotta, jewels, coins and ceramics testifying to the high level of civilization under the Hammadid dynasty.

Name: Historic Town of Ouro Preto
short_description: Founded at the end of the 17th century, Ouro Preto (Black Gold) was the focal point of the gold rush and Brazil’s golden age in the 18th century. With the exhaustion of the gold mines in the 19th century, the city’s influence declined but many churches, bridges and fountains remain as a testimony to its past prosperity and the exceptional talent of the Baroque sculptor Aleijadinho.
formatted_address: Praça Tiradentes - Ouro Preto, MG, 35400-000, Brazil

reviews.text: I visited here many years ago. It is a really nice town not far from Belo Horizonte. Many nice places to see - the churches, restaurants, school of mines, and other historical sites. I really enjoyed the visit.
The town that gave birth to the mining tradition in Minas Gerais and Brazil. Its streets are full of history. Typical mineirense food can be found everywhere with amazing dishes.

Beautiful!
Very recommended to visit this place. Very romantic, cozy, quiet and super safe!
If you have troubles with walking then I will recommend to not go here or just grab a (motor) taxi everywhere, because you need to walk a lot of hills up and down to visit the beautiful spots

Another great historical place to visit. We were amazed about the monuments.
People are so friendly and the food was one of the best we ever had.
Beautiful, unforgettable !! Too much to see, great food, amazing architecture. Skip Mariana and do a quick visit to Congonhas.

Name: Paphos
short_description: Paphos has been inhabited since the Neolithic period. It was a centre of the cult of Aphrodite and of pre-Hellenic fertility deities. Aphrodite's legendary birthplace was on this island, where her temple was erected by the Myceneans in the 12th century B.C. The remains of villas, palaces, theatres, fortresses and tombs mean that the site is of exceptional architectural and historic value. The mosaics of Nea Paphos are among the most beautiful in the world.

Name: Garamba National Park
short_description: The park's immense savannahs, grasslands and woodlands, interspersed with gallery forests along the river banks and the swampy depressions, are home to four large mammals: the elephant, giraffe, hippopotamus and above all the white rhinoceros. Though much larger than the black rhino, it is harmless; only some 30 individuals remain.

reviews.text:
We had a great experience at the Garamba National Park, the staff is so welcoming and amazing, good food and accomodations.
Big up to Moses and Midu the ranger and other rangers for the amazing work.
Vive le Parc National de la Garamba
If you don't like crowded places, Garamba National Park is the place for you.

Garamba National Park sits on DRC’s border with South Sudan. Political instability in South Sudan has made protecting giraffes from poaching even more challenging, with armed groups coming across the border to hunt as part of the illegal wildlife trade. Since 2013, it has also brought an influx of almost 90,000 refugees into the immediate vicinity of Garamba alone. Despite the local population’s efforts to protect the giraffe, the illegal wildlife trade is a multibillion dollar industry, and the poaching of giraffes is still a problem.
Very nice place leaving with animal in a peaceful way
I dont konw what palce look like but in the images very beautiful place

Name: Kahuzi-Biega National Park
short_description: A vast area of primary tropical forest dominated by two spectacular extinct volcanoes, Kahuzi and Biega, the park has a diverse and abundant fauna. One of the last groups of eastern lowland (graueri) gorillas (consisting of only some 250 individuals) lives at between 2,100 and 2,400 m above sea-level.
formatted_address: Quartier général, Tshivanga, Bukavu, Democratic Republic of the Congo

reviews.text: We visited the gorilla park in congo and it was beyond our expectations. We saw the gorillas family from a short distance, like 2 meters. The ranger explained about the difference between the mountain gorillas and the valley gorillas. The park is well organized and it worth it. Highly recommend and the price is affordable.

I absolutely loved my experience at Kahuzi Biega National Park. The people at the park were incredibly helpful. They picked us up from the Rwandan border and drove us to the park. They cooked us food and put us in a great place. You can tell they really cared about making sure we had a good time. We spent three days there, going to see habituated and not habituated gorillas.

I went with my mom who had problems with mobility due to her age. Seeing how we aren’t always on a trail and have to trample through the Congolese forest, it would have been very difficult but the rangers were super helpful. They helped her especially, which was very nice of them. When we saw the gorillas they did all they could for us to get good pictures and see all of them. They really made the experience extremely worthwhile.

I 100% recommend going here. I felt super safe and cared for. I love how the rangers here care a lot for their gorillas and the people who come to see them.

Simply amazing! Up close and personal with the gorillas in less than 20 minutes from leaving the lounge (on foot). Really knowledgeable staff, and great skill in both French and English (probably other languages as well). I could say more, but the photos can speak for themselves. :-)

What a beautiful park!  Seeing the majesty of the Eastern Lowland Gorilla in the wild is one of the most impressive experiences I have had in my life. Lambert is a knowledgeable and kind eco ranger. Juvenal was friendly and helped us to have the best experiences possible. Thank you!

The Kahuzi-Biega National Park offers an incredible access to a beautiful biodiversity. While the incredible experience of meeting wild gorillas is the  main attraction and definitely worth it! It's important to highlight that security and safety for both visitors and gorillas are taken very seriously by the park staff. On top of that, staff and guides are very friendly and incredibly knowledgeable about the park and its wildlife.

Name: Lower Valley of the Awash
short_description: The Awash valley contains one of the most important groupings of palaeontological sites on the African continent. The remains found at the site, the oldest of which date back at least 4 million years, provide evidence of human evolution which has modified our conception of the history of humankind. The most spectacular discovery came in 1974, when 52 fragments of a skeleton enabled the famous Lucy to be reconstructed.

reviews.text: Great hand-axes! High quality and durable will last for ever!

Name: Tiya
short_description: Tiya is among the most important of the roughly 160 archaeological sites discovered so far in the Soddo region, south of Addis Ababa. The site contains 36 monuments, including 32 carved stelae covered with symbols, most of which are difficult to decipher. They are the remains of an ancient Ethiopian culture whose age has not yet been precisely determined.

Name: Aksum
short_description: The ruins of the ancient city of Aksum are found close to Ethiopia's northern border. They mark the location of the heart of ancient Ethiopia, when the Kingdom of Aksum was the most powerful state between the Eastern Roman Empire and Persia. The massive ruins, dating from between the 1st and the 13th century A.D., include monolithic obelisks, giant stelae, royal tombs and the ruins of ancient castles. Long after its political decline in the 10th century, Ethiopian emperors continued to be crowned in Aksum.

Name: Lower Valley of the Omo
short_description: A prehistoric site near Lake Turkana, the lower valley of the Omo is renowned the world over. The discovery of many fossils there, especially Homo gracilis, has been of fundamental importance in the study of human evolution.

reviews.text:
The Omo River in southern Ethiopia is the largest Ethiopian river outside the Nile Basin Its course is entirely contained within the boundaries of Ethiopia, and it empties into Lake Turkana on the border with Kenya The river is the principal stream of an endorheic drainage basin, the Turkana Basin.
The river basin is famous for its large number of early hominid fossils and archaeological findings such as early stone tools, leading to its inclusion on the UNESCO World Heritage List in 1980.
Omo River a place where different tribal groups inhabited with there different cultures, way of life, and  language
You never been anywhere quite Like Omovalley Land of peace.
One of the largest ethiopian river in flows to the south over 700km to the north end of lake Turkana. Some of the ethnic grups are living along side the omo river & depend it for livelihood.
Magnificent view!!

Name: Asante Traditional Buildings
short_description: To the north-east of Kumasi, these are the last material remains of the great Asante civilization, which reached its high point in the 18th century. Since the dwellings are made of earth, wood and straw, they are vulnerable to the onslaught of time and weather.

reviews.text:
Wrong location, you will have the Asante Traditional Buildings located at Ejisu-Besease, Abirem, etc.
For instance, Asante Traditional Building(Ejisu-Besease Heritage Site),
Asante Traditional Building (Abirem Heritage Site)
The buildings are nice and beautiful Master Piece of ancient architectural edifices.

One of the shrine is located at PATAKRO, on the obusi Kumasi road.
Nice place to discover

Name: Maya Site of Copan
short_description: Discovered in 1570 by Diego García de Palacio, the ruins of Copán, one of the most important sites of the Mayan civilization, were not excavated until the 19th century. The ruined citadel and imposing public squares reveal the three main stages of development before the city was abandoned in the early 10th century.
formatted_address: RVP5+VCG, CA-11, Copan Ruinas, Copán, Honduras

reviews.text: Just wow! I have been to all the major Maya cities by now, this was the final visit, but a total highlight with all the pyramids, stairs, statues, carvings, steleas, birds and tunnels. Pointless that the tunnel and museum costed extra to enter, but something you must see. So bite the bullet. For this had a local guide, who gave more life to the ruins. A big amazing Maya experience!

Nice Mayan site and well organized.  Wheelchair accessible to the main courtyard, including the hieroglyphic staircase.  If you arrive between 8 - 9am, they put out food for the Scarlet Macaws that live in the area and dozens of them come in close to eat.  Note:  Bring bug spray for the tiny Mosquitoes that bite.  The town of Copan is 5 minutes away and well worth a night.  The main road from San Pedro Sula has many slow spots due to construction, plan on 4.5 hrs, not the 3 hrs 45 min Google maps shows.  The main entrance (not shown on Google maps!) to the site is next to the Texaco gas station on CA-11 just east of the town of Copan.

Amazing place with a lot of history and spectacular Nature, I loved this place. If you like Tikal you will be fascinated here. A lot of sculptures too. I would not recommend going to the museum ( + 10 usd) it wasn't worth it.

Great glimpse into the Mayan world in Honduras. It’s worth to get a guide so you can better understand what you’re seeing.
The amount of macaws flying around the pyramids really makes it even more beautiful.

+ great place and history
+ a lot to see for a whole day
+ some impressively well preserved steles and also residential buildings with still original stucco and red paint to be seen

- for 20$ entrances fee (plus 15$ optional for the tunnels), I would love to get at least a folder or some info material about the site.
- unfortunately there are also very few signs in English inside the archeological park. A few are only in Spanish, but also not a lot. They definitely want people to take a guide.
- and be aware: toilets are only at the entrance and rest area, and there is no possibility to buy food inside

Regarding information: If you have internet it might be easier to get information on the spot. If not make sure you get some information upfront and maybe store the wikipedia article on your phone or copy lonely planet pages. For us this was helpful.

Name: Church and Dominican Convent of Santa Maria delle Grazie with “The Last Supper” by Leonardo da Vinci
short_description: The refectory of the Convent of Santa Maria delle Grazie forms an integral part of this architectural complex, begun in Milan in 1463 and reworked at the end of the 15th century by Bramante. On the north wall is The Last Supper, the unrivalled masterpiece painted between 1495 and 1497 by Leonardo da Vinci, whose work was to herald a new era in the history of art.
formatted_address: Via Giuseppe Antonio Sassi, 3, 20123 Milano MI, Italy

reviews.text:
Who wouldn’t want to see The Last Supper?
We certainly did! However, when we checked the official website for tickets, they were only available long after our stay in Milan. Luckily, we found a fantastic guide who had tickets and truly enriched our experience with her insights.
I had always assumed The Last Supper was a fresco, but Leonardo da Vinci had a different approach—one that unfortunately led to significant deterioration over time. Thankfully, it has been carefully restored, allowing us to witness this iconic masterpiece in all its revived glory.
Without a doubt, a must-see!

Located at Via Giuseppe Antonio Sassi, 3, 20123 Milan MI, Italy 🇮🇹 .
This Basilica dates back to 1460 when the Dominican priests of the convent of Sant’Apollonia in Pavia were gifted a parcel of land in Milan. It had two 2️⃣ buildings, one to house troops and the other a chapel. The priests wanted to build a church and convent and in 1463, they started construction. The main parts of the convent were completed in 1469, whereas the church was finished in 1482. Local materials were used to construct the building. Inside the church, there are seven 7️⃣ chapels along each of the side aisles and were used by the most important families in Milan for burial and private prayer.
The convent contains the mural of ‘The Last Supper’ by Leonardo da Vinci which is in the refectory.
This UNESCO World Heritage listed building is a MUST when visiting Milan. But be sure to purchase your tickets online before you arrive, otherwise if you just turn up, you will be refused entry and told to come back after you have purchased your tickets. Also, tickets are tightly controlled to preserve Leonardo’s painting so they sell out fast. You need to book your tickets well in advance. The tours are a small group each hour and you have to stick with the guide. We were in the church for approximately 45 minutes total, the beauty and historic value made the visit well worth it.
Ticket prices -
Full Fare Tickets €15.00
Reduced Fare (18-25 years) €2.00
Under 18 years FREE
It’s a marvellous example of Renaissance architecture. The dome, designed by Bramante, is stunning. Giovanni Donato Montorfano’s frescoes were so beautiful. Even without the famous painting, the church alone is well worth the visit. Would totally recommend. Thumbs up!!! 👍👍👍

Santa Maria delle Grazie is a UNESCO-listed church and convent in Milan, best known for housing Leonardo da Vinci’s The Last Supper. Built in the late 15th century, it is a stunning example of Renaissance and Gothic architecture, with a striking dome designed by Bramante.
The  adjacent museum  is home to da Vinci’s masterpiece the last supper.
The entrance to the church is free but you need a Booking in advance is essential to see the last supper. Book in advance tickets sell out fast

The Basilica di Santa Maria delle Grazie is a must-visit gem in Milan, seamlessly blending history, architecture, and art. This UNESCO World Heritage site is not only a stunning example of Renaissance architecture but also home to Leonardo da Vinci’s The Last Supper, making it one of the most iconic cultural landmarks in the world.

The basilica itself is awe-inspiring, with intricate brickwork and a serene interior that invites reflection. The dome, designed by Bramante, is a marvel, showcasing the architectural genius of the era. Even without a ticket to see The Last Supper, the church alone is worth a visit.

The highlight, of course, is the adjoining convent’s refectory, where da Vinci’s masterpiece resides. Be sure to book your tickets well in advance, as entry is tightly controlled to preserve the painting. The guided tours provide fascinating insights into the history and techniques behind the artwork, making the experience unforgettable.

Wonderful church
I wish I could go back there.
Although we were unable to witness the Last Supper paint, the church and its interior art are truly remarkable.
When you are in Milan, you have to see this church.

Name: Ħal Saflieni Hypogeum
short_description: The Hypogeum is an enormous subterranean structure excavated c. 2500 B.C., using cyclopean rigging to lift huge blocks of coralline limestone. Perhaps originally a sanctuary, it became a necropolis in prehistoric times.
formatted_address: Triq Ic Cimiterju, Raħal Ġdid PLA 1116, Malta

reviews.text: Amazing experience - hard to picture this Neolithic subterranean structure underground and hidden for so many years- discovered accidently. It is a wonderful place to visit - get tickets early! They only allow so many visitors a day. Not a place you can just 'drop by'. Very well kept, clean bathrooms, a little shop at the entryway. Very cool, to think about Malta in this way, interesting attraction and I'm grateful I was able to visit during my time in Malta. Inside photos are not allowed - everything has to be secured in provided lockers. Audio is in many languages, which was very helpful.

This ancient underground temple is a somewhat unusual attraction. It sits unassumingly between residential buildings and it's a tiny space above ground without bathrooms. Access is restricted to a certain number of visitors per day, therefore you will need to buy tickets weeks in advance, which are then also overpriced. But it's still a gem worth visiting, giving you a glimpse into another world. A lost world in fact, a world we just don't know a lot about and probably never will.
It is one of the oldest neolitic sites in the world. Must see. No photos allowed inside. Buy your tickets at least two weeks in advance.

Book in advance!!!
I couldn’t enter the site as I should have booked at least a month ahead according to the reception. The site can take a maximum of 80 persons per day so the capacity is limited.
The place is in the middle of the city and accessible by public transportation. The entrance is quite discreet. Pay attention not to miss it.

I’ll come back!

We were lucky to find tickets for the next day but we paid 50 euro/person as they were "last-minute" tickets.  Strongly advise buying tickets in advance.
The Hypogeum is really unique, it is very different from the temples because it is something else, a prehistoric necropolis. The architecture is special - everything was dug in the rock with stone tools.
No photos allowed.

Name: City of Valletta
short_description: The capital of Malta is inextricably linked to the history of the military and charitable Order of St John of Jerusalem. It was ruled successively by the Phoenicians, Greeks, Carthaginians, Romans, Byzantines, Arabs and the Order of the Knights of St John. Valletta’s 320 monuments, all within an area of 55 ha, make it one of the most concentrated historic areas in the world.

Name: Megalithic Temples of Malta
short_description: Seven megalithic temples are found on the islands of Malta and Gozo, each the result of an individual development. The two temples of Ggantija on the island of Gozo are notable for their gigantic Bronze Age structures. On the island of Malta, the temples of Hagar Qim, Mnajdra and Tarxien are unique architectural masterpieces, given the limited resources available to their builders. The Ta'Hagrat and Skorba complexes show how the tradition of temple-building was handed down in Malta.
formatted_address: Triq Hagar Qim, Il-Qrendi QRD 2501, Malta

reviews.text: An amazing place located close to charming slopes, and in the background the sound of the sea and waves. The ruins themselves are a nice experience. The price also includes a cool 3D presentation and a lot of knowledge about our ancient ancestors and their constructions. I definitely recommend this place 🙂

Stunning temples set in a breathtaking and magical site. Very reasonably priced too. And you get to actually enter the temples and explore up close unlike the Stone Henge where you see it from far and have to pay special, extortionate prices if you wish to get closer! The mobile audio guide was very useful and informative too. Oh and gorgeous stray cats (being looked after and fed by some kind locals) to cuddle outside the site which was a bonus.

Entry is €10 for adults and is well worth the cost, providing access to both the Hagar Qim and Mnajdra temples.

There is a downloadable audio tour (several languages options), which will walk you through the temple complex over the course of 40 short snippets. I found the audio guide interesting, with the right level of detail.

The temple are incredibly impressive, with their megalithic structures dating back over 5000 years. Both temples are covered by a protective tent structure to keep out the elements.

Hagar Qim is slightly larger, and you are able to walk through the centre, as well as round the outside. The largest stones are over 50 tonnes.

There are bathrooms and a gift shop at the ticket office, along with a small museum and 3D video introduction.

Awe-inspiring to walk among some of the most ancient temples in the world and learn about the peaceful and spiritual nature of the people who built this incredible place. Older than both Stonehenge and the pyramids - absolutely not to be missed on a visit to the island of Malta.

If you're a history enthusiast, Haġar Qim is an absolute must-visit when in Malta. This ancient temple complex offers an incredible glimpse into Malta’s prehistoric past and is complemented by the nearby Mnajdra ruins, making it a captivating excursion for anyone intrigued by ancient civilisations.

Haġar Qim, dating back over 5,000 years, is perched atop a promontory with stunning views of the surrounding landscape. To the east lies a fertile plain, while to the west, the rugged garrigue slopes gently down towards the sea. This UNESCO World Heritage Site was not built for habitation but served as a temple dedicated to worship. Among its remarkable discoveries were statues believed to be connected to fertility rites, showcasing the spiritual and cultural significance of the site. Some of these artefacts are now exhibited at the National Museum of Archaeology in Valletta.

A short 500-metre walk downhill from Haġar Qim, the Mnajdra ruins await. These contemporary structures are thought to have been used by the same community due to their close proximity. Both sites share architectural similarities that underline the sophistication of the Neolithic builders.

We visited Haġar Qim in December 2024, and it was a delightfully sunny day with temperatures hovering around 17°C. The weather added to the experience, making it comfortable to explore the site without being overwhelmed by heat. The ruins themselves are relatively small, and it doesn’t take long to walk around, but the history they encapsulate is nothing short of mind-boggling.

Having seen a documentary on Haġar Qim, I had long been fascinated by how the Neolithic builders managed to construct these temples using massive stone blocks thousands of years ago. Standing in front of these ancient structures and imagining the sheer effort and ingenuity required to erect them was an awe-inspiring experience.

Practical Information
Tickets are easily available at the museum entrance, and one ticket covers both Haġar Qim and Mnajdra, making it excellent value for money. Upon entry, you can download a free audio commentary, which is available in multiple languages. This adds depth to the experience, offering detailed insights into the history and significance of the sites.

Before heading to the temples, you can also visit the on-site museum, which provides additional context about the ruins, their purpose, and the people who built them. The museum is a great starting point to fully appreciate what you’re about to see.

Haġar Qim is more than just an archaeological site—it’s a window into an ancient world. Whether you’re a history buff or simply someone who enjoys marvelling at the ingenuity of our ancestors, a visit to Haġar Qim and Mnajdra is bound to leave a lasting impression. The serene setting, coupled with the fascinating history, makes this an unforgettable experience.

If you're planning to visit, consider setting aside about 2-3 hours to take in both sites and the surrounding natural beauty. Don’t forget your camera—you’ll want to capture the spectacular views as well as the temples themselves!

Name: Durmitor National Park
short_description: This breathtaking national park was formed by glaciers and is traversed by rivers and underground streams. Along the Tara river canyon, which has the deepest gorges in Europe, the dense pine forests are interspersed with clear lakes and harbour a wide range of endemic flora.

reviews.text:
We spent 4 days exploring different parts of Durmitor National Park and wished i had another week! Incredible views, swimming spots and hikes! There are activities that are more touristy or ways to get more out there into the wilderness.
there is everything! Glacial swimming, Mountains, hiking and local food. If visiting id recommend hiring a car to get to all the best spots to avoid the large tourist traps.
Amazing views wherever you go. Parking near the black lake was 3 euros per hour but no entrance fee today for some reason.

This national park is huge and stunning, we would recommend 3 -4 days there. Top things to do include Tara river rafting (seasonal easy level in october when we went), curavac viewpoint hike (easy), black lake hike (easy), bobotuv kuk hike (hard - this is quite a dangerous in sections) and durmitor ring scenic drive. There’s also a bunch of additional hikes, horse riding and other sports. It’s 5 euros to enter the park each day.
We have visited the lake twice. First time on bikes, second time - by foot. Really charming place. We also rented a boat for 10 euro. Recommend that, really good experience.

Beautiful scenery, looks tasty of birdlife, lots of trails so I'd advise using an app like locus map to stay on the right track. Parking is extortionate unfortunately so if you're brave enough, try parking just before the long winding road down to the lake

Name: Røros Mining Town and the Circumference
short_description: Røros Mining Town and the Circumference is linked to the copper mines, established in the 17th century and exploited for 333 years until 1977. The site comprises the Town and its industrial-rural cultural landscapes; Femundshytta, a smelter with its associated area; and the Winter Transport Route. Completely rebuilt after its destruction by Swedish troops in 1679, Røros contains about 2000 wooden one- and two-storey houses and a smelting house. Many of these buildings have preserved their blackened wooden façades, giving the town a medieval appearance. Surrounded by a buffer zone, coincident with the area of privileges (the Circumference) granted to the mining enterprise by the Danish-Norwegian Crown (1646), the property illustrates the establishment and flourishing of a lasting culture based on copper mining in a remote region with a harsh climate.

Name: Archaeological Ruins at Moenjodaro
short_description: The ruins of the huge city of Moenjodaro – built entirely of unbaked brick in the 3rd millennium B.C. – lie in the Indus valley. The acropolis, set on high embankments, the ramparts, and the lower town, which is laid out according to strict rules, provide evidence of an early system of town planning.

reviews.text: Really wonderful archaeological site, possibly the most famous landmark in Pakistan. I expected a much more stunning experience (particularly in case of the lacklustre museum), but definitely a must see.

Mohenjo-Daro is an ancient city of the Indus Valley Civilization, dating back to 2500 BCE, located in Sindh, Pakistan. It was one of the world’s earliest urban centers, featuring advanced drainage systems, grid-planned streets, and notable structures like the Great Bath. A UNESCO World Heritage Site, Mohenjo-Daro remains an important archaeological and historical landmark, offering insights into early human civilization.
A must visit place to go, full of history and stories. The structure is amazing. But you must prepare for a lot of clay there 😁

Mohenjo-Daro is famous for its art found at the site, including trading seals like the Pashupati Seal and sculptures like the Priest-King and the Dancing Girl. The Indus Valley Civilization declined in the second millennium B.C.E., and the Harappans abandoned their cities, including Mohenjo-Daro.
Mohenjo-daro, group of mounds and ruins on the right bank of the Indus River, northern Sindh province, southern Pakistan. It lies on the flat alluvial plain of the Indus, about 50 miles (80 km) southwest of Sukkur. The site contains the remnants of one of two main centres of the ancient Indus civilization
Jaisalmer is in India while Mohenjodaro is in Pakistan. You will need visa to cross borders.
Gowariker took over three years to research and develop the script, working closely with archaeologists to ensure authenticity in the representation of his fictional story. The film was shot in Bhuj and Mumbai with brief schedules in Bhedaghat (Jabalpur) and Thane. The score and soundtrack are composed
Larkana District, Sindh, Pakistan. It lies on a Pleistocene ridge in the flood plain of the Indus, around 28 kilometres (17 mi) from the town of Larkana.

Visiting Mohenjo-Daro in Pakistan is a captivating journey into the past, immersing you in the rich history of one of the world's oldest civilizations. As you arrive at the site, the stark landscape of the Indus Valley stretches before you, marked by the remnants of an ancient urban center.

Name: Taxila
short_description: From the ancient Neolithic tumulus of Saraikala to the ramparts of Sirkap (2nd century B.C.) and the city of Sirsukh (1st century A.D.), Taxila illustrates the different stages in the development of a city on the Indus that was alternately influenced by Persia, Greece and Central Asia and which, from the 5th century B.C. to the 2nd century A.D., was an important Buddhist centre of learning.

Name: Buddhist Ruins of Takht-i-Bahi and Neighbouring City Remains at Sahr-i-Bahlol
short_description: The Buddhist monastic complex of Takht-i-Bahi (Throne of Origins) was founded in the early 1st century. Owing to its location on the crest of a high hill, it escaped successive invasions and is still exceptionally well preserved. Nearby are the ruins of Sahr-i-Bahlol, a small fortified city dating from the same period.

reviews.text:
I recently visited the Takht-i-Bahi ruins, a historical site located a short distance off the roadside. Unfortunately, there were no clear signboards or directions indicating the route to the ruins. Along the way, I had to ask several people for help before someone provided me with accurate directions. After getting the information, I bought some food and headed toward the ruins.

The road leading to the site is accessible for bikes, cars, and even buses. There’s parking available inside the premises, and you’ll encounter a police checkpoint where they verify your identity upon entry. I purchased a ticket for 100 PKR, while the fee for foreigners is 500 PKR.

A stone-paved path leads up to the top of the mountain where the ruins are located. Along the way, I saw a banner mentioning that some restoration work had been done with the support of Thailand. There are also benches placed every few meters for resting, which is very thoughtful for visitors.

Seeing the ruins for the first time left me astonished. The design, creativity, and sheer effort it must have taken by Buddhist ancestors to carry small stones up the mountain to construct this site are remarkable. When you enter the ruins, the first thing that catches your eye is the stupa. Though it is now empty, with no idols, it still exudes an aura and energy that hint at how life might have been for those who lived there centuries ago. There is also a protective area that overlooks the surrounding grounds.

At the end of my visit, I must say that the energy in the air at this site is incredible. It feels calm and peaceful—an experience unlike any other. I highly recommend visiting this site, especially for foreigners. It is safe, and the police presence ensures security.
