In Tai village is the ecotourism centre, who are fantastic and run the visits. You can contact them for arranging your stay and the prices. Going back from Tai to Guiglo, unless you leave in the morning, you need to take a moto the whole way.
The park is really nice, the camp is very nicely done, with amazing food and comfortable tents with beds. The monkeys come very close.
Check with the NGO about best access during rainy season. They have wellies to borrow, do take them!
I hate this place because of the  sun

Name: Old Havana and its Fortification System
short_description: Havana was founded in 1519 by the Spanish. By the 17th century, it had become one of the Caribbean's main centres for ship-building. Although it is today a sprawling metropolis of 2 million inhabitants, its old centre retains an interesting mix of Baroque and neoclassical monuments, and a homogeneous ensemble of private houses with arcades, balconies, wrought-iron gates and internal courtyards.

Name: From the Great Saltworks of Salins-les-Bains to the Royal Saltworks of Arc-et-Senans, the Production of Open-pan Salt
short_description:
The Royal Saltworks of Arc-et-Senans, near Besançon, was built by Claude Nicolas Ledoux. Its construction, begun in 1775 during the reign of Louis XVI, was the first major achievement of industrial architecture, reflecting the ideal of progress of the Enlightenment. The vast, semicircular complex was designed to permit a rational and hierarchical organization of work and was to have been followed by the building of an ideal city, a project that was never realized.

The Great Saltworks of Salins-les-Bains was active for at least 1200 years until stopping activity in 1962. From 1780 to 1895, its salt water travelled through 21 km of wood pipes to the Royal Saltworks of Arc-et-Senans. It was built near the immense Chaux Forest to ensure its supply of wood for fuel. The Saltworks of Salins shelters an underground gallery from the 13th century including a hydraulic pump from the 19th century that still functions. The boiler house demonstrates the difficulty of the saltworkers’ labour to collect the “White Gold”.

reviews.text: interesting, great for kids all age, saturday market, sogs cant enter museums but courtyard yes

Striking architecture with gardens of equally stunning proportions! The different sections of the garden were interesting to vistit and nice to see the sustainable approach with lots of natural habitats for wildlife. I hope to come back soon!

A wonderful and beautiful place, as much for its historical interest as a UNESCO heritage site, as for the botanical  garden spaces, curated in an attractive and accessible way with lots of information. Not to be missed if you are anywhere near.
Wow what an impressive location! Definitely worth a visit. Bring enough time as there is lots to see. Great if you have a day to spare in the area and need something to do.

An incredible experience learning about salt production and the wealth that this produced and how the owners of the salt production displayed their wealth.

The gardens here are divine and very well designed and cared for

Name: National History Park – Citadel, Sans Souci, Ramiers
short_description: These Haitian monuments date from the beginning of the 19th century, when Haiti proclaimed its independence. The Palace of Sans Souci, the buildings at Ramiers and, in particular, the Citadel serve as universal symbols of liberty, being the first monuments to be constructed by black slaves who had gained their freedom.

reviews.text: Beautiful tourist attraction, beautiful place, caring and welcoming people... Whenever i go to this place it's always a good experience.

We can see that King Christophe had a taste for luxury to have built a palace of this kind with large courtyards. I wish I could see a picture right after it was built, unfortunately camera technology wasn't that advanced.
What caught my attention the most was a bust I saw on one of the courtyards. According to an ancient, she represents the goddess of comedy.

A mind blowing historic site ! The ruins make the imagination reconstruct how luxe of a palace this must have been. The greenery surrounds you and the courts are so vast! The tree of justice still stands although held by cables but just a magnificent place

This is a legendary monument at Milot, on the road toward the Citadelle Laferrière. The ruins are very gigantic, titanic and.. ouh. When you see that, you'll see how big we human think if men with archaic tools can do that in 19th century. So now, we should be conscious that we must almost limitless, we can break the boundaries in our mind.
Unfortunately, earthquakes have gone with some part, even though, legend never dies, This Palace is still memorable and incredible.
A wonderful experience,  I was fortunate to have a tour guide that told me the history of the place.  The advance functionality that I was this place had,  is beyond my understanding.

Name: Río Plátano Biosphere Reserve
short_description: Located on the watershed of the Río Plátano, the reserve is one of the few remains of a tropical rainforest in Central America and has an abundant and varied plant and wildlife. In its mountainous landscape sloping down to the Caribbean coast, over 2,000 indigenous people have preserved their traditional way of life.

reviews.text: Very beautiful boat trip. Early in the morning you can see lots of bird life; toucans, green parrots, King fishers and much more. I suggest you bring a cushion for your butt because it's a long trip

It is a really nicest place out of pollution, the weather there is a little bit cold and tropical. There is an awesome flora and fauna, a thousand kind of plants and a variety of animal, makes you experience unforgetable.
My family loves our homy
Very kind place
Super

Name: Historic Centre of Florence
short_description: Built on the site of an Etruscan settlement, Florence, the symbol of the Renaissance, rose to economic and cultural pre-eminence under the Medici in the 15th and 16th centuries. Its 600 years of extraordinary artistic activity can be seen above all in the 13th-century cathedral (Santa Maria del Fiore), the Church of Santa Croce, the Uffizi and the Pitti Palace, the work of great masters such as Giotto, Brunelleschi, Botticelli and Michelangelo.
formatted_address: District 1, Florence, Metropolitan City of Florence, Italy

Name: Archaeological Site of Leptis Magna
short_description: Leptis Magna was enlarged and embellished by Septimius Severus, who was born there and later became emperor. It was one of the most beautiful cities of the Roman Empire, with its imposing public monuments, harbour, market-place, storehouses, shops and residential districts.

reviews.text:
Visiting Leptis Magna was like stepping into a different era. Walking through its massive stone archways and ancient streets, I could almost hear the echoes of history. The scale of this place is unbelievable—the amphitheater, the Hadrianic Baths, and the Arch of Septimius Severus are just breathtaking!

What amazed me the most was how well-preserved everything is. Standing there with the Mediterranean breeze and the golden sun lighting up the ruins, I felt a deep connection to the past. If you love history, architecture, or just stunning landscapes, this is a must-visit!

I’ve shared some of my best photos—hope they inspire you to visit one day! 📸
The most prominent city in Roman Africa. Well preserved and quiet. A perfect place to meditate and ponder the temporality of magnificence.
Very attractive place and sights in Leptis Magna. Here you can visit the realistic stories. A must visit.

Truly an incredible experience for history enthusiasts. Walking thru a Roman city was just mind blowing. The ruins are the best preserved one can see outside of Rome itself...ticked off on one of my lifetime bucket list things to do...2hours spent there but not enough...will go back for sure someday as there is so much to see and appreciate...
Such an amazing place. We had so much fun wandering around. It was sunny. The air was so refreshing. Everyone should go there for the educational rich experience 🤩

Name: Archaeological Site of Sabratha
short_description: A Phoenician trading-post that served as an outlet for the products of the African hinterland, Sabratha was part of the short-lived Numidian Kingdom of Massinissa before being Romanized and rebuilt in the 2nd and 3rd centuries A.D.

reviews.text:
A breathtaking ancient city with stunning Roman ruins, including a well-preserved theater overlooking the sea.
The site offers a glimpse into Libya’s rich history and is a must-visit for history lovers. Peaceful and not overcrowded, making it perfect for exploration.
Highly recommended ♥️

I can never express how different experience I have had to be standing and walking around the ruins.
Being in these ruins, I can only say experience along with imagination far surpasses any beauty pictures can give...

I wished I would have been able to upload videos, but I couldn't
I have been here with my friend and it’s beautiful ruins ancient. I really recommend to visit once .
♥️💯✅ nice historical place.

Breath-taking historical site, built in 2AD. Can't help but be in awe of such architectural splendor built more than 2,000 years ago, and still standing.
History is powerful because it gives us a glimpse of previous civilizations and the perennial character of human being, across centuries.
I visited this site in July 2010.

Name: Archaeological Site of Cyrene
short_description: A colony of the Greeks of Thera, Cyrene was one of the principal cities in the Hellenic world. It was Romanized and remained a great capital until the earthquake of 365. A thousand years of history is written into its ruins, which have been famous since the 18th century.

reviews.text:
The Archaeological site of Κυρήνη/Cyrene is a TOP site for all kind of travelers!

You can see the temple of Heracles, the Ancient Agora, the House of Jason Magnus with beautiful mosaics and many many more !

6star site!!!
One of the best places I really love to visit in Libya so historical places makes me feel special!
It's a unisco world heritage site, one of many in the city, it's a must see place, great to spend time with the family or on your own, wondering how did the ancient build such amazing architecture

Nice place 👌 ..
Historical monuments in ancient city..

Cyrene - an ancient Greek city (Roman later on) was founded in 631 BC by Greeks from Santorini, headed by Battus. It was eventually destroyed by the earthquake in year 365. It is much to be regretted that this fascinating ancient place is not commonly available for tourists.

Name: Aldabra Atoll
short_description: The atoll is comprised of four large coral islands which enclose a shallow lagoon; the group of islands is itself surrounded by a coral reef. Due to difficulties of access and the atoll's isolation, Aldabra has been protected from human influence and thus retains some 152,000 giant tortoises, the world's largest population of this reptile.

reviews.text: giant tortoise very attractable.........

I was lucky enough to visit this beautiful remote and protected island last month on an expedition cruise with Zegrahm.  There are only about 1000 individuals who are approved by special permit to visit this Atoll annually.

There is a small, dedicated research staff assigned to this Atoll, the world's second largest.

There are countless things you can do here, we spent two full days snorkeling the pristine and healthy coral reefs, cruising around the champignons (mushrooms) for bird watching, and coming ashore at the research center to meet the giant coconut crabs (super rare) and the Aldabra Giant Tortoise (only two giant tortoise remain, here and Galapagos).

It's stunning with crystal blue waters, white sand beaches, and friendly researchers happy to answer questions and lead you on a nature walk.

They take protecting this UNESCO World Heritage site very seriously so we had to submit to a bio security inspection of the items and our shoes we planned to bring on the island before we were able to make land to ensure we didn't bring outside seeds, soil and other contamination to the protected eco system here.

A real pleasure to have seen such a wonderful thing so few ever will.  I'm glad it's protected.
Beautiful place but you must arrange permission in advance to visit there. Only facilities are a research station under the auspices of Seychelles Island Foundation.
Aldabra, Seychelles has a thriving ecosystem. It’s great to see marine ecosystem doing se well, despite all the plastic floating about in the Indian Ocean.

The Aldabra Atoll (belonging to the Seychelles in the Indian Ocean) is probably one of the most spectacular scuba diving locations on the planet.  Aldabra is a UNESCO World Heritage Centre and protected from development.  As it is difficult to reach, very few come here and even fewer scuba dive.  It is a 2 day journey by boat from Victoria, the capital of the Seychelle Islands.

Name: Sacred City of Anuradhapura
short_description: This sacred city was established around a cutting from the 'tree of enlightenment', the Buddha's fig tree, brought there in the 3rd century B.C. by Sanghamitta, the founder of an order of Buddhist nuns. Anuradhapura, a Ceylonese political and religious capital that flourished for 1,300 years, was abandoned after an invasion in 993. Hidden away in dense jungle for many years, the splendid site, with its palaces, monasteries and monuments, is now accessible once again.

reviews.text: The hosts are genuinely lovely and honest with excellent English. Really good Sri Lankan breakfasts made completely from scratch each day, with good air and very clean basic rooms with fresh and well laundered linen. Good location within walking distance of some of the key sites, but there are a few flights of stairs to be navigated, which might not suit anyone with mobility issues. I gave a wee tip as thanks when I settled the bill and shortly after received a knock on my door because they thought I had overpaid. I can't remember that happening before on my travels!

Fantastic hotel in the city centre. Rooms are clean and beds have mosquito nets. The hotel has a fantastic rooftop with alle kind of plants, flowers, spices.
The only minor is that sometimes the waterpressure is low to nothing. Just a signal to the owner and the pressure is back again. Ohw...I showered with cold water. No idea how to turn on hot water but cold was a gift due to the heat. But of you really want to shower with hot water: ask the owner. The hotel offers different Stuppa and ruin tours and cloth can be washed.

I went alone to visit Anuradapura.
This place is highly secured   located in the town. Since the owners also living in same building they manage it very well and they are very friendly.
Easy to buy food and other things needed, just walking distance.  Distance from this place to Atamasthanaya less than 03 kms. I am very happy about this place.
The food, both breakfast and dinner, was absolutely amazing! Very welcoming owners and always happy to help with any (last minute) requests.

It's a family hotel on the main street, the owners are very honest, welcoming and help you to plan everything in details.

The food and juices are fresh and tasty. The living area is nice and aired and there is a rooftop terrace with a great view of the temple. Absolutely a great place where to rest and chill.

Name: Ancient City of Polonnaruwa
short_description: Polonnaruwa was the second capital of Sri Lanka after the destruction of Anuradhapura in 993. It comprises, besides the Brahmanic monuments built by the Cholas, the monumental ruins of the fabulous garden-city created by Parakramabahu I in the 12th century.
formatted_address: X223+QWM, Sudarshanarama Puranagama Rd, Polonnaruwa, Sri Lanka

reviews.text:
Fascinating, beautiful ruins of an ancient city. They're very spread out, so if you don't have a driver you may want to consider hiring one, or a bicycle. Once you've entered the main site, you can't leave and return, so plan lunch accordingly.
Some of the sites are holy, so you need to cover your arms and legs to visit, and also remove your shoes. The stones are very sharp underfoot!

The ancient capital with many amazing sites to visit.  If you like history and archeology it is a must see and you can tailor your time at each site accordingly.  We were all fascinated by the sites and as everywhere in Sri Lanka, the people are almost always simply lovely.

Important historical site in Sri Lanka, plenty of historic monuments and all building are sophisticated.
No entrance fees for locals but need to pay a small fee to enter with your vehicle.
You can access whole place with your vehicle.

When entering the ancient city they charge for a parking ticket at the entrance.
Inside the premises all the ancient remnants of the stupa, palaces and many more could be witnessed.
There is a car park inside thus can leave the vehicles and walk about the premises.
From the entrance towards right side there is a palace, Kumara pokuna etc. Most of the sacred places of the city are situated towards the left side of the main entrance.

We had a very underwhelming experience for 25 US dollars. I've also been to Bagan and Angkor Wat. They were much better and tourist friendly.  This place is so badly managed and not much to see.It seems like they also want you to pay for tour guide

Name: Ancient City of Sigiriya
short_description: The ruins of the capital built by the parricidal King Kassapa I (477–95) lie on the steep slopes and at the summit of a granite peak standing some 180m high (the 'Lion's Rock', which dominates the jungle from all sides). A series of galleries and staircases emerging from the mouth of a gigantic lion constructed of bricks and plaster provide access to the site.

reviews.text: You must wake up early in the morning to enjoy the sunrise at the top of Sigiryia Lion Rock. There are over 1200 steps to climb, but once you reach the plateau, the view is simply breathtaking. It's definitely worth the effort.

Worth it, did a sunrise walk, make sure to go back to the gardens to get pictures and maybe go to the museum because we didn't and I regret it slightly. It is expensive but we are tourists so get over it. Views are stunning and it's a cool experience. Saw loads of cute monkeys. We booked online (their cultural website, select all not just museum) but it looks like you can pay on card there too

I visited Sigiriya Rock yesterday with my family, and it was such an good experience! Our guide helped us get the tickets and walked us through the gardens before we started the climb. It was quite busy and It is recommended to come early morning

The climb to the top took us around 35-40 minutes. It’s a bit of a workout, but totally worth it. Once you get to the top, the views are absolutely breathtaking, and the remains of the old fort or palace are really interesting to explore. We spent some time taking lots of photos of the incredible views before heading back down.

The descent was quicker, about 30 minutes, and there are some small shops at the end where you can grab a drink or snack if you need to.

If you’re planning to visit, I’d definitely recommend taking plenty of water because the climb can be tiring. Don’t bother bringing snacks, though – the monkeys are everywhere, and they’ll grab anything they can! Also, don’t forget a good camera or your phone to capture the views

All in all, it’s a must-visit if you’re in the area. The history, the views, and the whole experience of climbing the rock made it an unforgettable day for us. Highly recommend it!

You have to climb 1200 steps. You can rest midway at different levels. There is drinking water available at the second last stop. Washrooms are available at this stop. Do carry an extra T-shirt to wear after climbing so that nobody complains about the stink!

Sigiriya Rock – Bibhu Experience

Sigiriya Rock also called the Lion Rock is a very famous place in Sri Lanka. It is a big rock with an ancient palace on top. The climb to the summit is a bit challenging but worth it. Along the way you can see beautiful frescoes (ancient paintings) and the famous lion paws carved into the rock. The surrounding gardens and water features are also very well-maintained and add to the beauty of the place. The view from the top is breathtaking, with lush green forests and landscapes stretching as far as the eye can see. It is one of the best historical sites in Sri Lanka.

Good things:
•The rock has beautiful old paintings (frescoes) inside.
•The view from the top is very beautiful.
•The gardens around the rock are well-maintained.
•It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site with a lot of history.
•Safe drinking water facility available in in half way gifted by Indian Embassy (With Love People of India)

Not-so-good things:
•The climb is a little hard because there are many steps.
•The weather is very hot so it can be tiring.
•The entrance ticket for foreigners is expensive. Must carry the passport For Indians cost 20 USD
•There are monkeys so be careful with your food and bags.

Best time to visit:
•Early morning or evening is best because the weather is cooler.
•Avoid midday as it gets too hot and crowded.

Tips:
•Wear comfortable shoes for climbing.
•Carry water because the climb can be tiring.
•Hire a guide if you want to learn about the history.
•Closing time 5.30 PM Local Time

Overall, Sigiriya Rock is a must-visit place in Sri Lanka. The climb is difficult, but the view and history make it worth it! A visit here will leave you amazed and inspired.

Name: Selous Game Reserve
short_description: Large numbers of elephants, black rhinoceroses, cheetahs, giraffes, hippopotamuses and crocodiles live in this immense sanctuary, which measures 50,000 km2 and is relatively undisturbed by human impact. The park has a variety of vegetation zones, ranging from dense thickets to open wooded grasslands.

reviews.text: Super friendly staff. JImmy was always smiling and ready to help with everything! Dulus was a wonderful server and hope to see him again one day! Freddy was also super cool and made us laugh a lot! The reserve was amazing, not many other jeeps like other places. Food was good. Great experience! Saw everything!! Even wild dogs!! And even on our walking safari. I liked the open Jeeps. We stayed in the tents and they were clean no bugs! Wish there was a little more light in the bathrooms but everything else was spot on. The views were fabulous. I loved the spot by the fire and the snacks were a nice touch too!

A wonderful Lodge surrounded by Africa's great beasts. Black Rhino abound great trophies if that is what you enjoy. If taking impressive photography is what you enjoy then this too is perfect. Staff are very helpful and welcoming, very warm people.

This is an amazing place for safari,  you can experience classic game drives spotting big mammals and predators but you enjoy also a boat safari on Rufiji River at sunset, a lot of birds and water birds, hippos and crocs . It's a huge park and it's not busy, during the day it's difficult you meet other jeeps.

Extremely friendly personell and a great safari trip. All guides have a huge knowledge about both the nature and how to find different wildlife. They stop whenever the touristj wants to take a picture on any animal.

Great place, lovely and very helpful staff! Food is just fine as is the location of this hotel. It is situated right next to a wildlife parc. Sometimes the animals come onto the hotel's grounds,which makes the experience here extra special.
I recommend this place.

Name: Cahokia Mounds State Historic Site
short_description: Cahokia Mounds, some 13 km north-east of St Louis, Missouri, is the largest pre-Columbian settlement north of Mexico. It was occupied primarily during the Mississippian period (800–1400), when it covered nearly 1,600 ha and included some 120 mounds. It is a striking example of a complex chiefdom society, with many satellite mound centres and numerous outlying hamlets and villages. This agricultural society may have had a population of 10–20,000 at its peak between 1050 and 1150. Primary features at the site include Monks Mound, the largest prehistoric earthwork in the Americas, covering over 5 ha and standing 30 m high.

reviews.text: Cahokia Mounds State Historic Site is an absolute treasure for history enthusiasts, nature lovers, and anyone interested in Native American culture. Climbing to the top of Monks Mound rewards visitors with breathtaking panoramic views of the surrounding landscape, including the St. Louis skyline .  We visited late in the afternoon and saw dozens of deer on the site.  Some of the history is a little disturbing, but extremely interesting.  Leashed pets are welcome on the site.  The museum is currently closed for renovations, but this is still a great place to visit.

Visiting the Cahokia Mounds is a fascinating way to explore the history of the mound builders. Monk Mound, the largest, features a staircase that takes you to the top, offering incredible views, including the St. Louis Arch in the distance. While the other mounds are smaller and not open for climbing, they add to the site’s historical significance. The visitor center is currently closed for renovations, but parking is available. Keep in mind that Monk Mound is across a busy road, though there is an additional parking lot nearby. It’s a must-see destination for history enthusiasts!

This is an amazing park. The signage is very well done. The paths are well maintained. The displays give a real sense of history. The reason for the park is especially impressive. Imagine the culture about a thousand years ago that created these impressive mounds

Peaceful, bring your walking shoes, hat, sunscreen, water, and snacks.  This is a nice easy walk with side trails to more. Drive across the highway to walk up 150 steps to Blue Mound for more sacredland energies.  This is a pyramid mound.  The visitor center is still closed. The trail maps are in the front of the building.  The early morning visit is cooler in August.  Enjoy!

This is an interesting historical place to visit. There are walking paths around the area where the smaller mounds are, and a lot of steps to go to the top of Monks Mound. The scenery from the top is fun to see as well. Not much shade on the grounds.

The museum and visitor center was closed when we visited in June 2024. It will be nice when it's open again and people can find out more about the Native Americans that used this site.

Name: Old Walled City of Shibam
short_description: Surrounded by a fortified wall, the 16th-century city of Shibam is one of the oldest and best examples of urban planning based on the principle of vertical construction. Its impressive tower-like structures rise out of the cliff and have given the city the nickname of ‘the Manhattan of the desert’.

Name: Rila Monastery
short_description: Rila Monastery was founded in the 10th century by St John of Rila, a hermit canonized by the Orthodox Church. His ascetic dwelling and tomb became a holy site and were transformed into a monastic complex which played an important role in the spiritual and social life of medieval Bulgaria. Destroyed by fire at the beginning of the 19th century, the complex was rebuilt between 1834 and 1862. A characteristic example of the Bulgarian Renaissance (18th–19th centuries), the monument symbolizes the awareness of a Slavic cultural identity following centuries of occupation.

reviews.text:
This is the pride of Bulgaria. The location is beautiful;nestled within the snow-top mountains.
The place is well preserved as UNESCO heritage site.
Guided tours would help with the history of this iconic architecture.

A very beautiful monastery, you can go inside without a ticket, but I advise you to get the combo ticket to see all the small museums they have inside, like the guest rooms and the old kitchen, which was spectacular. It cost us only €10 per person. The guide did not speak English, but she was very polite and walked us through the rooms. I would highly recommend it to everyone!!! there is so much history to learn.

The Monastery is a UNESCO World Heritage Site for a reason, it is full of history that dates back to the 10th century.
The place is big and surrounded by nature, looks out of this world when it snows.
You will love it once you reach it!

I went here as part of a Tour, I would definitely recommend having some kind of guide, if you can't have a physical person then at least an audio guide. There is a lot of explanation needed. Would recommend.

Beautiful place to walk around as it's in the mountains, there were a lot of cats in the monastery and a couple of dogs outside. They all follow you around if you have food.

You cannot eat, drink or smoke in the monastery and in the church, don't keep your hands in your pockets or wear hats as they say it is disrespectful.

The monastery itself is a 5 star place, 1 star deducted for the combine ticket tour, the tour guide (not sure if she is a tour guide) just unlock the door and let us look around without giving any information, it was kinda bored, we dont know what were we looking at, the guide just keeping unlock the door and lock the door repeatedly. The tour is highly recommended tho, just hope they can provide some basic information about what people are looking at.

Name: Ancient City of Nessebar
short_description: Situated on a rocky peninsula on the Black Sea, the more than 3,000-year-old site of Nessebar was originally a Thracian settlement (Menebria). At the beginning of the 6th century BC, the city became a Greek colony. The city’s remains, which date mostly from the Hellenistic period, include the acropolis, a temple of Apollo, an agora and a wall from the Thracian fortifications. Among other monuments, the Stara Mitropolia Basilica and the fortress date from the Middle Ages, when this was one of the most important Byzantine towns on the west coast of the Black Sea. Wooden houses built in the 19th century are typical of the Black Sea architecture of the period.

reviews.text:
The ancient town of Nessebar is located 30 km north of Burgas, on a small peninsula in the Black Sea, connected by a long and narrow isthmus to the new part of the town of Nessebar.  It is one of the oldest cities in Europe.  It was founded about 3000 years before the new era by the Thracians and is considered the city in Bulgaria with the most preserved architectural monuments from the Middle Ages.

In old Nessebar there are 23 churches and cultural monuments - from an early Christian basilica to a domed Byzantine church - examples that reflect the architectural and artistic influence of the Greek, Roman and Byzantine eras.

Today, the old Nessebar strives to preserve its romantic atmosphere with its narrow cobbled streets, small squares, two-story houses with stone ground and wooden upper floors that have external staircases and protrude above the streets, souvenir shops, pubs, taverns and beautiful flower gardens  .

The city is one of the main tourist attractions on the Southern Black Sea coast, and in particular for tourists vacationing in the Sunny Beach resort, which is adjacent to the north of the city of Nessebar.

A jewel in the sea! I spent all day on this little peninsula, and could come back had I got the time. The atmosphere of the restaurants and cafe, the ancient churches with a sea backdrop, the beautiful traditional houses of brick with smoked wood on top, everything about this place is so charming! I swam at the lovely beach at the south  tip of the peninsula, and was happy to see the lifeguard would place nice music for beach goers. (On the north side there are basketball courts, too!)
Beautiful site to see. Near centre of Nessebar.
The best
Beautiful place

Name: Srebarna Nature Reserve
short_description: The Srebarna Nature Reserve is a freshwater lake adjacent to the Danube and extending over 600 ha. It is the breeding ground of almost 100 species of birds, many of which are rare or endangered. Some 80 other bird species migrate and seek refuge there every winter. Among the most interesting bird species are the Dalmatian pelican, great egret, night heron, purple heron, glossy ibis and white spoonbill.

reviews.text: Its on World Heritage List for a reason. You can experience silence and natural beauty of unspoiled piece of land. There is a lake, which makes it attractive place for many birds. If you enter the tourist center you will see how many animals live there (and if you're lucky you'll see some herons and pelicans).
Amazing place. Close to the natural habitat of so many birds

Visited the place in the spring and the nature was very beautiful and green, but there was not a lot of birds for observing, that's why I recommend modernizing and improving the interactive part of the museum for the seasons in which the birds are not much and active!

Unfortunately, the biosphere reserve offers few viewing points, but from them you have a good view of the lake. There are some birds to watch and lots of amphibians to hear. Many lizards and snakes can be seen along the paths. We were lucky and even saw a turtle. The circular route around the lake marked on the information boards leads 3 kilometers along a busy main road and you can hardly see the lake the entire way.
You can see birds and find a little peace.

Name: Pirin National Park
short_description: Spread over an area of over 27,000 ha, at an altitude between 1008 and 2914 m in the Pirin Mountains, southwest Bulgaria, the site comprises diverse limestone mountain landscapes with glacial lakes, waterfalls, caves and predominantly coniferous forests. It was added to the World Heritage List in 1983. The extension now covers an area of around 40,000 ha in the Pirin Mountains, and overlaps with the Pirin National Park, except for two areas developed for tourism (skiing). The dominant part of the extension is high mountain territory over 2000m in altitude, and covered mostly by alpine meadows, rocky screes and summits.

reviews.text:
Pirin National Park is an absolutely stunning place to hike and be immersed in nature.

The trails in the alpine are clearly marked and well maintained and the huts around the park are wonderful to stay in.

There are many trails to choose from and peaks to climb.

Beautiful lakes, crystal clear streams, stunning mountains and breathtaking views Pirin is genuinely one of the most beautiful places I have ever been.

Perfect if you want to visit just for one day or spend several nights in the park.

Liked the slopes and facilities, even though everything closes a little early.  Beautiful nature, Ski passes are reasonably priced.  Can get a bit too busy on some days, but overall a great experience.  Keep in mind that driving might not be your best option on a busy day.
Beautiful, in late June the soil in many places is till wet because of the melting ice. But it’s stunning and offers lovely hikes.
The park is gorgeous! The mountains and the rivers are beautiful, and the weather is cool and nice. The lakes are cool and beautiful! Recommending the come prepared to a cold weather.

It’s a really nice place to ski but not that organized. They can do a better job in managing all the people that get there in peak season. It tends to be really crowded so you need to be patient with the lines to the gondola. But overall good value for money. Great for beginners.

Name: Wood Buffalo National Park
short_description: Situated on the plains in the north-central region of Canada, the park (which covers 44,807 km2) is home to North America's largest population of wild bison. It is also the natural nesting place of the whooping crane. Another of the park's attractions is the world's largest inland delta, located at the mouth of the Peace and Athabasca rivers.

reviews.text:
Wood Buffalo National Park is Canada's largest national park, spanning a vast area of 44,807 square kilometers (17,275 square miles) in northeastern Alberta and the southern Northwest Territories. It is renowned for its remarkable natural beauty, diverse ecosystems, and significant ecological importance.
Key Features and Importance:
* World's Largest Free-Roaming Wood Bison Herd: The park is home to the largest population of free-roaming wood bison in the world, a crucial conservation success story.

* Whooping Crane Nesting Habitat: Wood Buffalo National Park provides the only natural nesting habitat for the endangered whooping crane, making it a critical site for their survival.

* Peace-Athabasca Delta: The park encompasses a significant portion of the Peace-Athabasca Delta, one of the largest freshwater deltas in North America, offering diverse wetland habitats.

* Boreal Forest and Grasslands: The park features extensive boreal forests, grasslands, and other ecosystems, supporting a wide range of wildlife.
* UNESCO World Heritage Site: Wood Buffalo National Park was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1983, recognizing its outstanding universal value.
Activities and Attractions:
* Wildlife Viewing: Visitors can observe wood bison, elk, moose, wolves, and various bird species, including the whooping crane.
* Hiking and Camping: The park offers numerous hiking trails and camping opportunities, allowing visitors to immerse themselves in the natural environment.
* Canoeing and Kayaking: The Peace-Athabasca Delta provides excellent opportunities for canoeing and kayaking, exploring the waterways and spotting wildlife.
* Stargazing: Wood Buffalo National Park is renowned for its dark skies, making it an ideal location for stargazing and observing celestial events.
Visiting the Park:
* Accessibility: The park is remote and requires careful planning for access. Visitors can reach the park by air or by road, but transportation within the park is often limited.
* Permits and Regulations: Visitors may need permits for certain activities, and it is essential to adhere to park regulations to protect the environment and wildlife.
Wood Buffalo National Park is a remarkable wilderness area offering unparalleled opportunities for experiencing Canada's natural heritage. Its vastness, diverse ecosystems, and significant conservation value make it a truly special place.

Very large park with interesting trails and a high chance of encountering buffalo by the side of the road. Don't drive at night, because these large animals like to sleep on the road and they are dark and virtually invisible! This park has the largest night sky preserve in the world, so it's a fantastic place to see the Northern lights! Some of the trails were closed for maintenance while we were there, but we're managed to explore anyway :)

Absolutely breathtaking place! My first time driving through I seen a herd of maybe 30 or so buffalo and many calves. It was a sight I was looking forward to for a long time. Those animals are truly majestic. You don't get to see that everyday. It's a memory I'll cherish for the rest of my life
Thank God I saw Some Bison.  They like to Hide in the Woods.  Saw a Bunch of Black Bears and the Cutest Red Fox.  Otherwise the Drive is Okay, and Long.
Wonderful! You can follow the path, see bison, elk, moose, woodpecker and so on. Surrounded by nature

Name: Comoé National Park
short_description: One of the largest protected areas in West Africa, this park is characterized by its great plant diversity. Due to the presence of the Comoé river, it contains plants which are normally only found much farther south, such as shrub savannahs and patches of thick rainforest.

reviews.text: It's great to see this wildlife park, as West Africa really needs to preserve the wildlife that has mostly been hunted to extinction in this region. Don't expect a huge herds of wildlife like you see in South or East Africa, but you get to see a good amount of wildlife nonetheless.

Comoé NP is beautiful and huge. In March 2018 they were in a process of rebuilding after damage and neglect during the ivoirean civil war so it can be difficult to visit. Recommend you enter from the township of Bouna to the north east and visit the OIPR (Office Ivoirien Parcs et Reserves) in that town first - they will be very happy to help you and organise your park fees and guide. Lots of amazing birds and animals.
Very nice place, beautiful nature with lot of animals.
An amazing natural life reserve where you can rent a cabin and have three delicious meals per day.
One of the finest National Parks in West Africa.

Name: Sangay National Park
short_description: With its outstanding natural beauty and two active volcanoes, the park illustrates the entire spectrum of ecosystems, ranging from tropical rainforests to glaciers, with striking contrasts between the snowcapped peaks and the forests of the plains. Its isolation has encouraged the survival of indigenous species such as the mountain tapir and the Andean condor.

reviews.text:
The most beautiful national park of the country. Hard route but, highly recommend!

The best mountain landscape of the country.

Amazing sunrises and sunsets.

Be careful with your physical condition and the weather before going!

Beautiful landscape and not yet overrun by tourist. We visited the park with a local guide from Alausí and came by car to take a walk at the beautiful lakes. The view of the mountains was breathtaking and the calmness of the place was amazing. Be sure to bring lunch so you can strengthen yourself after the hike but take your trash with you :)
Beautiful but heavy walk to El Refugio. Expect lots of mud on a narrow path after heavy rain. The refugio is primitive but has a magnificient view at the area.

What a wonderful place! The park is beautiful with its lakes, the indigenous people, the animals and especially the tranquility. It is nice to relax in the "beach" directly at the lake and enjoy the view and the sun (when it's shining). It is not so crowded and very clean as well. A special place with a wonderful atmosphere! I would always visit the park again when I'm close by!
This national park and volcano are so worth the effort to visit. The views are great. I found the sulfur deposits to be interesting.

Name: Place Stanislas, Place de la Carrière and Place d'Alliance in Nancy
short_description: Nancy, the temporary residence of a king without a kingdom – Stanislas Leszczynski, later to become Duke of Lorraine – is paradoxically the oldest and most typical example of a modern capital where an enlightened monarch proved to be sensitive to the needs of the public. Built between 1752 and 1756 by a brilliant team led by the architect Héré, this was a carefully conceived project that succeeded in creating a capital that not only enhanced the sovereign's prestige but was also functional.

reviews.text: A FANTASTIC FRENCH ENSEMBLE OF BUILDINGS SURROUNDING THE PLACE STANISLAS  | THE SOUND AND LIGHT SHOW MAKES A CONTRAST WITH THE HISTORICAL BUILDINGS AND ATTRACTS OLD AND YOUNG |

The heart of Nancy and such a beautiful place. Plenty of good value bars and restaurants around the square and so much space that it never feels busy. We were lucky to get there to see the sun and lumiere show there which was quite magical to see.
What an absolutely wonderful town nancy is. Fabulous architecture art nouveau.  A really good walk from the square around the town using a map picked up in tourist information.

My first visit was 40 years ago and I was so happy to find the place as is well
Preserved and even more animated
I was so lucky to attend the last show for this season
On 17 July, 2024, my wife and I came to this great place. Buskers would perform beside the statue. We came again before the sky turned dark so that we wouldn’t miss the summer light show.

Name: Abbey Church of Saint-Savin sur Gartempe
short_description: Known as the 'Romanesque Sistine Chapel', the Abbey-Church of Saint-Savin contains many beautiful 11th- and 12th-century murals which are still in a remarkable state of preservation.
formatted_address: Pl. de la Libération, 86310 Saint-Savin, France

reviews.text: Spectacular ceiling frescos in this glorious old abbey. Really worth a detour and a visit to this historic small town with loads of charm and character. Very helpful Abbey shop and guides.
Wonderful iPad tour of the abbey, then a look around an exhibition. Really enjoyed it.
Beautiful abbey, stunning riverside location, with a very interesting self-guided tour, highly recommended
Breathtakingly beautiful. Very highly recommended for a visit. Welcome desk staff particularly helpful.

Really interesting old Abbey. Unusual frescos on the ceiling. Tablet guide available in English giving lots of information about the abbey and it's history. The little town of St Savin is a great day out with pretty walks over the river and terrace restaurants.

Name: Gulf of Porto: Calanche of Piana, Gulf of Girolata, Scandola Reserve
short_description: The nature reserve, which is part of the Regional Natural Park of Corsica, occupies the Scandola peninsula, an impressive, porphyritic rock mass. The vegetation is an outstanding example of scrubland. Seagulls, cormorants and sea eagles can be found there. The clear waters, with their islets and inaccessible caves, host a rich marine life.
formatted_address: Maison de la Mer, Route du Port, 20245 Galéria, France

reviews.text: Lovely to see and best by boat, make sure you get on one of those small boats, not the big ferries. The small boats can actually go even in some kind of caves. Very interesting rock formations and very beautiful views from the sea.

Amazing and beautiful area to visit. Clear water for snorkling with a lot of fish and interesting structure under water. Great landscape with huge and different colored rocks. But please remember, its a nature reservate so no garbage! No fishing! No fast driving with boots!
I visit this park in a speed boat. It was a nightmare. And about the park and rocks...well it's a problem of taste.

The most amazing place to visit in Corsica.
Just choose carefully your boat agency (even if they look all bad...)
Stunning place to visit, 100% must do in Calvi

Name: Pilgrimage Church of Wies
short_description: Miraculously preserved in the beautiful setting of an Alpine valley, the Church of Wies (1745–54), the work of architect Dominikus Zimmermann, is a masterpiece of Bavarian Rococo – exuberant, colourful and joyful.

reviews.text:
Visiting the Pilgrimage Church of Wies was an experience that left me truly in awe. Nestled in the beautiful Bavarian countryside, this UNESCO World Heritage site is a remarkable blend of spirituality, artistry, and natural beauty. The moment I stepped inside, I was captivated by the stunning Rococo architecture and the intricate details of the interior. The lavish decorations, the vibrant frescoes, and the serene ambiance all combined to create a sense of peace and reverence.

One of the most memorable aspects of my visit was the sense of tranquility that enveloped me as I walked through the church. It’s a place that invites reflection and contemplation, making it not just a visual feast but a spiritual retreat as well. The pastoral setting adds to the charm, with the lush green meadows and the picturesque mountains providing a perfect backdrop to this sacred site.

What also stood out to me was the warm welcome from the local community. Their pride in the church and its history was evident, and their hospitality made the visit even more special. If you have the chance to visit the Pilgrimage Church of Wies, take the time to explore its surroundings as well. The peaceful walks and the chance to connect with nature make for a holistic and enriching experience.

The Pilgrimage Church of Wies is not just a destination for those interested in religious sites or art. It’s a haven of beauty and serenity that touches the soul and leaves a lasting impression. A must-see for anyone traveling through Bavaria!

Anyone visiting the nearby Neuschwanstein Castle should drive just 25 minutes away to see this gorgeous church. The architecture is incredibly unique and jaw-dropping and my family and I spent 40 minutes marveling at its beauty. It is completely deserving of its UNESCO World Heritage Status. We couldn't believe that something this impressive was in the middle of a tiny town in Bavaria. The history is also interesting: a farmer's wife claimed she saw the Statue of the Scourged Saint, now housed in the Church, crying, which led many people from around the world to pilgrim to this church. I would recommend checking the website to confirm which time the church isn't running services and will allow visitors. I visited on a Friday in December and the visiting times were 12pm-2pm.

One of the most memorable places I visited while in Germany. Absolutely beautiful church intricately painted in pastel tones. What a lovely spot, even the nature surrounding the church is picturesque and peaceful, with adorable farm animals included.

Spectacular  beyond anything you would imagine if you see it from the outside. A pure gem worth the trip. The christ depictions the altar is like stepping through the looking glass. It sits with nothing but farms and greenery. It's right in the middle of the most amazing meadow just like someone imagined it in a dream, and it appeared.

A wonderfully located place with a dream church. The Wieskirche has been included in the UNESCO World Heritage List since 1983. This takes into account the outstanding artistic significance of the Wieskirche as a rococo jewel. In a unique way, the brothers Dominikus and Baptist Zimmermann have created a church interior that blooms with wonderful stucco work, but never appears overloaded or too lavish.

Name: Ajanta Caves
short_description: The first Buddhist cave monuments at Ajanta date from the 2nd and 1st centuries B.C. During the Gupta period (5th and 6th centuries A.D.), many more richly decorated caves were added to the original group. The paintings and sculptures of Ajanta, considered masterpieces of Buddhist religious art, have had a considerable artistic influence.

reviews.text:
interesting historical place, large scale caves, little information on site though, quite difficult access, there are quite a few steps to climb, you need to pay for transport for the last part of the way, plus the entrance ticket.
the big minus was the interaction with the vendors in the area that you can't avoid and that can be excessive.

Ajanta Caves have some of the most outstanding ancient paintings while Ellora Caves are known for their extraordinary architecture. Great & must visit place.  You will need 3-4 hr to explore all the caves. Well maintained and good hygiene. Parking place available. You can book tickets online.

Ajanta Caves are absolutely breathtaking!

😍 The ancient rock-cut Buddhist caves with their stunning murals and intricate sculptures transport you back in time.

The craftsmanship is unbelievable, and the peaceful atmosphere adds to the charm. Definitely a must-visit for history and art lovers! 🏛️✨

Try to go early to avoid crowds and take your time soaking in the beauty. 🚶‍♂️📸

Ancient place dedicated for Buddha. Marvellous architecture. Lots of caves are there and each one has unique story. Dholi & porter available at cheap cost. Many foreigners who fond of Buddhist would visit here frequently.

Hidden for centuries, the stunning artwork carved into the rock walls tells stories from ancient times

The detailed paintings and sculptures, dating back over 2,000 years, still retain their beauty. One fascinating fact is that the entire structure was created using just chisels and hammers

The caves feel like stepping into history, with every corner revealing intricate details of Buddhist culture. The walk can be tiring, especially in the heat, but it's worth it. A bit more maintenance in certain areas would make the experience even better

Name: Ellora Caves
short_description: These 34 monasteries and temples, extending over more than 2 km, were dug side by side in the wall of a high basalt cliff, not far from Aurangabad, in Maharashtra. Ellora, with its uninterrupted sequence of monuments dating from A.D. 600 to 1000, brings the civilization of ancient India to life. Not only is the Ellora complex a unique artistic creation and a technological exploit but, with its sanctuaries devoted to Buddhism, Hinduism and Jainism, it illustrates the spirit of tolerance that was characteristic of ancient India.

reviews.text:
I visited Ellora Caves last week, and I'm still reeling from the experience! This ancient rock-cut temple complex is an absolute marvel. The intricate carvings, sculptures, and paintings are a testament to India's rich history and architectural prowess.

The caves are well-maintained, and the guides are knowledgeable and friendly. The complex is vast, so be prepared to spend at least half a day exploring. Don't miss the Kailasa Temple (Cave 16) - it's a masterpiece!

If you're interested in history, architecture, or simply want to experience India's cultural heritage, Ellora Caves is a must-visit destination. I highly recommend it!

*Tips:*

- Wear comfortable shoes, as you'll be walking and climbing stairs.
- Bring water, snacks, and a hat to protect yourself from the sun.
- Hire a guide to get the most out of your visit.
- Respect the ancient monuments and surroundings.

Will I visit again? Absolutely!

Fantastic place to see engineering marvels of ancient India. One can just wonder about the technology and tools used during those times to carve the temple. I would suggest visiting this place either during the rainy or winter season, because the weather is very hot there during other seasons. Entry tickets can be bought at the gate, but I would suggest to book the ticket online to avoid the queue. Please take enough water and food with you, because once you enter through the gate there is no food available. Especially if there are kids with you.

Very well maintained caves. Very huge and amazing big sculptured rocks are seen here.
Also the picture present in the 20 rupees notes is one of the stones here.

Ellora Caves is a Mesmerizing Blend of History and Architecture.
Visiting Ellora Caves was an unforgettable experience! This UNESCO World Heritage Site is a masterpiece of ancient Indian rock-cut architecture, showcasing the brilliance of three different religions—Hinduism, Buddhism, and Jainism. The highlight of the visit was the Kailasa Temple (Cave 16), an awe-inspiring monolithic structure carved entirely from a single rock. The intricate carvings, grand pillars, and towering sculptures left me speechless.
The caves are well-maintained, and the surrounding landscape adds to their charm. Walking through these centuries-old carvings feels like stepping back in time. The artistry and engineering skills of the craftsmen are truly remarkable.

A few tips for travelers:

Wear comfortable shoes as there’s a lot of walking involved.

Visit early in the morning to avoid crowds and enjoy the serene atmosphere.

A guided tour enhances the experience, as the historical insights bring the caves to life.

Overall, Ellora Caves is a must-visit for history lovers, architecture enthusiasts, and spiritual seekers. It's a place that leaves you in awe of India's rich cultural heritage!

Visited in Early March. We reached there 6:30 am. Weather was very nice for the walk. If you are a serious lover of sculpture and history and religion, take a guide service. Otherwise use the help of Google and check for the caves of your interest. I recommend to visit cave 16 & 14

Name: Agra Fort
short_description: Near the gardens of the Taj Mahal stands the important 16th-century Mughal monument known as the Red Fort of Agra. This powerful fortress of red sandstone encompasses, within its 2.5-km-long enclosure walls, the imperial city of the Mughal rulers. It comprises many fairy-tale palaces, such as the Jahangir Palace and the Khas Mahal, built by Shah Jahan; audience halls, such as the Diwan-i-Khas; and two very beautiful mosques.
formatted_address: Agra Fort, Rakabganj, Agra, Uttar Pradesh 282003, India

reviews.text: The architecture is breathtaking and it's incredible to imagine how it was constructed centuries ago. The sheer scale and history of the fort is awe-inspiring. And the cherry on top - the stunning views of the Taj Mahal from the fort's balconies! Definitely worth a visit!
Agra fort is a really great place to visit for your cup of history tea..!! Not that well maintained but yes definitely worth going there once..! Gives you our rich history and cultural background..

Agra Fort is absolutely stunning! The architecture is breathtaking, and the views, especially of the Taj Mahal in the distance, are unforgettable. The fort is well-maintained, and every corner tells a story of India’s rich history.

The only downside is that it can get quite crowded, so I highly recommend going with a tour guide. Our guide was fantastic—helped us skip the long queues, shared fascinating historical details, and even took some amazing photos for us!

Overall, a must-visit when in Agra. Just plan ahead to make the most of your trip! And come in the morning!

Wonderful monument. Well maintained. Must see place. Carries enormous background of Emperor Jahangir. Huge visitors both Indian and international. Guide is required to understand the nuances. Rs 500 will get you a guide. It will take about 2 hours. Breathtaking views from the Fort of Taj Mahal.

Im so Amazed how people on that time manage to build this beautiful fort history tells us about everything who is good/bad in person but after all this enjoy the Architect. A lot lot to say about this go there gain your own experience.

Name: Taj Mahal
short_description: An immense mausoleum of white marble, built in Agra between 1631 and 1648 by order of the Mughal emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his favourite wife, the Taj Mahal is the jewel of Muslim art in India and one of the universally admired masterpieces of the world's heritage.
formatted_address: Dharmapuri, Forest Colony, Tajganj, Agra, Uttar Pradesh 282001, India

reviews.text: Considered more than a world wonder, this monument has a genuine Aura on its own.  There's mysterious stillness in this place combined with the air of awesomeness. Besides the architectural beauty, this monument stands for the greatness of love, artistry & skills of all those involved centuries ago. You can't have enough of it despite viewing the monument from all over the sides. It continues to haunt you forever !

What to say about an amazing sight, it did not disappoint.

Things be aware of. You will wait in a line to get in for security reasons. Security in India is a big show and VERY inefficient but be prepared to be crammed and touched by strangers.

If you get a guide, and you should, ask them to help and they’ll likely just drag you to the front of the queue anyway.

Enjoy the sites, take your time. They say it’s a 3 hour maximum time but no one is checking.

Look from every angle, they’re unique.

Also, expect a million people, you’re not going to get a quiet photo.

The Taj Mahal is truly beautiful! The white marble looks amazing, especially in the morning and evening. The place is big, peaceful, and full of history. Walking around the gardens and seeing the reflection in the water is a wonderful experience. It’s a must-visit if you love history and beautiful places!

Visiting the Taj Mahal was an incredible experience! The moment I stepped onto the premises, I was mesmerized by its grandeur and beauty. The intricate marble work, the stunning symmetry, and the sheer magnificence of this wonder left me in awe. The gardens were well-maintained, and the view of the monument reflecting in the water was breathtaking.

I visited on a weekday, so the crowd was manageable. The entry process was smooth, and the wait time was around 10-30 minutes. Security checks were thorough, but the staff was helpful and efficient.

Inside, the details of the craftsmanship were mind-blowing. The inlaid gemstone work and calligraphy on the walls added to its charm. It’s a place that truly embodies history, love, and architectural brilliance.

If you're planning a visit, I recommend arriving early in the morning to enjoy the serene beauty before the crowd builds up. Also, hiring a guide can enhance the experience, as they share fascinating historical facts. Overall, an unforgettable trip and a must-visit destination!

A place to visit once in your life. No words for it. There’s a reason its part of the 7 wonders of the world.Amazing stone work building made over 400 years ago by 20,000 people taking 22 years. It is well worth getting a guide if you want to learn the history.

* 2 or 3 hrs needed to have a good look and walk around it.
*Normal ticket price is 45/- per person for general entry. And 200/- to see the mausoleum.
* There is a buggy service also costing 60/- per peeson. You can buy ticket online also in advance.
* There are 2 slots available forenoon and afternoon. You can select any one as per your choice.
*Do not plan visits on Fridays. No entry for visitors and on other days it’s better to plan an early morning visit around 6-6:30 AM but then not during Winters

Name: City of Cuzco
short_description: Situated in the Peruvian Andes, Cuzco developed, under the Inca ruler Pachacutec, into a complex urban centre with distinct religious and administrative functions. It was surrounded by clearly delineated areas for agricultural, artisan and industrial production. When the Spaniards conquered it in the 16th century, they preserved the basic structure but built Baroque churches and palaces over the ruins of the Inca city.

Name: Historic Sanctuary of Machu Picchu
short_description: Machu Picchu stands 2,430 m above sea-level, in the middle of a tropical mountain forest, in an extraordinarily beautiful setting. It was probably the most amazing urban creation of the Inca Empire at its height; its giant walls, terraces and ramps seem as if they have been cut naturally in the continuous rock escarpments. The natural setting, on the eastern slopes of the Andes, encompasses the upper Amazon basin with its rich diversity of flora and fauna.

reviews.text: Buy ticket well in advance. Divided In different circuits based on view. Good view circuits sell well in advance. We been there in a less busy season and purchased ticket 3 days in advance yet were not able to get the best view circuits sell well.
This was one of the most amazing hikes I've ever done. The views are incredible, and the ruins are fascinating. I highly recommend it to anyone who is up for a challenge.

This 3-day trek to Machu Picchu was hands down the best experience of my life! It was a perfect mix of adventure, breathtaking scenery, and cultural immersion.

We kicked off the journey with a 2-hour drive from Cusco to our first stop, where we hopped on mountain bikes for an incredible 1-hour downhill ride. The views were absolutely unreal—towering mountains, lush green valleys, and winding roads that made the descent both thrilling and surreal.

After spending the night in a small town near Hidroeléctrica, we were up early for the next leg of our adventure—ziplining through the mountains! The 45-minute ziplining experience was exhilarating, offering a bird’s-eye view of the vast landscape. Just when we thought it couldn’t get any better, we headed to a river for white-water rafting. The rapids were thrilling but manageable, making it a perfect mix of excitement and fun.

Throughout the trip, meals were provided, keeping us fueled for the journey. On the third morning, we met with our guide for a 4-hour trek to Aguas Calientes, the base town for Machu Picchu. After arriving, we purchased our Machu Picchu tickets in person, which must be done in advance—an important tip for future travelers.

The next morning was the moment we had been waiting for. We took the bus up to Machu Picchu, where we hired a guide to take us through the incredible ruins. Standing among the ancient Incan city, surrounded by mist-covered mountains, was beyond words. The history, the energy, and the sheer beauty of Machu Picchu made every step of the journey worth it.

If you’re looking for an adventure-packed, unforgettable way to experience Machu Picchu, this 3-day trek is the way to do it!

Amazing place - a must visit for anyone. When you get to admission gate hike isn’t too bad - quite an incline at the start but once you get to view platform it is flat and down hill. The citadel is amazing with both the domestic and religious side. Lots of wild llamas and some dogs which have wondered up there. Cannot recommend enough - no picture will ever do this justice as one must experience this in person

Amazing place even though it is a real track getting there. We took the scenic rail journey with live music entertainment but hiking up for 3 days would have been just as fun if it wasn't for the rain (early December)

Name: Central Zone of the Town of Angra do Heroismo in the Azores
short_description: Situated on one of the islands in the Azores archipelago, this was an obligatory port of call from the 15th century until the advent of the steamship in the 19th century. The 400-year-old San Sebastião and San João Baptista fortifications are unique examples of military architecture. Damaged by an earthquake in 1980, Angra is now being restored.

Name: Monastery of the Hieronymites and Tower of Belém in Lisbon
short_description: Standing at the entrance to Lisbon harbour, the Monastery of the Hieronymites – construction of which began in 1502 – exemplifies Portuguese art at its best. The nearby Tower of Belém, built to commemorate Vasco da Gama's expedition, is a reminder of the great maritime discoveries that laid the foundations of the modern world.
formatted_address: Praça do Império 1400-206 Lisboa, 1400-206 Lisboa, Portugal

reviews.text: Another must-see in Lisbon, and definitely worth the wait! The entrance fee might be a bit steep, but it’s free with the Lisboa Card, so I highly recommend getting one. The architecture is breathtaking, with perfect symmetry and beautifully sculpted arches and interiors. Worth noting that you can't enter the church on Sundays, so be sure to plan your visit accordingly! Also, if you have a Lisboa card, just get into the queue and validate your ticket just outside the entrance.

This is such a beautiful  place. The peace and tranquility you breath here is outstanding. A lot of history and great architecture to see here. There were some spaces that were under restorations on the church side.
We went on a Weekday and bought the tickets on a little stand that is the park right in front of the monastery, then we had to do a line of about 10 minutes wait to be able to get into the church. For the entrance to the monastery on the side with those same tickets we did not have to wait at all, but still recommend to buy tickets online if you want to avoid the lines.
The interior of the monastery itself with the patio, the sculptures and the mosaics with the blue and yellow hues is simple beautiful. Definitively recommended if you are in Lisbon and have time to pass by.

It's beautiful from the outside, the church is free and awesome. Don't think it's worth going in and paying just for the views and courtyard entrance as other people's reviews have already mentioned it's a bit of a tourist trap. Not much into it inside, some people finish the journey after 30 minutes, that's not worth it. Still, a beautiful architecture, great look outside.

This is a must-see destination when visiting Lisbon. Plan on spending at least a half day here. Take your time and enjoy the work that took craftmen over 100 years to finish. This place is massive. When you approach the building, you can get a real appreciation of the size of this place.

such a beautiful historical place! the architecture here is breathtaking. the church was undergoing some restorations, so a couple areas were blocked off, but it was beautiful nonetheless. it was very interesting to see the tombs of some important historical figures. the views of the building from the courtyard area are amazing. it’s very easy to navigate inside. we went on a weekday around 3pm and there was no wait! i highly recommend this beautiful place!

Name: Monastery of Batalha
short_description: The Monastery of the Dominicans of Batalha was built to commemorate the victory of the Portuguese over the Castilians at the battle of Aljubarrota in 1385. It was to be the Portuguese monarchy's main building project for the next two centuries. Here a highly original, national Gothic style evolved, profoundly influenced by Manueline art, as demonstrated by its masterpiece, the Royal Cloister.
formatted_address: Largo Infante Dom Henrique, 2440-109 Batalha, Portugal

reviews.text: This stop was amazing. My only point of feedback, they didn't make it clear at the exit of the imperfect chapel that it *was* the end, so we walked through the door without getting all the pictures we would have taken and suddenly we were completely outside and didn't get to go in like some of the other visitors. The cloisters were beautiful.

Didn't have to pay to enter (not sure why) 🤔  on a Sunday morning. Amazing Gothic architecture with high sweeping ceilings, intricate stained glass windows 🪟 and carvings. Detailed descriptions of the various figures and designs throughout. Expect to spend an hour exploring the whole compound.

What an interesting place to visit. It's the exact equivalent of Battle Abbey in the UK (the town name - Batalha -means Battle. This was the site of the key battle which established the nation of Portugal, built by the grateful king to the glory of God in thanks. Building took over 250 years until, I guess, they lost interest! Not expensive - €7.5 for 65+ - very nicely restored. Not a huge amount of printed info but helpful staff, good free WiFi and some sort of audio guide (which we didn't try).

I recently visited the Batalha Monastery, and it was an unforgettable experience. The Gothic architecture is absolutely stunning, with intricate details and impressive stonework throughout. The monastery is rich in history, and walking through its halls feels like stepping back in time. The peaceful atmosphere and the grandeur of the building make it a perfect spot for anyone interested in history, architecture, or simply looking for a beautiful and serene place to visit. Highly recommended for a day trip!

Was able to purchase advanced tickets online at a discount from a travel agency (although did have to print them out). Another UNESCO world heritage site and a great attraction with lots of unique artifacts.

Name: Convent of Christ in Tomar
short_description: Originally designed as a monument symbolizing the Reconquest, the Convent of the Knights Templar of Tomar (transferred in 1344 to the Knights of the Order of Christ) came to symbolize just the opposite during the Manueline period – the opening up of Portugal to other civilizations.
formatted_address: Igreja do Castelo Templário, Estr. do Convento, 2300-000 Tomar, Portugal

reviews.text:
Visiting the Convento de Cristo in Tomar was an absolutely breathtaking experience! This UNESCO World Heritage Site is a masterpiece of history, architecture, and culture. The intricate Manueline designs, the stunning charola (rotunda), and the peaceful cloisters are awe-inspiring. Every corner of this convent tells a story of Portugal’s rich past, particularly its connection to the Knights Templar.

The grounds are vast and beautifully preserved, making it easy to spend hours exploring. The attention to detail in the carvings and the overall atmosphere truly transport you back in time. It’s also set in a picturesque location, adding to the magic of the visit.

Whether you’re a history enthusiast or simply looking to experience something extraordinary, this is a place you shouldn’t miss. Highly recommend it to anyone visiting Portugal—it’s worth the trip to Tomar!

The convent has the most stunning baroque sculptures and  paintings.

A central chamber had an impressive design displaying Jesus.  The amount of gold and colors were brilliant.
This Templar site is great! I loved strolling around and feeling the energy of the past glorious times! There is a window, which has such intricate design with its details carved in years 1510-1513.

If you love architecture and history this site is for you. What an amazing location do allow yourself plenty of time to discover and experience Life within. My biggest criticism is lack of information or an application to bring this fantastic heritage to life.

Such a beautifully preserved piece of history located on the hilltops above the picturesque town of Tomar. My husband is a bit obsessed with the Knights Templar and this was essentially their home base for centuries first as the Knights then as the Order of Christ. We weren’t anticipating this but the most adorable teens offered us a guided tour - they were volunteering for a school project. They were so sweet and incredibly knowledgeable about the history of the convent. Highly recommend especially if you’re a knights fan, architectural and/or history buff.

Name: Vallée de Mai Nature Reserve
short_description: In the heart of the small island of Praslin, the reserve has the vestiges of a natural palm forest preserved in almost its original state. The famous coco de mer, from a palm-tree once believed to grow in the depths of the sea, is the largest seed in the plant kingdom.

reviews.text:
Valle de Mai is a breathtaking nature reserve and a must-visit for anyone traveling to Praslin, Seychelles. Walking through this UNESCO World Heritage Site feels like stepping back in time—towering palm trees, lush greenery, and the famous Coco de Mer palms create an enchanting atmosphere.

The trails are well-marked and suitable for all fitness levels, making it easy to explore at your own pace. Along the way, you might spot the rare black parrot and other unique wildlife. The guided tours provide fascinating insights into the ecosystem, adding even more depth to the experience.

The sheer tranquility of this place is incredible. Whether you're a nature lover, a photographer, or just someone looking for a peaceful escape, Valle de Mai is pure magic. Highly recommended!

A prehistoric forest with amazing vegetation. The largest palm Coco de mer population in the world. The entrance fee is 450 rupees, but it is recommended to hire a guide to show you the hidden secrets of the forest. The fee they charged us for the guide was 1000 rupees.

This is one of the 2 World Heritage sites of the Seychelles. The other is Aldabra island which is hundreds of km away and hardly visited. The Vallee de Mai is well worth a trip so DONT skip this. Most large tours will just let you see from the entrance sadly. I paid for a guide Scy1000 to explain in detail the story of coco de mer and she was very good. You can buy a coco de mer with a certificate legally at the museum gift shop too.

It was such a beautiful experience, the coco de mer tree, the history, the way it grows l is just fascinating. It was pouring rain and we had umbrellas but because of the big leaves and the branches, we couldn't feel a drop. It is basically visiting a glimpse of the forest you see all over seychelles. It is definitely to be visited, it's an interesting place❣️
Very educational and worth paying the extra for a guide or you will miss so much. Best place to learn about the Coco de Mer.

Name: Old City of Berne
short_description: Founded in the 12th century on a hill site surrounded by the Aare River, Berne developed over the centuries in line with a an exceptionally coherent planning concept. The buildings in the Old City, dating from a variety of periods, include 15th-century arcades and 16th-century fountains. Most of the medieval town was restored in the 18th century but it has retained its original character.

reviews.text: One long cobblestone promenade flanked by shops on its North and South sides. It starts at Bern HB and goes all the way to the river and Bearpark at the end. The covered cloisters are convenient giving shade from too much sun or rain. You can imagine Einstein walking around here during his time in Bern. Although apparently he didn't have a sweet tooth and didn't consume chocolate, how can that be when living in Bern! All of Bern's main sights are around here and you only need less than a day to do them all, makes Bern a good day trip.

If you love historic buildings, Bern’s Old City is a must-see. The medieval architecture is stunning, and the streets are beautifully clean and well-organized. Shops are thoughtfully placed, so you can enjoy the views while exploring. A truly charming and unforgettable experience!

The Bern old town is lovely, colorful and very easy to walk around, even if it’s raining ☔️ there pathways next to the shops covered, as is UNESCO protected the buildings are old but very well maintained, you will be impressed! Many fountains to see and take pics with and of course the famous clock tower! You will need a couple of hours to stroll around the historical center, watch out for the trams and red buses are very frequent! Recommend it and take your time to enjoy it!

In my opinion, Bern's old town is one of the most beautiful and compact in the world. Its specialty is the arcades formed by the old buildings lining the streets. The arcades are lined with shops, restaurants, bars, art galleries, etc. It is worth walking around the old town, also along the banks of the Aare River, and climbing to the Rosengarten to admire the magnificent view of the old town. Every time I visit Bern I feel amazed.

LOVE this pretty place! So historic and colorful, tons of lovely photo spots! Love the iconic fountain and huge clock tower, as well as all the cute trains and buses that came in different shapes and sizes 🚂🚌🇨🇭❤️.

Was glad I dropped by Bern - after all it’s the capital of Switzerland, and a must drop by imo, even if it’s for a short day trip! 😆 I was really happy to be here 🥰👍.

Name: Abbey of St Gall
short_description: The Convent of St Gall, a perfect example of a great Carolingian monastery, was, from the 8th century to its secularization in 1805, one of the most important in Europe. Its library is one of the richest and oldest in the world and contains precious manuscripts such as the earliest-known architectural plan drawn on parchment. From 1755 to 1768, the conventual area was rebuilt in Baroque style. The cathedral and the library are the main features of this remarkable architectural complex, reflecting 12 centuries of continuous activity.

reviews.text: Wonderful place, with a picturesque church,  unique architecture that you need to experience it yourself.  Lifetime  experience which provides with unforgettable memories.

I love this place. It's worth every penny :)

This is the second time I have come here. I love all the woodwork on the walls and handrail, and 3d and paint details in the ceiling. I also love the old Earth globe. And all of it was hand made a loooooonh time ago!

There is a mummy too.

You can ask to get an audio guide.

Each ticket is 18 francs. You'll be asked to leave all bags and backpacks in a locker (which is free). The ticket includes other stuff.

There is a bathroom.

There is a gift store with some nice stuff.
Beautiful place. Not as big as I thought, but a must if you like books

Stunning. I highly recommend to visit the museum including the unparalleled library.
(1. Stiftsbibliothek, 2. Gewölbekeller, 3. Ausstellungssaal)
