In 2024, tickets are 18CHF for adults and children up to 16 are for free when accompanied by adults.

Enjoy the beautiful buildings, its surroundings and simultaneously get informed about the special history of the beautiful city St Gallen.

From the train station, it is approximately a 10-15 min walk, just follow the signs, it’s hard to miss.

Let me know if this review was helpful
Beautiful experience and amazing details, filled with history, on every corner

Name: Benedictine Convent of St John at Müstair
short_description: The Convent of Müstair, which stands in a valley in the Grisons, is a good example of Christian monastic renovation during the Carolingian period. It has Switzerland's greatest series of figurative murals, painted c. A.D. 800, along with Romanesque frescoes and stuccoes.

reviews.text: Incredible. Enchanting. Well worth the visit. It is on of the few Unesco Heritage im Switzerland. Well preserved. Magic. Even the manicured graveyard is astoundingly cared for. A beauty among the Alps.

Both the church and the monastery deserve a visit if you’re in that neck of the woods. 1-2 hours total depending on how deep you want to go but there is a lot of info and the 1,000-year plus art and history are fascinating. 30 CHF for the museum visit for a full family with kids is fair

Rare opportunity to experience Carolingian art. In complete silence.
Important: opening hours apply for museum, church with frescoes is open regardless.

Wonderful churche. The abbey was established ca. 780 by a bishop of Chur. In 881 the abbey passed over to be completely under the control of the Bishop of Chur. During the early years of the abbey, in the early 9th century, a series of frescos were painted in the church. Later, in the 11th and 12th centuries, the abbey experienced a second expansion and new paintings were added or painted over the old frescoes.
A very well presented example of convent life with an interesting insight into the lives of the nuns. The frescoes in the chapel alone are worth the time to visit

Name: Great Smoky Mountains National Park
short_description: Stretching over more than 200,000 ha, this exceptionally beautiful park is home to more than 3,500 plant species, including almost as many trees (130 natural species) as in all of Europe. Many endangered animal species are also found there, including what is probably the greatest variety of salamanders in the world. Since the park is relatively untouched, it gives an idea of temperate flora before the influence of humankind.

reviews.text:
Exploring Great Smoky Mountains National Park was an unforgettable experience! The park offers such a variety of roads and trails to explore, each offering its own unique views and opportunities for adventure. We spent our time hiking several trails, some of which were a bit steeper than we had expected, but the rewarding views at the top made it all worth it.

One of the highlights of our visit was becoming Junior Rangers! The park offers fun, interactive activities aimed at kids (but really enjoyable for adults too), and completing these tasks was a great way to connect with the park. We also enjoyed collecting stamps for our National Park book, which always adds a little extra excitement to the journey.

However, as much as we loved the natural beauty of the park, we did notice how crowded it can get—especially on the more popular trails and viewpoints. There were people everywhere, and finding parking in some areas became a bit of a challenge. This is definitely something to keep in mind if you're visiting during peak times.

Overall, the Great Smoky Mountains is a must-see for nature lovers, and while it can be a bit crowded, the stunning scenery and the range of activities available make it well worth the visit. We'll definitely be back for another adventure!

Visiting the Smoky Mountains was a truly serene experience. The breathtaking landscapes made me feel as if I had stepped into another country. The crisp, clean air was refreshing, and the sound of cascading waterfalls was incredibly therapeutic. I’m so glad I finally made the trip—it was well worth it!

We have a National Park Pass, and we try to go to all of the National Parks possible. The Great Smoky Mountains National Parks is gorgeous. I love how it spans between Eastern Tennessee and Western North Carolina. There are so many different ways to visit, and so many ways to take advantage of the beauty. Absolutely worth multiple visits.

The Great Smoky Mountains National Park is a nature lover's paradise! During my visit, I was lucky enough to spot a black bear in the wild, which was an unforgettable experience. The park's lush greenery, stunning waterfalls, and breathtaking views create an incredible atmosphere. Whether you're hiking, picnicking, or just exploring, there's something for everyone. Don't miss out on this extraordinary adventure! 🌲🐻🏞️"

This place is just beautiful. From the amazing scenery to some quality family time. Going to the mountains is just s feeling that is unmatched in today's fast paced world. I believe everyone should take the time to visit and decompress in God's great land.

Name: La Fortaleza and San Juan National Historic Site in Puerto Rico
short_description: Between the 16th and 20th centuries, a series of defensive structures was built at this strategic point in the Caribbean Sea to protect the city and the Bay of San Juan. They represent a fine display of European military architecture adapted to harbour sites on the American continent.

reviews.text: Restarted our vacation here in San Juan and then we started our cruise and ended our cruise from here. So this is the first place that we saw and it was a great start to our vacation. It is a very nice architectural castle! It has a very unique history and very beautiful views of the ocean and Countryside. There's not much left inside but what is left it looks really nice.

Visiting San Juan National Historic Site was like stepping back in time. Walking through the massive stone walls of Castillo San Felipe del Morro and Castillo San Cristóbal, I could almost feel the history that shaped Puerto Rico. The architecture is impressive, with hidden tunnels, old cannons, and strategic lookout points. The views from the fort walls were breathtaking—endless ocean on one side and the colorful charm of Old San Juan on the other. The staff shared so many interesting details about the island’s colonial past, which made the experience even richer. It’s the perfect place to explore, take in amazing views, and appreciate Puerto Rico's unique heritage.

I would actually love to go back to actually visit and go inside. I was on a tour so we really didn't have time to go inside; so we were able to just look on the outside and take pictures but it was very nice.
Amazing. Great place and incredible opportunity to see historic fort.
Absolutely amazing. Loved reading about the history and how breathtaking the views were.

Name: Jesuit Missions of the Guaranis: San Ignacio Mini, Santa Ana, Nuestra Señora de Loreto and Santa Maria Mayor (Argentina), Ruins of Sao Miguel das Missoes (Brazil)
short_description: The ruins of São Miguel das Missões in Brazil, and those of San Ignacio Miní, Santa Ana, Nuestra Señora de Loreto and Santa María la Mayor in Argentina, lie at the heart of a tropical forest. They are the impressive remains of five Jesuit missions, built in the land of the Guaranis during the 17th and 18th centuries. Each is characterized by a specific layout and a different state of conservation.

reviews.text:
Having already visited one of the Missiones in the area, we decided to explore the others nearby. The admission ticket allows you to visit all the missions within a 15-day period.

While this site isn’t as fully reconstructed as San Ignacio Miní, it still features large standing structures and unique elements, such as a better-preserved community garden area, which sets it apart from San Ignacio.

A guide welcomed us at the small museum, providing insightful explanations about the site and the region. They then accompanied us to the main buildings, sharing details about the architecture and the fascinating historical background.

There was only one other visitor so we had this beautiful spotb mostly to ourselves.
Ricardo the host was super helpful and friendly too!

I enjoyed this place and look forward to coming back when I have more time. I have seen many ruins in the Americas but the ruins in Misiones may be unique for presenting the remains of Catholic complexes in a beautiful natural environment. They are like an inverse image of the Mayan Tikal complex in Guatemala. There is a depth, beauty, and mystique here. You can almost sense the priests walking to and fro on the grounds.  Also, Ricardo, an employee on the grounds, is a very warm and engaging man who was a pleasure to chat with before and after my tour of the site. So, thanks again to Ricardo and everyone associated with the presentation of the ruins at Santa Ana!
Amazing place!!!! The history is here.
The ruins themselves are interesting but the way nature has reclaimed this once thriving mission is beautiful.  The guide was very knowledgeable and spoke English and Spanish.

Name: Talamanca Range-La Amistad Reserves / La Amistad National Park
short_description: The location of this unique site in Central America, where Quaternary glaciers have left their mark, has allowed the fauna and flora of North and South America to interbreed. Tropical rainforests cover most of the area. Four different Indian tribes inhabit this property, which benefits from close co-operation between Costa Rica and Panama.

reviews.text: Beautiful beautiful beautiful. If you want to connect with mother nature this is the place, the place is super quiet and people that work there are very knowledgeable. Huge advice if you want to come or get to this place you need to have a 4 by 4 car otherwise if you come waiting for by to the road would be very difficult. Other than that The place is magnificent.

Amazing mountain ranges, lush jungle and forests. High up in the mountains you get to see the páramo or alpine tundra ecosystem. You wouldn't believe such and extense and variable landscape fits in this seamingly tiny country.

These lands are considered to be of essential importance to all of humanity. It is a great place to visit and appreciate this patrimony we can all share and help conserve for future generations. In other regions you can find indigenous communities whete their traditional culture is still practice. They live very far into the jungle. Only your feet will get you there! (Photos taken at Cerro Brunka and Cerro Cabécar)

Contact me on my Facebook if you would like to visit.
The less people that come here the better. Nothing but pure magic.
Awesome, beautiful forrest.
Great view of Buenos Aires!

Name: Iguazu National Park
short_description: The semicircular waterfall at the heart of this site is some 80 m high and 2,700 m in diameter and is situated on a basaltic line spanning the border between Argentina and Brazil. Made up of many cascades producing vast sprays of water, it is one of the most spectacular waterfalls in the world. The surrounding subtropical rainforest has over 2,000 species of vascular plants and is home to the typical wildlife of the region: tapirs, giant anteaters, howler monkeys, ocelots, jaguars and caymans.
formatted_address: Ruta 101 Km 142, N3370 Puerto Iguazú, Misiones, Argentina

reviews.text: We absolutely loved this side of the falls – the park is stunning! There are so many amazing trails and wildlife to see, and it's very well organized. There are plenty of cafes and restaurant options, and you have several ways to get to the falls, whether by train, bike, or hiking. We bought our tickets online, so we got in quickly with barely any wait. The park opens at 8 am, so we got there right when it opened, and many of the trails were empty. The Devil’s Throat area is the most crowded, but the trails leading up to it are quieter. Seeing the falls and the surrounding jungle is an experience like no other. You could easily spend 8-9 hours here. Make sure to bring plenty of water if you’re hiking. If you only have one day, I highly recommend this side of the falls. We didn’t hire a tour guide – we took a taxi and explored on our own. Honestly, I don’t think a guide is necessary if you want to explore the entire park at your own pace.

Amazing scenery. Camera cannot justify the panoramic views.
We were lucky enough to be staying within the park so we could see the falls with very few other visitors

Totally worth the entry fee.  Flat paths to follow along the top of the waterfalls across a grand river. You get to be immersed in the river ways and such.  And then the trains inside the park take you to where you need to go.  What a magnificent sight

Beautiful place! The waterfalls are breathtaking and it's mesmerizing just to stare at the power of the water element. Don't forget a sunscreen even if it's  a cloudy day and comfortable shoes, you will walk minimum of 4km most likely over 10km. The lower track is prettier, I preferred taking the ramp to the dtairs

What an experience! Bring water, sunscreen and a hat and try to avoid the hottest time of the day! Beautiful well kept park with great facilities.
The train ride was fun and the wheelchair use and guided tour was absolutely fantastic.
I can recommend this stop on your visit to Argentine.
2 days in the area was great, but I would recommend 3 days. One full day for the park alone.

Name: Canadian Rocky Mountain Parks
short_description: The contiguous national parks of Banff, Jasper, Kootenay and Yoho, as well as the Mount Robson, Mount Assiniboine and Hamber provincial parks, studded with mountain peaks, glaciers, lakes, waterfalls, canyons and limestone caves, form a striking mountain landscape. The Burgess Shale fossil site, well known for its fossil remains of soft-bodied marine animals, is also found there.
formatted_address: Improvement District No. 9, AB T0L, Canada

reviews.text:
Don't miss your chance to enjoy what our mother nature did create
Its unbelievable how beautiful some places could be
Yes ,it's cold but if you put more clothes you definitely will enjoy that hike with so many lakes and such a fresh air

Now, I can truly appreciate why everyone says you have to visit Banff.  It’s gorgeous and we only made it as far as the city center.  That was enough to get my feet wet as I will definitely be back for more of Banff.  This National Park is worth the entry fee and some.  We spent about 3 hours in the little village and the variety of shops and restaurants were a delight.
We visited here in January 2025 and unfortunately for me there wasn’t much snow which everyone has been totally shocked about.

Just a beautiful experience.  This is a place that people can tell you about, like I am, but you will not appreciate the true beauty and vastness of this park until you visit for yourself.

Everywhere you look the sights are breathtaking.  At times I found myself just staring taking in the view being lost in nature.

My husband and I went to Banff with our toddler 9/18-25/24. It was chilly, and in the mornings, it sometimes got to below freezing. I wore leggings, a t-shirt, and a heavy fleece jacket with a beanie and it was enough to keep me warm! Wear layers so you can peel off as you hike. We wore trail runners and those were adequate for hiking. We stayed in Canmore and drove into Banff, which really wasn’t too far.

*NOTE: Get a bus pass to Moraine Lake and Lake Louise. We weren’t able to get the Parks Canada shuttle, so we went with a private company, Fairview Limousine Shuttle. It was CA$25 for Lake Louise and CA$35 for Moraine Lake per person, but if you wanted to do sunrise, it was like 3x the price. We did the shuttle to Moraine Lake at 7:15 am, so we got there just after sunrise, at 7:45. It was so cloudy that day that being there for sunrise wouldn’t have been worth it anyway.

Thursday, 9/19
- Peyto Lake (.8 miles total) - Got there at 1:30 pm, there were enough parking spots. Took less than 30 minutes total, including stopping for pics. Stay on the trail! The trees are incredible and smell amazing!! Absolutely stunning views. They have toilets with no running water in the parking lot.
- Bow Lake - Walked around a bit, didn’t really hike. We heard there’s a nice hike, which we would’ve done if we hadn’t started so late in the day!
- Mistaya Canyon (.7 miles total) - Took 20 minutes, pretty!!

Friday, 9/20
- Johnston Canyon to Upper Falls (3.4 miles total) - Got there at 8 am on a rainy and cold day, so there was plenty of parking. By the time we got down at 10:40, parking lot was full. Bathrooms with running water at the start. Because it was rainy and cold, the trail was almost empty. Very pretty! Took us a little over 2 hours, including stopping for lunch. We would’ve loved to do Ink Pots, but the toddler was cranky.
- Emerald Lake in Yoho National Park - Got there at noon and it was packed, had to park far away. Stroller-friendly boardwalk. Amazing views. Little cafe and bathrooms without running water. We were there for about 30 minutes, but there are plenty of trails if you choose to hike!
- Natural Bridge - Got there at 1 pm, found a parking spot. Bathrooms without running water. Quick stop, very cool.

Saturday, 9/21
- Tunnel Mountain Summit from Upper Parking Lot (2.6 miles total) - At 8:45 am, plenty of parking. Very cold—below freezing. Took us 50 minutes to get up with stops and pictures, spent 30 minutes at the top but it was just so cold. Took us less than 30 min to get down. The elevation gain was challenging.
- Two Jack Lake - Very pretty viewpoint! Go down the gravel path and look on either side for lovely views.
- Lake Minnewanka - Eh, skip it.
- Johnson Lake - Plenty of parking at 12:45 pm. Easy hike around the lake. Not worth it.

Sunday, 9/22
- Took Fairview Limousine Shuttle to Moraine Lake.
- Moraine Lake: Rockpile Trail (.8 km loop): Got to the lake at 7:45 and the shuttle left at 9 which was more than enough time. Quick walk up to take pics, hung out up there to pass the time until the bus came back.
- Lake Louise: Lake Agnes Tea House Trail (3.4 km one way): Lake Louise was STUNNING. Completely uphill hike to tea house with stairs at the end. We stopped a lot of times and drank a lot of water. Took 1:15 on the way up. Lake Agnes was fine, but nothing compared to Lake Louise. Spent about an hour at the tea house, the wait really wasn’t that long. Got tea, vegetable soup, biscuits, a cookie bar. Took an hour to get down. Much easier going down, but hard on the knees.

Monday, 9/23
- Hoodoos - Fine, pretty short. We followed the sign someone had written on and didn’t go past where the trail ended because there were. no views past it. If you don’t have time, this is fine to skip.
- Bow River - We stopped at the Bow Falls Viewpoint for a picnic lunch. It was so peaceful. We didn’t do the trails, but I’m sure it would’ve been lovely. Even just stopping there for lunch was so nice. Highly recommend!

Banff was incredible. Don’t pass it up!

The most beautiful place myself and family have been. Truly wonderful, peaceful, and a majestic testimony to God the creator. Canadian Rockies are so vast! Amazing colors to glacier-fed rivers and lakes. See actual glaciers as they descend from waterfalls to streams to lakes and to rivers.

Name: Port, Fortresses and Group of Monuments, Cartagena
short_description: Situated in a bay in the Caribbean Sea, Cartagena has the most extensive fortifications in South America. A system of zones divides the city into three neighbourhoods: San Pedro, with the cathedral and many Andalusian-style palaces; San Diego, where merchants and the middle class lived; and Gethsemani, the 'popular quarter'.

reviews.text: Me emcanto
Yes beautiful

Name: Salonga National Park
short_description: Salonga National Park is Africa's largest tropical rainforest reserve. Situated at the heart of the central basin of the Congo river, the park is very isolated and accessible only by water. It is the habitat of many endemic endangered species, such as the dwarf chimpanzee, the Congo peacock, the forest elephant and the African slender-snouted or 'false' crocodile.
formatted_address: 2222+235, Ikali, Democratic Republic of the Congo

reviews.text: Very dangerous snakes here.
Almost got attacked by a bird, but otherwise it was great!
It was very enjoyable
Good
Great

Name: Castles of Augustusburg and Falkenlust at Brühl
short_description: Set in an idyllic garden landscape, Augustusburg Castle (the sumptuous residence of the prince-archbishops of Cologne) and the Falkenlust hunting lodge (a small rural folly) are among the earliest examples of Rococo architecture in 18th-century Germany.

reviews.text:
Stunning historic castle. With guided tours in German and audio guides for non-German speakers to follow along with the guided tour. The tour lasted for an hour or so, covering all the main rooms and magnificent stairway.
The rooms don't have many of the original items of furniture, but this castle is all about the décor, which is fabulous.
Extensive formal gardens to enjoy with fountains and trees.
No wonder that the castle has been a UNESCO World Heritage site for 40 years. 😎👍👍👍👍👍

A beautiful palace with so many interesting and well maintained rooms and ornaments inside. A well organized guided tour for about 1 hour to explore the palace.
And after that we could take a walk looking a fancy garden.

Don't let the simpleness of the outside of the catsle trick you. The inside of it worth every penny and second. It was extremely pretty and well maintained. We were guided in German but at the cashier they did ask us which language we would like to listen to on the translator. Each room
has their own number which we can type in the translator and listen to the guide. Overall 10 out of 10. Btw the baroque garden of it is also really nice in my opinion

Beautiful. The staircase in this place is especially amazing, well a visit if you're in the area. There's a car park a couple of minutes walk away which accepts card payments, we had no problem finding a space on a midweek afternoon. It's worth noting that you're not allowed to walk around by yourself so try and arrive in time for one of the tours. Our tour guide spoke German but we were given an audio guide in English to listen to. The tour took about an hour, but I've knocked a star off my review because the guide seemed to mistime the tour and had to whizz us through the upstairs bedrooms etc, so much so that we couldn't listen to the audio guide info as he was moving from room to room so quickly. It was a shame to feel rushed at the end. Otherwise though, it was an impressive place to visit.

I was here for a Saturday strolling. When taking train 18, remember to take the one says Schwadorf; otherwise you have to leave your train and wait for the right 18 train.

It's a beautiful architecture as well known. The garden is very nice too. There're lots of weddings photo session outside the castle so you may have to go early to avoid the people in the background. I didn't walk all the way to Falkenlust because it's too far lol. The park was enough.

Name: Vatican City
short_description: The Vatican City, one of the most sacred places in Christendom, attests to a great history and a formidable spiritual venture. A unique collection of artistic and architectural masterpieces lie within the boundaries of this small state. At its centre is St Peter's Basilica, with its double colonnade and a circular piazza in front and bordered by palaces and gardens. The basilica, erected over the tomb of St Peter the Apostle, is the largest religious building in the world, the fruit of the combined genius of Bramante, Raphael, Michelangelo, Bernini and Maderno.

Name: Sun Temple, Konârak
short_description: On the shores of the Bay of Bengal, bathed in the rays of the rising sun, the temple at Konarak is a monumental representation of the sun god Surya's chariot; its 24 wheels are decorated with symbolic designs and it is led by a team of six horses. Built in the 13th century, it is one of India's most famous Brahman sanctuaries.

reviews.text:
Visiting the Konark Sun Temple on a weekday was an absolute delight. The absence of heavy crowds allowed me to truly soak in the grandeur of this architectural marvel. The temple, a UNESCO World Heritage site, stands as a testament to the brilliance of ancient Indian craftsmanship. Every intricate carving on the walls, from celestial dancers to mythical creatures, tells a story from centuries past.

The highlight of my visit was seeing the iconic stone chariot wheels, especially the one featured on the ₹10 note. Witnessing it in person felt surreal—it's not just a symbol of our heritage but also an engineering masterpiece. The precision with which these wheels are carved, aligning with sundial functionality, left me in awe.

The temple’s overall structure, dedicated to the Sun God, radiates an energy that is both mystical and inspiring. Though time has taken its toll, the remnants still showcase the genius of the builders. Walking through the ruins, I could imagine the temple in its full glory, standing as a beacon of devotion and artistry.

A must-visit place for history lovers, photographers, and anyone who appreciates heritage. Konark Sun Temple isn’t just a monument—it’s a journey through time

The Konark Sun Temple is a breathtaking UNESCO World Heritage Site and a true architectural marvel. The temple's chariot-shaped design, intricate carvings, and historical significance left me in awe. The detailed sculptures and stories etched into the stone are mesmerizing. The surrounding area is peaceful, and the museum adds more depth to the experience. It can get crowded, so visit early or late for a quieter time. A must-visit for anyone interested in history, culture, or spirituality!

Good historical place..visitor ticket is 40 rs. We had guide with us he gave detailed about this temple.beautiful architecture. No rush. carry cap/umbrella and water bottle  is recommended as temperature is higher

This is a world heritage site. Please remember this while visiting. There are certain spots where people are not allowed because of the unstable condition of the stones. Yet people climb them if they get the opportunity. Maintain cleanliness, don't litter and spit here and there. I saw many people doing it inside and around the premises. This place is breathtakingly beautiful with rich historical significance. Try to enrich yourself with the experience while maintaining civic sense.

I would like to recommend this place to each and every person. The history of this place is amazing. Every small detail of this place explains how strong our ancestors were. Physics was like a game for them and how thoughtfully and meaningfully each and every part of this place was constructed.
They made a sundial which shows the exact time.
Imagine if this temple was intact what would have happened? The view to the world would have been very much different.
I wonder how the site of a hanging sun god looks like. It's really very sad that we can't see that and till now no one in the world has dared to make such a temple.
If you are interested in history then don't forget to take a guide to know about this place better.

Name: Group of Monuments at Mahabalipuram
short_description: This group of sanctuaries, founded by the Pallava kings, was carved out of rock along the Coromandel coast in the 7th and 8th centuries. It is known especially for its rathas (temples in the form of chariots), mandapas (cave sanctuaries), giant open-air reliefs such as the famous 'Descent of the Ganges', and the temple of Rivage, with thousands of sculptures to the glory of Shiva.
formatted_address: Fisherman Colony, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

reviews.text:
Ancient temples that reflect the glory of erstwhile kingdoms, pristine beaches that emanate matchless natural beauty, rich cultural heritage that welcomes you
Mamallapuram (Mahabalipuram) is known for its 6th-century masterpieces of Pallava architecture. I recommend that anyone interested visit in the early morning to avoid the sun and crowds. First, visit the Shore Temple. I suggest walking to enjoy the place more interestingly. The Pancha Ratha complex requires an auto to visit. If you go to the top of the lighthouse, you will understand the significance of this place and how strategically important it was to the rulers, with water boundaries on all sides. In the evening, one can enjoy the beach.

A calm and peaceful place to spend some time there. Ticket prices are only 40 INR each. 600 INR if you're a foreigner. Every stone carries historical significance. Not a place to pray though but just to admire the historical architecture. Nice place to visit with family

Mahabalipuram Monuments are very old and full of history. The stone carvings are beautiful to see. It can be crowded, and some places need cleaning. The best time to visit is in the morning or evening when it is cooler.

Good for an early morning or late evening stroll. Work of developing the shore temple is in progress. Facility for drinking water and toilets have been provided for. Overall the space is to be watched out for post development.

The Group of Monuments at Mahabalipuram, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is one of India's most captivating historical and architectural treasures. Located on the Coromandel Coast of Tamil Nadu, it offers a fascinating glimpse into ancient Indian craftsmanship and religious art, especially from the Pallava dynasty.

Key Highlights:
Shore Temple: An iconic structure, the Shore Temple sits majestically by the sea, with intricate carvings and a serene atmosphere. The setting sun casts a beautiful golden light on the temple, enhancing its beauty.
Pancha Rathas (Five Rathas): These monolithic rock temples are shaped like chariots, with exquisite bas-relief carvings. Each ratha is dedicated to a different deity, and the unique architectural style makes them a must-see.
Arjuna’s Penance (Descent of the Ganges): A massive bas-relief sculpture that narrates the story of Arjuna's penance and the descent of the Ganges River. It’s one of the most impressive rock carvings in India, depicting gods, demons, and animals in intricate detail.
Cave Temples: The cave temples, including those dedicated to Vishnu and Shiva, are carved into the rock with sculptures and inscriptions that showcase ancient religious practices and art.
The Experience at 5:30 PM:
Visiting the Group of Monuments around 5:30 PM offers a wonderful opportunity to enjoy the scenery and the evening light. As the sun begins to set, the monuments take on a warm, golden hue, making the carvings and sculptures even more enchanting. The breeze from the nearby ocean adds a refreshing touch, and the lower evening light provides the perfect conditions for photography. The crowds tend to thin out as the day progresses, allowing for a more tranquil experience of the site.

The atmosphere during this time is ideal for soaking in the beauty and serenity of Mahabalipuram. The soft evening light and cooler temperatures create an unforgettable ambiance, especially as the monuments become silhouetted against the setting sun.

Tips for Visitors:
Timing: Arriving around 5:30 PM allows you to enjoy the monuments during the golden hour, which enhances the scenic beauty and the overall experience.
Photography: The evening light is perfect for photography, so be sure to bring a camera to capture the stunning architecture and landscapes.
Wear Comfortable Footwear: The site involves walking and exploring, so comfortable shoes are a must.
Sunset Views: Don’t miss the sunset by the Shore Temple, as it offers one of the best views at the site.
In conclusion, visiting the Group of Monuments at Mahabalipuram in the late afternoon, especially around 5:30 PM, provides a magical experience, combining the rich history and architectural marvels with the beauty of the evening light and the peaceful surroundings.

Name: Anjar
short_description: The city of Anjar was founded by Caliph Walid I at the beginning of the 8th century. The ruins reveal a very regular layout, reminiscent of the palace-cities of ancient times, and are a unique testimony to city planning under the Umayyads.

Name: Baalbek
short_description: This Phoenician city, where a triad of deities was worshipped, was known as Heliopolis during the Hellenistic period. It retained its religious function during Roman times, when the sanctuary of the Heliopolitan Jupiter attracted thousands of pilgrims. Baalbek, with its colossal structures, is one of the finest examples of Imperial Roman architecture at its apogee.

Name: Byblos
short_description: The ruins of many successive civilizations are found at Byblos, one of the oldest Phoenician cities. Inhabited since Neolithic times, it has been closely linked to the legends and history of the Mediterranean region for thousands of years. Byblos is also directly associated with the history and diffusion of the Phoenician alphabet.

Name: Tyre
short_description: According to legend, purple dye was invented in Tyre. This great Phoenician city ruled the seas and founded prosperous colonies such as Cadiz and Carthage, but its historical role declined at the end of the Crusades. There are important archaeological remains, mainly from Roman times.

Name: Lake Malawi National Park
short_description: Located at the southern end of the great expanse of Lake Malawi, with its deep, clear waters and mountain backdrop, the national park is home to many hundreds of fish species, nearly all endemic. Its importance for the study of evolution is comparable to that of the finches of the Galapagos Islands.

reviews.text: A little pice of heaven on earth.
Great boat ride experience. The eagles were awesome 👌 so were the cichlids.
Beautiful area definitely worth visiting. Can get quite busy and locals use the beach to wash, but it's a stunning part of the lake.

Lake Malawi National Park is a UNESCO World Heritage Site located in Mangochi, Malawi, Africa. It's known for its stunning freshwater lake, Lake Malawi, which is home to a diverse range of fish species, including colorful cichlids. The park offers opportunities for snorkeling, diving, and exploring the unique aquatic life. It's a beautiful destination for nature enthusiasts and those interested in biodiversity.
Fantasy interface with nature. Lake Malawi national park has the best species of fish.. Adding on top of the fact that you can catch and release the fishes makes it more fun.

Name: Chitwan National Park
short_description: At the foot of the Himalayas, Chitwan is one of the few remaining undisturbed vestiges of the 'Terai' region, which formerly extended over the foothills of India and Nepal. It has a particularly rich flora and fauna. One of the last populations of single-horned Asiatic rhinoceros lives in the park, which is also one of the last refuges of the Bengal tiger.

reviews.text:
Chitwan National Park is an incredible wildlife experience and a must-visit destination for nature lovers! 🐘🌳 The park offers an unforgettable safari experience where you can see wild elephants, rhinos, tigers, and a wide variety of bird species in their natural habitat. The lush greenery and diverse ecosystems make this park a true gem in Nepal’s natural beauty.

The jeep safari and canoe rides are well-organized and led by expert guides who provide fascinating insights into the park's rich flora and fauna. The thrill of spotting a one-horned rhinoceros up close or hearing the sounds of the jungle is something you will never forget. The nature walks also offer a peaceful way to explore the surroundings and connect with nature.

The park’s commitment to conservation and sustainable tourism is evident in the well-maintained facilities and the efforts made to protect the wildlife. It’s a perfect place for anyone wanting to experience Nepal’s natural side and engage with its vibrant wildlife.

Highly recommended for anyone interested in wildlife, nature, and adventure. If you’re in Nepal, a visit to Chitwan National Park is absolutely a must! 🦏🌿✨

We had an excellent morning at Chitwan National Park. We saw five rhinos, a heap of deer, lots of peacocks and wild boar. Sadly, no tiger but lots of tracks. Would highly recommend - this was my highlight of Nepal.

This national park is an absolute thrill and a must-visit, especially during your first or second day! The excitement of witnessing those magnificent animals up close is an experience like no other.

During the tour, we soaked up fascinating insights from our knowledgeable tour guide, making this adventure even more unforgettable. Don’t miss out on this fantastic opportunity!

This was our second family visit to Chitwan National Park, and it was an incredible experience! We were lucky enough to spot a tiger, along with many rhinos and even a wild elephant. The jungle walk was another highlight that we truly enjoyed. A trip to remember!

Chitwan National Park is a haven for wildlife enthusiasts and bird lovers. During my visit, I was amazed by the diversity of bird species, including elegant peacocks, vibrant wild ducks, various types of storks, and colorful kingfishers. The park’s rich ecosystem also offered thrilling sightings of crocodiles basking along the riverbanks and a majestic rhinoceros in its natural habitat.

One of the highlights was the canoe ride along the tranquil Ladhari River—a perfectly silent journey where we simply went with the flow, fully immersed in the beauty of the surroundings. The serene environment and well-preserved wilderness make Chitwan National Park a must-visit destination for anyone seeking a close encounter with nature’s wonders. An unforgettable experience!

Name: Historic Centre of Cordoba
short_description: Cordoba's period of greatest glory began in the 8th century after the Moorish conquest, when some 300 mosques and innumerable palaces and public buildings were built to rival the splendours of Constantinople, Damascus and Baghdad. In the 13th century, under Ferdinand III, the Saint, Cordoba's Great Mosque was turned into a cathedral and new defensive structures, particularly the Alcázar de los Reyes Cristianos and the Torre Fortaleza de la Calahorra, were erected.
formatted_address: C. Cardenal Herrero, º 1, Centro, 14003 Córdoba, Spain

reviews.text: The Mosque of Córdoba is a breathtaking masterpiece of Islamic architecture and a must-visit historical site. The stunning horseshoe arches, intricate red and white columns, and beautifully detailed mihrab create a mesmerizing atmosphere. The blend of Moorish and Christian influences makes it unique, reflecting centuries of history and cultural fusion. Walking through its vast halls feels like stepping back in time, and the peaceful ambiance adds to its charm. A visit to Córdoba is incomplete without experiencing this architectural wonder!

Incredible place. It's truly jaw-dropping.
A definite must see if visiting Cordoba.
€13 entrance fee.
I went yesterday, so it was out of season, so no queues.
I think in season you'd be better buying in advance.
It's a vast beautiful place, front floor to ceiling. It's an architectural marvel.
You have to see it for yourself.

The Mosque-Cathedral of Córdoba is a historic landmark in Spain, originally built as a mosque in 785 AD during Islamic rule. After the Christian Reconquista in 1236, it was converted into a cathedral. It features stunning red-and-white arches, an intricate mihrab, and a later Christian nave added inside. The mix of Islamic and Christian architecture makes it one of the most unique buildings in the world. Mosque-Cathedral of Córdoba. However, entry is free from 8:30 AM to 9:30 AM (Monday to Saturday) for silent visits (without guided tours).

Ticket Prices (Approximate)
•	General entry: €13
•	Seniors (65+) and students: €10
•	Children (10-14 years): €7
•	Children under 10: Free

The Mosque-Cathedral of Córdoba has accessible areas for visitors with disabilities, but some parts may be challenging due to the historic structure.

I came to Córdoba wanted to visit this UNESCO heritage site, coming here felt like stepping back in time. It began as a grand mosque built during Córdoba’s golden age under Islamic rule. Later, it was transformed into a cathedral when Christians took over the city.
When step inside, I was immediately greeted with a vast hall filled with hundreds of columns and arches in red and white stripes. Walking through them would lead to the center, find a stunning cathedral built later, with high ceilings and intricate designs, blending beautifully with the older Islamic architecture.
Outside is a peaceful courtyard filled with numerous orange trees and the sound of water from fountains. It’s a perfect place to pause and breathe in the surreal atmosphere.
Visiting the Mosque-Cathedral isn’t just about seeing a monumental building—it’s about feeling the history of a place where different cultures and religions came together.

Extraordinary place where Moorish architecture meets and mingles with catholic cathedrals. We went in February and booked tickets and it was quite busy. Drove to the venue from Torremolinos which was a lovely drive through the mountains. (About an hour and a half).

Name: Alhambra, Generalife and Albayzín, Granada
short_description: Rising above the modern lower town, the Alhambra and the Albaycín, situated on two adjacent hills, form the medieval part of Granada. To the east of the Alhambra fortress and residence are the magnificent gardens of the Generalife, the former rural residence of the emirs who ruled this part of Spain in the 13th and 14th centuries. The residential district of the Albaycín is a rich repository of Moorish vernacular architecture, into which the traditional Andalusian architecture blends harmoniously.
formatted_address: C. Real de la Alhambra, s/n, Centro, 18009 Granada, Spain

reviews.text: Walking up to the fortress taking some strength as it is quite the angle. We met our tour guide and walk through out. Plenty of walking, so make sure you have comfortable shoes. There’s lots to see the old Islamic carvings to the new sections were able to walk through. Most of. It was pretty busy, but not overly crowded.

Magnificent.

You need at least 5 hours to explore this place. I recommend you to bring your own snacks or drinks like bread, mineral water. Because the cafes are too far away from the palace. Also there is no halal food options in the cafes inside Alhambra.
There is also no prayer room so choose your visit time wisely.

They check for passport/ID. Bring comfortable shoes, a lot of walking and stairs. It gets very crowded. The towers of the castle is impressive, it allows great views of the city. The extensive garden is well maintained. Museum exhibits are small.

Amazing experience. The place is espectacular. Full of incredible views and buildings. The staff is very friendly and give us very good advices. Do not hesitate to ask them. Be aware that it is  necessary to buy tickets at least one month in advance, and it is mandatory to have your passport to enter if you are a foreign. We went to all the buildings in 3 hours.

It’s an amazing experience as our tour guide Mr. Cristian told us and by the way he is the best many thanks for your great tour.
Just please remember that You have to have your physical Passport/ Driven license and Your ticket very very important, and the tour minimum three hours and believe me it’s not enough. Because the palace is full of history, wonders, and beyond imagination buildings all of them are peace of art time fly fast because of the charms of the place.
You have to visit it totally recommend and city of Granada too it’s amazing place You will love it.

Name: Burgos Cathedral
short_description: Our Lady of Burgos was begun in the 13th century at the same time as the great cathedrals of the Ile-de-France and was completed in the 15th and 16th centuries. The entire history of Gothic art is summed up in its superb architecture and its unique collection of works of art, including paintings, choir stalls, reredos, tombs and stained-glass windows.
formatted_address: Pl. Sta. María, s/n, 09003 Burgos, Spain

reviews.text: Very beautiful cathedral with Gothic architecture and baroque style within multiple chapels. The audio guide was very well done and easy to follow with all the signs and directions. Highly recommend to visit

The best cathedral that I’ve seen in my life!! It’s really stunning and full of beautiful pieces of art. What to say about the Da Vinci drawing….a surprise for me.
I didn’t give 5 stars because there are two main chapels closed to visitors and that was a bummer! Also, my phone was out of battery so I couldn’t enjoy the online guide.

Amazing place with white storks nesting on the roof.
Lovely place to sit and have a coffee while soaking up the atmosphere and Spanish sunshine.

Burgos Cathedral is a stunning museum with exceptionally well-preserved historical artifacts, offering a glimpse into the past. Walking through its halls feels like stepping into a time machine, transporting to the 13th-16th centuries. For me, one of the finest cathedrals of its kind, showcasing Gothic architecture at its peak.

Outside WOW, inside WOW, if you look for a historic monument within beautiful place and amazing surroundings you just found it.

No doubt it’s one one the most beautiful cathedral which I saw. Its color its finish and its interior is state of art which can’t be ignored.
You need to see it!

Name: Monastery and Site of the Escurial, Madrid
short_description: Built at the end of the 16th century on a plan in the form of a grill, the instrument of the martyrdom of St Lawrence, the Escurial Monastery stands in an exceptionally beautiful site in Castile. Its austere architecture, a break with previous styles, had a considerable influence on Spanish architecture for more than half a century. It was the retreat of a mystic king and became, in the last years of Philip II's reign, the centre of the greatest political power of the time.
formatted_address: Av Juan de Borbón y Battemberg, s/n, 28200 San Lorenzo de El Escorial, Madrid, Spain

reviews.text:
We planned our visit to the Real Sitio de San Lorenzo de El Escorial from Madrid. The journey by bus was easy, quick, and affordable – definitely a great option. We had booked our tickets online, so we could go straight to the entrance. During the check-in, our bags were scanned, but unfortunately, we were only told later, in the middle of one of the historical rooms, that we should have left our backpacks in the lockers. It would have been helpful to be informed about this when our bags were first checked. If so, it wouldn't have been an issue, and we would have left them immediately since we didn’t need them.

The palace and monastery complex is a must for history enthusiasts! You can truly feel the history of Spain, whether under the Habsburgs or the Bourbons. The Royal Library and the Cathedral were especially impressive – real highlights.

What stood out most to us, however, was the constant presence of Saint Lawrence. Everywhere in the complex, we could find his martyrdom attribute – particularly the grill on which he was executed. It was fascinating how deeply this symbolism was embedded in the architecture and artwork. In the galleries, on sculptures, and in various rooms, we encountered images of the saint in many forms, and each time, his suffering and devotion were palpable. This unique symbolic presence gave the entire place a profound spiritual meaning.

Another unforgettable experience was visiting the royal tombs of the Spanish kings. We visited the graves with reverence, trying to find well-known figures, such as Don Carlos (the son of King Philip II, known from Friedrich Schiller’s work). Unfortunately, we couldn’t find him, and even after asking, no one was able to help us. In the Pantheon of the Kings, there were many visitors, and although photography wasn’t allowed, the sight of the tombs was truly impressive. It was also interesting to note that the pantheon is completely filled – we wondered where later kings like Juan Carlos I and Felipe VI, with their queens, would be laid to rest.

Finally, we visited the palace garden. A word of caution: the path through the garden is a one-way street, and you must walk back the same way to reach the exit. It can be a bit confusing for some visitors.

All in all, it was a wonderful trip, and we are grateful to have been able to experience Spain’s history so closely. The deep symbolic presence of Saint Lawrence and the visit to the royal tombs made this journey an unforgettable experience.

A very wet visit so unable to view gardens ( Sorry Alan T). The interior self guided tour is very full on . Monastery and Palace. A must visit if you have an interest in Spanish history or the Renaissance period.

Exceeded my expectations. When you think you’ve seen all hidden gems of this place you turn a corner and there is MORE incredible art/ history. With that said, highly recommend at minimum an audio guide if not joining a guided tour. And given yourself a significant amount of time, it took us three hours to do the two hour self guided audio tour. We were tired by the end but it was such a beautiful space and experience.

The monastery is interesting, but mostly from the outside. The gardens are very beautiful, but they can be accessed for free. The inside of the monastery is a bit disappointing, mainly painting on the walls, old chairs and old carpets.
Beautiful monastery, with so much to see, give yourself plenty of time. Wonderful selection of paintings. Amazing to see the pantheon!

Name: Works of Antoni Gaudí
short_description: Seven properties built by the architect Antoni Gaudí (1852–1926) in or near Barcelona testify to Gaudí’s exceptional creative contribution to the development of architecture and building technology in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. These monuments represent an eclectic, as well as a very personal, style which was given free reign in the design of gardens, sculpture and all decorative arts, as well as architecture. The seven buildings are: Parque Güell; Palacio Güell; Casa Mila; Casa Vicens; Gaudí’s work on the Nativity façade and Crypt of La Sagrada Familia; Casa Batlló; Crypt in Colonia Güell.
formatted_address: Carrer de Larrard, 41, Gràcia, 08024 Barcelona, Spain

reviews.text: Nice educational 4D movie for all ages that helps you understand Gaudi’s inspirations and works. We were only 6 people in the movie room. I am sure there would be more people if the price would be lower. Interactive walls were not well communicated as well. It is also a nice concept store with screens and miniatures. Again, more people would enter the store for shopping if the movie price is better positioned and mentioned outside the starting times with an LED screen.

It was ok. Loved the lizard 😁 It was interesting to see where Gaudi got his ideas from and how those extraordinary buildings were planned on paper.
However, I think there could be more information about 'the' buildings, especially, the Sagrada de Familia! As it is constantly being built and it would be nice to see what is waiting for us, presumably, in the near future.

The gift shop has some nice stuff, including a scaled model of Parc Guell. Don’t waste your money on the 4-D experience though. My glasses didn’t work and it was more of an animated/CGI recreated experience versus an educational documentary type experience.

Fantastic experience, went there with my nephews and they were so blown by the show.
The 4D and the moving seats are a game changer, also the place worked are super friendly and welcoming.
Also, the shop is super interesting with many surprises.
definitely recommend it.

waste of time and money....
At your presentation, I was expecting an experience that would be both educational and rich in content, especially considering the importance and brilliance of an architect like Gaudí.

Unfortunately, I found the presentation confusing, lacking a clear storyline, and providing very little information about Gaudí’s life, work, or influence. In my opinion, the content is quite limited and does not meet the level of expectation visitors would have for an attraction of this kind.

For comparison, a similar presentation I attended in Vienna offered a deeper understanding of the subject and a much richer experience for the audience. Therefore, I felt that your presentation, in comparison, did not meet those standards.

That said, I do believe there is room for improvement. I would be delighted if you considered adding more content to present Gaudí’s legacy in a more structured and educational way.

Name: Statue of Liberty
short_description: Made in Paris by the French sculptor Bartholdi, in collaboration with Gustave Eiffel (who was responsible for the steel framework), this towering monument to liberty was a gift from France on the centenary of American independence. Inaugurated in 1886, the sculpture stands at the entrance to New York Harbour and has welcomed millions of immigrants to the United States ever since.

reviews.text: Visiting the Statue of Liberty for a second time, now with my wife and children, was truly a memorable experience. Having first seen it in 2000, it was fascinating to witness how the statue continues to inspire awe. The sheer scale and historical significance are undeniable. The ferry ride to Liberty Island offers breathtaking views of the New York skyline, and standing at the base of Lady Liberty is a powerful reminder of freedom and opportunity. The kids were captivated, and it was wonderful to share such an iconic landmark with them. The organization and accessibility of the site have improved significantly since my first visit, making it a smoother and more enjoyable experience for families. A must-see for anyone visiting New York!

Visiting the Statue of Liberty in New York was an unforgettable experience, made even more special by the fact that I had just graduated. Taking the ferry from Battery Park, we enjoyed stunning views of the Manhattan skyline as we made our way to Liberty Island. The ride itself was smooth and enjoyable, with plenty of opportunities to take photos of the city and the iconic statue from a distance.

Once we arrived, standing in front of the Statue of Liberty was truly awe-inspiring. The sheer size and historical significance of the monument made the moment feel even more meaningful. As a recent graduate, I couldn’t resist capturing the occasion by taking a picture in my toga with Lady Liberty in the background—it felt like the perfect symbol of new beginnings and endless opportunities.

Exploring the island, we learned about the history of the statue and its role as a beacon of freedom and hope. The museum provided fascinating insights into its construction and significance. Climbing to the pedestal offered breathtaking views of the city and harbor.

Overall, visiting the Statue of Liberty was a once-in-a-lifetime experience. The combination of history, symbolism, and personal achievement made it a moment I will cherish forever.

An unmissable experience at New York's most iconic landmark! I purchased the tour through CityPASS, and the booking process was simple and convenient. The ferry departure point, located near the South Ferry subway station, is easily accessible, making the trip even more seamless.

Upon arriving at Liberty Island, I was welcomed by a historic and captivating atmosphere. The Statue of Liberty Museum offers a fascinating insight into the history of this iconic monument, while the gift shop provides great souvenirs to remember the visit. For an even more complete experience, there is an option to purchase an additional ticket to access the statue's interior and enjoy the view from a privileged perspective.

Without a doubt, a must-do tour for anyone visiting New York!

Visiting the Statue of Liberty filled me with so much joy! The ferry ride offered us the most stunning views of the New York City skyline, and seeing the statue up close was simply awe-inspiring. The grounds were impeccably maintained, and the exhibits were truly fascinating, enriching our understanding of the statue's history and significance. Ascending to the pedestal was a surreal experience, providing us with breathtaking panoramic views, and the museum was incredibly engaging with its detailed information on the statue's construction and its significance to immigrants. Overall, it was a profoundly moving journey through history, and I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone exploring New York City for its fantastic blend of culture, history, and picturesque landscapes.

We had an amazing time exploring the Statue of Liberty with family and friends! The experience was unforgettable, and it was a fantastic way to learn more about this iconic American landmark. We were fortunate enough to go up into the pedestal for a better view, which I highly recommend—though I’ll admit, the climb is quite the workout, so definitely take the elevator if you can! The panoramic views from the pedestal are absolutely worth it, offering a stunning perspective of both the statue and the surrounding New York Harbor.

The museum was also incredibly informative, offering rich historical context and interactive exhibits that brought the story of the Statue of Liberty to life. We were especially impressed by the knowledge and friendliness of the National Park System staff, who were eager to share insights and answer questions, making the visit even more engaging.

A fun added bonus was becoming Jr. Rangers, which was a great way to involve the kids and even adults in the experience. We also had a blast collecting stamps for our National Park Book—it's always a fun way to remember our visits!

I can’t wait to bring more family and friends here the next time I visit! The Statue of Liberty is truly a must-see, and this trip was a memorable and educational experience for everyone.

Name: Yosemite National Park
short_description: Yosemite National Park lies in the heart of California. With its 'hanging' valleys, many waterfalls, cirque lakes, polished domes, moraines and U-shaped valleys, it provides an excellent overview of all kinds of granite relief fashioned by glaciation. At 600–4,000 m, a great variety of flora and fauna can also be found here.

reviews.text:
This national park is GORGEOUS! The drive up to the park along the roads hugging cliff edges is a little scary if you're not fond of heights, but the park is totally worth the stressful drive.

It's like being transported into a different world when you're in Yosemite park. The scale of the trees and rocks and cliffs leave you feeling very small and the views are awe-inspiring! There are so many trails and the park is so vast, you'd definitely need at least several days to explore it all. I'd recommend planning out which trails and areas you'd like to explore ahead of time. There were restrooms available in rest areas or sometimes at the parking lots at the start of a trail - just note where they're at on the maps if you'd like to use a toilet before getting caught in the woods without one. Take a lot of water with you and stay hydrated, it was so hot out during the days we visited and depending on the area of the park you're in, we didn't see a lot of water refill areas. Definitely refill your bottles when you find a refill spot at a rest/lodging area.

Paved areas where cars would drive and some viewpoints we saw were wheelchair accessible, but getting a parking spot near a viewpoint can be difficult/a bit of a wait depending on the time of day. A lot of dirt/grass trails in the woods we walked could be quite rocky and were not wheelchair accessible, so this would definitely be something to check ahead of time for specific areas you'd like to visit if accessibility is a concern.

Visiting this park was an amazing experience and I'll definitely be going again!

The site, with its breathtaking landscape and awe-inspiring views, was nothing short of extraordinary. No photograph can truly capture the sheer beauty of this place. From the vibrant colors of the surroundings to the majestic vistas that stretch as far as the eye can see, every aspect of this destination left me utterly spellbound. It’s a wonder that lingers long after you leave, resonating deeply in your memory.

Yosemite National Park is absolutely breathtaking! The towering granite cliffs, stunning waterfalls, and endless scenic views make it one of the most incredible places I’ve ever visited. Whether you’re hiking to Glacier Point, standing in awe at El Capitan, or enjoying the peaceful beauty of Mirror Lake, every corner of the park feels magical. The air is fresh, the wildlife is abundant, and the energy of nature is truly revitalizing. It’s a must-visit destination for anyone who loves adventure, stunning landscapes, and reconnecting with nature!

As they say.. it’s all about the journey not the destination. The trip to Yosemite was nothing but a trip to remember. We drove from Santa Clara on a fine sunny morning. As we started approaching the Yosemite park, the serene landscape, the zigzag road, mountain, forest and beautiful sky, a seer pleasure of being in the moment.

Always beautiful, amazing experiences. I love going to Sentinel Dome during the summer time, the sun sets and moon is beautiful. The most beautiful part about it all is that every time you go on a hike it’s never the same, the weather changes how the world looks completely. Whether it’s hailing, raining, windy, snowing… always a new and memorable experience. I am so blessed to live so close to something like this.

Name: Mana Pools National Park, Sapi and Chewore Safari Areas
short_description: On the banks of the Zambezi, great cliffs overhang the river and the floodplains. The area is home to a remarkable concentration of wild animals, including elephants, buffalo, leopards and cheetahs. An important concentration of Nile crocodiles is also be found in the area.

reviews.text:
Mana pools was absolutely incredible and breathtaking, the remoteness and abundance of wildlife make it a top destination for campers and animal lovers.

Unfortunately a lot can be done to the campsites to make them more user friendly and hygienic. Ablution facilities are not good and not maintained. The price you pay for camping is not justifiable with what you get.

Otherwise the experience was a once in a lifetime.

Unique outstanding vegetation of large mahogany, baobab, and fig trees provide undisturbed nesting and habitation of different kinds of birds. Nature walking, fishing and canoeing are activities to look forward to at Mana Pools

You will understand why people talk about Mana Magic once you have been there. Really wild wilderness at its best. Stunning landscapes and endless photographic opportunities. The massive tree canopy with the game under it and the well known elephants standing on their hind legs to reach the highest branches makes for an unforgettable holiday. You can walk with the animals if you paid for that permit. You camp in between all the animals. Be careful and take it serious as it is not for sissies or chancetakers. Appreciate the wilderness and keep your distance.

📍Mana Pools National Park, Zimbabwe🇿🇼

Mana Pools National Park is one of Zimbabwe's most stunning and remote game reserves, located along the Zambezi River in the northern part of the country. The park is renowned for its beautiful landscapes, including vast floodplains, dense forests, and an array of wildlife. It’s also a UNESCO World Heritage Site, famous for its wild, untamed atmosphere and great biodiversity.

What makes Mana Pools special is the opportunity for close, on-foot interactions with wildlife, something not easily found in other African parks. Visitors can take guided walking safaris where they might encounter elephants, lions, buffaloes, and a host of other animals in their natural habitat. The park is also known for its incredible birdwatching opportunities, with over 350 species recorded.

This park is a UNESCO heritage site located close to Zambian border. We enjoyed seeing various birds and animals: lions, elephants, hyppos, watrhogs, several species of antelopes, etc. Safari was perfectly ogranised by Kanga camp.

Name: Historic Mosque City of Bagerhat
short_description: Situated in the suburbs of Bagerhat, at the meeting-point of the Ganges and Brahmaputra rivers, this ancient city, formerly known as Khalifatabad, was founded by the Turkish general Ulugh Khan Jahan in the 15th century. The city’s infrastructure reveals considerable technical skill and an exceptional number of mosques and early Islamic monuments, many built of brick, can be seen there.
formatted_address: MQ79+W86, Old Rupsa Bagerhat Rd, Bagerhat, Bangladesh

reviews.text: If you are not so interested you can escape it.

It's another name is 10 Dome Masjid(দশ গম্বুজ মসজিদ)

The Masjid is historic, although the renovation in the interiors made it lose its originality.
Nice
It's really amazing and remember us about our historical place
Quiet and calm place. Attended to a Dua mahfil.

Name: Ruins of the Buddhist Vihara at Paharpur
short_description: Evidence of the rise of Mahayana Buddhism in Bengal from the 7th century onwards, Somapura Mahavira, or the Great Monastery, was a renowned intellectual centre until the 12th century. Its layout perfectly adapted to its religious function, this monastery-city represents a unique artistic achievement. With its simple, harmonious lines and its profusion of carved decoration, it influenced Buddhist architecture as far away as Cambodia.

reviews.text:
Somapura Mahavihara, located in Paharpur, Naogaon, is one of the most significant archaeological sites in Bangladesh. It was built in the late 8th century during the reign of Dharmapala, the second ruler of the Pala Dynasty. Recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, this ancient Buddhist monastery was once a major center for learning, attracting scholars from all over South Asia.

How to Reach Somapura Mahavihara

1. From Naogaon Baludanga Bus Stand:

Take a direct CNG (auto-rickshaw) to Paharpur Bazar.

Alternatively, take a bus to Badalgachi and then a CNG or auto-rickshaw to Paharpur.

From Paharpur Bazar, an auto-rickshaw will take you to the historical site.

Attractions & Facilities

Historical Significance

Somapura Mahavihara was one of the largest Buddhist monasteries in ancient Bengal, covering 27 acres. The main temple stands in the center, surrounded by 177 rooms for monks. The architecture reflects the influence of Buddhist, Hindu, and Jain cultures.

Flower Gardens & Picnic Spots

The site is beautifully maintained with flower gardens, adding to its charm. There are designated picnic spots where visitors can relax and enjoy the surroundings.

Rules & Restrictions

Climbing the main temple is strictly forbidden by the authorities to protect the structure.

Visitors should respect the site and its historical importance.

Food & Dining

You can find affordable food options at the local shops near the site or at Paharpur Bazar, which offer traditional Bengali meals at reasonable prices.

Responsible Tourism

Visitors must keep the site clean by avoiding littering. Do not throw plastic or waste within the premises. Help preserve this remarkable piece of history for future generations.

Sompur Buddhist Vihara, located in the heart of Bangladesh, stands as a remarkable testament to the region's rich Buddhist heritage. Dating back to the 8th century, this ancient monastic complex is one of the largest and most significant of its kind in the country. Its impressive architecture features intricate terracotta carvings and a grand central stupa that reflects the artistry and devotion of its creators. Surrounded by lush greenery, the vihara exudes a sense of peace and spirituality, making it a serene retreat for visitors and pilgrims alike. The site not only serves as a historical landmark but also as a vital reminder of the flourishing Buddhist culture that once thrived in this area. Exploring Sompur Buddhist Vihara offers a unique glimpse into the past, inviting reflection on the rich tapestry of traditions that have shaped the region's identity.

Sompur Mahavihar or Paharpur Buddhist Monastery is an archaeological site. The place is very beautiful, a grandeur filled with antiquity. King Dharmapala, the second king of the Pala dynasty, built it around 770-810 AD. Many Chinese and Tibetan monks received their education here. If you want to witness a historical place, this is the best option. Happy Touring
N.B: Avoid visiting on sunday, because in this day the museum of this place remain off.

Sompur Mahavihara is a remarkable historical and archaeological site in Bangladesh! 🏛️✨ As one of the most significant Buddhist monasteries in South Asia, it offers a fascinating glimpse into ancient architecture, culture, and history. The massive brick structure, intricate terracotta designs, and peaceful surroundings make it a must-visit for history lovers.

However, better maintenance and improved facilities for visitors could enhance the experience. 🚶‍♂️🌿 Despite that, it's an incredible place to explore and learn about Bangladesh’s rich heritage. Definitely worth a visit! 📸👏

Let me know if you’d like any changes! 😊

Somapura Mahavihara, also known as Paharpur Boddho Bihar, is one of the most important archaeological and historical sites in Bangladesh. Located in the Naogaon district, this ancient Buddhist monastery was built in the late 8th or early 9th century during the Pala dynasty. It is one of the largest Buddhist viharas in the Indian subcontinent and a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1985.

The site reflects the architectural grandeur of early Buddhist art and culture. The central structure is a massive quadrangular complex with a large stupa in the middle, which once served as the focal point for religious activities. Around it are numerous smaller stupas, shrines, and monastic cells that housed monks. The intricate terracotta plaques adorning the walls depict scenes from daily life, mythology, and religious stories.

Somapura Mahavihara was not just a religious center but also a hub of learning, attracting scholars from different regions of Asia. Its influence spread across Southeast Asia, evidenced by similar architectural styles in countries like Myanmar and Indonesia. Despite its partial ruin today, Paharpur stands as a testament to Bangladesh's rich cultural and religious heritage, offering a glimpse into the flourishing Buddhist civilization of the past.

Name: Royal Palaces of Abomey
short_description: From 1625 to 1900, 12 kings succeeded one another at the head of the powerful Kingdom of Abomey. With the exception of King Akaba, who had his own separate enclosure, they all had their palaces built within the same cob-wall area, in keeping with previous palaces as regards the use of space and materials. The royal palaces of Abomey are a unique reminder of this vanished kingdom.

Name: Historic Centre of Salvador de Bahia
short_description: As the first capital of Brazil, from 1549 to 1763, Salvador de Bahia witnessed the blending of European, African and Amerindian cultures. It was also, from 1558, the first slave market in the New World, with slaves arriving to work on the sugar plantations. The city has managed to preserve many outstanding Renaissance buildings. A special feature of the old town are the brightly coloured houses, often decorated with fine stucco-work.

reviews.text: The historical city center is the highlight of Salvador. Grab a drink or acai bowl and just hang out to the music flowing through the streets all day and night. It's a vibe like no other. Uplifting and community centric. Just fyi - for security don't wander too far away from the main tourist center.

It is a very beautiful and picturesque place. There are plenty of shops with handcrafted souvenirs, such as bracelets, necklaces, hats, paintings, musical instruments, and more. You can also find many restaurants and cafes here, where traditional dishes are served. This is also the place where various parades with live music, dancing, and acrobatics take place.

Amazing place, this is the centre of Salvador. Rich of story, culture and colors! The main square is the one with the fountain in the middle but there is another one with a lot of stands where you can find local food, clothes, souvenirs and so on!
Beautiful space, I was here on Independence Day so there were many people and live music. Good selection of restaurants as well
The historic center is well maintained and policed. It's worth spending a few hours appreciating its architecture.

Name: Sanctuary of Bom Jesus do Congonhas
short_description: This sanctuary in Minais Gerais, south of Belo Horizonte was built in the second half of the 18th century. It consists of a church with a magnificent Rococo interior of Italian inspiration; an outdoor stairway decorated with statues of the prophets; and seven chapels illustrating the Stations of the Cross, in which the polychrome sculptures by Aleijadinho are masterpieces of a highly original, moving, expressive form of Baroque art.
formatted_address: Praça do Santuário, S/n - Centro, Congonhas - MG, 36415-000, Brazil

reviews.text:
Here is the world heritage was registered in 1985.
If you transfer between Belo Horizonte and Ouro Preto, you can stop here easily.
There are beautiful sculptures made by Aleijadinho.
Inside church is also beautiful space.
There is a vivid altar.
We went there on Friday afternoon, there were few people.
It was calm and silent place to feel Baroque art.

#sundayspecial in the city of the trump of the baroque @congonhas_mg, and spending my time at the @congonhas_interior, which retains the famous temple of buildings, the Passos da Paixão de Cristo, given the recognition of talent and brilliance of the artwork Aleijadinho. Awesome experience trough the historical cities of @minasgerais_br, highly recommend this place...🙏🙏🙏
Beautiful place! Historical, well mantained and with an amazing view.

This sanctuary in Minais Gerais, south of Belo Horizonte was built in the second half of the 18th century. It consists of a church with a magnificent Rococo interior of Italian inspiration; an outdoor stairway decorated with statues of the prophets; and seven chapels illustrating the Stations of the Cross, in which the polychrome sculptures by Aleijadinho are masterpieces of a highly original, moving, expressive form of Baroque art.
Amazing santuary so many wonderful paintings and sculptures about Christians. You could stay there for hours, seeing each detail...

Name: Thracian Tomb of Sveshtari
short_description: Discovered in 1982 near the village of Sveshtari, this 3rd-century BC Thracian tomb reflects the fundamental structural principles of Thracian cult buildings. The tomb has a unique architectural decor, with polychrome half-human, half-plant caryatids and painted murals. The 10 female figures carved in high relief on the walls of the central chamber and the decoration of the lunette in its vault are the only examples of this type found so far in the Thracian lands. It is a remarkable reminder of the culture of the Getes, a Thracian people who were in contact with the Hellenistic and Hyperborean worlds, according to ancient geographers.

reviews.text: I knew about the place in advance, but it was a nice surprise to find everything very well organised and carefully maintained - from the shop to the information centre to the clean rest room! The actual visit to the tomb, led by a highly professional guide, was an unforgettable experience! I would recommend the place to everybody interested in history and archaeology and ancient civilisations. Even without this specific interests the Tomb modern exposition would turn you into an adventurer and explorer of the ancient history of the Bulgarian lands! The design of the museum complex  was on par with the recognition UNESCO gave to the discovery by including it into the list of world heritage sites.

If there is one site to visit in Bulgaria, this is it! Absolutely unique monument of the ancient Thracian culture, that has no parallels all across Europe. Modern visitors center offering lots of information about the place in both Bulgarian and English. Note that they accept only cash payments for the entrance fee.

This place blew me away! Got a private English tour and the lady was lovely and knowledgeable.
Everything is in great condition- and to walk into and around such a grave/tomb- it was a bit surreal.
Never expected such a gem in the middle of nowhere and in a country that normally doesn’t take too much care of its historical assets.

It was fantastic experience . The guide answered all of our questions. The tomb and the whole atmosphere around is really low key epic. It is just so serene outside of tomb it feels like u will join the funeral procession in any moment. Yeah really good atmosphere in rural northeast Bulgaria. Tomb is really preserved u can see the paint that is spectacularly saturated . Really impressed. I hope they find other stuff near the whole region

Very interesting place that i visited. It was really old an very well preserved. It is Beautiful Tomb and the restoration takes more than 30 years  if I am right. Intetionaly I am not posting photos from the inside. So I recommend you visit it an enjoy the ride 😇✌️🙂

Name: Historic District of Old Québec
short_description: Québec was founded by the French explorer Champlain in the early 17th century. It is the only North American city to have preserved its ramparts, together with the numerous bastions, gates and defensive works which still surround Old Québec. The Upper Town, built on the cliff, has remained the religious and administrative centre, with its churches, convents and other monuments like the Dauphine Redoubt, the Citadel and Château Frontenac. Together with the Lower Town and its ancient districts, it forms an urban ensemble which is one of the best examples of a fortified colonial city.
formatted_address: Old Quebec, Québec City, QC G1R 3X2, Canada

reviews.text:
What an incredible city!!
So much to do and so much to see.
The historic value is unimaginable!
An absolute Must see in any and all seasons.
It’s my 4th visit and it definitely isn’t my last visit.
I highly recommended for everyone to visit at some point in their lives!!

Quebec is one of my favorite cities in Canada because of its cozy streets, charming stores and unique atmosphere. Walking through the old town is like traveling through time, with its historic architecture and cobblestone streets.

Local cafes and restaurants offer delicious food, and the stores are full of unique souvenirs and handicrafts by local artisans. I especially love visiting Quebec in the fall.
I recommend it to anyone who wants to enjoy the beauty and culture of this amazing city!

I have visited Quebec City in summer, fall, and winter and have thoroughly enjoyed it in each season (though winter is a bit cold). Old Quebec is such a beautiful area to walk around. My wife thoroughly enjoyed it. I liked walking around with my father on another trip. I hope to bring my child there one day. It is really beautiful

It is a place that you should not miss visiting. The restaurants, the shops and what I had the most fun with was the slide, as a very good experience. You should prepare yourself because it is quite cold to wait to be able to go up the slide.

Five Stars aren’t enough!
