Visiting Old Quebec City is like stepping into a fairy tale. The cobblestone streets, charming architecture, and rich history create an atmosphere unlike anywhere else in North America.
Every corner is filled with European charm, from the grand Château Frontenac towering over the St. Lawrence River to the quaint cafés and boutiques lining Petit-Champlain.
Walking through the fortified walls, you can feel the history come alive.

Name: Painted Churches in the Troodos Region
short_description: This region is characterized by one of the largest groups of churches and monasteries of the former Byzantine Empire. The complex of 10 monuments included on the World Heritage List, all richly decorated with murals, provides an overview of Byzantine and post-Byzantine painting in Cyprus. They range from small churches whose rural architectural style is in stark contrast to their highly refined decoration, to monasteries such as that of St John Lampadistis.

reviews.text: This church has very unusual design. It's situated not far from the central roundabout at Platres. No visitors at all, and it seems to have been closed for a long time. Nevertheless it is maintained in good condition and is definitely looked after.

Anglican Church of St George in the Forest is part of St. Paul’s Anglican Cathedral in Nicosia.
This Church is located in the depths of the Troodos Mountain range,  close to a British military base (Royal Airforce - Radar Installation).

Had a great family wedding in this church some years ago and returned for a little reminder of our happy memories there. It was closed but we still let the children ring the bell which they loved. There is a time schedule outside with open days and Sunday service.
Lovely and peaceful. With lovely people
Although closed as many times as I happened to visit, its beauty remains admirable. In the trees, in absolute silence, even though it is less than a kilometer from Troodos Square!

Name: Pont du Gard (Roman Aqueduct)
short_description: The Pont du Gard was built shortly before the Christian era to allow the aqueduct of Nîmes (which is almost 50 km long) to cross the Gard river. The Roman architects and hydraulic engineers who designed this bridge, which stands almost 50 m high and is on three levels – the longest measuring 275 m – created a technical as well as an artistic masterpiece.

reviews.text:
We arrived at 8.30 in the morning, very early in February and just as the sun was rising,, it was so quiet and beautiful.
There was hardly anyone around and we had the place to ourselves.
The ticket office was closed so we could not access the museum and the coffee shops were closed, although it looked like they may open later.
The car park was 9 euros and you collect a ticket on your way in and then pay at the machines in the wall near the ticket office.
Worth a visit to see such a beautiful piece of history

A place you don't want to miss if you're visiting the Gard department. Amazing views, lots of history, great museum and a nice place for a quick swim in the summer. The museum visit is a must. There is a café-restaurant and an ice cream shop on the side of the site and during most of the summer days there are music events, light shows, food trucks etc.

This place was breathtaking in person.  Over 2000 years old.  I had no problem taking a Uber there and back from Avignon.  Maybe as a back up - book your return Uber before going.

I walked over it, went down to both sides of the river and spent time just sitting and admiring the view.  Stopped and had a coffee there and the whole visit took me just under two hours.
I did not check out the museum, but it is only nine euros I believe.

A lot of beautiful paths for walking/biking.

Definitely come check this out if you’re thinking about it !!!!

This stunning Roman aqueduct is almost 2,000 years old. There are a number of optional concessions like a theater and museum. There is ample parking. Parking is not free as I had read elsewhere. I paid $9.75 by credit card at the exit. Unlike many parking lots in Europe you don’t have to seek out a separate payment machine before going back to your car.

Amazing Roman built bridge. Loads of easy parking. Routes to the bridge, from the car park, and surrounding walking paths are very well marked and easy to follow. The views are stunning of the surrounding countryside, the river valley and the bridge itself. There's toilets dotted around as well as refreshments. And to swim in the river from one of the many river bank pebbled beaches, with the bridge in the back ground is awesome. We swam up stream from the bridge and there were rocks on the side that you could climb and jump from into deep water (rocks about 8m high). They was also lots of shade, which was great given the amazing sunny weather.

Name: St Mary's Cathedral and St Michael's Church at Hildesheim
short_description: St Michael's Church was built between 1010 and 1020 on a symmetrical plan with two apses that was characteristic of Ottonian Romanesque art in Old Saxony. Its interior, in particular the wooden ceiling and painted stucco-work, its famous bronze doors and the Bernward bronze column, are – together with the treasures of St Mary's Cathedral – of exceptional interest as examples of the Romanesque churches of the Holy Roman Empire.

reviews.text: Even if you're not Christian or not religious at all, you can't help but be in awe of the history places like these hold. And even more, of the architects and especially the workers who have created these buildings without modern technology. And it's still here. The city of Hildesheim luckily left some space around it, so that you can really enjoy and appreciate it in all it's beauty. Highly recommended if this is what you're interested in.

If it would be Catholic, nice, sadly they overtook the probably once even more beautiful place. But the crypt is still catholic, and also really beautiful. Protestants even today gladly could not erase Mary completely outside of the history.
An essential visit, not least for the ceiling, if sadly totally rebuilt. Free entry.
Great Architecture. One of the best place to visit. Peace of mind. Wonderful.
Very nice church to rest your mind in the morning. Had some nice organ music to.

Name: Kaziranga National Park
short_description: In the heart of Assam, this park is one of the last areas in eastern India undisturbed by a human presence. It is inhabited by the world's largest population of one-horned rhinoceroses, as well as many mammals, including tigers, elephants, panthers and bears, and thousands of birds.

reviews.text: Awesome experience. Everyone should go there. This lifetime experience was beautiful and lovely. There was lots of animals like rhinos, deer, and elephants. This  experience will always be memorable. Love it.

Beautiful and well maintained tracks. Near by sighting of one horn rhino due to which Too many tourists are there so it's always crowded. Washroom inside park is not maintained at all. So make sure you can hold your pee for min of 3 hours as you can't get down of the car.

Amazing experience in the Jeep Safari. Saw many one-horned rhinos, alongside many other animals. However, no sighting of elephants and tigers - something that we knew anyways. But the whole landscape is just mesmerising, unlike other Safaris in India. This should be a must-do for all seeking thrill spotting wild animals.
It was a great experience. We'd seen migrate birds , rhinos and wild Elephants. You can feel the real wildlife  vibes. Lots of foreigners visit there . They are very familiar and kind.

On December 14th, 2024, we experienced the thrill of Kaziranga's Kohora Zone with a Jeep Safari, driven by a knowledgeable young guide. Our adventure began with a cluster of jeeps, all patiently waiting for a glimpse of a tiger hidden in the bush. We waited nervously for about twenty minutes, and then we saw a quick but amazing sight: a tiger jumping on a deer. The deer, surprisingly alive, ran quickly across the road right in front of us. It was a moment of pure, wild nature. We kept going on our jeep ride, and it was really exciting! The Kohora area was full of life. There were lots of tall grasses, like elephant grass and sugarcane, and different trees like Kumbhi and cotton trees. We enjoyed every bit of it. We saw a big eagle sitting on a tree, looking around. Deer, blue bulls, and wild buffaloes were eating grass. We also saw a mother rhino with her babies, which was very special. Later, we saw two elephants standing in a field. Turtles and alligators were lying in the sun by the river.
We stopped for a break at a pretty lake. It was peaceful and quiet. Elevated view points offered panoramic vistas. Then we continued and saw some rare birds and pretty deer. Our three and a half hour ride around the Kohora area was great. When we got back to the gate, there were little shops selling souvenirs and snacks to remember our trip. It was a perfect ending to a wonderful day. We loved seeing all the amazing wildlife in Kaziranga. Bring water, binoculars, hats, and sunglasses.

Name: Manas Wildlife Sanctuary
short_description: On a gentle slope in the foothills of the Himalayas, where wooded hills give way to alluvial grasslands and tropical forests, the Manas sanctuary is home to a great variety of wildlife, including many endangered species, such as the tiger, pygmy hog, Indian rhinoceros and Indian elephant.

reviews.text:
Manas National Park, located in the northeastern region of India, is a hidden gem for nature enthusiasts and wildlife lovers. The park is not only a UNESCO World Heritage site but also a designated biosphere reserve, offering an incredible range of flora and fauna. What makes this place truly special is the seamless experience Google Maps provides when exploring the park.

Upon searching for directions to Manas National Park, the map’s detailed routes and accurate navigation help travelers get to the park with ease. Whether you are coming from nearby cities like Guwahati or other regions, Google Maps offers real-time updates on traffic conditions and road closures, ensuring a smooth journey. The park itself is well marked, and key areas like the park's entrance, visitor center, and popular trekking routes are easy to locate.

Google Maps also features user reviews and photos, allowing travelers to get a glimpse of what they can expect. The map marks various wildlife sightings and activity areas, such as the river safari spots and trekking trails, making it easier for tourists to plan their visit.

While exploring the park, the GPS accuracy is spot on, helping you navigate through dense forest areas and remote corners of the reserve. If you're planning a trip to Manas, Google Maps is a great companion, providing essential information and making your visit stress-free and enjoyable.

For those seeking a serene and adventurous getaway in nature, Manas National Park is an unmissable destination.

Manas National Park, located in the foothills of the Eastern Himalayas in Assam, India, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site renowned for its exceptional biodiversity and stunning landscapes. The park spans approximately 950 square kilometers and shares its northern boundary with Bhutan’s Royal Manas National Park.  ￼

Manas National Park, located in the northeastern region of India, is an UNESCO World Heritage site. BEAUTIFUL & Calm nature and soothing weather in Feb-March is best for visiting this place. We have done 2 jungle safari and elephant safari. Great experience.  One thing I must say Royal Manas safari trip is  totally waste of money. BHUYANPARA RANGE is perfect for whole day safari. We have get chance to spot crossing elephant, variety of birds, Rhino, Deer many wild life. ELEPHANT SAFARI & Half day safari in Basbari forest is totally worth it. Have Great experience there. Highly recommended.

Manas National Park is one of the largest National parks in India. It is supposed to have a great variety of wildlife, but to my utter disappointment I wasn't able to have a glimpse of a single wildlife during my visit. In terms of natural beauty it is very rich.

Manas National Park vs Kaziranga:

1. Manas has better jeep safari, Kaziranga has better elephant safari.

2. Jeep safari is quite extensive, takes almost 4 hours. Elephant safari is quite short.

3. There is an elephant bathing and eating session also at 3:30, which is a unique experience, but advance booking is suggested for that.

4. Bio diversity is huge, more than 450 bird species, many mammals, tiger is hard to be spotted, so are other big cats

Ideal time is March

Name: Keoladeo National Park
short_description: This former duck-hunting reserve of the Maharajas is one of the major wintering areas for large numbers of aquatic birds from Afghanistan, Turkmenistan, China and Siberia. Some 364 species of birds, including the rare Siberian crane, have been recorded in the park.

reviews.text:
What an amazing place to be in.

E-rickshaw with a guide costs you Rs 1600 for 2hours, which can be extended for Rs 800 per additional hour.
Average time spent is 3hours.

Boating option is also available.

There are 3 temples inside the park.

Food options are limited but are good, hygienic and economical.

We visited mid February along with kids.

Perfect for bird watching beginners and enthusiasts. Hundreds of species, not over crowded and usually has serious bird enthusiasts visiting.

About 6 km road inside the park with 20 odd pathways to walk down around swamps to observe birds close up.

Options:
Walking, electric rickshaw, bicycle and horse tonga

Recommend the electric rickshaw:

- the drivers know the spots. Our driver took us to spot a python

- You have space to keep your stuff like a camera, binoculars, backpack and jacket.

- you save on energy to walk down the swamp pathways.

- If travelling with kids it's easier for them to enjoy as walking drains then out.

Food:
They have a basic canteen inside for tea,  chips, biscuits etc.

Recommend carrying a snack pack which you can enjoy while sitting on one of the many observation decks along swamp pathways.

Bathrooms:
Available near the canteen. Or better to use one at the forest guest house inside.

This is a wonderful wetland filled with birds of all sorts.
There are storks, herons, ducks, hens, ibises, cranes, deer and more.
You can either walk along the main path, or cycle around or take an e-rickshaw.
It is fun, the whole atmosphere is filled with sounds of various birds and to watch them soar and spread their wings is a memorable experience

I felt as if I was in an altogether new world. Could watch migratory birds. Though a bit expensive since taking battery rickshaw costs Rs 1200 and a guide will charge Rs 1200 for 3 hours. And Rs 300 each extra for an additional one hour. However worth spending as it is an awesome experience. I would suggest taking a guide as else you will not know how to find birds and they help you watch through their professional binoculars. Worth visiting.

This National Park is a hidden gem for nature and bird lovers. The serene environment, lush greenery, and abundance of bird species make it a peaceful getaway. Mornings are the best time to visit, especially during the winter season when migratory birds arrive. The sanctuary is well-maintained and offers a variety of exploration options: entry fees are ₹155 for Indian citizens, ₹62 for Indian students, and ₹955 for foreign nationals. Other options include boat rides (₹350-₹500 per hour), cycles (₹100-₹150 per day), tongas (₹300 for 3 hours), and e-rickshaws (₹375 for 3 hours). Guides are available at ₹300 per hour. Better signage and guides could enhance the experience. A great spot for photographers and families alike!

Name: Hatra
short_description: A large fortified city under the influence of the Parthian Empire and capital of the first Arab Kingdom, Hatra withstood invasions by the Romans in A.D. 116 and 198 thanks to its high, thick walls reinforced by towers. The remains of the city, especially the temples where Hellenistic and Roman architecture blend with Eastern decorative features, attest to the greatness of its civilization.

Name: Petra
short_description: Inhabited since prehistoric times, this Nabataean caravan-city, situated between the Red Sea and the Dead Sea, was an important crossroads between Arabia, Egypt and Syria-Phoenicia. Petra is half-built, half-carved into the rock, and is surrounded by mountains riddled with passages and gorges. It is one of the world's most famous archaeological sites, where ancient Eastern traditions blend with Hellenistic architecture.

reviews.text: Petra was brilliant! We like hiking and it was a lot bigger than we expected. Monastery is quite far, but we loved seeing it. Treasury was super pretty and not too far a walk from the entrance.

Visiting Petra was a truly unique and amazing experience! The breathtaking beauty of the ancient city, especially the iconic Treasury, left me in awe. Walking through the Siq and exploring the carved rock structures was like stepping back in time.

A few tips for future visitors: if you’re interested in a camel or horse ride, know that haggling is absolutely possible! Don’t accept the first price—negotiate to get a fair deal. Also, be prepared for some challenging paths. Some areas can be steep and rocky, making them tricky for those not used to uneven or dangerous terrain. Comfortable shoes and caution are a must!

Overall, Petra is a must-visit destination. The history, the atmosphere, and the sheer wonder of this place make it unforgettable! 🏜️🐪✨

Also, Is you come from an Arabic country dont forget to mention it when buying your ticket from the booth. They will charge you the same price as locals not foreigners.

Stunning, incredible experience. One of my favorite places ever. Due to surrounding conflicts at the moment, there were very few tourists. We have stayed the whole day over there, but there are routes for 3 days.

Beauty of this place cannot be imagine from photos. It's dam important to visit these historical places to and live the beautiful place.
Best time is to reach in winter and owtum
Always make sure to reach there in morning 10-12 since the place is huge and many places there to visit.

Worth every penny! We visited on a Friday during Ramadan in the rain and didn’t diminish our enjoyment at all. I really enjoyed the Sig on the way into see the treasury. Some of the colors of the rock due to their mineral content was just incredible.

Name: Quseir Amra
short_description: Built in the early 8th century, this exceptionally well-preserved desert castle was both a fortress with a garrison and a residence of the Umayyad caliphs. The most outstanding features of this small pleasure palace are the reception hall and the hammam, both richly decorated with figurative murals that reflect the secular art of the time.

reviews.text:
A very interesting place. The visitor centre was especially helpful as it explained all about the frescoes in the wall of the bath house. The bath house was the only building I went to, but the site is very large, with other places to see.
Highly recommended.
This site is included on the Jordan Pass.
Nice small hunting pavilion. The more beautiful are the paintings. But I don’t know for how many years since nobody seems to take care.

Qusair Amra, located in the eastern desert of Jordan, is one of the best-preserved examples of early Islamic architecture and art. Built during the 8th century under the Umayyad Caliphate, it is part of a larger complex that likely served as a retreat or hunting lodge for the Umayyad elite. The site is renowned for its striking frescoes, which cover the interior walls and ceilings, depicting scenes of daily life, animals, and even mythological figures—a rarity in Islamic art.

The small structure includes a reception hall, bathhouse, and a well-preserved dome that served as an audience hall. The bathhouse is particularly notable for its intricate frescoes, including a representation of the zodiac and hunting scenes, reflecting the blend of Byzantine, Persian, and local artistic influences.

Qusair Amra is a UNESCO World Heritage site, recognized for its historical significance and the insight it provides into the lifestyle and culture of the early Islamic period. Its remote desert location adds to its mystique, making it a fascinating destination for those interested in history and art.

This 8th-century Umayyad palace, also known as Quseir Amra or Qusayr Amra, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

It had amazing blend of Roman and Sasanian styles, with a simple exterior hiding a richly decorated interior. The reception hall-cum-bathhouse features vaulted ceilings adorned with colorful frescoes, depicting hunting scenes, portraits of rulers, and zodiac signs.

The frescoes are remarkable for their secular and pre-Islamic themes, showcasing the Umayyad civilization’s cultural and artistic achievements.

Believed to have been built during the reign of Umayyad Caliph Walid I (705-715 CE), Qasr Amra served as a caravanserai, bathhouse, and hunting lodge for the caliphs. Its location along the ancient trade route between Arabia and Syria made it an important stopover for travelers and merchants. What an amazing site. 5 stars.

One of the most amazing features of Qasr Amra is its breathtaking frescoes, which cover its walls and ceilings, turning the desert retreat into an artistic masterpiece. These intricate paintings feature hunting scenes, royal imagery, mythical figures, zodiac representations, and even scientific depictions of constellations. A truly unique site, not to be missed!

Name: Rock-Art Sites of Tadrart Acacus
short_description: On the borders of Tassili N'Ajjer in Algeria, also a World Heritage site, this rocky massif has thousands of cave paintings in very different styles, dating from 12,000 B.C. to A.D. 100. They reflect marked changes in the fauna and flora, and also the different ways of life of the populations that succeeded one another in this region of the Sahara.

reviews.text: I was there in 2005. Hot and inhospitable. Not foreigner friendly even if you have money.

مواقع تادرارت أكاكوس الصخرية

على حدود طاسيلي ناجر الجزائرية، وهي أيضًا موقع مدرج على قائمة التراث العالمي، يقع هذا المرتفع الصخري الغني بآلاف الرسوم الصخرية ذات الأساليب المختلفة كليًا والتي يعود أقدمها إلى 21 ألف عام ق.م. تقريبًا، ويمكن اعتبار أن أحدثها يرقى إلى القرن الأول ميلادي. وتعكس هذه الرسوم التعديلات العميقة التي طرأت على الثروة الحيوانية والنباتية وكذلك أنماط الحياة المتنوعة للشعوب التي تتالت على خذا الجزء من الصحراء الكبرى.

Rock-Art Sites of Tadrart Acacus - LIBYA

On the borders of Tassili N'Ajjer , also a World Heritage site, this rocky massif has thousands of cave paintings in very different styles, dating from 12,000 B.C. to A.D. 100. They reflect marked changes in the fauna and flora, and also the different ways of life of the populations that succeeded one another in this region of the Sahara.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Sites rupestres du Tadrart Acacus

À la frontière du Tassili n'Ajjer  également site du patrimoine mondial, ce massif rocheux est riche de milliers de peintures rupestres de styles très différents dont les plus anciennes remontent à 12 000 ans environ av. J.-C., les plus récentes pouvant être datées du Ier siècle de l'ère chrétienne. Ces peintures reflètent les modifications profondes de la faune et de la flore, ainsi que les divers modes de vie des populations qui se sont succédé dans cette partie du Sahara.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

塔德拉尔特•阿卡库斯石窟

塔德拉尔特•阿卡库斯石窟也是一个世界遗产遗址，位于阿尔及利亚阿杰尔的塔西里边境上。这座石山有数千种不同风格的壁画，时间可以追溯到公元前12 000年至公元100年。 这些壁画表现了动植物的明显变化以及撒哈拉地区每代人生活的不同方式。
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Наскальная живопись в горах Тадрарт-Акакус

Соседствуя с плато Тассилин-Аджер в Алжире, также объектом всемирного наследия, этот скальный массив обладает тысячами пещерных росписей самых разных стилей, относящихся к периоду от 12 тыс. лет до н.э. до 100 г. н.э. Они отражают важные изменения, произошедшие с фауной и флорой, а также различия в образе жизни народов, сменявших друг друга в этой части Сахары.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Rotskunstgebied van Tadrart Acacus

Tadrart Acacus ligt in de Fezzan, ten oosten van de stad Ghat en op de grens van Tassili N’Ajjer in Algerije. Dit rotsachtige massief bevat duizenden grotschilderingen in zeer verschillende stijlen, daterend uit 12.000 voor tot 100 na Christus. De verschillende grotschilderingen en gravures tonen scènes van de jacht of het dagelijks leven, rituele dansen en dieren. De rotskunst weerspiegelt opvallende veranderingen in de flora en fauna, alsmede de verschillende manieren van leven van bevolkingen die elkaar opgevolgd hebben in deze regio van de Sahara. Het gebied van Tadrart Acacus is meer dan 250 vierkante kilometer groot en tegenwoordig een woestijn.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Sitio rupestre de Tadrart Acacus

Colindante con el sitio argelino de Tasili n’Ajer, también inscrito en la Lista de Patrimonio Mundial, este macizo rocoso encierra miles de pinturas rupestres de diferentes estilos. Las primeras se remontan a 12.000 años antes de nuestra era y las más recientes datan del siglo I d.C. Esas pinturas muestran las considerables modificaciones experimentadas por la fauna y la flora a lo largo de ese periodo de más de 120 siglos, así como las distintas formas de vida de las poblaciones que se asentaron sucesivamente en esta región del Sahara.
Visited in 2008 ! Amaizing place on Earth.

Location and Values:  The rock-art sites of Tadrart Acacus are found in a vast area of desert landscape around (and mostly to the north of) the town of Ghat in south-western Libya.  The area includes the Acacus mountain range, and borders the Tassili N’Ajjer world heritage site in neighbouring Algeria.  Together with the Tassili N’Ajjer it is the premier rock-art area in the world, with hundreds of engravings and thousands of paintings.

The rock art of Tadrart Acacus dates back as far as 12,000 years. This incredible open-air gallery tells the story of the changing fortunes of this part of the Sahara and the people who have occupied the area over the millennia.  It is a story that traces the environmental effects of climate change which can be divided into distinct periods according to the characteristics of the rock-art legacy.  The oldest art belongs to the so-called Wild Fauna Period (10,000-6,000 BC) characterised by the portrayal of animals – elephants, giraffes, hippos and rhinos – that inhabited the area when it was much wetter than today.  Overlapping with this era is the Round Head Period (8,000-6,000 BC) when human figures appear alongside painted circular heads devoid of features.  At this time people were living as hunter-gatherers, but this gradually gave way to the Pastoral Period (5500-2000 BC) characterised by art that depicts the introduction of domesticated cattle, and a more settled existence with human figures handling spears and performing ceremonies.  As the climate became progressively drier and long-distance travel more important, the art of the Horse Period (1000 BC – AD 1) shows the introduction of horses and horse-drawn chariots.  Finally, the most recent period of rock-art in the Sahara (from about 200 BC to present) is the Camel Period, as these animals have played an increasingly important role.

Slideshow of the Rock-Art Sites of Tadrart Acacus:  The slideshow features a collection of stunning photos provided by David Coulson at the Trust for African Rock Art, the premier organisation working for the conservation of this extraordinary heritage.  It shows some of the incredible landscapes that provide a backdrop for this open-air gallery, and detailed studies of specific engravings and paintings from each of the main periods outlined above

When you are in southwestern Libya you feel the Saharan Tadrart Acacus mountains are windy, hot, and hyper-arid. But to your surprise the fossils recovered from the Saharan environment of the Takarkori rock shelter in southwestern Libya revealed that for much of the early and middle Holocene, from 10,200 to 4650 years back in time, this region was rich in water as well as life and was humid, with evidence of multiple human settlements and diverse fauna.

Tadrart Acacus has the rock shelters with significant floral and faunal remains, significant cultural artifacts and rock art pertaining to the period of early Holocene occupation of these shelters. The rich population of fishes about 80 percent in the faunal remains during 10,200-8000 years before present time gradually reduced to 40 percent by 5900-4650 years BP.  Advancement of aridity in the region impacted the survival of tilapia.
Standing now at  arid Tadrart Acacus and feeling the cool breeze of early and middle Holocene Period may be a tough task.
Earth has its own calculations. After some years from now, who knows the Earth may decide to bring back the  greenary, the water, rich flora and fauna to Tadrart Acacus. Hope for the same. Visit the marvels of Nature here at Tadrart Acacus. Good luck.

Name: Medina of Marrakesh
short_description: Founded in 1070–72 by the Almoravids, Marrakesh remained a political, economic and cultural centre for a long period. Its influence was felt throughout the western Muslim world, from North Africa to Andalusia. It has several impressive monuments dating from that period: the Koutoubiya Mosque, the Kasbah, the battlements, monumental doors, gardens, etc. Later architectural jewels include the Bandiâ Palace, the Ben Youssef Madrasa, the Saadian Tombs, several great residences and Place Jamaâ El Fna, a veritable open-air theatre.

Name: Rock Art of Alta
short_description: This group of petroglyphs in the Alta Fjord, near the Arctic Circle, bears the traces of a settlement dating from c. 4200 to 500 B.C. The thousands of paintings and engravings add to our understanding of the environment and human activities on the fringes of the Far North in prehistoric times.

reviews.text:
We had been here in November.
Museum is very interesting and as a good display of the history of Alta and much more. It has very interaktive displays like touch displays or quizzes, which makes it perfect for children and “soon to be bored” adults. Sadly, the outer parts were closed due to the season.

Amazing the open air museum. The visit is pleasant and definitely not long. There is a track with the main petroglyphs a bit more than 1 km and another of around 3 totally. I was lucky that was a sunny day because the location is absolutely beautiful.

Really interesting museum area! It is clear, why this is one of Unesco's World Heritage place. Walking path condition is rather good and there are ongoing revamping work. But remember, this external path can be some challenging older or mobility impaired people. If you want see more details from carvings, then you need think light. Early morning or late evening sun open more. Don't be too hurry. Read yours paper guide (includes ticket price), walk slowly and enjoy!  Really recommended place (must).

Absolutely incredible place and was so much more than we expected. Be aware that although there are 3 exhibitions inside the building, that if you want to see the rock carvings you have to walk outside either the shorter 1.5km route or the whole 3km route. We did the whole 3km.one, and it was so worth it! The path is very well maintained, and you walk mainly on raised wooden walkways while taking you past thousands of years of history in the rock carvings. At one point, the route goes right down to the beach, and from there, we were thrilled to see a pod of porpoises jumping in and out of the water! The rock carvings are so enigmatic, but I must admit having a very immature giggle at the fact that one person 6000 years ago had felt it necessary to carve a pooing reindeer😂 I loved this place so much and would definitely love to ho again!
Super interessting place! A must visit if in Alta. The museum and the outdoor area with Ancient stone carvings and art is simply mind blowing 😀 in a positive way.

Name: Chavin (Archaeological Site)
short_description: The archaeological site of Chavin gave its name to the culture that developed between 1500 and 300 B.C. in this high valley of the Peruvian Andes. This former place of worship is one of the earliest and best-known pre-Columbian sites. Its appearance is striking, with the complex of terraces and squares, surrounded by structures of dressed stone, and the mainly zoomorphic ornamentation.
formatted_address: Museo de, Chavín de Huantar 02395, Peru

reviews.text: This is a fantastic experience to see the site. 15 soles entry. A few hours from Huaraz by public transport (15 soles each way). Caution: during the long often unnerving, winding route, you reach high altitudes and must take a day or two to adjust to elevation before attempting to cross the mountain. A museum with objects taken from the site is on the other side of town. The site dates from 1500BC, and has been used since long before, though signage explains most the main structures are 800s BC. They do not allow you to climb most stairs or explore a significant portion of the site, and some paths are controlled for continued excavations. You mostly see things from the other side of a fence. But in some moments you get to interact with the site and go down passageways etcetera. The environment is gorgeous, as you're surrounded 360° by mountains. Don't miss out heading down to the creek that surrounds the site on two sides to enjoy the tranquility by the edge of the flowing stream still going 3000 years later.
Great spot to understand more about the history of this country.

Fascinating historical site to discover the Chavin people. You’ll need a tour guide to get the most out of it and understand the surroundings. The signs are in Spanish and English. The most fascinating part of the site are the underground tunnels. Several of the tunnels don’t allow photos so the place is even more interesting than the photos you see online would suggest.

I can't give this site less than 3 stars because even though it was closed, I'm fairly confident I will rate it 5 stars if/when I revisit and have the opportunity to go inside with a tour guide.

Unesco world heritage site 330. Be careful visiting as they seem to close randomly and have weird visiting hours/days. May require a reservation/appointment.

2022.08.20 0429 PET-RMN update: Interesting, I didn't read my own note as we went there on Tuesday 2022.08.16 (~8 hour drive by car from Lima) and it was closed due to a recent landslide in the area (~2 weeks prior). We did not call in advance or attempt to make reservations. However, we were able to see the u shaped complex, main temple (from the outside), and sunken plaza. We could also see the fanged deity from pretty close, taking pictures from over the wall. The fanged deity is much larger than I thought. I anticipated that it would be around 6-8 inches in diameter but it was more like 3-4 feet in diameter. If we have the opportunity, we should revisit to take the tour and see the museum located in the town of Chavin, as it was also closed. Tickets/tours include the ability to go inside the temple and view the several meter high stone rock pillar (obelisk) with partially transformed fanged deity carvings.

One of the most beautiful places I ever seen of my country ❤️ the landscapes are just amazing, the entrance fee is affordable and the local people is very nice and helpful.

I would definitely be back!

Name: Huascarán National Park
short_description: Situated in the Cordillera Blanca, the world's highest tropical mountain range, Mount Huascarán rises to 6,768 m above sea-level. The deep ravines watered by numerous torrents, the glacial lakes and the variety of the vegetation make it a site of spectacular beauty. It is the home of such species as the spectacled bear and the Andean condor.

reviews.text: One of the best parks I've ever had the pleasure of going to. I've spent the last few days in Huaraz and have been on a few hikes, they did not disappoint. The stunning views and peacefulness of the park is amazing. My friend made the most of it and has some fantastic drone shots that really show of the natural beauty of the park. I will be looking to return one day.
Beautiful mountain scenery! We cycled at the south of the national park in november and the road was very muddy. Don’t go by bike after heavy rainfall!
Beautiful national park. We did the Santa Cruz trek here which was great for spending a lot of time here.

This is a beautiful place to visit. You will not regret going here. The Laguna is so beautiful between the snowy peaks. If you have a nice day, the view can be spectacular. The drive up there is also beautiful. You will love it!
Don't think twice about including the park in a tour of Peru. It's amazing. There are plenty of day trips and multi day hikes with tours arranging access from Huaraz.

Name: Cave of Altamira and Paleolithic Cave Art of Northern Spain
short_description: Seventeen decorated caves of the Paleolithic age were inscribed as an extension to the Altamira Cave, inscribed in 1985. The property will now appear on the List as Cave of Altamira and Paleolithic Cave Art of Northern Spain. The property represents the apogee of Paleolithic cave art that developed across Europe, from the Urals to the Iberian Peninusula, from 35,000 to 11,000 BC. Because of their deep galleries, isolated from external climatic influences, these caves are particularly well preserved. The caves are inscribed as masterpieces of creative genius and as the humanity’s earliest accomplished art. They are also inscribed as exceptional testimonies to a cultural tradition and as outstanding illustrations of a significant stage in human history.
formatted_address: Avenida Marcelino Sanz de Sautuola, s/n, 39330 Santillana del Mar, Cantabria, Spain

reviews.text: One of the best musua compared to price quality ratio. The price is 3 euro normal, 2 euro reduced and during some days it's even free. Lots of free parking spaces for both cars and campers. The museum offers a look into the past, whilst it being a replica, it gives good insight into the history. The real location of the cave is closed off, however next to it there is a house for visitors and the view on top is really nice too. To even add, it's close to other nice locations nearby. I did not add many pictures to keep the surprise. Most interesting part is that you are able to try to carve in a stone yourself aswell to feel the experience.

A paltry €3 admission gets you into this amazing museum that includes some excellent and informative exhibits as well as a full size replica of the actual cave (which has been closed to the public for its preservation). For tourists, the replica exhibit is actually better than the cave itself, as it allows easier access and visibility to the centuries of human art within. A moving, inspiring experience.

I wasn’t able to buy tickets for kids in advance ( they are free , but still needed). Took us 90 mins in the line to get tickets with 1 person working the till.
Then we got the entry to the cave for an hour after we entered the museum. Not great at all.

Could have been so much better organized.

May 2023
You are able to view this replica of the original caves. Only archaeologists can view the real ones. Very interesting. I had a guided tour, and I would recommend this to learn a lot.
Then you can explore the museum on your own.
There is a gift shop with many interesting items. There is a restaurant on site, and lots of free parking.
Worth a visit for 3 euros but honestly the main attraction, neo cave itself is pretty small. I honestly wouldn’t go out of my way to visit this if I knew before hand.

Name: Old Town of Segovia and its Aqueduct
short_description: The Roman aqueduct of Segovia, probably built c. A.D. 50, is remarkably well preserved. This impressive construction, with its two tiers of arches, forms part of the setting of the magnificent historic city of Segovia. Other important monuments include the Alcázar, begun around the 11th century, and the 16th-century Gothic cathedral.

reviews.text: Impressive structures and view from the top easily walk from bus station. Lots of nearby shops and eateries. One hour bus ride from Madrid with frequent scheduled buses. Highly recommended for a quick getaway from Madrid. It’s a beautiful city.

The Aqueduct of Segovia is an incredible feat of ancient Roman engineering and one of Spain’s most impressive historical landmarks. The massive stone structure, built without mortar, has stood the test of time for nearly 2,000 years, showcasing the ingenuity and skill of its creators. Walking beneath its towering arches is a breathtaking experience, and the surrounding old town of Segovia adds to its charm. Whether you’re a history enthusiast or just a traveler looking for stunning sights, the aqueduct is a must-see.

An absolutely incredible feat of engineering, a must visit when you're in Madrid. This is the most incredible Roman structure I have ever seen. It is mind blowing how it stays standing purely on physics and not cement. A sight to behold and I wish I'd had time to walk the entire 15km.
What a beautiful and breathtaking place. As soon as you arrive it invites you with its impressive beauty. Recommend walking the town to the castle.

It’s surreal to see this in person. I’ve looked at it so many times on the internet while planning the trip but to actually stand before this engineering marvel made in the 2nd century is mind blowing.

We did a private walking tour which was worth it because we learned so much about it, the history and what the plaza was like during the time the aqueduct was constructed. She brought us to the top of the aqueduct so we could see how short it was at the top and where the water used to run. Fascinating.

I recommend getting a guide especially if you’re a group and can split the expense so it doesn’t cost too much.

Name: Monuments of Oviedo and the Kingdom of the Asturias
short_description: In the 9th century the flame of Christianity was kept alive in the Iberian peninsula in the tiny Kingdom of the Asturias. Here an innovative pre-Romanesque architectural style was created that was to play a significant role in the development of the religious architecture of the peninsula. Its highest achievements can be seen in the churches of Santa María del Naranco, San Miguel de Lillo, Santa Cristina de Lena, the Cámara Santa and San Julián de los Prados, in and around the ancient capital city of Oviedo. Associated with them is the remarkable contemporary hydraulic engineering structure known as La Foncalada.
formatted_address: Lugar el Pevidal, 6, 33194 Oviedo, Asturias, Spain

reviews.text: At the summit of Monte Naranco, located at an elevation of 634 meters, stands the giant Christ the Savior statue on Pico el Paisano, erected in the 1950s. From here, you can enjoy stunning panoramic views of Oviedo and the surrounding landscapes. If you're walking up from the city, it's faster to follow the hiking trail directly from the Iglesia de San Miguel de Lillo, rather than taking the road.

We arrived there when it was raining.
This is the beautiful place to relax and see the city from the top.
It was very easy to arrive by car. I saw some hiking and biking, too.

Nice view to look down Oviedo town.
I started from Oviedo train statin.
It takes about 2 hours to go up & 1 & half hours to come down to Oviedo train station.
There is nice picnic area just before the monument. It doesn’t look like difficult train from beginning but last 20mints was intense hiking.
I need to share the road with car. Not enough space for walk.
Most of cars are driving slow. But still need to aware of it.
Beautiful view great for hiking and picnics fresh mountain air.
Great views on a clear day! The hike is quite steep and tough if you decide to walk

Name: Santiago de Compostela (Old Town)
short_description: This famous pilgrimage site in north-west Spain became a symbol in the Spanish Christians' struggle against Islam. Destroyed by the Muslims at the end of the 10th century, it was completely rebuilt in the following century. With its Romanesque, Gothic and Baroque buildings, the Old Town of Santiago is one of the world's most beautiful urban areas. The oldest monuments are grouped around the tomb of St James and the cathedral, which contains the remarkable Pórtico de la Gloria.
formatted_address: Santiago de Compostela, Municipality of Santiago de Compostela, A Coruña, Spain

Name: Old Town of Ávila with its Extra-Muros Churches
short_description: Founded in the 11th century to protect the Spanish territories from the Moors, this 'City of Saints and Stones', the birthplace of St Teresa and the burial place of the Grand Inquisitor Torquemada, has kept its medieval austerity. This purity of form can still be seen in the Gothic cathedral and the fortifications which, with their 82 semicircular towers and nine gates, are the most complete in Spain.
formatted_address: Pl. de la Catedral, 8, 05001 Ávila, Spain

reviews.text:
I don't think it was worth 8 euros. I understand that you feel the need to go. I went, but it was not as good as I expected for that price

Basílica de los santos Vicente was only 3 euros and almost as nice.

I absolutely loved the tour through the cathedral. The walls are made out of a rock tinted with red which gives the cathedral a uniquely beautiful ambiance. The details are sublime and the audio guide does a good job at explaining the significance of the art. I highly recommend a visit. Buy the tickets at the entrance.

It is a mixture of Gothic and Romanesque styles and is considered the first Gothic cathedral in Spain. It was built from the 12th to the 14th century to serve the Savior. The cathedral's apse served as part of the city walls, and in addition to its religious purposes it played an important role in the defense of the city.

This was the most surprising place for me, for I didn't expect anything different from the usual sights in Spanish cathedrals. I was very much fascinated by the place as it is marvellous and splendid. Furthermore the staff was very polite and they offer you a free audio guide with the ticket. The VR experience is simply amazing!

Visited in August 2024
This was a fantastic Cathedral in Avila which is a town that was fortified with huge walls by request of King Alfonso VI of León in the 11th century. Not to be missed!
The Cathedral of the Savior is a temple of Catholic worship in the Spanish city of Ávila , episcopal seat of the diocese of the same name. It was designed as a temple and fortress, its apse being one of the cubes of the city wall . The building, a mixture of Gothic and Romanesque styles , dates back to the  12th century and is considered the first Gothic cathedral in Spain. It has a Latin cross plan consisting of three naves, a transept and a semicircular chancel with a double ambulatory . This variety of architecture gives rise to a sober and fortified exterior that gives way to Gothic lightness with Renaissance touches on the inside. It is surrounded by several stately homes or palaces, the most important being those of the Velada family , the Child King family and the Valderrábanos family , which were assigned the defence of the Puerta de los Leales.

Name: Punic Town of Kerkuane and its Necropolis
short_description: This Phoenician city was probably abandoned during the First Punic War (c. 250 B.C.) and as a result was not rebuilt by the Romans. The remains constitute the only example of a Phoenicio-Punic city to have survived. The houses were built to a standard plan in accordance with a sophisticated notion of town planning.

reviews.text:
The entrance is off the beaten path. No signs, so I used Google maps to get there. The actual entrance is just a bent over wire fence. ( I think we're not supposed to visit :/ Sorry)
Inside, it's abandoned, but impressive nonetheless. A lot of underground graves, dug up in a single HUGE rock. On top of each grave, there's a number. And these numbers reach the couple hundreds. I'm not sure what they mean. Because i can't believe there's 400 burial sites in such a little space.
Each grave has stairs going 2 meters deep, at the end of the stairs, there's a stone "door", most of the time, it's a circular shape, some of them are squared; only a couple of them are sealed shut.
I know snakes love these places, so I didn't go downstairs. But I think some of them are connecting and creating an underground chamber, because I could see rays of sunlight.
Nice museum, the ruins not so amazing
Amazing Punic / Phoenician burial site....

Very interesting Punic tombs carved in the rock.
The place is available free of charge. Possibility to park.
Lack of infrastructure. Sławojka toilet :)

Karkouane - an ancient Phoenician city, located on Cape Ras at-Tib, the oldest ruins of which date back to the 6th century BC. The remains of the defensive walls and a carefully planned urban layout with streets intersecting perpendicularly come from the period of the city's greatest prosperity (4th and 2nd centuries BC). In the museum you can see many articles from this period. Worth visiting.

Name: Historic Areas of Istanbul
short_description: With its strategic location on the Bosphorus peninsula between the Balkans and Anatolia, the Black Sea and the Mediterranean, Istanbul has been associated with major political, religious and artistic events for more than 2,000 years. Its masterpieces include the ancient Hippodrome of Constantine, the 6th-century Hagia Sophia and the 16th-century Süleymaniye Mosque, all now under threat from population pressure, industrial pollution and uncontrolled urbanization.
formatted_address: Sultan Ahmet, Ayasofya Meydanı No:1, 34122 Fatih/İstanbul, Türkiye

reviews.text: One of my favorite places that we went to on our vacation was the Hagia Sophia. It was simply filled with history and awe. It was quite busy for a February weekday but I heard that the summer was even more packed. The art work that was still intake was very detailed. The colors were amazing, hundreds of years retained.

Little trick might be to get tickets at the museum and start there first as it’s the same ticket to enter mosque. That line is much bigger.  This allows you to learn about the mosque before u go in and makes you notice things you otherwise may have missed.

I would say worth 47 euros (25 just for mosque balcony) to get the mosque plus museum because it’s this grand techno visual spectacle that guides you through the history. Downstairs of the mosque is just for prayer.

The mosque itself is gorgeous and quite impressive from the outside. It is costly to get in but you do get to see some historical Byzantine era artwork alongside Islamic calligraphy. There are even seraphim’s that decorate the mosque. However, it is unfortunate that only Turkish nationals are allowed to visit the lower part of the mosque where foreigners are relegated to the visitor areas. Nevertheless it is an iconic landmark and there are some interesting historical pieces that are worth looking at. If you go later like at 18:00 there are little to no lines.

A good visit. It is a marvel to experience. Go early and miss the crowds. Non-muslims only allowed in upper area, where you can see most of everything. Do not be fooled into buying the inflated ticket with promises of more access.

This was a beautiful space there is no doubt however it’s outshine by the fact it’s disgustingly overpriced. We bought tickets at the ticket box, maybe it’s better to book online?

I almost can’t remember the beautifully preserved walls, the stunning architecture and the theatrical visual display at the museum. Very unfortunate that some of Istanbul best kept history is so incredibly inaccessible due to cost.

Name: Göreme National Park and the Rock Sites of Cappadocia
short_description: In a spectacular landscape, entirely sculpted by erosion, the Göreme valley and its surroundings contain rock-hewn sanctuaries that provide unique evidence of Byzantine art in the post-Iconoclastic period. Dwellings, troglodyte villages and underground towns – the remains of a traditional human habitat dating back to the 4th century – can also be seen there.
formatted_address: Yukarı Kızılçukur Vadisi, Bahçelievler, 50500 Ortahisar/Ürgüp/Nevşehir, Türkiye

reviews.text: Good hiking spots, nice rock formations and beautiful views particularly across various different valleys. Highly recommended for everyone visiting Turkey. Might not be as awesome as Himalayas or Alps but the rock formations and valleys are fairly nice for easy hikes.

Göreme National Park is the most iconic and historically rich area of Cappadocia, recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. It is home to ancient cave churches, rock-cut monasteries, and breathtaking fairy chimneys, making it a must-visit destination for history and nature lovers.

This is one of the most fantastic landscapes I've ever seen, with its iconic fairy chimneys and breathtaking vistas.

Millions of years ago volcanic eruptions covered the area in ash, and then with lava. The ash turned into soft rock or tuff. In the still air, vertical rainfall has worn away the tuff, but where it's protected by lumps of hard lava above, it remains, forming fairy chimneys.

You should definitely aim to spend a few days here, there's so much to see. Hire a car or motorbike, take a balloon ride, and hike the multiple trails.

An UNESCO world heritage site with an incredible landscape. You think you were on the moon. Known for it's collection of cave churches going back to the 11th century.
Home  to multi-colored cliffs, rock towers, pillars, tent rocks and fairy chimney rock.

A must see

great weather, astonishing view!
It’s awesome to see what the mother nature has created in this dreamland!
Definitely a MUST to take the hot air ballon ride!

Name: Great Mosque and Hospital of Divriği
short_description: This region of Anatolia was conquered by the Turks at the beginning of the 11th century. In 1228–29 Emir Ahmet Shah founded a mosque, with its adjoining hospital, at Divrigi. The mosque has a single prayer room and is crowned by two cupolas. The highly sophisticated technique of vault construction, and a creative, exuberant type of decorative sculpture – particularly on the three doorways, in contrast to the unadorned walls of the interior – are the unique features of this masterpiece of Islamic architecture.
formatted_address: Kemenkeş, Ulu Cami Cd., 58300 Divriği/Sivas, Türkiye

reviews.text: We made a detour to Divrigi to see the mosque and hospital, not knowing if it could be visited after the restoration work. Both the mosque and the hospital can be visited inside now and they are simply magnificent. The level of detail of the mosque gates is incredible, it is a work of art. The inside of the hospital is also very well restored and lightning truly makes it stand out. Well worth it. The town itself is also very welcoming. We had a great half day here.

We made a detour to Divrigi just because of the Great Mosque and Hospital.  We learnt that it was re-open a few weeks ago after 8 years of restoration.  It was totally worth it! Unfortunately, the hospital is still in restoration, so it is not open yet.  But the mosque itself is worth a visit.  The security guard was very nice and he tried to explain the history and key facts to us through google translate.

Make sure you catch the shadow of the man reading the quran at the exit portal 3pm-4pm in summer time.  In the early morning, there is a woman shadow at the portal at the Mosque's entrance too.

The hotels in Divrigi may charge more for foreigners, so we camped at the ridge behind the Great Mosque for a night. For those who bought a tent with them, you may consider camping as an option.
The architectural complex is great and justifies a visit at Divrigi. It is recently renovated and the visit is free.
The Great Mosque is under a major renovation for few years and will be for few more years.  Still can see the doors from our side platform, but that is it, nothing else is accesible.
Very good ancient mosque. Have to visit.

Name: Gondwana Rainforests of Australia
short_description: This site, comprising several protected areas, is situated predominantly along the Great Escarpment on Australia’s east coast. The outstanding geological features displayed around shield volcanic craters and the high number of rare and threatened rainforest species are of international significance for science and conservation.

reviews.text: I have never been here
i was attacked here

Name: Iguaçu National Park
short_description: The park shares with Iguazú National Park in Argentina one of the world’s largest and most impressive waterfalls, extending over some 2,700 m. It is home to many rare and endangered species of flora and fauna, among them the giant otter and the giant anteater. The clouds of spray produced by the waterfall are conducive to the growth of lush vegetation.

reviews.text: After seeing both sides of the park, we preferred the Argentina side because it felt more organized, with plenty of options for exploring, whether by train, shuttle, or on foot. The Brazil side had more of a touristy vibe, but they do offer more boat rides. The observatory deck is close to the falls, and the trails provide amazing views. There are also many cafes and restaurants on-site, and a hotel as well. It can get quite crowded, so be prepared for that. The park opens at 9 am. If you're into hiking or biking, they offer an 18km jungle trail, along with a shorter 3km round-trip trail that takes you to the river.

Our visit to Cataratas do Iguaçu last March was absolutely unforgettable. The falls are breathtaking—a true wonder of nature that everyone should experience at least once. The park is well-organized, with clear paths and viewpoints that provide incredible photo opportunities from multiple angles. We particularly appreciated the mix of accessibility and adventure, as the trails cater to all fitness levels.

It was extremely hot for us Canadians so make sure to bring water, sunscreen and a hat.

The roar of the falls, the lush greenery, and the mist in the air created an immersive experience that left us in awe.

If you’re visiting South America, this is an absolute must-see destination. We highly recommend setting aside a full day to truly soak in the beauty and magic of Cataratas do Iguaçu. Then add another day to visit the Iguazu side too for a different perspective and experience of this magical place.

Iguaçu Falls is, without a doubt, the most breathtaking waterfall I’ve ever seen. Spanning the border of Brazil and Argentina, this natural wonder is a jaw-dropping spectacle of power and beauty. The sheer scale of the falls, with over 275 cascades surrounded by lush rainforest, is overwhelming.

The panoramic views from the Brazilian side are stunning, offering a full perspective of the falls, while the Argentine side brings you closer to the roaring water. Walking along the trails and boardwalks, you feel the mist on your face and hear the thunderous roar—it’s an unforgettable, immersive experience.

Every angle offers something extraordinary, from the famous Devil’s Throat to the smaller, graceful streams. The surrounding wildlife, including butterflies, toucans, and coatis, adds to the magic. Truly, Iguaçu Falls is a masterpiece of nature and an absolute must-visit for anyone who loves adventure and stunning landscapes.
Amazing place. Must to see. Big car park spot. 60 reals a day. Please remember to take raincoat. Strongly recommended!

Absolutely spectacular falls, one of the largest waterfall systems in the world. Very well organized and maintained national park, lots of buses to take a ride to different spots, snack booths and infinite places to take pictures. Do not miss the devils throat. No photograph will do justice to what you will see with your own eyes.

Name: Roman Monuments, Cathedral of St Peter and Church of Our Lady in Trier
short_description: Trier, which stands on the Moselle River, was a Roman colony from the 1st century AD and then a great trading centre beginning in the next century. It became one of the capitals of the Tetrarchy at the end of the 3rd century, when it was known as the ‘second Rome’. The number and quality of the surviving monuments are an outstanding testimony to Roman civilization.

reviews.text:
This was one of my grandmother's favorite places to visit back home when she was young. I'm so grateful to have been afforded the opportunity to travel back to the homeland and see all of the beautiful sites that she grew up with.

No entrance fee to pay, which is a wild concept to me. It seems like everything in America has an entrance fee.

There is a small gift shop that you can visit and there are small trifold brochures in several languages that you can buy near the entrance.

Everything is so intricate and ornate, from the ceiling to each and every statue/figure throughout the building. My mind was blown by this place. It is a must stop spot, regardless of your faith.
Beautiful experience. This cathedral was huge! If you’re a history junkie or museum junkie, this is a place for you to visit. 11/10 recommend! Till then, let’s explore!

The Trier Saint Peter Cathedral is truly a treasure! As the oldest cathedral in Germany, it combines Romanesque, Gothic, and Baroque elements, giving it a uniquely layered architectural style. The interior is both grand and serene, with its high ceilings, intricate stonework, and beautiful stained glass filtering in natural light.

This cathedral isn’t just about beauty—it holds centuries of history, including ancient relics and artifacts. The quiet, reverent atmosphere makes it an ideal spot for reflection. A visit here can be a highlight of any trip to Trier!

Goated place fr 🧘‍♂️ come Here for mental Peace in Summer and Wear extra warm cloths in Winter cause Wind blows hard Here. Fr no Cap.

Apparently der Dom of Trier is 1700+ years old. So Just think about it. We are Just normal peasants, who will See think and die somewhere in time. BUT THIS WILL STAND STRONG.

Ok too much yapping in GenZ.

I Hope you enjoy your time Here 😊.

9.8/10

It lost 0.2 Points because Wind blows hard Here.

And i Just have night Photos. But it's Most Beautiful during Sunny day.

An absolutely stunning building! Calm, peaceful, and beautiful. On a trip to Trier this was a lovely place to spend an hour. There is something beautiful to look at in literally every corner. It is free to enter.

Name: Temple of Apollo Epicurius at Bassae
short_description: This famous temple to the god of healing and the sun was built towards the middle of the 5th century B.C. in the lonely heights of the Arcadian mountains. The temple, which has the oldest Corinthian capital yet found, combines the Archaic style and the serenity of the Doric style with some daring architectural features.

reviews.text: The temple of Apollon Epicurius, is one of the most well preserved temples in Greece, if not the most preserved one. The road to arrive at the temple has a lot of sharp turns and might be a little tiring to drive there but it's worth it because the temple is really magnificent. It has a small entrance fee of 6 euro and a big parking spot outside of the archeological site. When I was at the site, some restoration work was in progress. The site was not well organized and some work was still in progress but I was able to see the main temple of Apollon along with a small video they play at the site, regarding the temple.
Very impressive monument. A must-see. Also the landscape around is very beautiful.
Amazing, definitely worth visiting if one is interested in Ancient Greek temples

Getting to this place is not easy. It took me more than an hour driving on the very best (sigh) of the roads Greece has to offer, but it was extremelly worth to visit, the temple is stunning. Of note, you are probably going to be visiting from a way lower situated place, so it would be wise to bring some extra clothing. I didn't realize how high in the mountains the temple is, and was freezing in my shirt.

The next destination is the mountain nest Bassae, 65 km away, with its UNESCO World Heritage Site. The route there runs over small, winding mountain roads and passes with great views, but takes almost 2 hours. When we arrive in the mountain solitude at 1130m above sea level, we are presented with a bizarre sight. The unusually elongated temple of Epicurus Apollon, with 6x15 columns, is packed like a Christo art object. The magnificent building from the 5th century BC. is exceptionally well preserved but in danger of collapsing. Therefore, at the end of the 1980s, there was no hesitation and the whole thing was put into a supporting skeleton and packed weatherproof. The restoration work continues to this day. Here 3 different ancient architectural styles are said to be found and the first chapter of building history. The complex is surrounded by the remains of a small settlement in which cyclamen seem to feel very comfortable.

Name: Churches and Convents of Goa
short_description: The churches and convents of Goa, the former capital of the Portuguese Indies – particularly the Church of Bom Jesus, which contains the tomb of St Francis-Xavier – illustrate the evangelization of Asia. These monuments were influential in spreading forms of Manueline, Mannerist and Baroque art in all the countries of Asia where missions were established.

reviews.text:
Amazing building and a centerpiece of an arcological survey of India. ASI also has a museum along with a church.
Timing 10 to 5 pm
Recommended to go before 4pm because sometimes prayer also going on so they will not allow to enter.
Beutiful building.
Proper parking.
Scenic view.
If you have interest in historical things then must visit because it have the ruins and things of Portugese architecture.
Must visit.

After visiting the Basilica of Bom Jesus, we stopped by the Churches and Convents of Goa but didn’t explore much. However, the place is truly stunning, with its rich historical charm and beautiful architecture.

It’s a great spot for capturing amazing photos, and the peaceful surroundings add to the experience. If you’re in Goa, it’s definitely worth a visit to admire the heritage and take in the beauty of these historic churches.

The Churches and Convents of Goa, designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, offer a fascinating glimpse into the region's rich cultural and religious history. These structures, primarily built during the Portuguese colonial period, reflect a blend of European architectural styles and local influences, showcasing the unique heritage of Goa.

Among the most prominent is the Basilica of Bom Jesus, renowned for housing the relics of St. Francis Xavier. Its Baroque architecture, with a grand façade and intricate interior, is awe-inspiring. Similarly, the Se Cathedral, dedicated to St. Catherine, stands as one of the largest churches in Asia, celebrated for its majestic architecture and the Golden Bell.

The Church of St. Cajetan, modeled after St. Peter's Basilica in Rome, features Corinthian architecture and an elegant dome. The Convent and Church of St. Francis of Assisi, with its striking frescoes and ornate altars, further exemplifies the artistic excellence of the period.

These churches and convents are not just architectural marvels but also centers of spiritual and cultural significance. They highlight the pivotal role of Christianity in shaping Goa's history and culture. Visitors are often enchanted by the serene beauty, historical depth, and spiritual ambiance of these sacred sites, making them a must-visit for anyone exploring Goa.

Goa's churches and convents constitute a UNESCO World Heritage site. It is exactly opposite Basilica Bom Jesus. Se Cathedral, which is one of the largest churches, took nearly 80 years to build.  It exemplifies the Portuguese-Manueline architectural style. The splendor of the gardens enhanced its beauty. It is a must-see destination due to its tranquil atmosphere.

My visit to the Basilica of Bom Jesus was a profound experience immersed in the rich history of Jesus. As one of the oldest and largest churches, it stands as a testament to Goa's cultural heritage. The awe-inspiring architecture left me in awe, showcasing the skill and dedication of its builders. A must-visit destination for anyone seeking to explore the intersection of faith and history in Goa.

Name: Khajuraho Group of Monuments
short_description: The temples at Khajuraho were built during the Chandella dynasty, which reached its apogee between 950 and 1050. Only about 20 temples remain; they fall into three distinct groups and belong to two different religions – Hinduism and Jainism. They strike a perfect balance between architecture and sculpture. The Temple of Kandariya is decorated with a profusion of sculptures that are among the greatest masterpieces of Indian art.

Name: Group of Monuments at Hampi
short_description: The austere, grandiose site of Hampi was the last capital of the last great Hindu Kingdom of Vijayanagar. Its fabulously rich princes built Dravidian temples and palaces which won the admiration of travellers between the 14th and 16th centuries. Conquered by the Deccan Muslim confederacy in 1565, the city was pillaged over a period of six months before being abandoned.

reviews.text:
It feels like stepping into a lost kingdom where every stone has a story to tell

The massive temples, intricate carvings, and towering pillars whisper tales of a glorious past

Walking through the ruins, it’s hard to believe this was once a thriving empire filled with traders, artists, and warriors

The Best part?

The musical pillars that produce different notes when tapped, an architectural marvel that still amazes people today. The only downside is the scorching heat during midday, so early mornings or evenings are the best times to explore

A lovely location with significant historical significance. For everyone with even a passing interest in culture, this is a must-see location. A wonderful experience is made up of the legends surrounding the surrounding regions, the plateaus, the temples, and the monuments.

A ticket for entry is present. Need to buy that ticket and can enter all the historical monuments by showing the ticket itself. Tickets can be purchased using a QR code that will present outside of the gate in any of the monuments.

It is amazing to see all the rich culture of india. Most of them are ruins which are preserved carefully. Good attractions to know more about Indian people and culture during ancient times and trading. The only drawback is the climatic conditions of the area. It is scorching hot between 11 am to 3 pm, which makes the trip a bit exhausting.

Just stunned by this beautiful place. What a carvings what a maintainance. Just pure proof of history. There is a entry fees of rs35 per person for an Indian, which you can scan and buy on the spot. You can also purchase tickets in advance through tourism website. It's worth every penny.

Hampi, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is a treasure trove of ancient monuments that showcase the rich history and architecture of the Vijayanagara Empire. Here are the top monuments to visit in Hampi:

1. *Virupaksha Temple*: A majestic temple dedicated to Lord Shiva, with intricate carvings and sculptures.
2. *Vitthala Temple*: A stunning temple with 56 musical pillars that produce musical notes when tapped.
3. *Hazara Rama Temple*: A beautifully crafted temple with intricate carvings depicting scenes from the Ramayana.
4. *Royal Enclosure*: A sprawling complex that houses the ruins of the royal palace, temples, and other structures.
5. *Lotus Mahal*: A stunning example of Islamic architecture, with intricate arches and domes.
6. *Elephant Stables*: A unique structure that showcases the advanced architectural skills of the Vijayanagara Empire.
7. *Queen's Bath*: A beautifully crafted bath with intricate carvings and sculptures.

*Tips and Insights*

- Hire a guide to get a deeper understanding of the history and significance of the monuments.
- Wear comfortable shoes and clothing, as you'll be walking and exploring the monuments for several hours.
- Bring sunscreen, hats, and water to protect yourself from the sun.
- Respect the monuments and the local culture by not touching or damaging the structures.
- Take plenty of photos to capture the beauty and grandeur of the monuments.

*Getting There*

Hampi is located in Karnataka, India, and is easily accessible by road, rail, or air. The nearest airport is Bellary Airport, which is about 60 km from Hampi. You can also take a train or bus from major cities like Bangalore, Hyderabad, or Mumbai.

*Accommodation*

Hampi has a range of accommodation options, from budget-friendly guesthouses to luxury resorts. You can choose one that suits your budget and preferences.

*Best Time to Visit*

The best time to visit Hampi is from October to February, when the weather is cool and pleasant. Avoid visiting during the summer months, as the heat can be intense.

Name: Fatehpur Sikri
short_description: Built during the second half of the 16th century by the Emperor Akbar, Fatehpur Sikri (the City of Victory) was the capital of the Mughal Empire for only some 10 years. The complex of monuments and temples, all in a uniform architectural style, includes one of the largest mosques in India, the Jama Masjid.

Name: Old Town of Ghadamès
short_description: Ghadamès, known as 'the pearl of the desert', stands in an oasis. It is one of the oldest pre-Saharan cities and an outstanding example of a traditional settlement. Its domestic architecture is characterized by a vertical division of functions: the ground floor used to store supplies; then another floor for the family, overhanging covered alleys that create what is almost an underground network of passageways; and, at the top, open-air terraces reserved for the women.

Name: Chan Chan Archaeological Zone
short_description: The Chimu Kingdom, with Chan Chan as its capital, reached its apogee in the 15th century, not long before falling to the Incas. The planning of this huge city, the largest in pre-Columbian America, reflects a strict political and social strategy, marked by the city's division into nine 'citadels' or 'palaces' forming autonomous units.
formatted_address: Site Museum, Av. Chan Chan 101 Urb, Trujillo 13000, Peru

reviews.text: Nice place to see and it will take 2 hrs to quickly pass all objects

Awe inspiring place for its huge scale more than anything. The mud carvings are attractive and lots of conservation and repair work is ongoing. The museum is a little small and dated but the city makes up for it.

Go in the morning and arrive by 9am if taking a bus/collectivo to have the site to yourself. You can take the H bus from Ovalo Grau or take the B bus that go along Avenue España. All of the red buses that say "Huanchaco" will work and if you say "Chan Chan", they'll drop you off before a quick 10 minute walk to the site. The museum is free, but skip it. The archeological museum in Trujillo has better pieces and better explanations in English and Spanish for only five soles. Guides are 60 soles at the site, we declined.
Unbelievable place to visit 🙏 the site is immense. Just so worth going. There is so much beauty and detail here 😍 take a guide to delete deeper into the history

Nice archeological site, arrive early so the sun and heat doesn't ruin your experience.  I like the place , but those roofs take away the magic (I know they are needed for the protection of the site) . Parking could be a hassle if you arrive late.

Name: Historic Centre of Évora
short_description: This museum-city, whose roots go back to Roman times, reached its golden age in the 15th century, when it became the residence of the Portuguese kings. Its unique quality stems from the whitewashed houses decorated with azulejos and wrought-iron balconies dating from the 16th to the 18th century. Its monuments had a profound influence on Portuguese architecture in Brazil.

reviews.text: Wow, what a place full of history. Honest you can just get lost in this place with all the beautiful colors of merchandise in the streets with wonderful little stores to buy gifts and to find hole in the wall places to eat. I highly recommend going to the top of the cathedral of Evora, what a beautiful view.

A few highlights of our walking tour of Evora’s historic center:

Praça do Giraldo is a 13th century square paved with the traditional calçada portuguesa in geometric patterns.

The fortified Cathedral of Santa Maria, the Igreja de São Francisco and adjacent Chapel of Bones are worth visiting.

But the most interesting was the ruins of the Roman Temple, a symbol of the Roman presence in the Iberian Peninsula still standing today.

There is much more to see and enjoy!
We spent a week in January and  truly.njoyed spending a week.getting to know the historic centre. A lot to do and see and guided experiences were excellent.
Lots of nice shops and restaurants around a quaint village and historical sites. Take your time.
Charming little city, very well preserved. Most monuments have a somewhat modest scale but the general atmosphere is quiet and distinctive. Interesting details around every corner.

Name: Studenica Monastery
short_description: The Studenica Monastery was established in the late 12th century by Stevan Nemanja, founder of the medieval Serb state, shortly after his abdication. It is the largest and richest of Serbia’s Orthodox monasteries. Its two principal monuments, the Church of the Virgin and the Church of the King, both built of white marble, enshrine priceless collections of 13th- and 14th-century Byzantine painting.

reviews.text:
Beautiful, peaceful, holy. This of the beaten path monastery is worth the visit especially for those of Serbian heritage.

Monastery Studenica was built in the 11th century by Grand Prince Stefan Nemanja, who later become the 1st king of Serbia and the founder of Nemanjić dynasty. The interior is adorned by beautiful frescoes amongst which is the Studenica Crusifiction. A large amount of Byzantine blue paint was used for this fresco. Byzantine blue is saturated monarch purple with blue undertones. At the time, this pigment was valued more than gold. Just a few kings were adorned with capes in this color. Artists such as Raphael, Botticelli and Titian whose patrons were rich and influential were able to use this color in their masterpieces. How was a prince of a small Balkan country able to acquire this paint is still a mystery.
Stefan Nemanja, St. Simeon both brothers of St. Sava as well as their mother Anastasija are entombed in Studenica.

Studenica Monastery is probably the most famous, beautiful and largest monastery in Serbia, and a UNESCO heritage site. It was built in the 12th century by the rulers Stephan Namanja and his son Stephan the First-Crowned, of Nemanjic dynasty, and later expanded by other rulers. There are 3 churches (one was closed), as well as ruins of another one, monastic residences and other buidings. Churches are adorned with amazing frescoes from different periods, the most famous and well preserved one being the Crucifixion, fron 1209,  in the main church.
