The Airavatesvara temple complex, built by Rajaraja II, at Darasuram features a 24-m vimana and a stone image of Shiva. The temples testify to the brilliant achievements of the Chola in architecture, sculpture, painting and bronze casting.

reviews.text:
It’s an ancient temple with chozha architecture, some renovation is going on,it’s Siva temple but couldn’t find a name
The architecture matches with Tanjore temples, one more temple sri Bramha purishwarar is also near by which is completely filled with inscriptions

Great historical place.The Chola temples, built during the reign of the Chola dynasty in ancient South India, are architectural marvels that continue to captivate visitors to this day. These temples, dedicated to Hindu deities, are known for their intricate craftsmanship, grandeur, and spiritual significance.

One remarkable feature of Chola temples is their architectural style. They exhibit a perfect blend of creativity, precision, and structural integrity. The temples are characterized by towering gopurams (entrance gateways), intricate stone carvings depicting mythological stories, and intricately carved pillars. The sculptures and artwork found within the temples are truly awe-inspiring, showcasing the talent and skill of the artisans of that era.

Moreover, Chola temples served not only as places of worship but also as cultural and social centers. They were centers of learning, where scholars gathered to discuss philosophy, science, and literature. The temples also hosted vibrant festivals and religious ceremonies that brought communities together.

Visiting a Chola temple today offers a glimpse into the rich heritage and spirituality of ancient India. The serene atmosphere, the divine presence, and the architectural magnificence create an aura of tranquility and awe. Exploring the temple complex, one can admire the intricate details of the sculptures, marvel at the towering structures, and experience a deep sense of reverence.

In conclusion, Chola temples are a testament to the architectural brilliance and cultural richness of the Chola dynasty. Their timeless beauty and historical significance make them a must-visit for anyone interested in history, art, and spirituality.

Built during the 11th and the 12th centuries, the Living Temples at Thanjavur are a UNESCO World Heritage Site in Tamil Nadu. The construction of the temples is attributed to the Chola Dynasty who ruled southern India from 200-1246 AD. The temples are dedicated to the Hindu deity Shiva and are remarkable examples of Dravidian architecture.

Get set to undertake an adventurous journey back in time by visiting the trio of three great Chola temples: Brihadeshwara Temple at Tanjore, Airavateshwara Temple in Darasuram, and Brihadeeshwara Temple in Gangaikonda Cholapuram. The three temples were built by the kings of Chola dynasty which was one of the greatest kingdoms of South India. The ones at Tanjore and Cholapuram were built in the 11th century while the one at Darasuram was built in the 12th century.

Interesting fact: Raja Raja Cholan was inspired to build the Brihadeshwara Temple at Tanjore due to a dream he had while visiting Sri Lanka.
Entry fee: None
Open from: 6.30 am to 8.30 pm (The temples are shut from 12 pm to 4pm)
Must see: The first royal portrait at Brihadeshwara Temple where Raja Raja Cholan can be seen paying obeisance to Lord Natarajar.
Built By: Emperor Rajaraja
Built In: 1010
One of the most breathtaking experiences 😍 Architectural Wonder n Craftsmanship

Name: Sundarbans National Park
short_description: The Sundarbans covers 10,000 km2 of land and water (more than half of it in India, the rest in Bangladesh) in the Ganges delta. It contains the world's largest area of mangrove forests. A number of rare or endangered species live in the park, including tigers, aquatic mammals, birds and reptiles.

reviews.text: Sundarbans National Park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1987, is renowned for its unique ecosystem and the elusive Royal Bengal Tiger. Visitors often describe the park as a paradise for nature enthusiasts, offering a rich tapestry of mangrove forests and diverse wildlife. One traveler shared their experience, noting that the Sundarbans is a delta region with much to offer its admirers.  Another visitor, on their sixth trip to the park, expressed their fascination with its unparalleled natural beauty and the thrill of spotting a tiger after multiple visits.  While tiger sightings are rare and require patience, the park's serene environment and biodiversity make it a worthwhile destination for those seeking an immersive wilderness experience.

This destination is an excellent choice for a short getaway from Kolkata, perfect for a day or two. While there aren’t a plethora of activities, the boat rides are truly delightful and provide a rich experience. Cruising through the serene waters allows you to soak in the natural beauty of the surroundings, making it a relaxing escape from city life. If you’re interested in spotting a tiger, plan your visit during the mating season, as this increases your chances of seeing these majestic animals in their natural habitat. However, it’s best to avoid visiting during the summer months, as temperatures can soar, making boat rides less enjoyable. The heat can detract from the overall experience, so visiting during the cooler months will enhance your trip. Overall, this place offers a peaceful retreat with beautiful scenery and the opportunity to connect with nature. Whether you’re seeking relaxation or a bit of adventure, it’s a worthwhile destination close to Kolkata. Embrace the charm of the area, enjoy the boat rides, and keep an eye out for wildlife, making your outing both memorable and enriching.

The largest mangrove forest of india, home to many kind of wild animals, birds, reptiles and the royal bengal tiger. A must visit if you want to explore the wild side of nature as well as connect to the simple village life, where people have to fight with nature and the animals for their livelihood.

Sundarbans is a mangrove forest area in the Ganges Delta formed by the confluence of the Ganges, Brahmaputra and Meghna Rivers in the Bay of Bengal. Spread across parts of India and Bangladesh, this forest is the largest mangrove forest in the world. The Sundarbans Reserve Forest (SRF), located in the south-west of Bangladesh between the river Baleswar in the East and the Harinbanga in the West, adjoining to the Bay of Bengal, is the largest contiguous mangrove forest in the world.The Sundarbans is home to over 100 Bengal tigers, one of the largest single populations of tigers in one area.

Very nice place for refreshing our family members and you can see tiger,deer, different types of bird, crocodile, turtles, monkey,kvi kavi rhinoceros
So very informative guide

Name: Venice and its Lagoon
short_description: Founded in the 5th century and spread over 118 small islands, Venice became a major maritime power in the 10th century. The whole city is an extraordinary architectural masterpiece in which even the smallest building contains works by some of the world's greatest artists such as Giorgione, Titian, Tintoretto, Veronese and others.
formatted_address: Venetian Lagoon, Metropolitan City of Venice, Italy

reviews.text: It is a perfect city. Nights are much more interesting and beautiful. Italy is the most magnificent country in the world. Homeland of art, music and pleasure

The Venice Lagoon is an awe-inspiring and enchanting natural wonder that captivates the soul. As one of the most iconic and historically significant landmarks in the world, it offers an experience like no other.

Stepping into the Venice Lagoon feels like entering a timeless dream, where centuries-old architecture and Venetian charm blend seamlessly with the tranquil waters. The unique network of canals and waterways, elegantly traversed by gondolas and vaporettos, creates an atmosphere of romance and adventure that is unparalleled.

The lagoon's beauty is further enhanced by the stunning architecture of the city, with magnificent palaces, churches, and bridges that seem to float atop the water. The craftsmanship and artistry of these structures are a testament to the rich history and cultural heritage of Venice.

Exploring the Venice Lagoon unveils a world of hidden gems and cultural treasures. From the majestic St. Mark's Square and the iconic St. Mark's Basilica to the artistic wonders housed in the city's museums and galleries, there's no shortage of sights to behold and stories to uncover.

As the sun sets over the lagoon, the city takes on a magical glow, adding an extra layer of charm to its already mesmerizing ambiance. The play of light on the water and the reflections of the architecture create an ethereal scene that leaves a lasting impression.

However, it's essential to remember that the Venice Lagoon faces challenges, including rising sea levels and overtourism. Preserving this unique ecosystem and cultural treasure is crucial for future generations to experience the beauty and history it holds.

Visiting the Venice Lagoon is an unforgettable journey that touches the heart and sparks the imagination. Its timeless allure, artistic splendor, and romantic atmosphere make it a must-see destination for anyone seeking a transformative and enriching travel experience.
Enchanted place, that only locals know, id est almost free of tourists by now, and full of birds and a wonderful nature. A paradise for rowers too.
One of the most beautiful and stunning places i've ever been to. Wonderful atmosphere, incredible architecture and buildings, definitely worth a visit!
One of most mesmerizing place on this planet earth.

Name: Piazza del Duomo, Pisa
short_description: Standing in a large green expanse, Piazza del Duomo houses a group of monuments known the world over. These four masterpieces of medieval architecture – the cathedral, the baptistry, the campanile (the 'Leaning Tower') and the cemetery – had a great influence on monumental art in Italy from the 11th to the 14th century.
formatted_address: Piazza del Duomo, 56126 Pisa PI, Italy

Name: Sian Ka'an
short_description: In the language of the Mayan peoples who once inhabited this region, Sian Ka'an means 'Origin of the Sky'. Located on the east coast of the Yucatán peninsula, this biosphere reserve contains tropical forests, mangroves and marshes, as well as a large marine section intersected by a barrier reef. It provides a habitat for a remarkably rich flora and a fauna comprising more than 300 species of birds, as well as a large number of the region's characteristic terrestrial vertebrates, which cohabit in the diverse environment formed by its complex hydrological system.

reviews.text: This reserve is so big; we really enjoyed the trip; warching the birds; first time saw spoonbills; they are so beautiful. We could also see the ruins. The best part is floating in the very cool and clear water of the Mayan canal. Luckily we could spot the manatee, but very fast so not very clearly

Incredible experience. We were staying in Playa Del Carmen and had a 1+ hour transport to get there but it was completely worth it.

Manuel was an amazing guide. Speaking three languages and effortlessly switching between we had every question no matter how small answered.

We're so lucky to see 3 manatees and crocodiles. Will never forget the lazy float down the river. An unforgettable experience!

We entered from Tulum. The guy asked for $250 pesos each. The road was a disaster - 1 mile took us 40 min just to get to a dirty beach covered with garbage. Will try to go from Muyil next time and hopefully it’ll work. Whatever you do don’t go through Tulum!
Wonderful place to watch different animals and enjoy the mangroves and spectacular water of Punta Allen .

if u wanna go by car or moto its wastw of your time, car suspension and money. they charge for enter to place where is nothing interesting, after 15km you arrive to the beach full of rubbish. on the way there are teo or three ugly restaurants, you have to pay even to enter. all 15km beach side there are private villas hidden behind big gates. the road is no comment. its not worth even 1peso. dont go there!

Name: Pre-Hispanic City and National Park of Palenque
short_description: A prime example of a Mayan sanctuary of the classical period, Palenque was at its height between AD 500 and 700, when its influence extended throughout the basin of the Usumacinta River. The elegance and craftsmanship of the buildings, as well as the lightness of the sculpted reliefs with their Mayan mythological themes, attest to the creative genius of this civilization.
formatted_address: Carretera a Palenque- Zona Archaeologica Km. 8, 29960 Palenque, Chiapas, Mexico

reviews.text: This is one of my favourite places in Mexico. A lot of pyramids surrounded by beautiful greenery all around you. Many vendors selling so many beautiful things. I strongly advise to visit this place early in the morning because of the people and the weather. We visited the place in late April.

We have visited Teotihuacan and Tikal ruins, and here in Palenque, the jungle ruins are on equal level - simply stunning experience! Don't miss the small museum. 2 surprises are held within. A recreation of Pakal's sarcaphogus and an entire room with the restored clothing and funeral mask of Pakal's wife (The Red Queen)!
For international guests: from Palenque Centro Google maps Colectivo to ruins. White vans have small window sign RUINAS. 25 pesos per person. These drivers will take you to the parking/entrance to the large buildings of the ticket office. Walk the length of the parking through a few buildings to the Taquerilla. Here, line up to the right at NIH for federal price $215 /person. Then, line up at the left for entry cost to the archeological site $100 pesos. Recieve the paper bracelet and receipt with QR to pass through security entrance. Now you can choose to walk (uphill) 4kms to the site entry or pay $60pesos round trip (or pay one way 30$ and take a chance a direct van appears for Centro while exiting the site or down at the museum) for a second colectivo to drive to the site entry. Receive a 2nd bracelet for proof of transport payment. Remember, this van returns only to the parking/ticket area. You still need a van to take you back to Palenque Centro 25$ pesos. The museum is free. Worth it! The nature hike in the jungle to The Forgotten Temple and Motiepa waterfall is wonderful... listen for the howler monkeys

During our vacation in Mexico we visited quite a few ruins, but this place made a lasting impression.

From the parking lot, we left the beaten track with our guide and entered the jungle. While walking our guide told us in detail how agriculture and mother earth is all connected, how the way of living were decided through the Mayan calender and the connected events.

Suddenly as we entered a clearing in the morning mist we had a glimpse of the ruins. The scene was as taken from an Indiana Jones movie and made a lasting impression, just beutiful

We walked around and into some of the temples while our guide told us everything worth knowing. We even took an extra trip into the jungle where there are wildlife and ruins that have not yet been dug out.

We can highly recommend hiring a guide as you will get so much more out of your visit with help from an experienced person.

I very highly recommend a visit to these ruins. There is so much to learn from these original original inhabitants and their way of living.

I gave come to love this place 🥰

As a tourist, I appreciated the well-preserved of the ruins of  Palenque, for me, was a truly immersive experience.
a journey through time, culture, and nature. It's a place that will stay with me forever, and I highly recommend it to anyone seeking a deeper connection with our shared human heritage.

The ruins are truly stunning but don't skip the jungle portion which is gorgeous, very interesting but does require you to hire a guide. We got one near the entrance who spoke impeccable English and could negotiate to 800 pesos.

Name: Historic Centre of Mexico City and Xochimilco
short_description: Built in the 16th century by the Spanish on the ruins of Tenochtitlan, the old Aztec capital, Mexico City is now one of the world's largest and most densely populated cities. It has five Aztec temples, the ruins of which have been identified, a cathedral (the largest on the continent) and some fine 19th- and 20th-century public buildings such as the Palacio de las Bellas Artes. Xochimilco lies 28 km south of Mexico City. With its network of canals and artificial islands, it testifies to the efforts of the Aztec people to build a habitat in the midst of an unfavourable environment. Its characteristic urban and rural structures, built since the 16th century and during the colonial period; have been preserved in an exceptional manner.
formatted_address: Historic center of Mexico City, Centro, Mexico City, CDMX, Mexico

Name: Pre-Hispanic City of Teotihuacan
short_description: The holy city of Teotihuacan ('the place where the gods were created') is situated some 50 km north-east of Mexico City. Built between the 1st and 7th centuries A.D., it is characterized by the vast size of its monuments – in particular, the Temple of Quetzalcoatl and the Pyramids of the Sun and the Moon, laid out on geometric and symbolic principles. As one of the most powerful cultural centres in Mesoamerica, Teotihuacan extended its cultural and artistic influence throughout the region, and even beyond.
formatted_address: 55825 San Martín de las Pirámides, State of Mexico, Mexico

reviews.text: Be ready to walk, a lot, and go up and down stairs (optional for getting around but you will miss many things). So many buildings and things to see, it really is incredible. Worth visiting if you can. Bathrooms spread out, lots of people selling the same stuff all over, some sell water but make sure you buy something at the entrance, or at the store next to the museum or else you will be thirsty.

A must-see stop if visiting Mexico City. It can get crowded and hot, so recommend getting there as early as possible. There is a lot of walking involved, and there are options for walking tours or self guided. Take a bottle of water and soak in the sights of these beautiful temples.

A must if you are in CDMX. It’s about a one hour drive with no traffic, take an uber. Our return trip was about 1.5 hours. We took a private driver, but it was too expensive. Save your money to get a private tour guide there! Bring cash to pay them!! There are no ATMs and guides only take cash. You learn so much and can’t truly appreciate the place without a guide. They have so much inside information that you can’t get from a guidebook. And they can point out so many details you would otherwise miss.

You can only climb one smaller pyramid now. They have a guard protecting the others so don’t get any stupid ideas. They are protecting them from collapse.

It can be way hotter there than in Mexico City. Bring a hat, sunglasses, maybe an umbrella for the sun, and a refillable water bottle. There are bathrooms, vendors and food by the entrance, then nothing after that. There are souvenir vendors inside, I wish they wouldn’t allow them as they impede some good photos of the pyramids and sites. Plus they don’t sell useful items..not one sold hats or sunglasses, water, anything a tourist might actually buy during a trip there.
My second time in my life!! It is a great historic experience. Wear comfortable shoes there is a lot of walking and put on sun block!! Do not forget a water bottle. It is a must go place.

I loved this place! You can definitely feel a powerful energy. HOWEVER! Make sure your tour isn’t a trap that takes you to several different places so you spend money before getting there! But the experience is unforgettable.

Name: Historic Centre of Oaxaca and Archaeological Site of Monte Albán
short_description: Inhabited over a period of 1,500 years by a succession of peoples – Olmecs, Zapotecs and Mixtecs – the terraces, dams, canals, pyramids and artificial mounds of Monte Albán were literally carved out of the mountain and are the symbols of a sacred topography. The nearby city of Oaxaca, which is built on a grid pattern, is a good example of Spanish colonial town planning. The solidity and volume of the city's buildings show that they were adapted to the earthquake-prone region in which these architectural gems were constructed.
formatted_address: Ignacio Bernal S/N, 71233 San Pedro Ixtlahuaca, Oax., Mexico

reviews.text:
If you love history, culture, and exploring on foot, Monte Albán is a must-visit. The site is breathtaking, both for its historical significance and the incredible energy you can feel as you walk through it.

Be sure to wear comfortable sneakers, bring a hat, plenty of water, and sunscreen—especially on sunny days, as there’s little shade.

It’s truly impressive to witness what our ancestors built and the legacy they left behind. At the entrance, there’s a small but insightful free museum, as well as a restaurant where you can grab a bite after your visit.

An unforgettable experience that I highly recommend!

This was our second visit of Monte Alban, we forgot how big and beautiful it is. This is really one of the best ruins you might found in Mexico. This place is so impressive especially due to his position on the top of the hill. This should be considered in the top list you like visiting antique site

Absolutely stunning! Monte Alban does not disappoint. It’s only about 25 minutes outside the city. Be prepared to bring good walking shoes, water, sunscreen and a hat. I would recommend going early to beat the heat. Besides the amazing ruins, there is a small free museum with artifacts, a gift shop and a small restaurant that overlooks the hills with a beautiful view. Guides in English and Spanish are available for those that want a more in depth look at the site. This is a must for any history buff.

Honestly, Monte Alban was vastly more impressive than I expected. Boasting a few nice views of Oaxaca and an impressive archaeological repertoire it is a definite plus on any itinerary to the city.

There are a few particularly nice vantage points from which to gaze down upon the Zapotec ruins. Don't skip the museum, as it houses some of the original sculptures.

The ruins of this ancient Zapotec capital make up one of the most important archaeological sites in all of Latin America.

Very impressive and spread out. A must-do if you're in/near Oaxaca. Easily accessible via taxi from Oaxaca city centre ($250 & c.20 minutes). The site is huge and good to explore at one's own pace, and can take up to two hours to see it all. There are a few paved paths, otherwise it's free-for-all so good shoes are advisable. There are some signs giving information on key sites, but to get the most out of it you may want to get a tour guide. The adjacent museum is small but worth a visit. There is a small outdoor cafe selling cold drinks. Get there early to avoid the crowds. There are many people at the start offering paid tours, which may be of interest.

Name: Historic Centre of Puebla
short_description: Puebla, which was founded ex nihilo in 1531, is situated about 100 km east of Mexico City, at the foot of the Popocatepetl volcano. It has preserved its great religious structures such as the 16th–17th-century cathedral and fine buildings like the old archbishop's palace, as well as a host of houses with walls covered in tiles (azulejos). The new aesthetic concepts resulting from the fusion of European and American styles were adopted locally and are peculiar to the Baroque district of Puebla.
formatted_address: Historic Centre of Puebla, 72000 Puebla, Mexico

Name: Ksar of Ait-Ben-Haddou
short_description: The ksar, a group of earthen buildings surrounded by high walls, is a traditional pre-Saharan habitat. The houses crowd together within the defensive walls, which are reinforced by corner towers. Ait-Ben-Haddou, in Ouarzazate province, is a striking example of the architecture of southern Morocco.

Name: Bahla Fort
short_description: The oasis of Bahla owes its prosperity to the Banu Nebhan, the dominant tribe in the area from the 12th to the end of the 15th century. The ruins of the immense fort, with its walls and towers of unbaked brick and its stone foundations, is a remarkable example of this type of fortification and attests to the power of the Banu Nebhan.

reviews.text: Magnificent, imposing world heritage site. A maze of restored, unfurnished rooms and barracks. Beautiful cafe, pottery shop, gallery, and little Honey museum within. Additional charge gains entry to the Old Mosque next door (do not miss).
This is a big one. Very nice and there is also the third oldest mosque next to it. Try to visit during evening time so you can enjoy the fort by the daylight and also the night lighting.
Incredible location, great views and historical site, friendly staff. Experience takes about 45 minutes maximum, would recommend having lunch just behind the fort.

Imense fort. Count on 2-3 hours. Many corners to visit. Many details to absorb. Minus: lack of labels, no exhibitions at all, lack of decoration in most places. There is a small coffee shop, a pottery shop and an art gallery (closed). Plentybof stairs...can become a mazze after a while. Better read something about the place beforehand otherwise will become boring. Great views over the city. Tickets a bit overpriced for tourists.

Beautiful fort showcasing the rich history of Oman. Very well maintained structure.

There are numerous rooms, chambers and pathways interconnected in a beautiful way. The views from the top, overlooking the city are amazing.

There's a cafe as well. A new pottery-making centre has opened as well.

It's good to spend ample time (atleast 2-3 hours) in this massive fortress complex to relish the beauty of its architecture and the vibes of the place.

Definitely worth a visit!

Name: Manú National Park
short_description: This huge 1.5 million-ha park has successive tiers of vegetation rising from 150 to 4,200 m above sea-level. The tropical forest in the lower tiers is home to an unrivalled variety of animal and plant species. Some 850 species of birds have been identified and rare species such as the giant otter and the giant armadillo also find refuge there. Jaguars are often sighted in the park.

reviews.text: An incredible remote place, river level was very low when we visited. The rainforest here is some of the most amazing we’ve ever seen. Nice lodges too

Went on a 4d/3n tour in Manu National Park it felt fairly authentic and you got to spend a lot of time in the jungle. The food at the lodges were great and well crafted with little resources. The guides were very knowledgeable and accommodating to specific wants. The activities are good, you can hike up a mountain for a couple hours to see monkeys or take a motor canoe to a good hiking spot with balsam rafts and get lucky and see a white cayman. Overall I was happy with my time in Manu but be aware it is a 10+ hour bus ride from Cusco.

The amazon basin in peru, stretching into Bolivia and Brazil, is a truly untouched piece of the planet where you could trek for days without any signs of human life. Wild life is plenty, from all kinds of insects, to jaguars, snakes, crocodiles and massive butterflies to immense large trees and flowers that can be only found this part of the planet. To see wildlife you might want to spend 1 to 2 weeks at minimum. Besides walking you can go by boat on the river as no other forms of transport will be going here. As long as this is still there, and as long as you are phycapable of doing this, you definitely should. You can and should only go with a team including a guide. Treks can be organized from bigger cities in Peru.

A truly unique and interesting part of our beautiful world.
Reaching the national park is an 8-10 hours if drive, mostly on gravel and dirt roads. As you descend from the higher elevation levels of the park, you will see different rainforests and different wildlife. Manu is the most diverse rainforest ecosystem: they have the complete animal food-chain, not simply great quantity of certain spieces as other part of the Amazonas. A trip to Manu is eye-opening and challenging, and might not be for the week-hearthed.
Spent 7 days 6 nights. Could have spent a few more

Name: Cathedral, Alcázar and Archivo de Indias in Seville
short_description: Together these three buildings form a remarkable monumental complex in the heart of Seville. The cathedral and the Alcázar – dating from the Reconquest of 1248 to the 16th century and imbued with Moorish influences – are an exceptional testimony to the civilization of the Almohads as well as that of Christian Andalusia. The Giralda minaret is the masterpiece of Almohad architecture. It stands next to the cathedral with its five naves; the largest Gothic building in Europe, it houses the tomb of Christopher Columbus. The ancient Lonja, which became the Archivo de Indias, contains valuable documents from the archives of the colonies in the Americas.
formatted_address: Av. de la Constitución, s/n, Casco Antiguo, 41004 Sevilla, Spain

reviews.text: What a fantastic experience.  We booked the rooftop tour and it was an amazing way to see this beautiful building.  Our guide, Luisa, was very knowledgeable.  It was great to have the radio with headphones to hear her. If you love art and architecture, I highly recommend this tour. The tour also includes the rest of the Cathedral, the Giralda tower, and another church which is gorgeous. Very worth 20 euros.

It’s impossible to put into words the atmosphere and historical significance of this place—every inch is filled with grandeur and history. This masterpiece of Gothic architecture is truly breathtaking in both scale and beauty. Inside, you’ll find stunning stained glass windows, majestic vaulted ceilings, and priceless works of art. Climbing the Giralda rewards you with a breathtaking panoramic view of Seville. You can feel the centuries of history come alive in every detail. A must-visit spot that leaves a lasting impression!

Absolutely stunning cathedral! The outside is a Gothic marvel with the Giralda tower stealing the show—gorgeous details everywhere you look. Inside, it’s just as breathtaking: the massive altar, stained glass, and Columbus’s tomb make it unforgettable. A must-visit in Seville, though it can get crowded—go early if you can!

The Seville Cathedral is a stunning masterpiece, renowned for its breathtaking beauty and immense size. It is the largest Gothic cathedral in the world and a UNESCO World Heritage site, showcasing intricate architectural details, magnificent artwork, and a rich history that spans centuries. The grandeur of its design and the impressive Giralda Tower make it a must-see landmark in Seville 🤩🧡

The Catedral de Sevilla (Seville Cathedral) is one of the most stunning and monumental Gothic cathedrals in the world! It’s a must-see when visiting Seville. The sheer size and intricate detail of the architecture are awe-inspiring, with towering spires, beautiful stained glass windows, and ornate chapels throughout.

Inside, you'll find the tomb of Christopher Columbus, which adds an extra layer of historical significance to the cathedral. The Giralda Tower, originally a minaret, offers panoramic views of the city after a climb to the top—well worth the effort!

The cathedral is located in the heart of Seville, surrounded by beautiful gardens and other historical sites. Whether you’re drawn to its architecture, history, or religious significance, the Seville Cathedral is an unforgettable experience.

Name: Nemrut Dağ
short_description: The mausoleum of Antiochus I (69–34 B.C.), who reigned over Commagene, a kingdom founded north of Syria and the Euphrates after the breakup of Alexander's empire, is one of the most ambitious constructions of the Hellenistic period. The syncretism of its pantheon, and the lineage of its kings, which can be traced back through two sets of legends, Greek and Persian, is evidence of the dual origin of this kingdom's culture.

reviews.text: Visiting Mount Nemrut was an unforgettable experience. The colossal statues are breathtaking, especially at sunrise. The hike might be a bit challenging, but it's absolutely worth it for the stunning views and the serene atmosphere at the summit. Truly a masterpiece of ancient times, not to be missed if you're in Turkey!

Great place to see king antiochos and helenistic gods statues with the amazing view.
hint:
-be ready for 20-30 min. mountain hiking to the peak
-take some jacket or fleece regardless of the season
-facility(food, drinks) below opens in first week of April, otherwise bring some water or food with you
-east terrace has better view(personal opinion:) )
-try to catch sunset or sunrise
-follow the way of karakus tumulusu, cendere bridge(longer)
An amazing historical moment in the world

I was moved to tears when I first saw these incredible ancient statues. The half hour steep  walk up was hard on the lungs and the descent was hard on the knees. But worth the massive effort. At the top of this ancient mound are huge statues that are magical. Definitely a highlight in my exciting life. If you adore archeology and ancient art, you would love to see the sunset over this 2,000 year old site.

Great view and nice sunset experience. The statues are wild to look at, although smaller than I expected. We came from Malatya and it really does take 2hr, most of the drive is a lot of tight hill climb on decently paved road. It gets narrow in some portions, but nothing scary really. Once you get close to the top, you have to stop at a building and pay for entrance. Note that it's cash only. They say there's no signal for a card reader, although my phone worked fine. The last bit of drive is unpaved and pretty warn. If you have a little wheezy car like we did, you need to keep your momentum, there are some areas to get a running start if you botch it. It's not a vehicle I would have picked for this task, but it made it up. You can also walk, but it's at least 2km of switch backs and you're at 7700m elevation so it will take you a while.

Name: Blenheim Palace
short_description: Blenheim Palace, near Oxford, stands in a romantic park created by the famous landscape gardener 'Capability' Brown. It was presented by the English nation to John Churchill, first Duke of Marlborough, in recognition of his victory in 1704 over French and Bavarian troops. Built between 1705 and 1722 and characterized by an eclectic style and a return to national roots, it is a perfect example of an 18th-century princely dwelling.
Country name: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

reviews.text: It is a fantastic and wonderful place to visit. Plenty to see and do and all at your own pace. You do need more than one visit as you are unable to take everything in. The palace is steeped in history, and its most famous person is Sir Winston Churchill. The shop is a must and the cafe does both hot and cold food.

Beautiful! It's a magical place with so much history, you can feel it. You can go to the room where Churchill was born, see the state rooms, the chapel and visit the Churchill Museum. Gardens are also beautiful. Take your dog (not allowed inside) on the grounds for a good hike and make a day of it.

Well worth the visit! What an amazing place, the Palace itself is in such amazing condition & it really is a fantastic example of conservation. The staff were all friendly & helpful & happy to have a chat about any questions we had. The formal gardens are beautiful & you could easily spend a day just walking the grounds. For kids there is a fantastic Yew Hedge maze which is fun & very well designed. There is also The Adventure playground which is great for young kids. My one criticism would be the pricing layout & options for day only visitors,  perhaps in the future the might consider creating a day only ticket for those who don't want an annual pass, as the pricing is quite high if you aren't in a position to return on multiple occasions.

Had a fantastic Sunday evening here.
Tickets were booked a month in advance and were running out fast.
However, on site staff was not too keen to stick to the allocated slot since there was no queue. Hence we did both palace and the gardens about 1 HR earlier.

Overall the palace is amazing and well maintained. The story is very well embedded into the architecture and fits like a glove.

The gardens are a delight for sight provided it is not raining or too foggy. Be ready for a decent walk and suggest comfy shoes.

Kids loved it, and there is more than enough parking available on site. Advise you book in advance as it's easier

Enjoyed the Palace and Churchill exhibition. Glad we joined the free narrated tour as so much more information was learnt.Recommend buying tickets in advance. Would have liked to have seen more of the palace but a lot is not for tourists. We will be coming back to Woodstock to stay as it's a really good town,and as it's £38 for an annual pass gives you the opportunity to re explore the town and palace.Grounds are a good walk,and will be better in summer to view.

Name: Palace of Westminster and Westminster Abbey including Saint Margaret’s Church
short_description: Westminster Palace, rebuilt from the year 1840 on the site of important medieval remains, is a fine example of neo-Gothic architecture. The site – which also comprises the small medieval Church of Saint Margaret, built in Perpendicular Gothic style, and Westminster Abbey, where all the sovereigns since the 11th century have been crowned – is of great historic and symbolic significance.
Country name: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

reviews.text:
Visiting Westminster Abbey with my family was an unforgettable experience. From the moment we stepped inside, we were in awe of the stunning architecture, intricate details, and deep historical significance of this iconic landmark. Walking through its halls, you can truly feel the weight of centuries of British history.

Seeing the Coronation Chair, the final resting places of monarchs and legendary figures like Sir Isaac Newton and Charles Dickens, made the visit even more special. The craftsmanship of the stained glass windows and the grandeur of the high ceilings left us speechless. It’s a place that brings history to life, making it an enriching visit for the whole family.

Whether you're drawn to the royal history, the incredible artistry, or the peaceful atmosphere, Westminster Abbey is a must-see in London. It was a fantastic experience for all of us, and I highly recommend it to anyone visiting the city!

Yes we found a very nice spot to have a great view  of the Westminster Abbey. A very quiet park connected to the Westminster school. Via this place you can enter the cafe of Westminster Abbey. We always find it great to search for special places so you can have a better (or another) view of this historical building.

Awe-Inspiring and Humbling Experience

Westminster Abbey is absolutely breathtaking — a place where history, art, and humanity’s greatest achievements all come together. Walking through it is overwhelming in the best way — every corner, every stone, and every memorial tells the story of people who have contributed so much to mankind. From poets and scientists to monarchs and visionaries, the sheer number of brilliant minds and influential figures honored here is staggering.

The architecture is stunning, the atmosphere reverent, and the sense of history palpable. It’s impossible not to feel moved standing among the tombs and memorials of those who shaped the world. Visiting Westminster Abbey isn’t just sightseeing — it’s an experience of reflection and wonder. Truly unforgettable.

An amazing place if you love history and architecture. One of the oldest abbeys in England. It’s under the Church of England religion. This is where many of the monarchs are buried and also lots of monuments to other famous people in history. The self guided audio tour was easy to navigate and gave lots of useful information about the history of the abbey. There’s also an amazing upstairs special exhibit you can add to your ticket and definitely worth the additional £5 Even if you’re not religious the history alone is worth the visit.

Westminster Abbey is a masterpiece of Gothic architecture, renowned for its stunning stained glass windows and intricate stone carvings.
As the traditional site for English and British coronations since 1066, it holds immense historical significance.
The Abbey also serves as the final resting place for numerous monarchs and notable figures, offering a profound journey through British history.
Visitors can explore the Queen’s Diamond Jubilee Galleries, which showcase a remarkable collection of artifacts spanning over a millennium.
An audio guide is available to enrich your visit with detailed insights into the Abbey’s storied past. ￼

Name: City of Bath
short_description: Founded by the Romans as a thermal spa, Bath became an important centre of the wool industry in the Middle Ages. In the 18th century, under George III, it developed into an elegant town with neoclassical Palladian buildings, which blend harmoniously with the Roman baths.
Country name: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

Name: Kilimanjaro National Park
short_description: At 5,895 m, Kilimanjaro is the highest point in Africa. This volcanic massif stands in splendid isolation above the surrounding plains, with its snowy peak looming over the savannah. The mountain is encircled by mountain forest. Numerous mammals, many of them endangered species, live in the park.

reviews.text: What can I say. This is an experience you can only say you fully appreciate and would do again AFTER you fully complete it. Every day was an experience. I loved every single day except the final day. I did love it for what I achieved along with the rent of my team because it was exceptionally hard. But it was an amazing experience only a handful of people can say they have done. #Actionchallenge was my choice of agent to use to escort us to the summit and I do not regret a moment. They were professional in every aspect. My choice of clothing was #Craghoppers as they were affordable, light and perfect for all climates. Amongst this journey I made so many fantastic friends whom I have stayed in touch with and have met up with again since. Highly recommend. Tanzania is a wonderful country.
One of the best hikes I’ve made. Beautiful yet quite easy. If you get to travel to Tanzania go for Kilimanjaro as well

Climbing Kilimanjaro was one of the biggest adventures of my life. I had to fight elevation sickness during final push but I made it in the end. We went for 7 days Machame route with Seregenti Joy Tours with an amazing guide Baraka.

I summited Mount Kilimanjaro with the tour company Jambo Kilimanjaro Voyage and they were amazing! Our guides and staff were super nice and patient. We did the 7 Day Machame and it had amazing views. Highly recommend this local company as Frances and his team were 5 Stars! Very safe and treated our group like family. Thank you for the lifetime memory. Take extra gear and leave for the staff if you can. They will definitely appreciate it.

Mount Kilimanjaro, Tanzania 🇹🇿

👉 It is the highest peak in Africa and one of the most iconic and sought-after trekking destinations in the world.

👉 Mount Kilimanjaro is located in northeastern Tanzania, near the border with Kenya.

👉 It is within Kilimanjaro National Park, a UNESCO World Heritage site.

👉 The summit of Mount Kilimanjaro, known as Uhuru Peak, stands at an impressive 5,895 meters (19,341 feet) above sea level, making it the highest free-standing mountain in the world

Follow Page 👆

#mountkilimanjaro #tanzania #africa #tour #world #tourists #tanzaniasafari #tanzaniaunforgettable #tanzanianationalparks #tanzaniatourism #tanzaniaweddings #animals #tanzaniafashion #Amazon #AngelinaJolie #artist #anime #affordable #toyota

Name: Chaco Culture
short_description: For over 2,000 years, Pueblo peoples occupied a vast region of the south-western United States. Chaco Canyon, a major centre of ancestral Pueblo culture between 850 and 1250, was a focus for ceremonials, trade and political activity for the prehistoric Four Corners area. Chaco is remarkable for its monumental public and ceremonial buildings and its distinctive architecture – it has an ancient urban ceremonial centre that is unlike anything constructed before or since. In addition to the Chaco Culture National Historical Park, the World Heritage property includes the Aztec Ruins National Monument and several smaller Chaco sites managed by the Bureau of Land Management.

reviews.text: Chaco canyon offers absolutely amazing Indian ruins in excellent condition, you can walk around on designated paths. I do believe they have guides you can hire to tour you around the ruins and give some history. The ruins are pretty far apart so you definitely need to be driving or biking. One thing that surprised us, we came in on a Google route from the north and that road was a pretty rough dirt road. I wouldn't want to be in a little car.

Beautiful and remote archaeological site. The road in and out is rough and I would suggest going under the suggested speed limit and therefore adding time to the Google maps estimate. It is an amazing opportunity to interact in the ruins themselves and go for a longer hikes through the desert. Make sure you fill your tank before you head out as there are no services for quite a distance around this site.
Incredible ruins. Amazing Petroglyphs. Remote and no cell service. Campgrounds have no hook ups (elec. or water) for campers. Bathrooms have flush toilets and are heated, no showers.

Yes... The road to this area is pure hell. It starts out being paved from Hwy 550 and paved around the park property but in between that is washboard hell... I'm probably missing a few nuts and bolts off the truck... Not sure why the part in between cannot be paved. The jaring, vibrating, shaky ride there is almost worth it to see and explore the many ancient dwellings, petroglyphs, etc. Would I ever return? No, not until the road is fully paved. I recommend the park but I do not recommend to horrible ride there!

First of all let me just say, if you are planning on bringing a rental car here, good luck. This is possibly the worst road I’ve ever driven on in my life. Huge potholes, ditches, it will DESTROY a car that is not meant for terrain. That being said, the site itself is incredible! Lots of stuff to see, lots of stuff to walk around and explore. And really fascinating stories and facts to gather along the way. Definitely recommend if you find yourself out here

Name: Hawaii Volcanoes National Park
short_description: This site contains two of the most active volcanoes in the world, Mauna Loa (4,170 m high) and Kilauea (1,250 m high), both of which tower over the Pacific Ocean. Volcanic eruptions have created a constantly changing landscape, and the lava flows reveal surprising geological formations. Rare birds and endemic species can be found there, as well as forests of giant ferns.
formatted_address: Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, HI 96785, USA

Name: Monticello and the University of Virginia in Charlottesville
short_description: Thomas Jefferson (1743–1826), author of the American Declaration of Independence and third president of the United States, was also a talented architect of neoclassical buildings. He designed Monticello (1769–1809), his plantation home, and his ideal 'academical village' (1817–26), which is still the heart of the University of Virginia. Jefferson's use of an architectural vocabulary based upon classical antiquity symbolizes both the aspirations of the new American republic as the inheritor of European tradition and the cultural experimentation that could be expected as the country matured.

reviews.text: We've been wanting to visit here for years and finally made the trip this past fall. AMAZING! It was surreal visiting Thomas Jefferson's home, seeing things he owned, made and used, and walked where he walked. The tour takes you to the grounds, through his home, and the tunnels under the home. You will learn a lot here. I would recommend this to anyone interested! I'm hoping to go back soon to see some of the other famous homes in the area.

What an incredible experience I had at Monticello. The history of this place is fascinating. I enjoyed the tour and the reconstructions of the buildings. I can tell that much care and concern was put into restoring this location. I believe this is an excellent place to recount the history of Thomas Jefferson and to learn more about the blemished history of slavery in our country.

Beautiful home, views and gardens! Such an amazing home for such an important person in our history. They do try and paint the full story here and include the good and the bad. There’s so much to take in, between the stunning views and gardens (especially in the spring and summer). To the house with so many cool inventions and beautiful architecture. To the grounds and museum at the start. You can spend many hours here

I came here for a school trip, and it was amazing to go on a tour and see and hear all of the history this place has to offer. Our tour guide was nice, and very informative and knowledgeable. I recommend coming to see this place!

We did the Behind the Scenes tour which allows you to go to the second and third floors, including the dome room.  Well worth it! Our guide, Bob, was amazing and very informative.  I learned a lot about Thomas Jefferson as a person and not just as a president.

Name: Frontiers of the Roman Empire
short_description: The ‘Roman Limes’ represents the border line of the Roman Empire at its greatest extent in the 2nd century AD. It stretched over 5,000 km from the Atlantic coast of northern Britain, through Europe to the Black Sea, and from there to the Red Sea and across North Africa to the Atlantic coast. The remains of the Limes today consist of vestiges of built walls, ditches, forts, fortresses, watchtowers and civilian settlements. Certain elements of the line have been excavated, some reconstructed and a few destroyed. The two sections of the Limes in Germany cover a length of 550 km from the north-west of the country to the Danube in the south-east. The 118-km-long Hadrian’s Wall (UK) was built on the orders of the Emperor Hadrian c. AD 122 at the northernmost limits of the Roman province of Britannia. It is a striking example of the organization of a military zone and illustrates the defensive techniques and geopolitical strategies of ancient Rome. The Antonine Wall, a 60-km long fortification in Scotland was started by Emperor Antonius Pius in 142 AD as a defense against the “barbarians” of the north. It constitutes the northwestern-most portion of the Roman Limes.
Country name: Germany,United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

reviews.text: Besides the weather it was very enjoyable.  Information provided was succinct and interesting.  The exhibition at the entrance was  particularly well designed and set out.
Absolutely loved it and love the staff. Dog friendly which is brilliant. Well worth visiting.

Such a cool piece of English history, definitely worth a visit, even if it's for a nice walk. The car park is paid, but the rate is not expensive. There's a little field with sheep, so be aware when bringing pets or little ones with you.

Had a great walk along the wall. There are plenty of places to stop and see amazing views that have almost been untouched.
Got a very lucky day with good weather for some great pics.

Came on short day trip and left wanting to organise a weeks hiking trip with Friends.

Simply beautiful country side and with museums and historically important places right along its length .

I loved the view over the bridge crossing the Irving

Name: Wet Tropics of Queensland
short_description: This area, which stretches along the north-east coast of Australia for some 450 km, is made up largely of tropical rainforests. This biotope offers a particularly extensive and varied array of plants, as well as marsupials and singing birds, along with other rare and endangered animals and plant species.
formatted_address: Cashmere Kirrama Rd, Kirrama QLD 4872, Australia

reviews.text: Beautiful clean location.  Great for family camping.
The most amzing falls I have seen in Australia

Name: Manovo-Gounda St Floris National Park
short_description: The importance of this park derives from its wealth of flora and fauna. Its vast savannahs are home to a wide variety of species: black rhinoceroses, elephants, cheetahs, leopards, wild dogs, red-fronted gazelles and buffalo, while various types of waterfowl are to be found in the northern floodplains.

reviews.text:
In the Central African Republic, the Manovo Gounda St Floris National Park is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

It covers an area of 1,740,000 hectares of remarkable natural formations. The vast savannahs support an ecosystem of a variety of flora and fauna. Mammals populating the park include many endangered species, such as black rhinos and red-fronted gazelles. The Dzanga-Ndoki National Park, another conservation area in the country, is part of the transboundary UNESCO World Heritage Site "Sangha Trinational," which is emblematic of the humid tropical forests across the Congo Basin. #TheNewSilkRoad.
amazing! a rhino ate my child :sadface: but worth it for the flick

Parc National du Manovo-Gounda-Saint Floris is a national nature reserve in the Central African Republic. This park is located in the north of the country and covers a large area of ​​about 17,400 square kilometers.

Established in 1933, Manovo Gonda Sant Flores National Park was registered as a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1988. The park has a diverse mix of natural environments including savannahs, forests, canyons and lakes, making it home to enormous biodiversity.

Manovo Gonda St. Flores Park is home to a large number of wildlife, including African elephants, giraffes, lions, leopards, leopards, gazelles, giraffes and more. The park is also home to a variety of rare birds and reptiles.

However, the protected areas face significant environmental challenges including poaching, desertification and loss of natural habitats, which threaten the region's wildlife. Therefore, the local government, in cooperation with nature conservation organizations, works to protect this reserve and preserve its unique biodiversity.
Fortified peasant fortress - Harman conundrum, Brasov county
This place is really magnificent, I really liked it.

Name: Trinidad and the Valley de los Ingenios
short_description: Founded in the early 16th century in honour of the Holy Trinity, the city was a bridgehead for the conquest of the American continent. Its 18th- and 19th-century buildings, such as the Palacio Brunet and the Palacio Cantero, were built in its days of prosperity from the sugar trade.

reviews.text: We drove from Trinidad through the Valley of the Sugar Mills before finally exploring the very historical site of the Hacienda Manaca Iznaga. We found a lookout and the views were superb. There is no prize for guessing how the valley got its name. But unfortunately the beauty of the countryside masks the terrible slavery that went on in the production of sugar cane.
Amazing view
Worth the stop for the view!
Great views to both the valley and the sea side. Worth a stop over.
Beautiful we stopped here after a bike tour to get refreshments

Name: Strasbourg, Grande-Île and Neustadt
short_description: The initial property, inscribed in 1988 on the World Heritage List, was formed by the Grande-Île, the historic centre of Strasbourg, structured around the cathedral. The extension concerns the Neustadt, new town, designed and built under the German administration (1871-1918). The Neustadt draws the inspiration for its urban layout partially from the Haussmannian model, while adopting an architectural idiom of Germanic inspiration. This dual influence has enabled the creation of an urban space that is specific to Strasbourg, where the perspectives created around the cathedral open to a unified landscape around the rivers and canals.

reviews.text: An island located in Strasbourg.It has it's simbolical houses which are beautiful.The river Ill is also stunning and it is a must go in Strasbourg.
Amazing night show, beauty! Can’t beat German buildings in France.

The Grande Île is an island that lies at the historic centre of the city of Strasbourg in France. Its name means "Large Island", and derives from the fact that it is surrounded on one side by the main channel of the Ill river and on the other side by the Canal du Faux-Rempart, a canalised arm of that river.

La Grande Île in Strasbourg is a nostalgic treasure, where history whispers through its cobblestone streets and half-timbered houses.

As you wander, the majestic silhouette of the Strasbourg Cathedral looms overhead, a constant reminder of the city's rich past.
The vibrant atmosphere, filled with the aroma of freshly baked pastries and the sounds of laughter from nearby cafés, evokes memories of leisurely afternoons spent exploring its charming alleys. Each corner reveals a story, from the quaint shops to the scenic canals that reflect the enchanting architecture.

This UNESCO World Heritage site captures the essence of Strasbourg, blending French and German influences, making it a unique cultural gem. La Grande Île is not just a place to visit; it's a journey through time, leaving you with a longing to return to its timeless beauty.
Nice place but very crowded at the weekend, we couldn’t find a place to eat at any restaurant around almost for an hour.

Name: Mount Athos
short_description: An Orthodox spiritual centre since 1054, Mount Athos has enjoyed an autonomous statute since Byzantine times. The 'Holy Mountain', which is forbidden to women and children, is also a recognized artistic site. The layout of the monasteries (about 20 of which are presently inhabited by some 1,400 monks) had an influence as far afield as Russia, and its school of painting influenced the history of Orthodox art.

Name: Meteora
short_description: In a region of almost inaccessible sandstone peaks, monks settled on these 'columns of the sky' from the 11th century onwards. Twenty-four of these monasteries were built, despite incredible difficulties, at the time of the great revival of the eremetic ideal in the 15th century. Their 16th-century frescoes mark a key stage in the development of post-Byzantine painting.

reviews.text: This is a must-visit. There just isn't anything else like it. The atmosphere, feeling of majesty and the experience of being there is just mind-blowing. I feel like my visit has broadened my experience of what could be in this world. The sense of adventure and excitement in visiting each monastery was excellent, and some of the frescoes which did not allow photography were very awesome.

A surreal place. We came by bus tour. I recommend it as I don’t know how we would have managed the tolls and the parking. It was wonderful. Amazing nature views with monasteries on every rock. Amazing history.

This is an incredible place to visit. The mountains are just stunning and it's blissfully peaceful in the monasteries. If you have a free day in Athens I would definitely recommend Meteora as a day trip. It's a bit of a long drive(6 hours), and it was a bit rushed when we visited so I would definitely recommend staying for 2 days.

Breathtakingly magnificent!

Visited 3 monasteries and had a good workout. Please be prepared to walk.

It’s recommended to join a small group tour as going to monasteries may be a challenging.

Absolutely loved this experience. Truly remarkable views, we visited the inside of 2 Monistaries but Great Meteora was closed. We went on a tour with Booking.com and it was fantastic,  the best thing I ever did. The tour guide went over and beyond   explained everything in great detail and was even happy to help with taking photos.

Name: Paleochristian and Byzantine Monuments of Thessalonika
short_description: Founded in 315 B.C., the provincial capital and sea port of Thessalonika was one of the first bases for the spread of Christianity. Among its Christian monuments are fine churches, some built on the Greek cross plan and others on the three-nave basilica plan. Constructed over a long period, from the 4th to the 15th century, they constitute a diachronic typological series, which had considerable influence in the Byzantine world. The mosaics of the rotunda, St Demetrius and St David are among the great masterpieces of early Christian art.

reviews.text: An archaeological site are the tombs of the early Christian era, as was most of the present area. A particular problem was the underground water currents that descended into the area, which brought the dead to the surface. There is no marking and no attempt to highlight the site as an archaeological attraction by the municipality! They recently put up bars so that illegal acts don't continue in the area!

That's a little crazy. Historical stones that would be a sensation in many other cities are vegetating here. I happened to pass by and wondered what that was...

So please, you can do more with it. So it's a neglected piece of history!

Unfortunately a gem left to its own devices. It's a shame that these ancient pre-Christian monuments are not highlighted. There is a hidden connection with the church of Saint Dimitrios and of course beyond it with the rest of the churches of Thessaloniki.  it's a shame they don't use them as attractions. But if they did, history would have to change.
Early Christian temple of the first half of the 5th century AD. at the junction of Lagadas and Agios Dimitrios streets, of a cemetery character, perhaps connected with the martyrdom of Saint Nestor.
Overgrown, you can see what is under the bridge to which there is no passage

Name: Sanctuary of Asklepios at Epidaurus
short_description: In a small valley in the Peloponnesus, the shrine of Asklepios, the god of medicine, developed out of a much earlier cult of Apollo (Maleatas), during the 6th century BC at the latest, as the official cult of the city state of Epidaurus. Its principal monuments, particularly the temple of Asklepios, the Tholos and the Theatre - considered one of the purest masterpieces of Greek architecture – date from the 4th century. The vast site, with its temples and hospital buildings devoted to its healing gods, provides valuable insight into the healing cults of Greek and Roman times.

reviews.text:
The Stadium at the Asclepieion of Epidaurus isn't just a site; it's a living, breathing piece of history that encapsulates the spirit of ancient Greek athleticism and healing. This visit was nothing short of magical, transporting me back to an era where sport and medicine were intertwined in the most profound ways.

Located next to the famed Sanctuary of Asklepios, this stadium is a testament to the architectural prowess and cultural sophistication of ancient Greece. The moment you step onto the sacred ground, you're enveloped by a sense of awe. The remnants of the starting lines, the semi-circular seating for spectators, and the panoramic views of the surrounding Peloponnese countryside create an unforgettable ambiance.

What struck me most was the harmonious blend of nature with man-made structures; olive trees and wildflowers now grow where once athletes competed, adding a layer of peace to this energetic venue of the past. The acoustics, even in ruins, hint at the vibrant gatherings that once filled these spaces with cheers and the sounds of competition.

The experience of walking down the ancient path toward the starting blocks, imagining the athletes preparing for their races, gives you a real sense of connection to those who came before us. This site is not just about sport; it's a celebration of human achievement, health, and the pursuit of excellence.

For anyone with a passion for history, archaeology, or simply those in search of a profound travel experience, this stadium in Epidaurus is a must-see. It’s not just a place; it's a story, an echo of our collective past, and a reminder of the enduring legacy of Greek culture. Follow balkan fam on Facebook, Instagram and check our blog page on balkanfam.com for more adventures

Fun to see, the theatre is pretty cool but not that much is left to see besides the theatre. Almost got kicked out because we were “dancing” however nowhere were we informed of any rules. The epidaurus has a lot of rules so be aware everyone

This site is a fascinating glimpse into the past, offering well-preserved ruins, informative signs, and a breathtaking setting. Walking through the ancient structures, you can truly feel the history come alive. The views are stunning, and the atmosphere is peaceful, making it a great place for exploration and reflection. Highly recommend visiting early in the morning for fewer crowds and better lighting for photos. A must-see for history enthusiasts and curious travelers alike!

Really great ancient ruins, but unfortunately like nearly all of Greece's ruins, leaves nearly all to the imagination with almost no restoration work completed and apparently no serious intention to do so.  Until much greater effort and investment is made to restore and reuse the sites, this is a once only visit attraction,  and really of low interest for kids, especially if you've already visited numerous other sites
Enjoyable trip.  The amphitheater is currently used for performances because it's natural acoustics.  You could speak at a normal voice tone and hear what is being said.

Name: Medieval City of Rhodes
short_description: The Order of St John of Jerusalem occupied Rhodes from 1309 to 1523 and set about transforming the city into a stronghold. It subsequently came under Turkish and Italian rule. With the Palace of the Grand Masters, the Great Hospital and the Street of the Knights, the Upper Town is one of the most beautiful urban ensembles of the Gothic period. In the Lower Town, Gothic architecture coexists with mosques, public baths and other buildings dating from the Ottoman period.

reviews.text: The whole city is amazing, to think this was designed so long ago, the castle and walls have all been maintained for hundreds of years, there is a few areas open to explore inside the castle for a extremely low price and alot to see around the town

An absolutely amazing bustling, beautiful medieval town with so much to see it took me two visits this time ... and I've been before. Apart from the occasional scooter rider, it's gloriously traffic free..Drink or eat away from the main squares which are often silly prices.

This was my absolutely favorite place to visit. There is a a lot to do and see here. There is also quite a few shops. My recommendation is the tour the castle first. With so many shops you might not otherwise make the castle.
This place was better than even Lindos if u ask me. We got there from our hotel by taxi (15 euros for 5 people) and spent the whole day there.

What a wonderful place to visit! Always something to see or do and of course relax! The water here is such a unique color, so beautiful and my favorite beach is Tsambica beach. Old Town or the medieval town is amazing! There are so many restaurants and shops! Have been having lots of fun going on day trips on ships and also going to various islands that are close to Rhodes. Not all these photos are old town.

Rhodes Old Town was the most beautiful and prettiest Island . The wonderful shops had the most gorgeous Turquoise/Opal jewellery and gorgeous dresses and tops in the most vibrant colours and the best choice we had seen anywhere in the other Islands we visited on our Cruise. Rhodes wad special and classy in every way from the many Cafe's, Restaurants and Bars to the warm and welcoming locals in every shop we had the pleasure to browse in. We will definitely be very happy to return to Rhodes Old Town in the near future.

Name: Nanda Devi and Valley of Flowers National Parks
short_description: Nestled high in West Himalaya, India’s Valley of Flowers National Park is renowned for its meadows of endemic alpine flowers and outstanding natural beauty. This richly diverse area is also home to rare and endangered animals, including the Asiatic black bear, snow leopard, brown bear and blue sheep. The gentle landscape of the Valley of Flowers National Park complements the rugged mountain wilderness of Nanda Devi National Park. Together they encompass a unique transition zone between the mountain ranges of the Zanskar and Great Himalaya, praised by mountaineers and botanists for over a century and in Hindu mythology for much longer.

reviews.text: Went for satopanth taal trek..trek route passed through NDNP..pristine  beauty.

This place is heavenly and worth the visit . this place requires permit to enter which you can obtain at nominal fees .

The forest and waterfalls over here are pristine and very beautiful .One must visit here.also known as the Nanda Devi National Park, is a spectacular expanse of wilderness in the upper reaches of the Himalayas. The Nanda Devi Biosphere Reserve and the Valley of Flowers, both a part of the prestigious UNESCO World Heritage List.

As you move along the way tipsy turvy curves and negotiate the hairpin bends while heading to the Govind Ghat or Badrinath, the majestic flora and fauna and nature of Nanda Devi National Park would leave you charmed. Be it the hustling river near Vishnu Prayag or the checkpoint of BRO near Govind Ghat, everything about this Biosphere reserve is phenomenal. If you are traveling in your own vehicle make sure that you stop somewhere along the road and click the stunning pics.

while doing cable cars there are sprawling greens, the ski lift is safe and very enjoyable. However, there was a problem with the power that day and we were stuck on the way there in midair for about 5-7 minutes, and had to wait around 15 minutes to be able to go back.

Trek:- trek was an amazing experience for me exploring the India's oldest Trekking route. The trek started from Ramni and ended in Auli.
Hello everyone DTS SERVICE SEY TOUR BOOK NOW AND HAPPY JOURNEY
It was a dream come true visiting Nanda Devi national park. The air, the atmosphere , the Himalayan landscape streching into the horizon all of it makes this place something very special and magical.
Inspite of rain we got the most beautiful view we could have asked for. We were lucky enough to see the Blue poppy also.

Name: Old Towns of Djenné
short_description: Inhabited since 250 B.C., Djenné became a market centre and an important link in the trans-Saharan gold trade. In the 15th and 16th centuries, it was one of the centres for the propagation of Islam. Its traditional houses, of which nearly 2,000 have survived, are built on hillocks (toguere) as protection from the seasonal floods.

Name: Timbuktu
short_description: Home of the prestigious Koranic Sankore University and other madrasas, Timbuktu was an intellectual and spiritual capital and a centre for the propagation of Islam throughout Africa in the 15th and 16th centuries. Its three great mosques, Djingareyber, Sankore and Sidi Yahia, recall Timbuktu's golden age. Although continuously restored, these monuments are today under threat from desertification.

Name: Historic Town of Guanajuato and Adjacent Mines
short_description: Founded by the Spanish in the early 16th century, Guanajuato became the world's leading silver-extraction centre in the 18th century. This past can be seen in its 'subterranean streets' and the 'Boca del Inferno', a mineshaft that plunges a breathtaking 600 m. The town's fine Baroque and neoclassical buildings, resulting from the prosperity of the mines, have influenced buildings throughout central Mexico. The churches of La Compañía and La Valenciana are considered to be among the most beautiful examples of Baroque architecture in Central and South America. Guanajuato was also witness to events which changed the history of the country.

Name: Pre-Hispanic City of Chichen-Itza
short_description: This sacred site was one of the greatest Mayan centres of the Yucatán peninsula. Throughout its nearly 1,000-year history, different peoples have left their mark on the city. The Maya and Toltec vision of the world and the universe is revealed in their stone monuments and artistic works. The fusion of Mayan construction techniques with new elements from central Mexico make Chichen-Itza one of the most important examples of the Mayan-Toltec civilization in Yucatán. Several buildings have survived, such as the Warriors’ Temple, El Castillo and the circular observatory known as El Caracol.

reviews.text:
Truly spectacular. We spent about 2 hours there and didn’t see everything but did 80%! As we were a larger group we had to cater for all needs and it got hot.

We went for around 9:15am and it’s  a little quieter, at midday it’s busy and hot!
Very informative guide through Royal Caribbean Cruises.  They do charge 60 pesos for filming.  ( we just took pics. ). Would visit again. Weather was great. A+ destination.
Great to see the Ancient Pyramids. Had a wonderful tour guide. In awe of the structures and history. Had fun with the merchants. They traded the clothing off of my husband's back. 😆

Majestic place. It's my second time visiting and I still haven't seen everything. The guided tour goes around a few main buildings, but there are many more in the jungle. Our guide David was amazing. So funny and a great story teller. It is hot, but definitely worth a visit.

A must-see historical site.
I wish they did not allow street vendors inside or created dedicated areas for them, instead of having all the side roads filled with souvenirs, and people constantly offering you to buy stuff. Ruins the magic.
We did get a beautiful hand-crafted mask but I’d rather it have been a specific are for that or the market at the end could be expanded.

Name: Archaeological Sites of Bat, Al-Khutm and Al-Ayn
short_description: The protohistoric site of Bat lies near a palm grove in the interior of the Sultanate of Oman. Together with the neighbouring sites, it forms the most complete collection of settlements and necropolises from the 3rd millennium B.C. in the world.

reviews.text:
Amazing site that is off the beaten path. First though, do follow Google maps with care, it leads you on a route that supposedly crosses the river but the actual road is now broken right after a turn.

Instead you will need to find a path down to the dry river bed and try to sight the entrance to the site and follow it. 4WD only, if you are in a sedan, just park at the road side and walk. The car can at maximum reach to the base of the hill and you will still need to walk up.

The beehive tombs are an amazing sight with a number of them in a row making it all the more imposing ( you can see them in a distance) as they are atop a hill.

Nice serene environment. The tombs are nice view against the mountains backdrop. Park your car just before the river beds and walk about 300m to the beehive tombs. When on foot, do not cross and go up the riverbed, instead walk along the riverbed towards the tomb. About 50m you’ll see a gate but that’s locked so continue another 200m and there will be a dirt path on the left leading up to the beehive tombs.
Amazing place, wonderful at sunset. No information, no tickets, you have to cross a dry riverbed. I had to walk through vegetables patches which madr everything better.

If you're confused about where to go, you just need to go to the wadi (channel) & park there, then look for the path & sign leading up to the tombs.
Very nice view👍

Magical place. I have skipped Bat and went only to this place and felt like it was enough. It's nice to experience this place around sunset, because the materials are changing colours.
Good half an hour out of one and half I was there completely alone on summer afternoon.

Name: Historic Centre of Lima
short_description: Although severely damaged by earthquakes, this 'City of the Kings' was, until the middle of the 18th century, the capital and most important city of the Spanish dominions in South America. Many of its buildings, such as the Convent of San Francisco (the largest of its type in this part of the world), are the result of collaboration between local craftspeople and others from the Old World.

reviews.text: A must see when visiting Lima! Historical and beautiful. A great place to see the President's Palace, and if you're lucky, the changing of the guard. The cathedral was also very impressive. Statues, fountains, open spaces... It's lovely.

Must Visit in Lima! We happened to be there on a Sunday and there was a cultural parade happening! The parade was so long and nice to see the cultural dance side of Peru! We also saw the change of guards (wasn’t so exciting)! But overall, a very exciting place and it’s a must visit!

Lovely main square of Lima, this time was all closed  due new government measurements.  Looks more organised from time to time you can  go in and take photos. I  love the Spanish influence architecture especially the wooden balconies and the government palace. I advise to come day light and wait for the artificial light to do the magical work. Photos are just breath taken.
Great place to visit the national cathedral, various government buildings, restaurants, vendors, and get great photos.  Felt pretty safe
Photos taken Dec 21st, so the plaza was beautifully decorated with Christmas lights. Try to take a seat somewhere and enjoy the beauty, especially at night with all the lights.

Name: Old City of Salamanca
short_description: This ancient university town north-west of Madrid was first conquered by the Carthaginians in the 3rd century B.C. It then became a Roman settlement before being ruled by the Moors until the 11th century. The university, one of the oldest in Europe, reached its high point during Salamanca's golden age. The city's historic centre has important Romanesque, Gothic, Moorish, Renaissance and Baroque monuments. The Plaza Mayor, with its galleries and arcades, is particularly impressive.

Name: Sinharaja Forest Reserve
short_description: Located in south-west Sri Lanka, Sinharaja is the country's last viable area of primary tropical rainforest. More than 60% of the trees are endemic and many of them are considered rare. There is much endemic wildlife, especially birds, but the reserve is also home to over 50% of Sri Lanka's endemic species of mammals and butterflies, as well as many kinds of insects, reptiles and rare amphibians.

reviews.text:
Sinharaja Forest Reserve, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is Sri Lanka’s most significant tropical rainforest, known for its rich biodiversity and high endemism. Covering approximately 11,187 hectares, it is home to rare flora and fauna, including the Sri Lanka blue magpie, purple-faced langur, and green pit viper. The dense forest has a humid climate, making it a hotspot for researchers and nature lovers.
Main Entry Points:
1.	Deniyaya Entrance – Popular for access to Patna Forest Reserve and Mulawella Trail.
2.	Kudawa Entrance (Weddagala) – The most commonly used entrance, leading to Sinhagala Trail and birdwatching areas.
3.	Pitadeniya Entrance – Provides access to waterfalls like Duvili Ella and deeper parts of the forest.
