Each entrance offers unique experiences, from birdwatching to waterfall hikes and deep jungle trails.

Best place in Srilanka to study the bio-diversity. It is home to hundreds of Endemic plants and animal which you can not watch anywhere else in the world. Highly recommended to take the assistance of registered forest tour guide. There are beautiful waterfalls hidden inside the forest. If you wish you can take a swim at crystal clear water on Gin river. Do not forget to wear leach socks when you explore the forest.

A Hidden Gem of Biodiversity

Sinharaja Forest is nothing short of a paradise for nature lovers! If you have a passion for birds and lizards, this place will absolutely enchant you. As I walked through the lush trails, I was surrounded by a vibrant ecosystem filled with unique endemic species that you can’t find anywhere else in the world.

Wildlife Paradise:
The variety of birds was astonishing! I saw colorful species flitting through the trees, and the sound of their calls added to the enchanting atmosphere. The lizards, with their bright colors and interesting behaviors, made for great photo opportunities. However, if you're expecting large wildlife like in the African savannah, you’ll need to adjust your expectations.

Stunning Scenery:
The forest is rich with hidden waterfalls that create a serene backdrop. I took a refreshing swim in the Gin River, and the crystal-clear water was simply divine. It felt rejuvenating, surrounded by the soothing sounds of nature.

Guided Experience:
I highly recommend hiring a registered forest tour guide. Their knowledge added immense value to my experience, as they pointed out various species of plants and animals that I would have otherwise overlooked. Their passion for the forest was infectious.

Preparation Tips:
A must-do is to wear leach socks! It made my exploration much more comfortable, as leeches can be quite prevalent in wet areas.

Conclusion:
If you’re a nature enthusiast or just looking for a peaceful retreat away from the hustle and bustle, Sinharaja Forest should definitely be on your travel list. It’s a treasure trove of biodiversity that left me in awe. I can’t recommend it enough!

A Must-Visit Tropical Paradise: Sinharaja Forest Reserve

Sinharaja Forest Reserve is an absolute gem for anyone passionate about nature and adventure. This UNESCO World Heritage Site is a pristine rainforest that offers a truly immersive experience. The moment you step into the forest, you’re greeted by the sound of rustling leaves, chirping birds, and the occasional call of monkeys.

One of the highlights of my visit was the exceptional guides with enormous knowledge. They provided fascinating insights into the forest's rich biodiversity and pointed out species I would have never noticed on my own. From rare endemic species of plants and animals to vibrant insects and spiders, every moment was a discovery.

The forest teems with life, including colorful lizards, elusive reptiles, and even tiny frogs hiding under leaves. Watching birds flutter through the canopy and spotting playful monkeys swinging between trees was unforgettable. The well-maintained trails lead to picturesque waterfalls, where you can pause and soak in the tranquility. Along the way, you’ll also cross scenic bridges that add a touch of adventure to the journey.

I highly recommend a full-day tour to truly appreciate this natural wonder. Sinharaja Forest Reserve is not just a destination; it’s a journey into the heart of nature's beauty. Perfect for wildlife enthusiasts, photographers, and anyone looking to connect with the natural world.

Sinharaja Forest Reserve is a breathtaking tropical rainforest in Sri Lanka, teeming with rich biodiversity and lush greenery 🍃. A UNESCO World Heritage Site, it offers an immersive experience for nature lovers, with vibrant birdlife, rare wildlife, and serene hiking trails. The tranquil atmosphere and fresh air make it a perfect escape into nature. A must-visit for eco-tourists and adventure seekers! 🐾🍃.

Name: Sacred City of Kandy
short_description: This sacred Buddhist site, popularly known as the city of Senkadagalapura, was the last capital of the Sinhala kings whose patronage enabled the Dinahala culture to flourish for more than 2,500 years until the occupation of Sri Lanka by the British in 1815. It is also the site of the Temple of the Tooth Relic (the sacred tooth of the Buddha), which is a famous pilgrimage site.

reviews.text:
Immensely beautiful. No words to explain how great it is!
It’s a sacred place so no shoes inside, you need to leave them at the entrance. The floor can be extremely hot, if you cannot handle it in ber foot, you are allowed to wear socks. Wear a long, simple dress or bring a scarf to cover your shoulders. Lastly, be respectful where to take pictures or videos: check for signs/boards or ask to some guardians that are walking around.
Tourist trap that turns religion into business. It’s better to walk around the lake and streets to experience the real life of Kandy, not some worshipping of stones

Nice place to see, but we were deeply disappointed by the ceremony yesterday evening. Way too crowded, a rather aggressive atmosphere, and a dangerous environment if something happens. In case of physical pressure or fire, people can hardly get away. Also, as a tourist not participating in the ceremony, there is hardly anything to see.
The place is very peaceful. And you do have a lot of friendly locals. The Buddha temple is so beautiful but do make sure you were modest cloths covering unto your knees.
Beautiful city. Historical buildings. Amazing views. So crowded

Name: Old Town of Galle and its Fortifications
short_description: Founded in the 16th century by the Portuguese, Galle reached the height of its development in the 18th century, before the arrival of the British. It is the best example of a fortified city built by Europeans in South and South-East Asia, showing the interaction between European architectural styles and South Asian traditions.

reviews.text: Pretty good views of the sea with a few access points to the beach. Well worth visiting the suburb as well, as it has lots of restaurants and shops for clothing and jewely. Should take about 1.5 to 2h to visit without rushing. Highly recommended.

The city is not worth visiting if this wasn’t here. I wouldn’t stay in the city but this fort is amazing place to visit. All of the shops are really nice and well presented. There are some amazing food and drinks shops here too not to mention the stunning views and history here.
There’s a nice beach to go on. It’s only small but not overcrowded and the waves are calmed by the rocks.
If you’re in the area visit this for half a day or take a ride in from outside the city. It’ll be worth it.

We spent a day exploring the fort with its iconic lighthouse, church and fancy shops and eateries, it did not disappoint.

Just a wonderful place to mooch, the architecture is wonderful populated with such joys as coconut sambal, a small restaurant that serves a selection of curries and you get to eat as much as you want for around 1600 ( £5).  The food was astonishing.

We came across an impromptu game of cricket with the girls bearing the boys in the town sq. Near the Banyan tree.

Lots of fancy up market shops and eateries too.  Just a  great place to explore, highly recommended

[If you found this review and photos  helpful then please hit like as it encourages me]

Must-Visit Place in Sri Lanka – Galle Fort

Galle Fort is a must-visit when in Sri Lanka! The blend of history, stunning architecture, and scenic ocean views makes it a truly unique experience. The charming streets, vibrant cafes, and beautiful sunset views add to its charm. A perfect spot to explore, relax, and soak in the rich culture. Highly recommended!

A stunning old fortress, first constructed by Portuguese settlers, then enhanced by Dutch and finally British settlers. Inside are many fantastic boutique hotels, shops, and restaurants for all tastes and budgets.

If you can, take a tour of the city walls and learn more about Galle Fort's fascinating history.

Top tip: you can watch cricket from the ramparts for free!

Name: Medina of Sousse
short_description: Sousse was an important commercial and military port during the Aghlabid period (800–909) and is a typical example of a town dating from the first centuries of Islam. With its kasbah, ramparts, medina (with the Great Mosque), Bu Ftata Mosque and typical ribat (both a fort and a religious building), Sousse was part of a coastal defence system.

reviews.text:
A Historical Gem in Sousse

I recently visited the Ribat of Sousse and was thoroughly impressed by this historical gem. The Ribat is wonderfully preserved, offering a captivating glimpse into its rich history. Climbing the tower was an absolute highlight, providing stunning views over Sousse and the Medina. The museum inside offers fascinating insights, and the well-maintained facilities add to the overall experience.

A must-visit for anyone exploring Sousse, especially for history enthusiasts. My only suggestion would be to perhaps add more informational plaques in multiple languages to enhance the visitor experience further. Highly recommended!

Tunisia is full of amazing stories thanks to its rich hostory. Sousse is a beautiful historic city that offers a lot of hidden gems. Take a local tour guide, usually waiting at the entrance of the old town, and enjoy the history and all the exciting stories.

This fortification is well maintained and a worthy place visiting while in Sousse. It is located at the foot of the Medina and in the heart of the city.
You will find many meanderings in this fort. The architecture is very impressive. I’d recommend exploring the entire complex as during my visit it would appear that most people just want a view from the tower.
The view from the tower is really nice. It is a 360 degrees view. From the lower balconies, you can also observe views of the bustling clothes market to one end of the Medina.
I would definitely recommend visiting here when in Sousse.
There is paid parking near the Médina wall but a few yards away, there’s free parking literally everywhere. If you are combining a visit to the Ribat and the archaeological museum, you can always leave your vehicle at the museum and walk down the hill via the old city walls or even through the Médina. It takes about 15 minutes down hill!
Entry price is very reasonable. Good security.

There are many lovely things about The Medina in Sousse. As with all Medina’s that we went through this one has its usual labyrinth of alleyways, compelling doors and of course lots of shops and sellers. Then towards the end of our wandering we came across the historic Ribat. This is the oldest monument in the Sousse medina, dating back to 821 A.D. It was part of a large network of similar fortresses. It has great views of the surrounding city and sea.
Smalll but beautiful fortress, breathtaking views from the top of the tower, lots of shopping around this area

Name: Kairouan
short_description: Founded in 670, Kairouan flourished under the Aghlabid dynasty in the 9th century. Despite the transfer of the political capital to Tunis in the 12th century, Kairouan remained the Maghreb's principal holy city. Its rich architectural heritage includes the Great Mosque, with its marble and porphyry columns, and the 9th-century Mosque of the Three Gates.

Name: Xanthos-Letoon
short_description: This site, which was the capital of Lycia, illustrates the blending of Lycian traditions and Hellenic influence, especially in its funerary art. The epigraphic inscriptions are crucial for our understanding of the history of the Lycian people and their Indo-European language.

reviews.text:
Excellent site for a very good price of 3EUR or 115TL

Doesn't get many visitors but has some spectacular remains, escape the crowds at more popular sites and step into history at Letoon instead :)

I thoroughly enjoyed and recommend to all.

Plenty of detailed description boards which really enhanced the visit.

Allow at least one hour.
Wear good shoes, put on suncream and bring water.

Quite a small site with a lot packed in the first and main site is the amphitheatre, which leads onto the 3 main, temples at the back of the site. Well worth a detour if in the area.
3 Euro entry
It is very poorly excavated site yet they charge you to get in the only highlight of the visit is turtles in the pond and maybe replica mosaic ( not the real thing)

UNESCO has attached their status to this site as it’s classified as one of the most important sites of the Lycian civilisation. Though it’s a smallish archaeology site by Turkish standards and that’s why I’m only giving it three stars. It’s still very much worth a visit for the arches to the amphitheater and the amazing little mosaics next to the Apollo Temple (you need to climb on top to see them)

It is ancient Lykian city built in 2nd century AD. You can see several temples, ruins of a church and of course the ancient theater. The site can be reached from Fethiye - Kas highway and an additional 10km into villages. There is not many things to see as most of the buildings are only ruins. It is a world heritage site, entrance fee is 12 Turkish liras, free under age of 18. Parking is available.

Name: Hierapolis-Pamukkale
short_description: Deriving from springs in a cliff almost 200 m high overlooking the plain, calcite-laden waters have created at Pamukkale (Cotton Palace) an unreal landscape, made up of mineral forests, petrified waterfalls and a series of terraced basins. At the end of the 2nd century B.C. the dynasty of the Attalids, the kings of Pergamon, established the thermal spa of Hierapolis. The ruins of the baths, temples and other Greek monuments can be seen at the site.

Name: Henderson Island
short_description: Henderson Island, which lies in the eastern South Pacific, is one of the few atolls in the world whose ecology has been practically untouched by a human presence. Its isolated location provides the ideal context for studying the dynamics of insular evolution and natural selection. It is particularly notable for the 10 plants and four land birds that are endemic to the island.
Country name: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

Name: Tower of London
short_description: The massive White Tower is a typical example of Norman military architecture, whose influence was felt throughout the kingdom. It was built on the Thames by William the Conqueror to protect London and assert his power. The Tower of London – an imposing fortress with many layers of history, which has become one of the symbols of royalty – was built around the White Tower.
Country name: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

reviews.text: What a cool place! Can easily spend 3-4 hours here (or less if you want). There’s so much to see and read about - from medieval weapons to the Crown Jewels to the prisoners kept in the tower - it’s all there. They also offer free tours from guides with your ticket purchase. Beware of lots of steps!

An amazing experience! The tour was well-organized, and our guide was fantastic—very funny and engaging while sharing the rich history of the city. It made the whole experience both educational and entertaining. The sights were absolutely beautiful, and we got to appreciate London in a whole new way. Highly recommended for anyone wanting to explore the city's history with a fun and knowledgeable guide!

The Tower of London is a truly fascinating place, rich in history and incredibly well presented. Everything is beautifully described, making it easy to follow the stories behind this iconic fortress, from its role as a royal palace to its darker past as a prison.

For anyone even slightly interested in history, this is an absolute must-visit. The atmosphere of the ancient walls, the stories of past monarchs, and the legendary ravens all add to the unique experience.

A true highlight of the visit is the Crown Jewels – simply breathtaking. The intricate craftsmanship and historical significance make them an unforgettable sight.

Highly recommended for history lovers and anyone wanting to experience a key part of British heritage!

Loved it! The crown jewels are definitely worth it to see. Unfortunately, I have no photos of them here because you’re not allowed—they’re pretty strict about it.

If you go, make sure to do the free initial tour included. We were in a big group with this guy who was super awesome and entertaining. Definitely one of the highlights.

A brilliant piece of British history, the Tower of London is a fascinating glimpse into the English past as it sits perched along the banks of the Thames.

I'm from a state whose capital is named for one of the Tower's most famous prisoners, Sir Walter Raleigh. It was fascinating to be in the same location. I loved walking through the White Tower and seeing all the arms and armor on display. It was really cool to see the ravens fluttering and hopping around the grounds.

It's also absolutely worth the wait to see the Crown Jewels. The breadth of the collection available to view was amazing. Taking a tour with one of the Yeoman Warders is a great way to learn even more of the Tower's history.

Name: Canterbury Cathedral, St Augustine's Abbey, and St Martin's Church
short_description: Canterbury, in Kent, has been the seat of the spiritual head of the Church of England for nearly five centuries. Canterbury's other important monuments are the modest Church of St Martin, the oldest church in England; the ruins of the Abbey of St Augustine, a reminder of the saint's evangelizing role in the Heptarchy from 597; and Christ Church Cathedral, a breathtaking mixture of Romanesque and Perpendicular Gothic, where Archbishop Thomas Becket was murdered in 1170.
Country name: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
formatted_address: Cathedral House, 11 The Precincts, Canterbury CT1 2EH, UK

reviews.text:
Visiting Canterbury Cathedral was an unforgettable experience. I was in awe of the towering arches, intricate stained glass, and sheer grandeur of the place. The craftsmanship is incredible, with every detail telling a story. The light streaming through the windows creates a magical atmosphere, making it easy to see why this cathedral has been a place of worship and pilgrimage for centuries.
Despite being a popular attraction, there’s a calm and almost sacred feel to the space. Walking through, I couldn’t help but take my time, admiring the scale of the architecture and the history embedded in every stone. The sense of reverence is undeniable, and it’s a place that truly makes you pause and reflect.
Whether you’re fascinated by history, appreciate beautiful architecture, or just want a peaceful escape, the cathedral is worth every moment.

A very nice Cathedral, many things we can find here.

They have a viewing gallery on the first floor, near the reception, and the shop.
I like the shop, we can buy many nice things for kids, and adults.

The toilets are big, and clean (turn left after the exit door).

Price for now :
Children (age 17 and under) : free to enter.
Adults (valid for 12 months) : £17 per person.

Canterbury cathedral, from bird's eye view, appears more or less like two enormous churches built back to back. Because of this, walking in, the temple continues on and on, past ornate tombs and chapels hung with saints and relics, rising up along three or four flights of stairs, for over 160 metres. The cathedral feels warm and alive, well kept and beautifully restored. Similarly, the close surrounding the church is verdant, sprinkled with majestic old plane trees, and a highway for the King's School students walking between their dormitories and classrooms. Take care not to forget the cloister and chapter house, because of the size of the complex, it is easy to get lost in the beauty.

Just a heads up that tickets are £18, but its definitely worth the visit as it lasts for a year. The architecture is astounding and well preserved. There is a lot of walking involved with steep and uneven stairs so be careful, but there are also places you could sit and rest your legs. The archbishop bears in the gift shop are super super cute.

Also a lot of chapels within the cathedral that you could pray in so it's definitely functional as well. Would pop by for Sunday service if I ever got the chance to. Just a bummer that there's a disco event being set up during my visit.

Photos are not allowed in the crypt, which is completely understandable judging that it is a praying area. But I didn't some altars and crosses because I can't bring myself to in good conscience. But I did pray a few "our father"s though!!

Magnificent structure with a rich history. The architecture combined with lights creating a peaceful, reflective and somewhat eerie environment.

I can picture the pilgrims walking through the interior and taking it all in after suffering a difficult journey. Not something to be truly appreciated after arriving in a comfortable air-conditioned coach.

Name: Archaeological Site of Mystras
short_description: Mystras, the 'wonder of the Morea', was built as an amphitheatre around the fortress erected in 1249 by the prince of Achaia, William of Villehardouin. Reconquered by the Byzantines, then occupied by the Turks and the Venetians, the city was abandoned in 1832, leaving only the breathtaking medieval ruins, standing in a beautiful landscape.

reviews.text: Beautiful sight highly worth visiting. As we visited in march it was not crowded at all and the entrance was for free (on a Sunday). Do note that it is quite a hike to visit the entire park. This may be challenging in the heat of the Greek summer. Bathroom facilities are limited to only at the bottom of the park/hill.

Wonderful site, beautiful view on they way up. To make it all the way to the castle bring some time and energy, but its worth the effort. 12€ entry, plan at least 1h to go up and down. Leaving some pictures for further impressions.

Mistra, huge Norman-Bizantic medieval city/religious complex of various structures, though be prepared for a huge effort to see-visit all the attractions there (some climbing) - I suggest 1stly go to Mistra then to Sparta. It's easy to get there by car, parking is small but if you are lucky you will find a spot. Take some extra food for cats. Take plenty of water and good shoes. Still wort visiting...afterwards got to Sparta:)  PS. Be careful, the number of paths around the hills is big, don't lost yourselve.

The palace is closed for renovations but there is Soooooo much to walk around and explore with placards to read. You could spend several hours seeing everything. Your admission ticket gets you into both entrances and the museum. Start at top parking lot first and explore the castle and then walk down to palace. If you want to go further down drive down to that lot and then see the rest walking up hill. Otherwise it is a LOT of steps

Visited in March 2024

This was a fantastic site we visited as we drove thru Sparta. It is a little drive out of town up into the mountains. There is a lot of walking to do but it is well worth it to witness this history and absorb the fantastic views. The site is undergoing multiple restorations but they don't interfere with visiting at all. It is good to bring you a water bottle when you come. It is a lot to see so also good to set aside the better part of a day to see it and arrive early before the tour busses to see it with fewer people.

Name: Archaeological Site of Olympia
short_description: The site of Olympia, in a valley in the Peloponnesus, has been inhabited since prehistoric times. In the 10th century B.C., Olympia became a centre for the worship of Zeus. The Altis – the sanctuary to the gods – has one of the highest concentrations of masterpieces from the ancient Greek world. In addition to temples, there are the remains of all the sports structures erected for the Olympic Games, which were held in Olympia every four years beginning in 776 B.C.

reviews.text: Great site. Unreal sizes of the Doric columns makes u feel in awe. Beautiful site, Spring nature at its best. Early March visit with excellent temperatures and not too many visitors.

An amazing experience exploring ancient Olympia with our tour guide, Penelope—an incredible source of knowledge. It’s almost impossible to fully grasp the depth of Greece’s rich civilization, which could take a lifetime to study and appreciate.

I loved Penelope's little folder of pictures showing what various places, objects, and people might have looked like in ancient times—it really helped visitors visualize the past.

One suggestion: more signs in different languages reminding visitors not to touch the precious ruins. During our visit, some restoration work was underway, which was wonderful to see.

We had a fantastic, educational time! However, we wished the museum had more interactive exhibits to engage younger visitors.
There are better ancient Greek sites, but the museum is not to be missed. I was completely moved by the pediment reliefs. Just masterful. And interesting exhibition showing how they were designed.

We started the day early in the morning with a visit to the Archaeological Museum of Olympia followed by the Archaeological Site of Olympia. The former is mainly known for the exhibition of sculptures. The latter was where the first ever Olympic Games took place, in 776 BC. It was here that we saw, among other things, the temple of Zeus, the temple of Hera, the Council house where athletes took the Olympic oath, the Treasury houses, the Gymnasium (training complex), the Palestra (wrestling grounds), and the running track. Unfortunately, we encountered heavy rain and could not venture beyond the running track to check out the horse track.

Here are some photos taken at the Archaeological Site of Olympia.

Entrance in high season: 12 €
Entrance in low season: 6 €

DOGS ARE NOT ALLOWED!
(Although there are some free roaming dogs on the site?)

There could be more signs and maybe translations from the engravements of some ruins at the ancient site, most of the time you're not sure of what you're looking at.

Barely any people at all during low season but some maintenance work.

The entrance includes two museums, very intetesting and a lot better signs and information.

Name: Buddhist Monuments at Sanchi
short_description: On a hill overlooking the plain and about 40 km from Bhopal, the site of Sanchi comprises a group of Buddhist monuments (monolithic pillars, palaces, temples and monasteries) all in different states of conservation most of which date back to the 2nd and 1st centuries B.C. It is the oldest Buddhist sanctuary in existence and was a major Buddhist centre in India until the 12th century A.D.

reviews.text:
Sanchi Stupa is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and one of the most significant Buddhist monuments in India. The place has a calm and serene atmosphere, making it ideal for those seeking peace and spiritual connection. The intricate carvings on the grand toranas (gateways) beautifully depict scenes from Buddha’s life and teachings. The site is well-maintained, and the detailed descriptions provided help visitors understand the rich history and symbolism behind the structures. The panoramic views from the hilltop add to its charm, making it a picturesque location for photography and meditation.

The only drawback is that guide charges are quite high (₹800 for Hindi, ₹1200 for English), which might not be affordable for everyone. However, the site itself is well-documented, and one can explore it independently while still gaining valuable insights.

The Sanchi Stupa is located in sanchi, vidisha about 50 km from Bhopal. The Stupas of Sanchi is a World Heritage site... that's why many foreign tourists visit here. The Site is clean, well managed and easily accessible. The Campus can be roamed by walking. The Stupas and other ruins are so well preserved and maintained, you cannot believe that it's 2 millennia old.
The Place is very peaceful although it was a public holiday and many people visited there...you can feel some sort of energy here.

The Great Stupa of Sanchi is built by Ashoka the Great in the 3rd century B.C.E. It's one of the oldest Stone structures in india about 2,300 years old. After the Kalinga war and attaining Buddhism, Ashoka began to spread the teachings of Buddha. But the whole campus was not built under Ashoka's reign. It was extended during the Shung and Satvahana period.
Sanchi Stupa is one of the monuments that gives you an idea how culturally prosperous India was.

The Sanchi Stupa is a remarkable testament to India’s rich cultural and spiritual heritage. As a UNESCO World Heritage Site, it offers an incredible glimpse into ancient Buddhist art, architecture, and history. The intricately carved gateways (toranas) are truly mesmerising, showcasing stories from Buddha’s life and teachings. The peaceful surroundings and well-maintained premises make it an ideal destination for history enthusiasts, architecture lovers, and those seeking serenity. The site also provides informative plaques and guides to enhance the visitor experience. A visit to Sanchi Stupa is not just a journey through history but also a spiritual retreat. Highly recommended!

The Sanchi Stupa is a must-visit for history buffs, archaeology enthusiasts, and anyone interested in the profound impact of Buddhism. This UNESCO World Heritage Site offers a unique glimpse into the rich cultural and religious heritage of ancient India.

Consider hiring a local guide to gain deeper insights into the history and significance of the stupa and its carvings.

Tickets to buy at the entrance.

This monument is printed on a 200 rs note. So don't forget to bring the note and get a picture.

Dec - 2024

Visiting the Buddhist Monuments at Sanchi was a profoundly enriching experience during my solo trip. A UNESCO World Heritage Site, Sanchi is a treasure trove of history, culture, and spirituality. The site’s ancient stupas, monasteries, and intricate carvings reflect the essence of Buddhist art and architecture, making it a must-visit for history buffs, spiritual seekers, and travelers alike.

The Good:
Architectural Grandeur: The Great Stupa (Stupa No. 1), the most prominent structure at Sanchi, is a marvel of ancient Indian architecture. Its massive dome, surrounded by exquisitely carved gateways (toranas), tells stories from Buddha's life and Jataka tales. The craftsmanship is truly awe-inspiring.
Rich History: Sanchi’s monuments date back to the 3rd century BCE, commissioned by Emperor Ashoka, and stand as a testament to the spread of Buddhism in India. Walking through the site feels like stepping back in time and connecting with a rich cultural heritage.
Peaceful Ambience: The site exudes a serene and tranquil atmosphere, ideal for introspection and meditation. Surrounded by lush greenery, Sanchi offers a perfect escape from the chaos of city life.
Well-Maintained: The Archaeological Survey of India has done an excellent job maintaining the site. The pathways are clean, and there are information boards that provide context to the monuments, making the visit informative and engaging.
Panoramic Views: Located on a hilltop, Sanchi offers stunning views of the surrounding countryside. The panoramic vistas add to the spiritual and aesthetic charm of the site.
Museum: The on-site museum houses several artifacts and relics from Sanchi and nearby regions. It’s a great place to delve deeper into the history and significance of the site.
The Challenges:
Hot Weather: If you visit during the summer months, the heat can be intense. There is limited shade, so carrying water and a hat is essential.
Connectivity: Sanchi is a bit off the beaten path, and reaching the site can be challenging if you don’t have your own vehicle. Public transport options are limited, so plan accordingly.
Limited Food Options Nearby: While there are small eateries around, the food choices are basic. If you have specific dietary preferences, it’s better to carry your own snacks.
Crowds on Weekends: Sanchi can get crowded on weekends and holidays, which might take away from the peaceful experience. Solo travelers seeking solitude may prefer to visit on weekdays.
Suggestions for Future Visitors:
Best Time to Visit: Plan your trip during the cooler months (October to March) for a more comfortable experience.
Start Early: Arrive early in the morning to avoid crowds and enjoy the site in peace. The early hours also provide better lighting for photography.
Carry Essentials: Bring water, sunscreen, a hat, and comfortable walking shoes, as you’ll be exploring the site extensively.
Hire a Guide: To fully appreciate the historical and cultural significance of the monuments, consider hiring a local guide. Their insights and storytelling will make your visit more meaningful.
Combine with Nearby Attractions: If time permits, explore nearby sites like Udayagiri Caves, which are also rich in history and heritage.
Final Thoughts:
The Buddhist Monuments at Sanchi are a true gem of India’s cultural and spiritual heritage. The site beautifully blends history, art, and serenity, making it a must-visit for anyone traveling through Madhya Pradesh. My solo visit was a journey of discovery and reflection, offering a deeper understanding of India’s rich Buddhist legacy.

Whether you’re a history enthusiast, a spiritual seeker, or a curious traveler, Sanchi has something to offer. The mesmerizing architecture, tranquil surroundings, and profound historical significance make it an unforgettable destination.

Name: Cliff of Bandiagara (Land of the Dogons)
short_description: The Bandiagara site is an outstanding landscape of cliffs and sandy plateaux with some beautiful architecture (houses, granaries, altars, sanctuaries and Togu Na, or communal meeting-places). Several age-old social traditions live on in the region (masks, feasts, rituals, and ceremonies involving ancestor worship). The geological, archaeological and ethnological interest, together with the landscape, make the Bandiagara plateau one of West Africa's most impressive sites.

reviews.text: I watched a goat get skinned and gutted as it hung from a tree limb above a flowing stream. Then one of the farmers shared some, still warm, freshly brewed millet beer.  The Dogon country has an ether that I have never forgotten.
drove there in 1994 very striking
It is the home of the Dogon. The disneyland of Mali. A pass for trekking. I don't know if the current security conditions are the best.

The Bandiagara cliff, in Mali, today represents one of the major sites of archaeological, ethnological and geological importance in the whole of Africa.  The cliff, which in geological terms corresponds to a sheer rock face, composed of sedimentary rock, is, in the case of Bandiagara, a wall approximately 500 meters high, which emerges from sandy soil, almost 200 kilometers long. Located in eastern Mali not very far (about 65 kilometers) from the city of Mopti. Its importance is increased by the presence of human settlements dating back to the 11th century. In fact, at that time the Tellems arrived on the cliff, a pygmy people (at least this is the opinion that archaeologists gave after finding bone texts in the tombs), who lived in accommodation created between caves and hollows in the rock. They chose that place due to its difficult accessibility, in fact they accessed their homes through ropes, thus making their lives safer.
Starting from the 14th century, another people arrived in the area, the Dogon, fleeing from the Islamic invasions in the Mendè kingdom and in an attempt to preserve their culture and their complex traditions. They settled in the area of ​​the cliff (today, in fact, the cliff is called "land of the Dogon"), leading to the escape of the Tellem (towards Burkina Faso) or their assimilation. In fact, archaeologists have found many elements among the Dogon customs that recall the Tellem traditions. The Dogon, a very interesting people from an ethnographic point of view and with a complex cosmogony, have transformed over time the caves inhabited by the Tellem into burial places, causing the around them an aura of mystery and sacredness.

In 1989, UNESCO included the Bandiagara Cliff among the World Heritage Sites to be protected and preserved for posterity. There is great fear for the stability of buildings which require continuous and constant maintenance.

The Cliff constitutes a complex cultural place, made up of almost 300 Dogon villages, ancient quarries and tomb architecture, and masked rites which still today (despite the abandonment of the villages witnessed in recent decades) make this place unique and rare.
A region inaccessible today, magnificent and magical

Name: Banc d'Arguin National Park
short_description: Fringing the Atlantic coast, the park comprises sand-dunes, coastal swamps, small islands and shallow coastal waters. The contrast between the harsh desert environment and the biodiversity of the marine zone has resulted in a land- and seascape of outstanding natural significance. A wide variety of migrating birds spend the winter there. Several species of sea turtle and dolphin, used by the fishermen to attract shoals of fish, can also be found.

reviews.text:
Amazing Area
I recommend totally!
You have a diversity of landscapes amazing 🤩

It's one of the world's most rare sanctuaries of its kind, proudly a national treasure. It was still summer time, so there wasn't too much wildlife yet, meaning I was lucky to appreciate uninterrupted views of the plains and hills. That sunrise was heavenly and the  morning peacefulness was accentuated with the constant wind sound from the ocean, reassuring me it will be waiting for my next visit. InshaAllah.
P.S.: I really hope it stays that way.

Lovely bit of coastline that we had the pleasure of being able to travel through in our journey through Mauritania. It is generally unspoilt in that it hasn't been commercialised, so you it's a bit like stepping back in time. Unfortunately some area are spoiled by litter and travelling by other. Than an SUV could get you into trouble on some of what are called 'roads'.
Amazing, beautiful
yes,very nice park. havent been there dough,but would really love to see it.

Name: Monastery of Alcobaça
short_description: The Monastery of Santa Maria d'Alcobaça, north of Lisbon, was founded in the 12th century by King Alfonso I. Its size, the purity of its architectural style, the beauty of the materials and the care with which it was built make this a masterpiece of Cistercian Gothic art.

reviews.text:
The monastery church was free to visit, very large and beautiful in an austere way for Portugal.  The royal tombs inside are very ornate.
The cloisters, dining room, kitchen and other parts of the monastery have a small entry fee.  Again the building is beautiful and the kitchen was very impressive, the chimney is huge!  I strongly recommend taking the paid tour.

Genuinely breathtaking marvel, particularly the internal yard. As a very fortunate person who grew up in Rome and had the luck of traveling extensively, only few religious buildings in Europe stun me, and this was one of them. 🙂

The Monastery of Alcobaça is a stunning example of Gothic architecture, located in the heart of Portugal. As I stepped through the imposing entrance, I was immediately captivated by the grandeur and simplicity of the interior. The soaring ceilings, intricate stonework, and peaceful atmosphere created a truly awe-inspiring experience.

One of the highlights of my visit was the Royal Pantheon, where the tombs of King Pedro I and his beloved Inês de Castro are located. The intricate carvings on their tombs tell the tragic tale of their love, making it a poignant and unforgettable moment.

In addition to the main church, the monastery complex offers a wealth of other interesting features. I explored the cloister, admiring the courtyard and detailed carvings. I also visited the chapter house, where the monks once gathered for meetings, and the refectory, where they dined.

The Mosteiro de Santa Maria de Alcobaça, located in Alcobaça, Portugal, is a magnificent Cistercian monastery and a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Founded in 1153 by King Afonso Henriques, it symbolizes the establishment of the Cistercian Order in Portugal and the country's early Christian history.
The monastery is renowned for its grand Gothic architecture, including the austere yet majestic church, the largest in Portugal at the time of its construction. Highlights include the Royal Cloister and the intricately carved tombs of King Pedro I and Inês de Castro, whose tragic love story is a defining part of Portuguese history. This serene and monumental site is a testament to faith, artistry, and devotion.
One of the most iconic places in West region. Historical monument. Worth the visit and also take the opportunity to experience the amazing "pastelaria conventual"

Name: Mosi-oa-Tunya / Victoria Falls
short_description: These are among the most spectacular waterfalls in the world. The Zambezi River, which is more than 2 km wide at this point, plunges noisily down a series of basalt gorges and raises an iridescent mist that can be seen more than 20 km away.

reviews.text: Victoria Falls, located in Zambia, is a stunning natural wonder and one of the largest waterfalls in the world. Its dramatic cascade of water creates a spectacular sight and a mist that can be seen from miles away. The surrounding area offers beautiful scenery and various activities, including guided tours and boat rides. It's a must-visit destination for anyone seeking awe-inspiring natural beauty.
We got to see herds of elephants and giraffes ! That was the highlight of the visit. Kudos to the security guys who work 24/7 for the protection of the rhinos !
From the Victoria Falls, deep into the bush and it’s surroundings. An abundance of Hippo’s, Elephants, Crocodiles, Buffalo, Impala and lots of different bird species. Conservation at it’s best.

The reason we gave this park 4 stars is its small and needs maintenance. We self-drove our car in and around the park….they really want to have you get a tour guide, but it’s unneeded. The bathrooms are rough at the entrance and the park needs to maintain the roads and signs. You get your fees paid, go in and start driving around the paths. Not all are clearly marked, but you can’t get lost as it’s all loops. We saw loads of wildebeest, zebra, impala, and warthogs. The cape Buffalo came out in the afternoon into the marshy grasslands and walked all around in front of us. The hippos were seen in the River! The elephants were all over the opposite river bank. We had a great drive! The rhino seem to be tracked and protected by a group of people/tour guides. They want you to pay them so they take you to them and view the rhino. It seemed a little too “unnatural” to us. We saw rhinos in the wild in Etosha and didn’t need to be led to them and pay an armed “guard/guide”. Again, the park is small and will only take you a few hours to drive slowly through and around.

The park is located in the southern part of Zambia, in Livingstone. I absolutely enjoyed my game drive at the park. While the park is relatively small, it is home to a variety of wildlife. I got to see White Rhinos,Zebras, Buffalos, Gazelles, monkeys and some baboons. The park has got elephants as well but I was unlucky to spot any during my drive.  While in the park, one can easily see the Zambezi River and spot some Hippos and crocodiles along the river side. The park provides a blend of natural beauty, wildlife and adventure making it a popular destination for visitors seeking a memorable African experience.

Name: Jesuit Missions of the Chiquitos
short_description: Between 1696 and 1760, six ensembles of reducciones (settlements of Christianized Indians) inspired by the ‘ideal cities’ of the 16th-century philosophers were founded by the Jesuits in a style that married Catholic architecture with local traditions. The six that remain – San Francisco Javier, Concepción, Santa Ana, San Miguel, San Rafael and San José – make up a living heritage on the former territory of the Chiquitos.

reviews.text: San Jose
Beautiful Jesuit mission

This complex is a beautiful place, to learn from the inside a little of the history of the Jesuit missions in its different rooms.

Entry to this sector costs 10bs for nationals and 20bs for foreigners.

To access only the main patio and walk inside is free.
Very well preserved World Heritage Site, affordable price, attentive staff, very interesting introductory video that places you in time and space and rooms with detailed bilingual information

Pretty building.
The Misional guide is a true history buff.
Don't miss the guide session

Name: Mount Huangshan
short_description: Huangshan, known as 'the loveliest mountain of China', was acclaimed through art and literature during a good part of Chinese history (e.g. the Shanshui 'mountain and water' style of the mid-16th century). Today it holds the same fascination for visitors, poets, painters and photographers who come on pilgrimage to the site, which is renowned for its magnificent scenery made up of many granite peaks and rocks emerging out of a sea of clouds.
formatted_address: Huangshan Mountain, Huangshan District, Huangshan City, China, 245801

reviews.text: Beautiful scenery. Enjoyable cable car ride. Many trails to hike. You can choose hike up and down instead of the cable but it can be quite a feat!

So many people! And they close the main peak every few years for maintenance. But worth going to see the good sights and historical places. The trails are all mostly good and very doable for an average fit person.

Even when it is super duper crowded, in early Aug, and super duper hot, it is an incredible sight to behold in all directions. Compared to our last trip, 12 years ago, everything is more built up - more hiking trails, more eshops, more hotels. A bit of the old charm is gone for sure. Do the hike to the Fairy Bridge, it is a great hike and all the other tourists don't go there so it was our only peaceful hike (2145 stairs from the top though, one way!).
Well organized paths, lights and night. Amazing landscape. Well worth the time but easy if speaking Chinese.
Outstanding Beauty, Very well kept trail pathways throughout the Mountains. The Hotel we hiked up to was clean and had a great view. A great location to add to your bucket list.

Name: Colonial City of Santo Domingo
short_description: After Christopher Columbus's arrival on the island in 1492, Santo Domingo became the site of the first cathedral, hospital, customs house and university in the Americas. This colonial town, founded in 1498, was laid out on a grid pattern that became the model for almost all town planners in the New World.
formatted_address: Ciudad Colonial, Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic

Name: Palaces and Parks of Potsdam and Berlin
short_description: With 500 ha of parks and 150 buildings constructed between 1730 and 1916, Potsdam's complex of palaces and parks forms an artistic whole, whose eclectic nature reinforces its sense of uniqueness. It extends into the district of Berlin-Zehlendorf, with the palaces and parks lining the banks of the River Havel and Lake Glienicke. Voltaire stayed at the Sans-Souci Palace, built under Frederick II between 1745 and 1747.

reviews.text: I've always loved Sanssouci Palace, but never actually went through the whole park. There is so much more than the palace, it's amazing! I can definitely recommend a stroll through this amazing park with wonderful buildings at every step.

Lovely protected unesco site where you can visit two palaces and the complimentary buildings that were built throughout. The park and the landscape are a joy to walk around. Must visit where you can easily spend the whole day where it is worth giving time to the rest places of the compound
Winter is probably not a good time to visit as the statues in the garden are all boarded up. However, it is still nice to work around the garden if the weather is nice.

The palace’s terraced vineyard is not just decorative. Frederick the Great grew grapes and figs here, demonstrating his love for agriculture.
Ыome of the trees in the park are over 250 years old and were personally planted by Frederick himself.
Best Time to Visit: Early mornings or late afternoons are perfect to avoid crowds and enjoy peaceful walks.

A Day of Rococo Splendor at Sanssouci Park
My visit to Sanssouci Park in Potsdam was a delightful journey through history and natural beauty. The park, renowned for its stunning gardens and opulent palaces, lived up to every expectation.
The centerpiece, Sanssouci Palace, is a masterpiece of Rococo architecture. Its elegant facade, adorned with intricate sculptures and ornate details, is a sight to behold. The interior is equally impressive, with lavishly decorated rooms filled with exquisite furnishings and artwork.
Beyond the palace, the park's sprawling grounds offer a serene escape. The terraced vineyards, adorned with grapevines and fountains, are a picturesque sight. The New Palace, another architectural gem, is a testament to Prussian grandeur. The Orangery, with its impressive collection of citrus trees, is a must-see for nature lovers.
I particularly enjoyed strolling through the park's winding paths, surrounded by lush greenery and the gentle sound of birdsong. The peaceful atmosphere was the perfect antidote to the hustle and bustle of city life.
Overall, my visit to Sanssouci Park was a memorable experience. The combination of historical significance, architectural beauty, and natural splendor made it a truly enchanting destination. I would highly recommend it to anyone visiting Berlin or Potsdam.

Name: Delos
short_description: According to Greek mythology, Apollo was born on this tiny island in the Cyclades archipelago. Apollo's sanctuary attracted pilgrims from all over Greece and Delos was a prosperous trading port. The island bears traces of the succeeding civilizations in the Aegean world, from the 3rd millennium B.C. to the palaeochristian era. The archaeological site is exceptionally extensive and rich and conveys the image of a great cosmopolitan Mediterranean port.

reviews.text: Birthplace of Apollo. The island is very beautiful and has lot of ruins. You can take boat from Mykanos and good to go with a guide. Guide will give you indepth details of each ruin. Good scenic island.

As wonderful as the vast array of must-see places are throughout Greece, Delos is a largely overlooked gem.  Read a little about it - it is the true cradle of western civilization in many ways.  And if nothing else, a great place to go to for a few hours (ferry ride from nearby islands such as Mykonos or Paros) away from crowds to enjoy hiking while viewing fascinating archaeological ruins, and to scale the stairs to the central peak (and enjoy some of the most fantastic 360 degree views - and wind!).

Definitely worth to visit. It preserved so well and its authenticity and it was amazing to just being in the site. I was in the tour wishing I could spend more time. It was great discovery of the Mykonos and Greece.

A must see in Greece! If you are on a nearby island (such as Mykonos), hop on a ferry and prepare to immerse yourself in a rich archaelogical past that will make you feel like you're taken back to that time period. Absolutely incredible views and historical descriptions 👌

I cannot recommend this place enough for those that love their ancient history and want to experience ancient Greece. There is so much to see and you get a real sense of life in ancient Greece on a grand scale.

My only advice would be to experience this place when in good health and it is a bit hilly and a climb up the summit is highly recommended.

Name: Monasteries of Daphni, Hosios Loukas and Nea Moni of Chios
short_description: Although geographically distant from each other, these three monasteries (the first is in Attica, near Athens, the second in Phocida near Delphi, and the third on an island in the Aegean Sea, near Asia Minor) belong to the same typological series and share the same aesthetic characteristics. The churches are built on a cross-in-square plan with a large dome supported by squinches defining an octagonal space. In the 11th and 12th centuries they were decorated with superb marble works as well as mosaics on a gold background, all characteristic of the 'second golden age of Byzantine art'.

reviews.text: Wasn’t able to spend too much time here since we arrived and didn’t realize it was 15 minutes prior to closing for the afternoon. They do offer a tour for 4 euro but is a lovely place to go sit and enjoy the scenery when the doors are opened. There is a very minimal restroom on sight, so keep that in mind when visiting.

The Monastery offers a serene and peaceful atmosphere, perfect for those interested in history and religion. However, reaching the monastery can be challenging. There are two paths leading to it; one includes a 750-meter stretch filled with dirt, gravel, and stones. It's advisable to avoid the route from Dafnonas unless your car is well-suited for rough terrain. Instead, prefer the road from Epar. Od. Chiou Elidas for a smoother journey. Once there, you'll find a tranquil environment that allows for quiet reflection and appreciation of the monastery's historical significance.

Monastery is worth to visit but be careful try to follow road to Avgonima. If you follow Google maps blindly you will finish at the wrong position so you will have to leave your car down the hill and walk up the hill to the Monastery some 750m. Not funny at all, trust me. 🤣😪

One of the 3 unesco heritage monasteries in Greece. You have to follow the brown signs, because otherwise the maps can lead you along gravel roads. The monastery itself is very beautiful and you can see the skulls of the monks killed as a result of the mass murder by the Turks. is another monastery. The hiker has a very beautiful view and photo opportunities. The monastery itself is free, if you want to visit the museum part, it costs 4 euros for an adult and 2 euros for a child. The monastery is open in the morning at 7:00 a.m., closed for a while during the day and open again in the evening.

Amazing architecture, friendly community, very welcoming. Was honestly chilling at times, as all of the monks skulls are on display, and I think I may have wandered into some ruins I was not supposed to be in, but definitely a great location if your looking for an amazing veiw of chios, connecting with god, or history.

Name: Historic Centre of San Gimignano
short_description: 'San Gimignano delle belle Torri' is in Tuscany, 56 km south of Florence. It served as an important relay point for pilgrims travelling to or from Rome on the Via Francigena. The patrician families who controlled the town built around 72 tower-houses (some as high as 50 m) as symbols of their wealth and power. Although only 14 have survived, San Gimignano has retained its feudal atmosphere and appearance. The town also has several masterpieces of 14th- and 15th-century Italian art.
formatted_address: Piazza Sant'Agostino, 53037 San Gimignano SI, Italy

reviews.text:
San Gimignano is like a more compact version of Sienna. It's a small medieval town that is just lovely to visit!

Walking along the streets of this place is like taking me back centuries ago, traversing the same narrow and rolling alleys of this magnificent town.

The towers were said to be a sign of wealth back then. Only a couple remain but one can only imagine the awe of people witnessing these colossal structures.

Definitely a must visit place in Italy!

San Gimignano is the reason we came back to Tuscany after visiting it last yearfor a few hours, while driving through Tuscany.

Beautiful walled medieval town, that was originally restored in 1800s, and probably the biggest attraction in Tuscany.

The towers were a sign of wealth, and the taller the tower, the wealthier the family that owned them.

They were originally built as protection against marauding neighboring townspeople, street scuffs, etc.  these towers were connected to the residences of the owners.

You can climb the  tallest tower in town, for 7 Euros.
A beautiful and historical town in Toscany region. I definitely recommend to visit this place. Picturesque landscapes, amazing people, good food and great atmosphere ❤️

Scenic old town. It was cold when I visited.
Got an idea of how it was a few hundred years ago. Perhaps they kept their fortunes with them in the towers?

200% of history, 300%of atmosphere .
A place unlike any other, a unique monument at every turn.
I highly recommend a visit, it is a very special experience and feeling here.

Name: Tsingy de Bemaraha Strict Nature Reserve
short_description: Tsingy de Bemaraha Strict Nature Reserve comprises karstic landscapes and limestone uplands cut into impressive 'tsingy' peaks and a 'forest' of limestone needles, the spectacular canyon of the Manambolo river, rolling hills and high peaks. The undisturbed forests, lakes and mangrove swamps are the habitat for rare and endangered lemurs and birds.

reviews.text: Beautiful!! Definitely a must stop. The hike is not that hard, we saw older people doing it. And it was definitely worth it. The rocks of the mountain are breathtaking.

The word tsingy translates as the place where one cannot walk, a name that indicates just how impenetrable this place can be. In fact, the Tsingy de Bemaraha – Madagascar’s most extensive plateau of limestone karst pinnacles – is untouched by humans, except for a few trails and bridges. The formations are around 200 million years old and the reserve's little-disturbed forests, lakes, mangrove swamps and canyons are an ideal habitat for all manner of wildlife – there are 11 different kinds of lemur and 45 endemic species of reptile here.

The big Tsingy is a wonderful hiking experience. In the dry season be prepared for overhead sun with little to no shade. You will likely be given a harness upon arrival, which will be needed when climbing. A good level of fitness is required for the hike/climb, which requires you to slip through tight spaces and walk near steep drops. Not for the vertigo-prone. Expect to spend around 5 hours hiking. Near the edge of the reserve is a more forested area with many species of lemurs and birds-perfect for the enthusiast. But I would recommend against bringing an expensive camera as it is most certainly going to get damaged. Remember to bring plenty of fluids and food, and to always wear your harness when guidelines are present for it. The trails in the tsingy are clearly marked with both km signs and spray painted rocks
Very scary hike but a unique and really beautiful place
When we say a forest, we mean a place full of trees, but can you imagine a forest from pictures like this? Not only that, but it is also a place where lemurs live like no other, really a great place.

Name: Tongariro National Park
short_description: In 1993 Tongariro became the first property to be inscribed on the World Heritage List under the revised criteria describing cultural landscapes. The mountains at the heart of the park have cultural and religious significance for the Maori people and symbolize the spiritual links between this community and its environment. The park has active and extinct volcanoes, a diverse range of ecosystems and some spectacular landscapes.

reviews.text: The Tongariro Alpine Crossing is a hike like no other! Every step is a journey through dramatic volcanic landscapes, emerald lakes, and rugged craters. The Devil’s Staircase? A brutal climb, but the views make it worth it. Red Crater—raw, powerful, and unforgettable. The descent past the shimmering Emerald Lakes? Absolutely surreal. Weather changes fast, so be prepared for anything. Legs were on fire, but so was my sense of adventure. A true bucket-list hike that delivers challenge, beauty, and pure magic. Would I do it again? In a heartbeat.

Since we only arrived in the late afternoon, I hiked about 40 minutes of the Alpine Crossing before turning back while my husband went a little further. The terrain of the national park was so intriguing since three volcanoes make their home here. 🌋 There are restrooms along the way, and the path is entirely unpaved. We enjoyed checking out the visitor center too and getting some guidance from a ranger before setting out on a hike. The highlight was, of course, seeing Mount Doom.

So beautiful place!
Marvelous alpine crossing hike! We did it for 7 hour with a good speed but several chill breaks)

It's one way trail, so you need to book a shuttle in advance

Accessible volcanoe walk. Mostly trails and wooden walkways.  Good scenery and native bush on the descent.  A fun sandy "scree" run from the top.
Lots of signs declare it to be 11 miles.  We measured 16 miles.

Wow! Absolutely 💯
BUT! Please make sure you have prepared for this 6-8 hour strenuous hike! It is not for the faint-hearted and you need to be sure you can sustain the tough uphill and stairs for extended periods of time. I'm so glad I trained for this. It was beyond fabulous 😍

Name: Te Wahipounamu – South West New Zealand
short_description: The landscape in this park, situated in south-west New Zealand, has been shaped by successive glaciations into fjords, rocky coasts, towering cliffs, lakes and waterfalls. Two-thirds of the park is covered with southern beech and podocarps, some of which are over 800 years old. The kea, the only alpine parrot in the world, lives in the park, as does the rare and endangered takahe, a large flightless bird.

reviews.text: Great day cruising through parts of it.  Waterfalls,wildlife, and views
Very good
The best🏞️
Beautiful view
It was heavenly

Name: Río Abiseo National Park
short_description: The park was created in 1983 to protect the fauna and flora of the rainforests that are characteristic of this region of the Andes. There is a high level of endemism among the fauna and flora found in the park. The yellow-tailed woolly monkey, previously thought extinct, is found only in this area. Research undertaken since 1985 has already uncovered 36 previously unknown archaeological sites at altitudes of between 2,500 and 4,000 m, which give a good picture of pre-Inca society.

reviews.text: Absolutely Amazing! The nature and the animals!
Yes, excellwnt place
wish i could go
Great  place
pretty place

Name: Historic Centre of Saint Petersburg and Related Groups of Monuments
short_description: The 'Venice of the North', with its numerous canals and more than 400 bridges, is the result of a vast urban project begun in 1703 under Peter the Great. Later known as Leningrad (in the former USSR), the city is closely associated with the October Revolution. Its architectural heritage reconciles the very different Baroque and pure neoclassical styles, as can be seen in the Admiralty, the Winter Palace, the Marble Palace and the Hermitage.

reviews.text:
It’s great that the Hermitage now has a large modern platform for contemporary art!!!
Moreover, 100 steps from the Hermitage itself.
The Main Staff (RF Ministry of Defense) generally needs to be moved from the city center - what is the point of having headquarters in this place? Security facilities have belts and prohibit photographing historical sites; tourists laugh out loud at their comments. "What? Can't you take a picture of the Hermitage? Atlantov? A car with black license plates will get into the frame? Bugagaga.. idiots!" )))

We visited an exhibition of impressionist paintings and had a very good impression of the exhibition complex: clear navigation, convenient stairs, and an elevator. As for the content, as always in the Hermitage, everything is located very logically, equipped with signs; if you came without a tour, there is an audio guide.

One of the main assets of St. Petersburg. Main headquarters of the Hermitage. There are a lot of beautiful and impressive paintings and exhibitions. Immerse yourself in the reign of Peter I, see what weapons, interior items, clothing, and dishes looked like. At the very end you can enjoy Malevich’s “Black Square”). I definitely recommend visiting.

We were at the exhibition "Glasstress. Window to the Future". This is an exhibition of contemporary artists who created their works in glass on the island of Murano, in Venice. The exhibition was prepared by the Hermitage together with Studio Berengo (Venice).
I recommend it to everyone. Very interesting and beautiful. You just need to purchase tickets online in advance.
And it’s important!!! Buy tickets only on the official website (State Hermitage - Online tickets
tickets.hermitagemuseum.org). The ticket costs 500 rubles. More expensive on other sites.

My son and I attended the Glasstress exhibition and really enjoyed it! Tickets must be purchased on the website. The exhibition is magnificent, I recommend everyone to catch it before it closes.
The museum workers were upset. There was an absolutely unfriendly aunt at the checkout; they found out what was what with leading questions a hundred times. In the wardrobe it’s even worse: I asked to hang my coat on hangers - they threw the hangers, saying hang it yourself, then they took the coat away. When they took the things away, they said don’t forget to give them a tip on your shoulders)) guys, well, that’s not a big deal at all...

Name: Kizhi Pogost
short_description: The pogost of Kizhi (i.e. the Kizhi enclosure) is located on one of the many islands in Lake Onega, in Karelia. Two 18th-century wooden churches, and an octagonal clock tower, also in wood and built in 1862, can be seen there. These unusual constructions, in which carpenters created a bold visionary architecture, perpetuate an ancient model of parish space and are in harmony with the surrounding landscape.

reviews.text: This open air museum is really great and well organized. You arrive here by ship and then you stay there for 4 hours before return. The 1st 2 hours you have a guide, also in english, the other 2 hours you are free to do whatever you want. There is also a restaurant there and souvenir shops. The main church is still closed for reconstruction.

I was searching for a spot in the St. petersburg area online and decided to look for Kizhi, just out of curiosity  --- I visited this place back in 1973...
Yes, that's 47 years ago!!       I was in high school at the time, and taking part in a Russian language study summer trip!     This was one of several excursions while I was staying in Leningrad (St. Petersburg!)     Back in the cold war era..!!!            Anyway, seeing all the online photos now sure brought back some memories!        I remember seeing those wooden churches with such amazing detail, and wondering how and why they were built.     Going by the recent photos, it looks like this place has been well maintained, which is good.

If you find yourself in the area for any reason, this is a worthwhile side trip.

Wooden architecture can be found throughout Russia, but Kizhi Island boasts some of the nation's most famous, and most intricate, examples. These structures on Kizhi Island date from various centuries (the oldest from the 14th century), Blessed with one of the most picturesque ensembles of Russian wooden churches, the Lake Onega island Kizhi provides the most scenic destination on Russia’s greatest waterway, the Volga.

Famous Kizhi - the legend says these churches and other buildings were built without any nail. Truth it or not, doesn't matter as Kizhi quite popular among tourists either Russian or International (On the day we were visiting Kizhi, huge ship had arrived with dozens of tourists mostly Americans and German). Kizhi is a magic place, quiet and like no other. The way people used to live here was recreated - students and volunteers dressed in   relevant clothes will tell you some stories about how Kizhi was established, what people ate and how they survived long and cold winters. Beatiful choir consisting of 4 or 5 singers will bring you some sense of this place

I don't know if I believe everything I am told about this place (Built by one man who threw his axe in the lake upon completion) but it is something special to see.  Love outdoor museums and this one is great.

Name: Kremlin and Red Square, Moscow
short_description: Inextricably linked to all the most important historical and political events in Russia since the 13th century, the Kremlin (built between the 14th and 17th centuries by outstanding Russian and foreign architects) was the residence of the Great Prince and also a religious centre. At the foot of its ramparts, on Red Square, St Basil's Basilica is one of the most beautiful Russian Orthodox monuments.

reviews.text:
A Glimpse into Russian History and Architecture
The Kremlin Architectural Complex beside Red Square, and it was an unforgettable experience. The entrance, conveniently located near the State History Museum, made it easy to access the treasures within.

Opting for the Kremlin ticket, I was treated to a comprehensive tour of this historic site. The Cathedral of the Archangel and the Dormition Cathedral left me in awe with their breathtaking architecture and rich history. The intricate details and sheer grandeur of these structures were truly remarkable.

Exploring the complex felt like stepping back in time, offering a fascinating insight into Russian culture, art, and politics. The well-preserved historical artifacts and exhibits added depth to the experience.

I highly recommend the Kremlin ticket for anyone interested in immersing themselves in the heritage of Russia. It's a journey through centuries of culture and power, leaving you with a newfound appreciation for this iconic site. Don't miss out on this opportunity to witness the heart of Moscow's history.

Beautiful place with a rich history, energized atmosphere, and incredible architecture. Highly recommend the tour of the inside of the Kremlin, where you can visit cathedrals dating back to the 13th century. Great place to be anytime during the day, but especially at night! (I would also advise making a stop at the eternal flame, which honors the loss of soldiers' lives in WWII).

A place full of history, the churches, and gardens are well worth the visit. Its impressive how this place is so well maintained. You can see the cannons left behind by Napoleon. You can also see iconic buildings from Russia's history although the tourist can really only see them from the outside, yet its still very worthwhile.

Fantastic experience. We took the opportunity to take a cruise excursion into Moscow on high speed  train. We had the most wonderful tour guide who had a great head of knowledge. It was a long day but so worth the money for the trip.  Loved every minute of it. Would recommend the trip.

Amazing, a must see place. Have a tour that takes in the Cathedrals and the Treasury museum, spectacular. Finish it off by visiting Red Square in the evening, with everything lit up.

Update Sep 2023 - that review didn't age very well!! 😲 Maybe we can revisit in about 20 years....

Name: Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings, Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra
short_description: Designed to rival Hagia Sophia in Constantinople, Kyiv's Saint-Sophia Cathedral symbolizes the 'new Constantinople', capital of the Christian principality of Kyiv, which was created in the 11th century in a region evangelized after the baptism of St Vladimir in 988. The spiritual and intellectual influence of Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra contributed to the spread of Orthodox thought and the Orthodox faith in the Russian world from the 17th to the 19th century.

reviews.text:
I visited just before the start of war, so my review is based on my experience at that time.

Another beautiful historic religious building in Kyiv. Definitely going to visit again when things return to normal.

The Cathedral of St. Sophia in Kyiv, also known as Sophia of Kyiv, is a masterpiece of Byzantine architecture and a symbol of Ukrainian history and culture. Built between 1017 and 1037 during the reign of Grand Prince Yaroslav the Wise, it served as the spiritual and political center of the medieval Kyivan Rus' empire. The cathedral's stunning interior is adorned with intricate mosaics and frescoes, showcasing the artistic achievements of the period and attracting visitors from around the world to marvel at its beauty and significance.

Orthodox cathedral from 11st with golden dome and bell tower separated from the church. Metropolit's residence and the museum are part of the cathedral complex. Cathedral is inscribed on the World Heritage List along with the Kyiv Cave Monastery complex. Place to visit while in the city.
I travel a lot so I've seen many beautiful cathedrals. But still St. Sofia impressed me to the bottom of my heart. Amazing antient place with gorgeous wall-paintings.

Tramendous historical place to visit, built in the 11th century. Several buildings with excibitions and fresco on the religious topics. I would advise to explore it with the guided tour and buy souvenirs.
As I was born in this city, I have visited it many times. Attached are 2 old historical photos that I liked and my photos :)

Name: Itchan Kala
short_description: Itchan Kala is the inner town (protected by brick walls some 10 m high) of the old Khiva oasis, which was the last resting-place of caravans before crossing the desert to Iran. Although few very old monuments still remain, it is a coherent and well-preserved example of the Muslim architecture of Central Asia. There are several outstanding structures such as the Djuma Mosque, the mausoleums and the madrasas and the two magnificent palaces built at the beginning of the 19th century by Alla-Kulli-Khan.
formatted_address: А, Болтаева-41, 220900, Xiva, Xorazm Viloyati, Uzbekistan

reviews.text:
A place like 1001 nights. Wonderful old ancient city in very good condition. For the best photo come in the early morning or late night. The streets are empty and the lights illuminate the historic scenery.
With entrance fee you may enter several museums, without you may enter the city but can't go inside buildings, museums etc.

Ichan Kala is a mesmerizing historical site that transports visitors back in time. Walking through its grand gates feels like stepping into a Silk Road-era city, where every narrow alley, towering minaret, and ancient madrasah tells a story. The well-preserved architecture encapsulates the rich history of Khiva’s rulers, showcasing the grandeur of past dynasties.

The fortified city is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, filled with stunning palaces, mosques, and intricate tilework. Exploring its monuments gives a true sense of Uzbekistan’s royal legacy and cultural heritage. A must-visit for history enthusiasts and travelers seeking an authentic experience of Central Asia’s past
An amazing experience! A top attraction! A must see!!! The entrance is free and you have to pay for some sights (in my opinion the full ticket of 250.000 SUM is not worth it).

What a beautiful historical building and museum. You can see the kings living quarters as well as his wives living quarters.

The building design and details are well preserved. Too bad they have souvenirs sellers everywhere, including inside of some rooms and courtyards. It’s a bit over the top commercial at its worst.

It seems much more like a large souvenir shop (with extremely high prices, so much so that they even asked me $20 for a simple bell) than an open-air museum. I absolutely do not recommend buying an entrance ticket to the old city, also because most of the museums/monuments only have other stalls inside (and in any case the quality of Uzbek museums is, in general, very low). It is a place that, thanks to the omnipresent flow of tourists, does not have even a shadow of authenticity.

Name: Shark Bay, Western Australia
short_description: At the most westerly point of the Australian continent, Shark Bay, with its islands and the land surrounding it, has three exceptional natural features: its vast sea-grass beds, which are the largest (4,800 km2) and richest in the world; its dugong (‘sea cow’) population; and its stromatolites (colonies of algae which form hard, dome-shaped deposits and are among the oldest forms of life on earth). Shark Bay is also home to five species of endangered mammals.

reviews.text:
Went to Steep point. Great camping and fishing. It's a tough road in and out. You will see busted up trailers on the side of the track going in. We had seven people, three cars, 2 boats and one camper. We ended up braking 3 wheel guards, 1 X leaf spring and killed one tire.

It's about 130km from the blacktop in and that took about 4 hours and took us 5 hours to get out (leaf spring).

Make sure you take enough beers as if you run out then you have none. Take back up in with you. (We had a spare leaf spring) Things like spare glasses, shoes, water, CB radios, hat ECT.

You can catch fish from the beach and rocks. Remember they don't call this area shark bay for nothing. There are lots of them.

Make sure to take all your rubbish out with you

See it before it all goes.

There are national parks, stromatolites that are millions of years old, beaches made entirely from shells and artesian hot tubs fed by hot springs. The entire peninsula is abeautiful UNESCO World Heritage site, full of wildlife and sparsely populated by people. I love it so much ❤❤❤😘

Parts were spectacular although the camping spots south of Denham were basic. The lookouts, especially Eagle Bluff ... just awesome. What is so impressive about Shark Bay is the diversity ... the stromatolites, the amazing Shell Beach, the wild dolphins of Monkey Mia and then the dugong, sharks, turtles and bird life that can all be seen from the shore. A very special place.

Sep 22 - Road was recently graded, but still heavily corrugated in parts. Allow 3 to 4 hours to get to Steep Point from the turnoff on to Useless Loop Road. Shelter Bay was a great place tp stay with aqua coloured water - Beautiful!

Great holiday spot for fishing and relaxing. We stayed at Denham Seaside Caravan Park. Very clean and tidy,  good camp kitchen, ablutions and laundry. Has a fish cleaning facility just off the beach. There are a couple of grocery shops, a pub, bakery/cafe, 2 fuel stations, a restaurant, a post office/pharmacy plus a couple of takeaways, and the obligatory souvenir shop.
We had a great 10 days there exploring the area.

Name: Historic City of Sucre
short_description: Sucre, the first capital of Bolivia, was founded by the Spanish in the first half of the 16th century. Its many well-preserved 16th-century religious buildings, such as San Lázaro, San Francisco and Santo Domingo, illustrate the blending of local architectural traditions with styles imported from Europe.

Name: Serra da Capivara National Park
short_description: Many of the numerous rock shelters in the Serra da Capivara National Park are decorated with cave paintings, some more than 25,000 years old. They are an outstanding testimony to one of the oldest human communities of South America.
formatted_address: R. Dr. Luís Paixão, 188 - Milonga, João Costa - PI, 64770-000, Brazil

reviews.text: This is one of the places in the world that everybody should have the chance to go. The park is amazing - ancient paintings, amazing views, preserved nature and kind people. Not even us brazilians are used to know about it or go there - so, spread the word. There is infrastructure and even people with disabilities can visit some of the archeological sites.
