This National Park is an amazing place with an outstanding environmental conservation program done by the Park staff and the FUMDHAM. Acess to the sites with prehistoric paintings is very easy. The trails and roads in the Park are very well kept, nevertheless, as per local regulations, there’s the need to be acompannied by a local guide, as the Park is huge and it’s very easy to get lost.

It was so hard to find a guide because it is not organized for tourists especially when you don't stay in the accommodation with connection to the park. Going with a guide is required but I couldn't get an English speaking guide. But seeing ancient painting some of which are 15000 years ago was definitely interesting. And the view is great as well. I hope they make it easier to visit for everyone in the near future.

We've visited many National Parks around the world.   Serra da Capivara is by far amongst the most beautiful and well presented. Stunning landscape.     Great hike on beatiful trails to the hundreds of well preserved cave paintings.   We did a 1.5-day tour to cover different areas of the park.   A guide is required.   Most guides don't speak English.    So if you are not fluent in Portugese or Spanish, I recommend that you ask the hotel to help recommending an English-speaking guide for you in advance. Baixo Ouro Park Hotel is the best place to stay.   It's a beautiful hotel with basic but very clean rooms, and located only a few-minute drive from the main entrance.      Sao Raimundo (NSR) airport is the closest to the park.    At the time of our visit (November 2023), Azul is the only airlines flying here from Recife, 3 times per week.    Serra da Capivara Park is not easy to get to, but is definitely worth a visit.

Serra da Capivara National Park is a remarkable and culturally significant natural treasure located in northeastern Brazil. Renowned for its astonishing collection of prehistoric rock art, the park is a testament to the ancient civilizations that once thrived in the region.

Covering an expansive area of over 1,300 square kilometers, Serra da Capivara National Park boasts a diverse landscape of canyons, valleys, and plateaus, offering breathtaking vistas at every turn. However, it is the park's rich archaeological heritage that truly sets it apart. The rock art found here dates back thousands of years and provides invaluable insights into the lives and customs of the early inhabitants of the region.

Exploring the park is like stepping back in time. Visitors can embark on guided tours led by knowledgeable experts who unravel the stories behind the intricate rock paintings and engravings. These ancient artworks depict scenes of daily life, hunting expeditions, rituals, and a myriad of animals that once roamed the area. It is a mesmerizing journey into the history and cultural heritage of Brazil.

Beyond the rock art, Serra da Capivara National Park offers a haven for wildlife enthusiasts and nature lovers. The park is home to a diverse array of flora and fauna, including capybaras, maned wolves, armadillos, and a wide variety of bird species. The preserved ecosystem provides a sanctuary for these creatures, and visitors can encounter them while exploring the park's trails.

To fully experience the wonders of Serra da Capivara National Park, it is advisable to allocate several days to explore its vast expanse. The park offers camping facilities and guesthouses, providing visitors with the opportunity to immerse themselves in the natural surroundings and fully appreciate the park's tranquility.

Serra da Capivara National Park stands as a testament to the deep-rooted history and natural beauty of Brazil. It offers a unique blend of archaeology, nature, and adventure, captivating the imaginations of all who venture within its borders. For those seeking an unforgettable journey into the past, this extraordinary park is a must-visit destination.

Name: Old Rauma
short_description: Situated on the Gulf of Botnia, Rauma is one of the oldest harbours in Finland. Built around a Franciscan monastery, where the mid-15th-century Holy Cross Church still stands, it is an outstanding example of an old Nordic city constructed in wood. Although ravaged by fire in the late 17th century, it has preserved its ancient vernacular architectural heritage.

reviews.text: This charming old city is filled with vibrant, colorful buildings that add a unique character to its streets. Local shops and museums are dotted throughout, offering a glimpse into the town’s rich history and culture. It’s the perfect place to wander at a leisurely pace, taking in the timeless beauty of the architecture and the relaxed atmosphere of the old town. Whether you’re exploring hidden alleyways or soaking up the local vibe, this picturesque city invites you to slow down and savor every moment.
Lovely town. Very cute. Nice to have a walk and enjoy its streets and buildings. Be there before 17:00h, after that almost everything is closed.
Lovely place, very picturesque, wander through the cobbled streets and admire beautiful wooden houses. There are some cozy cafes and art galleries, too. Sometimes this place looks a bit deserted.

The old town is worthy to be seen. Some buildings need renovation and with more flowers and plants the place would gain more attractivity. The most abhorrent thing there was the continuous flow of cars rushing through the narrow streets, disfiguring the historical and picturesque atmosphere. Some drivers seemed to do bone lazy and despicable sightseeing by car. A historical place like this should be car free or cars just allowed for local residents.

Just at The edge of Rauma's famous wooden old town is this beautiful simple styled white hotel. It is almost unbearable that it was already completed in 1937 and therefore is almost 90 years old and that the Finn's would create such a nice building in such a dark time. You will find these kind of buildings in every Finish city.

Name: Fortress of Suomenlinna
short_description: Built in the second half of the 18th century by Sweden on a group of islands located at the entrance of Helsinki's harbour, this fortress is an especially interesting example of European military architecture of the time.

reviews.text: Great place to spend a few hours! This island has an historic fortress, museums, shops, and more. Best of all it's just a short boat ride from Helsinki, so it's easy to get to.

Suomenlinna Fortress is an absolute must-visit when in Helsinki. This stunning sea fortress offers breathtaking views and a glimpse into Finland's rich history. The fortress itself is a UNESCO World Heritage site, and it's easy to see why. The well-preserved architecture, the scenic surroundings, and the peaceful atmosphere make it a perfect place to spend a day.
Getting there is a breeze. A short 20-minute ferry ride from Helsinki's Market Square takes you to the island. And the best part? You can use your regular HSL Zone AB ticket for the ferry, making it an affordable outing.
I visited on a beautiful sunny day, and the weather was perfect for exploring the fortress. I highly recommend taking a stroll around the island, visiting the museums, and enjoying a picnic with a view. Suomenlinna is a true gem, and I can't wait to visit again.

If you only have the time to do one thing in Finland, go to Suomenlinna. Each island has a different set of surprises, and you could explore for hours and there would still be so much more to see. The ferry is included in the standard metro pass. 10/10 experience.

Suomenlinna Island in Helsinki is a must-visit destination for history lovers and nature enthusiasts. This historic sea fortress, a UNESCO World Heritage site, offers a glimpse into Finland’s past while providing breathtaking scenery. Taking a boat tour to the island is a fantastic experience, as the surrounding landscapes are truly picturesque.

A timeless gem of Helsinki! Suomenlinna Island, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is a captivating blend of history, nature, and Nordic charm. Wander through centuries-old fortresses, tunnels, and cannons while soaking in panoramic sea views and rugged coastal beauty. The maritime museums and quaint cafés add depth to the experience, and the short ferry ride from the city center feels like a mini-adventure. Perfect for history buffs, picnics, or simply strolling along windswept paths with the Baltic breeze in your hair. Don’t miss the sunset – it paints the fortress walls in golden hues! �🏰🌊 Tip: Wear comfy shoes and pack a picnic for the ultimate island day!

Name: Paris, Banks of the Seine
short_description: From the Louvre to the Eiffel Tower, from the Place de la Concorde to the Grand and Petit Palais, the evolution of Paris and its history can be seen from the River Seine. The Cathedral of Notre-Dame and the Sainte Chapelle are architectural masterpieces while Haussmann's wide squares and boulevards influenced late 19th- and 20th-century town planning the world over.

reviews.text:
The Seine River Cruise was an enchanting way to experience the beauty of Paris from a unique perspective. Gliding along the calm waters of the Seine, I was captivated by the breathtaking views of the city’s iconic landmarks, each illuminated in its own grandeur.

The cruise offered a perfect blend of relaxation and discovery. Seeing landmarks like the Eiffel Tower, Notre-Dame Cathedral, and the Louvre from the river provided a new appreciation for their architectural splendor. Passing under the historic bridges, especially Pont Alexandre III, was a delightful experience, as each had its own story and charm.

The ambiance on board was serene and romantic, enhanced by the soft lighting and gentle breeze. For those who choose the evening cruises, the city truly lives up to its name as the “City of Lights.” Watching the Eiffel Tower sparkle while floating on the Seine was a moment I’ll never forget.

The staff was courteous, and the audio guide provided fascinating insights into the history and significance of the landmarks. Everything was well-organized, from boarding to the duration of the cruise, making the experience seamless and enjoyable.

I’d highly recommend the Seine River Cruise to anyone visiting Paris. Whether you’re looking for a romantic evening, a relaxing escape, or a new way to explore the city, this cruise is a must-do. My only regret is not doing it sooner!
There are some amazing sunset views. Would like to go on a boat cruise here one day. In general the area is relatively clean but the water can improve.

Not a very wide river, per say. But a long one. Vikings sailed up it to conquer. Canals were built to expand it. Bridges are built to cross over it. And dams are built to harness it. Long boats motor it for its beauty, and tourists gaze at it for the French vive la France feeling that is truly this landmark river of Paris, France.

Loved to stroll along the river.
Kids’s eyes were captured by a swan in the river.

The Seine River is the lifeblood of Paris, winding gracefully through the heart of the city and offering some of the most picturesque views. Its banks are lined with iconic landmarks like the Eiffel Tower, Notre-Dame, and the Louvre, making a stroll or boat ride along the river a quintessential Parisian experience. The Seine is not just a beautiful waterway but also a symbol of Paris’s history and romance, especially at sunset when the city’s lights reflect off its gentle waters. Whether you're walking along its scenic quays or cruising on a bateau-mouche, the Seine offers a tranquil and unforgettable glimpse of the city’s magic.

Name: Cathedral of Notre-Dame, Former Abbey of Saint-Rémi and Palace of Tau, Reims
short_description: The outstanding handling of new architectural techniques in the 13th century, and the harmonious marriage of sculptural decoration with architecture, has made Notre-Dame in Reims one of the masterpieces of Gothic art. The former abbey still has its beautiful 9th-century nave, in which lie the remains of Archbishop St Rémi (440–533), who instituted the Holy Anointing of the kings of France. The former archiepiscopal palace known as the Tau Palace, which played an important role in religious ceremonies, was almost entirely rebuilt in the 17th century.
formatted_address: Pl. du Cardinal Luçon, 51100 Reims, France

reviews.text: What makes Reims Cathedral stand out in the long list of beautiful French cathedrals is the massive collection of larger than life-sized statues that adorn its outside. Take note of the list of enormous petrified Royals looking down at you from the Western Facade, and the similarly large animal-shaped gargoyles all around the temple. Inside, most remarkable is the collection of modern and contemporary stained glass, innovative, unique pieces, that most will either love or hate. In winter, bring a jacket. It will be cold inside.

Impressive cathedral with thousands of carvings to the exterior covering every inch of stone. The interior is less impressive and I was not keen on the replacement stain glass at the rear, looked a bit psychedelic if I'm honest.
The strangest thing is the Souvenir shop slap bang in the cathedral.  Reminded me of the story when Jesus found the sellers in the church and he threw them all out. Seems its OK for the church to sell out of its own building lol.

This is a stunning example of Gothic architecture and a site of immense historical importance. It served as the coronation site for French kings for centuries, making it a cornerstone of France’s royal history. The intricate sculptures and awe-inspiring stained glass windows are reason enough to visit, but what makes it truly unforgettable is the nightly light show through December at 8 PM.

I was lucky to stumble upon the very first evening of the show, which brought the facade to life in a captivating display of color and light. It’s a beautiful way to experience the cathedral in a modern, engaging context. Whether you’re interested in history, art, or just seeking a memorable experience, this landmark is absolutely worth a visit.

Our tour group stopped in Reims, France to check out the Roman Catholic Cathedral of Notre-Dame of Reims. It is similar to the Notre-Dame in Paris, which was still damaged when we arrive there.  It was built in 1212 and it took 64 years to complete. The exterior is very impressive with its gothic architecture and gargoyles.

The Reims cathedral is the traditional place where the kings of France were once coronated. Multiple fires have damaged or destroyed parts of the cathedral over its long and eventful life. During the French Revolution it was even closed and turned into a storehouse for grain. Much of the symbols of royalty were destroyed, the reliquary melted down for gold and the bells melted down as well for cannon balls.

During WW1, the floor was covered inside with hay and used as a hospital. It was heavily damaged and almost left in its badly damaged state as a war memorial, until it was eventually repaired in 1938. With all that it has been through in its long life, it is a very beautiful and impressive cathedral with its tall, narrow, arched roofs and stained glass.

A very impressive cathedral, inside and out.

The cathedral was dedicated to the Virgin Mary and was the traditional location for the coronation of the kings of France. What a beautiful heritage, wow. Its a must if you like French history and Christianity.

Name: Abbey and Altenmünster of Lorsch
short_description: The abbey, together with its monumental entrance, the famous 'Torhall', are rare architectural vestiges of the Carolingian era. The sculptures and paintings from this period are still in remarkably good condition.

reviews.text:
Located in a sleepy same-named town Lorch, the Abbey itself is not a must see, it is not amazing, it is not impressive, one might wonder why is it listed as a world heritage site? But this place has a certain ambience, an aura if you will, that is hard to describe - it’s peaceful, calm and unbelievably picturesque! Also it is surprisingly a great place for relaxation!

The entry is free to the premises of the Abbey, however if visitors want to visit the chambers of the Kings Hall, a guided tour ticket must be purchased. Unfortunately the tours are available only in German (if you want English, you need to contract the place in advance). Luckily the staff here was very friendly and welcoming, therefore they let me join the German tour to visit the chambers only, free of charge! Very much appreciated!

The whole area of the Abbey is very well preserved and maintained, it is neat and clean, especially the pitch-perfect grass is very inviting. In the nearby museum, where guided tour tickets can be purchased (payments possible with card), some English brochures with explanations about this place are available. Many restaurants and cafes are lined up on the road leading to the main square, therefore plenty of choice of food. Train station is approximately 10 minutes away by foot.

Recommended If you pass by, however I would not plan this as a main destination. Visited in August 2022.

The "Königshalle" belongs to UNESCO world heritage now. Researchers are still not sure what its exact purpose was back in the times. But one thing is sure it was built 764 & still stands. The top level, only to be seen with a guide, has still wall paintings from different centuries.

We had a great guide how gave us all the information he could, based on the facts already discovered by the archeologists.
The place is beautiful and perfect for family, and the history is very interesting
Quite a quaint town with its UNESCO easily accessible
There's a nice walk around the garden near the abbey where you can learn about local plants and enjoy the beautifully maintained architecture.

Name: Borobudur Temple Compounds
short_description: This famous Buddhist temple, dating from the 8th and 9th centuries, is located in central Java. It was built in three tiers: a pyramidal base with five concentric square terraces, the trunk of a cone with three circular platforms and, at the top, a monumental stupa. The walls and balustrades are decorated with fine low reliefs, covering a total surface area of 2,500 m2. Around the circular platforms are 72 openwork stupas, each containing a statue of the Buddha. The monument was restored with UNESCO's help in the 1970s.
formatted_address: Jl. Badrawati, Kw. Candi Borobudur, Borobudur, Kec. Borobudur, Kabupaten Magelang, Jawa Tengah, Indonesia

reviews.text: I recently visited Borobudur Temple during my holiday, arriving around 3 or 4 PM after the rain. The weather was perfect, creating a serene and refreshing atmosphere. The temple’s view was stunning, and the calm surroundings made the experience even more enjoyable. Compared to previous visits, I noticed significant improvements—everything is now well-organized, clean, and well-maintained. The management has done a great job in preserving this historical site while enhancing the visitor experience. Overall, it was a wonderful visit, and I highly recommend coming in the late afternoon for the best ambiance

The worship site is a huge accomplishment of human feat. The location is still under further development. The sacred sanctuary does provoke a sense of holiness and serenity. However the entrance to the top of the temple costs a lot more and international visitors be ready to pay a lot more for the exorbitant price as the board calls for extra foreign transaction fee.

Must visit tourist attraction when in Jogjakarta. Although it is at Central Java, the drive is worth it. Good to have a guide explaining the significance of this heritage site. Plenty of scenic sights to view and to see up close the ancient ruins are amazing and breathtaking.
We could not climb the temple as it is closed for climbing on Mondays. But it was stunning! Works cannot describe the detail of the work that it took to build and then preserve this wonderful place.

Fantastic place to visit a beautiful piece of history that you can go and visit. It is 100% worth your time. Stunning vistas and fantastic tour guides who are very knowledgeable on the area and temple. Tour is Fantastic and we had a great

Name: Ujung Kulon National Park
short_description: This national park, located in the extreme south-western tip of Java on the Sunda shelf, includes the Ujung Kulon peninsula and several offshore islands and encompasses the natural reserve of Krakatoa. In addition to its natural beauty and geological interest – particularly for the study of inland volcanoes – it contains the largest remaining area of lowland rainforests in the Java plain. Several species of endangered plants and animals can be found there, the Javan rhinoceros being the most seriously under threat.

reviews.text:
Beautiful remote island, 8hour from jakarta, upgrade the room in Fauna so one room for 4people and 3 bathrooms for 7 rooms, lol.

Not meet with the rhino but meet many monkeys, deers and pigs. The beach really beautiful, dont miss to play kayak and take picture/video with drone.

When i was there, the electricity was bad. Grill corn and eat the fried banana at night, something you should try.

Taman Nasional Ujung Kulon(ujung kulon national park) is a park where endangered animals are kept, especially rhinos. Along the road to the park there are beatiful views of the beach, green and very cool mountains
More than half of my age and still a wonderful place of nature beauty, tranquility preserved, a must to go destination

The Park is located on the western tip of Java, Indonesia, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and the last remaining habitat of the critically endangered Javan rhinoceros.

One of the best experiences you can have when in Indonesia.

The park covers over 120,000 hectares and is home to a diverse range of wildlife, including tigers, leopards, and various species of birds.

You can either drive to the park or take a bus. Actually you need to take several buses and mini vans to get here.

Once you arrive at the park, you can explore the park by hiking, boating, or camping. It is recommended to plan and make arrangements with park staff or local tour operators to ensure a safe and enjoyable visit.
Awesome park, need to go in with a government authorized guide in areas, great jungle/wildlife, one of the best National parks I’ve been to in Indonesia

Name: Komodo National Park
short_description: These volcanic islands are inhabited by a population of around 5,700 giant lizards, whose appearance and aggressive behaviour have led to them being called 'Komodo dragons'. They exist nowhere else in the world and are of great interest to scientists studying the theory of evolution. The rugged hillsides of dry savannah and pockets of thorny green vegetation contrast starkly with the brilliant white sandy beaches and the blue waters surging over coral.

reviews.text: Visiting the Komodo Islands was an unforgettable adventure! The stunning landscapes, crystal-clear waters, and the chance to see the iconic Komodo dragons up close made it a truly unique experience. The guided tours were well-organized, ensuring both safety and respect for the wildlife. Snorkeling in the vibrant coral reefs was another highlight, with breathtaking marine life all around. This is a must-visit destination for nature lovers and adventure seekers. Highly recommended!

This is a spectacular place. A private day trip from our hotel by boat to this beautiful place. The steep steps to the top for these views are worth it.

Pink beach, worth a swim!

Komodo dragons a must see, a chance to walk around the park and see them in their natural habitat, a friendly, knowledgeable guide at your-side.

If you're looking for a travel destination packed with adventure, natural beauty, and unique experiences, then Komodo Island should be high on your list.

One of the reasons we made an Indonesia and South Pacific cruise was to see the Komodo Dragons.  We were not disappointed.  The preserve was amazing.  On our two hour trek we saw 9 different dragons.  Two large males, several females and some juveniles.

Dragons are unique creatures.  The males are from 6 to 8 feet long and weight up to 600 pounds.  I understand they have some even bigger. They can move surprisingly fast when after prey.  You have a guide and a park ranger when hiking through the jungle.

The weather can change rapidly.  We were caught in a downpour after we got back to the entrance.  It was an awesome visit.  A once in a lifetime adventure.

We flew over from Bali just for the day trip to Komodo Island then flew back & it didn’t disappoint! They’re amazing animals, we were lucky enough to see 4 on our tour and we only took the medium length tour. The rangers are very informative and take great photos for you too.

One of the world’s great national parks. So many diverse islands with many spectacular and famous dive sights, Komodo dragons and unearthly vistas. While there are day trips taking in half a dozen of the better known places I’d highly recommend against it. There’s just to much to see and do, you can’t possibly fit it all in in one day. It would feel so rushed and crowded, just being part of the mass tourist machine isn’t much fun. If you can, do a small group or best of all private multi day charter. Or private day charters. There’s so many boats in Labuan Bajo you won’t have a problem finding one that suits your needs and it’s such an advantage to be able to customise the itinerary over multiple days.

Name: Prambanan Temple Compounds
short_description: Built in the 10th century, this is the largest temple compound dedicated to Shiva in Indonesia. Rising above the centre of the last of these concentric squares are three temples decorated with reliefs illustrating the epic of the Ramayana, dedicated to the three great Hindu divinities (Shiva, Vishnu and Brahma) and three temples dedicated to the animals who serve them.
formatted_address: Jl. Raya Solo - Yogyakarta No.16, Kranggan, Bokoharjo, Kec. Prambanan, Kabupaten Sleman, Daerah Istimewa Yogyakarta 55571, Indonesia

reviews.text: We bought our ticket for Prambanan temple prior at Borobudur as they offered a special deal of two locations for one price at the ticket counter- unfortunately the Borobudur tickets for walking amongst the stones were sold out so this offer to walk only outside the stone area and a entry to Prambanan was the best alternative option. FYI buy your Borobudur tickets online a week in advance- this is a new process implemented two months ago! With the ticket purchased from Borobudur as ‘foreigners’ we enter through a different entrance where it is air conditioned, with fresh clean toilets and we get a free bottle of water. There is also the option to hire a professional guide (110k). Personally, I found this temple more enjoyable than Borobudur. We had free range to explore the grounds without the limitations instilled at Borobudur at a flat rate price. There are actually four temple spots to visit. I highly recommend checking out the smaller ones first as they aren’t far from the main one and are hardly visited but are just as fascinating and beautiful- they are also older than the main site. There are options to cycle or take a large golf cart there but it’s unnecessary as they aren’t that far. However, the walk to the exit is a very long way and ends with a long journey through souvenir shops, drink stands, etc. with crowds of visitors heading the same way. Prambanan temple is totally worth visiting, friendlier staff and better managed compared to Borobudur :) All up we spent about two hours here. If you have extra time, there is also a museum to check out on the way to the exit.

Another splendid heritage attraction worth exploring. A knowledgeable guide makes the visit more interesting, giving insights into the history and background of this ancient site. Beware of rain though if it happens as the steps can be slippery. Otherwise it’s a great experience.

Prambanan Temple is honestly mind blowing. Just thinking about how they built this masterpiece back then is crazy. The architecture, the detailed carvings, the whole vibe so cool. And the history behind it super interesting. If you're into that, you can dig deeper at the Prambanan Temple Museum.

But it’s not all about history here. You can ride a tandem bike with your homies, cruise around on a scooter, try archery, check out some animals near the temple, or hit up the Prambanan market for souvenirs. So yea it’s not just an ancient site, it’s a fun spot to explore too. No wonder so many school trips happen here, it’s got the perfect mix of learning and good times.

Absolutely worth visiting! I personally enjoyed it even more than Borobudur Temple. The intricate details and towering structures are breathtaking. Make sure not to miss the smaller temples within the Prambanan complex—they add so much to the experience. A truly unforgettable site!

Prambanan is an incredible historical site!!!
The temple complex, a UNESCO World Heritage site, is stunning with its tall Hindu temples and intricate stone carvings.
It’s a peaceful and spacious place to explore, offering a glimpse into Indonesia’s rich cultural and religious history.
I enjoyed learning about the stories behind the temples, particularly the mythological tales depicted in the carvings.
The site is well-maintained, and you’ll find plenty of opportunities for photos.
It can get quite hot, so be sure to stay hydrated and wear sun protection.
Overall, Prambanan is a must-see attraction for anyone visiting Yogyakarta, especially if you’re interested in history, culture, or architecture.

Name: Historic Centre of Morelia
short_description: Built in the 16th century, Morelia is an outstanding example of urban planning which combines the ideas of the Spanish Renaissance with the Mesoamerican experience. Well-adapted to the slopes of the hill site, its streets still follow the original layout. More than 200 historic buildings, all in the region's characteristic pink stone, reflect the town's architectural history, revealing a masterly and eclectic blend of the medieval spirit with Renaissance, Baroque and neoclassical elements. Morelia was the birthplace of several important personalities of independent Mexico and has played a major role in the country's history.
formatted_address: Centro histórico de Morelia, 58000 Morelia, Mich., Mexico

Name: Island of Mozambique
short_description: The fortified city of Mozambique is located on this island, a former Portuguese trading-post on the route to India. Its remarkable architectural unity is due to the consistent use, since the 16th century, of the same building techniques, building materials (stone or macuti) and decorative principles.

reviews.text: Wonderful experience with very friendly people in the Island.

I love this place. It's a cute little Island in the Nampula province. I drove there from Malawi, it took me two days and was a great trip.

The Island is calcareous coral reef joined to the main land by a long single lane bridge. One half of the Island is called stone town - with colonial Portuguese buildings and the other half is macuti town with traditional buildings with thatched palm leave roofs.

The people, the food, the atmosphere is just incredible. I loved my time here.

I stayed at Jardim dos Aloes and found it hard to leave. They took such good care of me. Have a meal at Sara's and Saquina's.

Go on a bicycle tour to learn the history. Go on a boat trip to the islands and depending on season you may get to see whales, Dolphins. The snorkeling at the wreck is great and the light house us very cool. I asks went on a kayaking and snorkeling trip aims the island. Book with ilha de blue.

I will go back again

Island of Mozambique is a wonderful place to visit and make tourism.

The history of Mozambique began from this place.

The name Mozambique is due to an Arabian man called Mussa Bin Bique.

The island is beautiful, the buildings remember Portugal because of its architecture. There are nice hotels and beautiful beaches.

I have been in this place and I loved so much.

It's a amazing Island, I visited with my Girlfriend and we had a lot of fun, I mean a lot the people are so friendly we visited almost every single corner of the island, we ate At Zaval 5 (unt Mariamo's restaurant), spent some times at the Café central with a good company of the waiter Mussa, we swam, the island is small but it has a lot to offer, it's memorable monuments and historical events.
I'm going back at the end of the year.
You can find everything you want in there, banks, hotels, hotels, restaurants, mosques, churches, transportation services, night clubs. And many more.
Great place to visit, the island is small but has a great mix of places to stay, restaurants, sandy beaches and hundreds of historic buildings to check out.

Name: Air and Ténéré Natural Reserves
short_description: This is the largest protected area in Africa, covering some 7.7 million ha, though the area considered a protected sanctuary constitutes only one-sixth of the total area. It includes the volcanic rock mass of the Aïr, a small Sahelian pocket, isolated as regards its climate and flora and fauna, and situated in the Saharan desert of Ténéré. The reserves boast an outstanding variety of landscapes, plant species and wild animals.

Name: Danube Delta
short_description: The waters of the Danube, which flow into the Black Sea, form the largest and best preserved of Europe's deltas. The Danube delta hosts over 300 species of birds as well as 45 freshwater fish species in its numerous lakes and marshes.

reviews.text:
Amazing places and a must see.
Definitely have to take a boat to have a ride around to see flora and fauna. Danube has 3 branches that can be visited by boat, any you take is beautiful.
Many hotels and pensions around so just talk at the reception and they will help you book a trip around.
On the boat it will be windy in any season, take what you need so you feel confortable.
Amazing, breathtaking place. Another "must see" pláče in your life! Trust me 😉

The Danube Delta is one of the last wild places in Europe; in Romania, it is also known as the birds' paradise.

You must visit this place if you are passionate about nature; if you decide to do it, please avoid the high-speed boats, whose pilots have the habit of suddenly approaching the bird colonies so that some bored tourists can take some pictures of dubious quality. We don't need such visitors, since we have enough Romanians who practice this form of destructive tourism.

Bonus:
If you decide to visit an authentic fishermen's village located in this area, you may have the opportunity to try some traditional Romanian food (the fisherman's "bors") that cannot be found anywhere else.

Such a wild and beautiful place to go. If you’re into adventure I would recommend to organize a few days trip with your friends or family and go out there and explore with a canoe 🛶 and a tent 🏕. I promise you will remember the experience for a long time (not only because of the mosquitos 🦟😁). Btw that’s something to take into consideration either you go wild or get a room on Airbnb.
Great food all around, nice people, stunning views and birds 🦢 and a great opportunity to reflect on your life. Ask God to reveal Himself to you and you will be surprised 😲
Stop reading reviews about this place and just go see it for yourself, you won`t regret it.

Name: Poblet Monastery
short_description: This Cistercian abbey in Catalonia is one of the largest in Spain. At its centre is a 12th-century church. The austere, majestic monastery, which has a fortified royal residence and contains the pantheon of the kings of Catalonia and Aragon, is an impressive sight.

reviews.text: A place full of history, quiet and surrounded by nature, where you can relax your thoughts a little and also enjoy a good coffee at the cafe inside or buy a souvenir from the internal shop. Highly recommended! ✌️

Serene, restful, minimalist are a few of the words that come to mind. The restaurant served delicious Catalan fare and the wine was top. The monastery is a UNESCO heritage site and well worth a visit.

I throughly enjoyed my day at Poblet Monastery and wasn’t expecting how futuristic the tour felt. The visitors centre was excellently modern with sliding screens and walkways to educate you with every step.

Afterwards we visited the Monastery itself and it was very well kept with breathtaking views from the garden/cloister. You may come across the monks as they are working and you can even arrange a talk with them.

On the tour you will be prompted to download an app that guides you around - headphones are a must for this. This mini basilica is well worth the visit and I even spied a wonderful cafe as I was leaving!
Fantastic monastery! I recommend visiting it in the morning, as it is less crowded. Anyway, this monastery is outstanding and did not disappoint. Superb!

Part of 3 UNESCO World Heritage, the scenic route with video and explanation are of a very good quality. It’s obviously a must see if you are traveling in the area.

You can buy a combined ticket with the 3 sites. This ticket is working for 2 years. There is a pause at noon on each site so it is recommended to visit them on two days. A good pretext to stop in on of the good restaurants near Valls (for a Calçotada for exemple).

Name: Rangiri Dambulla Cave Temple
short_description: A sacred pilgrimage site for 22 centuries, this cave monastery, with its five sanctuaries, is the largest, best-preserved cave-temple complex in Sri Lanka. The Buddhist mural paintings (covering an area of 2,100 m2 ) are of particular importance, as are the 157 statues.
formatted_address: Kandy - Jaffna Hwy, Dambulla, Sri Lanka

reviews.text:
I think this has been my favourite place so far. Despite the large number of tourists, the caves still feel holy. The painting of the interior is stunning! And the number of Buddha statues creates a special atmosphere difficult to describe.
You can buy flowers near the entry if you want to make an offering (budget 100 rupees for 5 flowers). There's then a steep couple of flights of stairs to the entrance. Remove your shoes (tip around 50 rupees when you collect them). There are four caves, plus a Hindu temple. You can receive a blessing there (leave a donation, 50 rupees per person is fine).

A very beautiful experience.  Fantastic for a good and long walk with the possibility of great fantastic views.  You have to climb many stairs to reach the caves.  But the experience is worth it.  It is not handicap friendly.  Love the beautiful and big Buddhas.  It seems that the place has been preserved in an authentic style, which makes the experience unique.  Near the Temple there are many good bed and breakfasts.

Cool stop off, wouldn't go far out of my way to go here. Cheaper than some other places but not loads of time required here, it is a fairly impressive place though. Go first thing to avoid the heat and the crowds as it was quiet when we arrived and super busy when we left. Really nice views from the top. Wear socks and expect to tip to store shoes.

A temple with very old history. A must visit if you are in the area. Photography is allowed. You must dress properly and respect the rules of the temple. You have to buy tickets to visit the historical caves if you are a foreigner. Wearing shoes or slippers is  not allowed. Until the caves, you have to climb up through the stairs. It's not so difficult if you are a person without health problems. Up there, you have an amazing view. You can even see sigiriya from there but far away. If you need an extra dress to cover yourself, you can buy or rent from up there. Always crowded there. So you know what you are waiting

The Royal Cave Temple is definitely worth a visit. You can explore several well-preserved rooms, each with its own unique charm. Be aware that you have to leave your shoes at the entrance, so it’s good to have some small change for the shoe deposit. Also, be careful – the ground gets extremely hot, and it’s easy to burn your feet.

Name: Royal Domain of Drottningholm
short_description: The Royal Domain of Drottningholm stands on an island in Lake Mälar in a suburb of Stockholm. With its castle, perfectly preserved theatre (built in 1766), Chinese pavilion and gardens, it is the finest example of an 18th-century north European royal residence inspired by the Palace of Versailles.

reviews.text: One of my favorite places in Stockholm. You can easily reach here via public transport. The palace looks beautiful both front and back view. There is a big garden in the back with nice fountains. It is a big area and you can spend a whole day here in the palace and the garden area.  Visit during autumn for the colorful trees.

A beautiful palace with lots of history! To visit the palace you need to pay but all outside areas including the Royal gardens are free to enter, I'd say paying for entrance is definitely worth it as the inside has lots of beautiful art and furniture. Sadly the Chinese palace was closed as it's only open between may and september.
The current royal residency. Cool and instructive 1 hour guided tour. Most of the palace is closed to the public, but the few pieces that you access are worth the visit. A nice park.

They say Drottningholm Palace was built to impress, and impress it does. From the amazing design, the incredibly well kept gardens, the symmetry, and the many many water fountains. Quite a nice place to get lost while wandering around the massive compound. It's also fun for family picnics as there are plenty of places to sit and chill. There is a reliable public transport just outside, and it's easy to find buses connecting to nearby suburbs and towards Stockholm Central.

Tip 💡: go before 11 am if you plan to visit on weekend, and the whole palace will be yours. At 11 excursions begin, so it becomes busy.

Tip 2 💡: you can download audio guide app from Apple Store or Google play free of charge as not all the rooms have descriptions.

Name: Historic Town of Sukhothai and Associated Historic Towns
short_description: Sukhothai was the capital of the first Kingdom of Siam in the 13th and 14th centuries. It has a number of fine monuments, illustrating the beginnings of Thai architecture. The great civilization which evolved in the Kingdom of Sukhothai absorbed numerous influences and ancient local traditions; the rapid assimilation of all these elements forged what is known as the 'Sukhothai style'.
formatted_address: 498 12, Tambon Mueang Kao, Amphoe Mueang Sukhothai, Chang Wat Sukhothai 64210, Thailand

reviews.text: Another great experience. It was very interesting to see the transition between traditional Thai architecture and Khmer architecture, within such close proximity. The ruins, in some instances, had been maintained quite well, and the park was not overly crowded. Another enjoyable visit that we would recommend.

You get transported back in time while visiting the historical park here. The place is serene, has numerous ruins and some preserved or restored monuments.Many temples and statutes exist and people worship as well.

You can either walk around, bike or rent a gold cart to explore the place. Tickets are not that expensive 100 baht if you are a foreigner. You do have to pay extra for taking the golf cart in which is another 50 baht. You can rent them outside starting at 200 baht/hour.

Overall it was a beautiful experience, I assume it would be more fun to come in the morning as it gets hot during the day. We did spot a small snake I. The ruins but looked pretty harmless.

Final Night of the Sukhothai Lighting Festival – Don’t Miss This Magical Experience!

Tonight marks the grand finale of the breathtaking Sukhothai Lighting Festival, where the ancient ruins of Sukhothai are illuminated in a mesmerizing display of lights and colors. Experience the enchantment of Thailand’s historic capital as the glowing temples, shimmering lanterns, and serene reflections on the water create an unforgettable spectacle.

Join us for this one-of-a-kind evening, filled with cultural performances, traditional music, and the warm glow of thousands of lights. Whether you're here to capture stunning photos, immerse yourself in history, or simply soak in the magical atmosphere, this is your last chance to witness the beauty of Sukhothai in a whole new light.

✨ Don’t miss it – come and be part of this extraordinary night! ✨

One of the highlights of our 2 weeks Thailand tour. The whole park is an archeological treasure from the first Kingdom of Sukhothai. The remains we see date back to 13 century and are pretty well preserved.
Take a bike from any of several rentals across the main gate and wander through this huge area. There are several Temples to visit within the park, as well the ancient Royal Palace - all included in the entry fee.
Take your time and enjoy to the fullest this fab UNSECO site

Sukhothai is the former capital of Thailand, it is a very beautiful city, full of romance and history. We rented a "golf car" for 300 baht for two hours (this time was enough for us, just right). You also have a bicycle at your disposal. I do not recommend walking in hot weather

Name: Historic City of Ayutthaya
short_description: Founded c. 1350, Ayutthaya became the second Siamese capital after Sukhothai. It was destroyed by the Burmese in the 18th century. Its remains, characterized by the prang (reliquary towers) and gigantic monasteries, give an idea of its past splendour.
formatted_address: 196 หมู่ที่ 4 Thanon Khlong Tho, Tambon Pratuchai, Amphoe Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya, Chang Wat Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya 13000, Thailand

reviews.text:
The conditions here are large, with ruins over a large area, which the first four photos are an example of. If you are going to see everything within the walls, you need to calculate some time, and if you are visiting the place for the first time, it may be sensible.

Water can also be good to have in backup, it can get hot without too much shade. This is a great place to visit for those who like this type of ruins, but it can be recommended for everyone to experience a piece of history from the past.

There are various sales stalls outside the walls, and in the surrounding area, and there is plenty of parking before entering the area within the walls.

Located at Khlong Tho Road, Pratu Chai Sub-district, Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya District, Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya, Thailand 🇹🇭.
This historic landmark covers the ruins of the city of Ayutthaya, Thailand. The city was founded by King Ramathibodi I in 1351, though it is thought to be significantly older based on evidence that the area was already occupied during the Mon Dvaravati period. Further sources mention that the area was occupied by the Khmers around 850AD and they established a stronghold naming it Ayodhta after one of the holiest Hindu cities in India 🇮🇳 at that time. The early history of Ayutthaya is connected to this Khmer settlement.
The city was captured by the Burmese 🇲🇲 in 1569. Though not pillaged, the city lost many valuable and artistic artifacts. It was the capital of the country until its destruction by the Burmese army in 1767. In 1969, the Thai Government began renovations of the ruins, scaling up the project after the site was declared a historical park in 1976. Part of the park was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1991.
Everything about the site is on a grand scale. It’s huge so be prepared for a lot of walking and wear comfortable shoes. Take your time going through the site, and maybe come by yourself without a guide so you can take all the time you need. Wear long pants and cover your shoulders because they might not let you in if you are not dressed modestly. But wear comfortable clothes as the site is spread out over several kilometres. The entrance fee is 50 Baht, this will get you to all areas. Take water and a hat. Might be best to visit early in morning or afternoon to avoid heat. You can rent a bike as a way of getting around the park. There are several sales stalls selling souvenirs and something to eat. Ayutthaya is a place reeking of history and spirituality. It showcases Thailands rich heritage. It’s a MUST when visiting Thailand. Thumbs Up!!! 👍👍👍
Huge park where you can spend hours if not days trying to see all the temples. Amazing Thai Art and Traditional Culture at his finest.

I finally visited Ayutthaya in my 4th trip to Bangkok and I realised what a mistake I made by not going sooner!! This is a must visit for any history enthusiast. It helps paint a picture about the birth and development of Bangkok. It is very educational but also relaxing and eye opening to see. So many opportunities for nice photos, practice your photography skills at the same time feel you took a Time Machine back in history. Go early to avoid the crowds. Spend the night in Ayutthaya for a more relaxed experience and to see more of the historical sites. I also think it is great to stay to support the local restaurants and guesthouses. Anyways it is a nice change of pace from the big city. You can take tour guide one day and explore at your own pace the next day.

To be honest, even after two full days here I would still return just for the visuals of sunsets over the temples and to be around the friendly people of Ayutthaya.

Well worth the visit! Ayutthaya historical Park is spread out over many kilometres
This place is absolutely beautiful, feels quite surreal most temples and other remnants of buildings were well maintained.
We were lucky to see elephants on our way in , you can also ride them if you like to see parts of Ayutthaya.
Tuk tuks are readily available also.
The$8 pass brought on site will cover all areas .
Take water and hats.
This place is definitely worth a visit.

Name: Thungyai-Huai Kha Khaeng Wildlife Sanctuaries
short_description: Stretching over more than 600,000 ha along the Myanmar border, the sanctuaries, which are relatively intact, contain examples of almost all the forest types of continental South-East Asia. They are home to a very diverse array of animals, including 77% of the large mammals (especially elephants and tigers), 50% of the large birds and 33% of the land vertebrates to be found in this region.
formatted_address: J85C+F85, Rabam, Lan Sak District, Uthai Thani 61160, Thailand

reviews.text:
Bare bones. You pay the entrance fee, and it’s basically dirt roads to the viewing area. A few areas were tight, 2 cars would not be able to pass each other. But when we went it, midday, dry season… it was quiet. During the day it was fairly quiet wildlife wise as well, but on the way back the wildlife began to stir.

At the end of the 9km drive, you park the car, there are restrooms but not much else. Cross a walking suspension bridge, chat with the administrator at the center, walk to a pavilion honoring one of the researchers who was killed protecting the wildlife here and eventually setting up the park as a  UNESCO World Heritage Center.

We went during dry season and mid-day but managed to see some deer by a small watering hole, some monkeys by the bridge gazebo and on the drive back some reptiles and a peacock.

I loved every minute of my time at Huai Kha Khaeng - it was the highlight of my trip to Thailand. It wasn’t easy to reach but that made it even more worthwhile. Saw around 30 wild bantheng on the first day, many footprints including tiger, leopard, elephant .. found out a tiger had been seen 12 days before from the lookout I was in. Was welcomed and introduced to an English speaking guide, Jaeb. He had an amazing knowledge of the animals & pointed out so much. He was there to meet me on my second and final day too. Such a special place … wild & wonderful, found it so thrilling to be walking in the footsteps of so many wild animals .

The park is peaceful. It has been set up with conservation in mind. We spent around 3 hours in the park. Although we didn't see too many animals, it's clear there are a lot around. I'd recommend spending longer if you want to see more animals.

This is a very well protected area, unknown to many, including Thailand's own people! This sanctuary has a history of protection for almost three decades and the wildlife population recoveries are impressive.

One best wildlife sanctuary in Thailand. It is a good place for bird watching and relax. Tourist can only visit at day time with limited administration area. However, along 10 km into this area is the best place for bird watching.

Name: Butrint
short_description: Inhabited since prehistoric times, Butrint has been the site of a Greek colony, a Roman city and a bishopric. Following a period of prosperity under Byzantine administration, then a brief occupation by the Venetians, the city was abandoned in the late Middle Ages after marshes formed in the area. The present archaeological site is a repository of ruins representing each period in the city’s development.

reviews.text: This is an ancient Roman settlement although its history is far older. You can explore the ruins although much is still intact. There are beautiful mosaic floors and rooms to explore. Pair up with the blue hole why not.

10E pp admission is very steep, for this country. Worth it?

Ruins are not all that impressive.  The theatre is flooded, in a swamp (it was worst, in photos), green, buggy water.  The rest of i is rough stone, cemented arches, nothing really memorable at all.  The museum is decent, small, but nice place to visit (WCs there are very good, paper towels, soap and copious water...but no drinking water).  Small artifact expositions down the stairs.  High point on castle was locked. The 'acropolis' 50m up stone path, just a jumble of rocks.

The star, the mosaics, were buried in sand to protect them. Sign says periodically exposed.  OK, but we did pay 10E pp, so how about a roof?

WCs near entrance are also very good.  Lots of benches to sit, places to picnic (cafe on top closed, March2025).  Ample parking gratis out front (March, low season, there were maybe 10 of us visiting today).  Paths and signs are ok, some maintenance work being done (new wood) but not much.  At least there's no trash around.  Very modern entrance, turnstiles, friendly folks there.  Just not sure it's worth 10E.
Absolutely spectacular, basically an entire Roman village. We went in the off-season in December and had the whole place to ourselves. Albania is a very unique surprise.

The ruins of a Hellenic and Roman ruin are very well preserved and well maintained. A World Heritage Site, the park is a great place to spend hours under the huge trees. A map will help you find your way around, which is very useful as the park covers a large area. It is also easily accessible by public transport. It is a must visit.

We had an excellent afternoon here at the National Archaeological Park. It is really well conserved and maintained. It was very cool to see ancient ruins including structures from the Middle Ages, a basilica and a Roman theatre. But it was even cooler to see these sites amongst the flourishing flora and fauna in their surroundings. This is what makes this place unique. Lush, dense woodlands and beautiful lakes serve as wonderful backdrops to these fascinating historical sites.

We spent about 2 hours going round but could easily have spent double that time strolling around the park.

Highly recommended!

Name: Kasbah of Algiers
short_description: The Kasbah is a unique kind of medina, or Islamic city. It stands in one of the finest coastal sites on the Mediterranean, overlooking the islands where a Carthaginian trading-post was established in the 4th century BC. There are the remains of the citadel, old mosques and Ottoman-style palaces as well as the remains of a traditional urban structure associated with a deep-rooted sense of community.

Name: Fraser Island
short_description: Fraser Island lies just off the east coast of Australia. At 122 km long, it is the largest sand island in the world. Majestic remnants of tall rainforest growing on sand and half the world’s perched freshwater dune lakes are found inland from the beach. The combination of shifting sand-dunes, tropical rainforests and lakes makes it an exceptional site.

reviews.text: My new favourite place! Visited for the first time in my 4wd with my partner. Camped in Zone 2 near Eurong, no facilities but we are self sufficient so not an issue. Had access to the beautiful 75 mile beach. Would recommend arriving early to get a good spot if staying that close to Eurong - access to and from our site was affected by the tides so keep an eye on them if planning to drive up/down K’gari. We spent time in Eurong at the resort with some cocktails, also the food from the bakery was amazing. Fuel was available but expensive (to be expected) so be prepared. We drove around the island over a few days checking out the lakes inland and up the island to Eli Creek, the wreck, Cathedral, Indian Head and through to Orchard Beach. Absolutely loved coming here and will be back. Next time we plan to stay up near Waddy Point, a bit further to travel but less busy, although be prepared with tyre pressure and recovery gear as we did see a few people get bogged. Keep an eye on the tides when travelling up and down the beach. Also plenty of signs about Dingoes, we saw a couple but weren’t an issue - just keep your food packed away. They were smaller than I expected!

K'gari is a fantastic Island with a lot to offer. Whether you go by yourself or on a tour, you will have a great time. We did a tag-along with Dingo's and had a good time. The driving can be a little rough, but if you've tried a little off-roading before you'll probably be fine. Be aware of the waves though! I'd recommend spending most of your time at the inland lakes as they are stunning and make for a good and relaxing time. The Champagne pools are ok, but a little underwhelming and the shipwreck is a rusty boat.
Well worth a trip!

This is such a wonderful island. Visited as part of a tour and really enjoyed learning about how the island was formed, how the lakes were formed and how the island is now a world heritage site. The lakes here are unlike anything I have ever seen before, the water is so clean and some of the creeks also have clear water that is actually drinkable. Highly recommend visiting, it is worth all the money!
Well worth going , take a bus tour if you want to know more about the history of the island ,the creeks and lake are great fro swimming
What can I say amazing place. Jurassic park vibes, I’ll be back to do a 4wd tour of the island. Ecology guided tour was good I’d recommend

Name: Angkor
short_description: Angkor is one of the most important archaeological sites in South-East Asia. Stretching over some 400 km2, including forested area, Angkor Archaeological Park contains the magnificent remains of the different capitals of the Khmer Empire, from the 9th to the 15th century. They include the famous Temple of Angkor Wat and, at Angkor Thom, the Bayon Temple with its countless sculptural decorations. UNESCO has set up a wide-ranging programme to safeguard this symbolic site and its surroundings.

reviews.text: Mind blowing ancient site. It's not a ruin as it's amazingly intact. I wanted to visit for years and it didn't disappoint. Just incredible! You need to buy a ticket at the central ticket office and that gets you into all the temples in the complex. A must if you're in Cambodia!

Stunning place! Go early in the morning (and I mean early, like 4am) to get a good spot to witness the sunrise over the Angkor Wat. There are so many temples and places to visit here that you can spend a week, if you are a history buff. We spent 2 days and it was a great experience.

Great place. Anyone who is interested needs to go early in the morning to cover the complete temple properly. It's definitely a good temple, but the entry fee is very unreasonably high and not worth it. The temple is not maintained properly, and there are no proper instructions or any writeup other than the outer walls or directions signage to cover the temple. It has a lot of potential and history, but nothing has been provided, and you have been charged $37 just for nothing.

Amazing experience.   I highly recommend the sunrise viewing.   It's an early wake up but well worth it.    The energy in this place is great.   The history is very interesting.    The preservation even after 1000 years is astonishing.    In addition to Ankor Wat there are many other temples near by to explore and see.     We visited four in one day and relatively close to each other.   I had such a good time exploring.    The temples are massive and you can spend a lot of time just getting lost.    We had a guide which I also
recommended.     He taught us much about the history of the temples and Cambodia.    Also took us to a great place for brunch.   I also really like the vibe in seam reap.    The people are nice and food is great.   If your into nightlife and markets there is a lot of that as well.

Really beautiful, we went at sunrise and loved it. We chose to stand further back away from the crowds and it made the experience much more enjoyable.
A breathtaking temple with so much history.

Name: Jiuzhaigou Valley Scenic and Historic Interest Area
short_description: Stretching over 72,000 ha in the northern part of Sichuan Province, the jagged Jiuzhaigou valley reaches a height of more than 4,800 m, thus comprising a series of diverse forest ecosystems. Its superb landscapes are particularly interesting for their series of narrow conic karst land forms and spectacular waterfalls. Some 140 bird species also inhabit the valley, as well as a number of endangered plant and animal species, including the giant panda and the Sichuan takin.
formatted_address: Jiuzhaigou County, Ngawa Tibetan and Qiang Autonomous Prefecture, Sichuan, China, 623402

reviews.text: Went there in March; the Long Lake was still covered with snow. The weather was nice. We spent a day there and visited Mirror Lake, Peacock Lake, Panda Lake, Pearl Shoal Waterfall, Long Lake, Five Flower Lake, Rhinoceros Lake, and Tibetan villages. The pork sausage dipped in Maya chili was delicious, and it cost 10 yuan. Once in a lifetime—gotta visit there!

Went there end of December.  A little cold but much less tourist than during high season. We were lucky to have some snow also. It’s just an amazing place. One of the most beautiful place I ever saw. Next time I will hike there

Some truly amazing and spectacular once-in-a-lifetime scenes. Worth the visit, in spite of crowds, it is something you need to see in front of your own eyes and experience for yourself. The beauty is breathtaking. We visited in winter, which is off peak. We did not see as many colours as one would in autumn or spring, but it was spectacular to see snow on the mountains and also parts of the waterfalls frozen. It is really quite amazing.

Visit Jiuzhaigou in early Dec 24 . Winter is off-season to travel, so the entrance fee is cheaper than the peak season . Enjoyed the natural beauty of winter . Suddenly felt the winter sun is so warm .  Natural scenery is so beautiful that it made me fall in love with this place .

UNESCO world heritage site that needs not much introduction. There is a new bullet train station called Huanglongjiuzhai, which would bring you much closer to this park. It would still take about 1.5 hours to 2 hours to get here, so definitely recommended to stay at a location near to this place and then dedicate a full day for this. First of all, the park is huge and most likely you would not be able to see all of the lakes. But there are a couple of must go spots which are the most spectacular or beautiful. Due to the number of tourists daily, the park has defined processes so it is rather easy to navigate the park. For example, upon entering the park, the bus that we boarded brought us to long lake, which is at the 1 end of the park. If we would have board another bus, we may have ended at the other end of the park. Generally, the idea is to start from one end of the park and travel towards the mid point when the 2 valleys intersect, then head to the other end and go from there. It is almost impossible to walk the entire park, but there would be prominent points where you are encouraged the board the bus to narrow the walking distance to the next lake/spot. The restaurant/food are only at Nuorilang centre, while there are other snacks at the various spots around the park. Note the pass is only for a single day visit so if you plan to do 2 days to explore the park, you will need to buy entrance ticket for each day. There are also plenty of toilets within the park.

Name: Huanglong Scenic and Historic Interest Area
short_description: Situated in the north-west of Sichaun Province, the Huanglong valley is made up of snow-capped peaks and the easternmost of all the Chinese glaciers. In addition to its mountain landscape, diverse forest ecosystems can be found, as well as spectacular limestone formations, waterfalls and hot springs. The area also has a population of endangered animals, including the giant panda and the Sichuan golden snub-nosed monkey.
formatted_address: PRXF+F7W, Ping Song Lu, Song Pan Xian, A Ba Zang Zu Qiang Zu Zi Zhi Zhou, Si Chuan Sheng, China, 623301

reviews.text:
Huanglong is a must-visit once in a lifetime! Go before you get old because there are many steps to climb, but you can take your time. A gondola ride is necessary, and while the battery car is optional, I highly recommend it since there’s still a lot of walking afterward.

We visited in March, and it was freezing in the morning, so be prepared for the cold. I suggest taking the higher path for the most stunning views of the turquoise water terraces. Bringing a portable oxygen canister was a lifesaver—definitely take one with you!

Hiking with views of beautiful snow, snowscape forest, and listening to the flow of water from melted snow.

Caveats - as it was snowing the evening before, roads can get frozen making it difficult for transport to reach the destination.

Need to be careful while hiking because of slippery conditions due to melted snow.

Bring sunglasses and refrain from staring at snow to avoid blinding of the eyes / photokeratitis

There are risks of altitude sickness.

Take cable or hiking? I went for a hike but had assistance from a guide.

Would i do it again? Yes.
Beautiful park with amazing landscape scenery! The path up and down is well built with wooden stairs that are wide and easy to ascend and descend. A must visit destination!

Visited on 17/9. We decided to take cable car to the top 五彩池 and walked down the stairs, it took me 2 hours to reach the exit (approx 4km). Very exhausted but it was fun, can see so many extraordinary jade colour travertine pools along the way.

A beautiful scenic area in Sichuan, China, famous for its colorful terraced pools and limestone formations, surrounded by lush forests. The vibrant blue and green waters and stunning waterfalls create a peaceful atmosphere. Due to the high altitude, oxygen bottles are sold for CNY 20 per bottle, which can be helpful for visitors adjusting to the elevation. It's a unique and serene destination, perfect for nature lovers.

Name: Wulingyuan Scenic and Historic Interest Area
short_description: A spectacular area stretching over more than 26,000 ha in China's Hunan Province, the site is dominated by more than 3,000 narrow sandstone pillars and peaks, many over 200 m high. Between the peaks lie ravines and gorges with streams, pools and waterfalls, some 40 caves, and two large natural bridges. In addition to the striking beauty of the landscape, the region is also noted for the fact that it is home to a number of endangered plant and animal species.

reviews.text:
Incredible landscapes, Wulingyuan is the name of the neighborhood of one of the two entrances to Zhangjiajie National Forest Park.
Allow a full day to see the main peaks, 2 days to do the whole park.
Don't forget to take the Charming Xiangxi Theatre in the evening, which is a 15-minute walk from the entrance!

Wulingyuan, an awe-inspiring natural wonder, is renowned for its majestic mountains, often referred to as the Avatar Mountains due to their striking resemblance to the floating mountains depicted in the movie "Avatar". This spectacular area, encompassing 48 uniquely shaped peaks, stands as a testament to nature's artistry, drawing visitors from around the globe.

Each of the 48 mountains in Wulingyuan boasts its own distinct character, with towering pinnacles and lush greenery that create a breathtaking panorama. The region's beauty is further enhanced by the mists that often shroud the peaks, lending an ethereal quality to the landscape. This misty veil adds an element of mystery and enchantment, making every view feel like a glimpse into an otherworldly realm.

The flora and fauna of Wulingyuan are as diverse as its topography. The area serves as a sanctuary for a wide array of wildlife, and its dense forests are home to numerous plant species, some of which are rare and endemic. The harmonious coexistence of such biodiversity adds another layer of allure to this natural paradise.

First, it is a very large area with an insane amount of walking up and down stairs. If you are like kung fu panda who hates stairs, avoid like the plague.
Second, very poor signages and total chaos as even the locals are lost like everyone else. For a world famous destination it has a very lowly standard of providing clear directions, customer service and  crowd control.
Third, only the Avatar area is amazing. Forget the rest.
Four, it is too expensive.
Five, it is merciless and indifferent to physically challenged people and senior citizens. It is quite clear that this park doesn't welcome such categories of people.
The sights are truly amazing ! Really fortunate that we managed to see the mountains and had a lovely walk in the canyons !
Avatar mountain….lots to see here…. Really nice area.

Name: Historic Centre of Prague
short_description: Built between the 11th and 18th centuries, the Old Town, the Lesser Town and the New Town speak of the great architectural and cultural influence enjoyed by this city since the Middle Ages. The many magnificent monuments, such as Hradcany Castle, St Vitus Cathedral, Charles Bridge and numerous churches and palaces, built mostly in the 14th century under the Holy Roman Emperor, Charles IV.

reviews.text: Old Town Square is the heart of Prague and a place where the city's magic truly comes alive! Stunning architecture, street musicians, and an atmosphere steeped in history. The Astronomical Clock is especially impressive, mesmerizing with its design and mechanism. During Christmas time, the square transforms into a fairy tale: markets adorned with lights, festive decorations, and the aroma of mulled wine create a magical mood. The food here is absolutely delightful! Traditional trdelník with cinnamon, hot sausages, and roasted chestnuts are a real treat for food lovers. It’s a place where you must try everything to fully enjoy the atmosphere!

Wonderful square with multiple tourists objectives near or within and it is a good place to start your own tour.
Near you will find an exceptional illusion museum, a spectacular steel museum, sex machine museum, wax museum and so many more
In within you have the cathedral and the astronomical watch which are very nice and impressive to see.

Charming, cute, big but cozy at the same time. It has a very unique atmosphere. I wouldn't necessarily recommend dining in any of the restaurants located at or nearby the old town square but visiting this place itself, and getting lost in streets around the square can be very enjoyable indeed. Overall score: 5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

❤️Absolutely stunning! This square is a must-see for anyone visiting Prague. The beautiful architecture, the vibrant atmosphere, and the rich history make it a truly unforgettable experience. The Astronomical Clock is a fascinating sight, and the surrounding buildings are equally impressive. Whether you're strolling through the square, enjoying a meal at one of the many cafes, or simply people-watching, you're sure to have a wonderful time.

I highly recommend spending some time exploring this beautiful square. You won't be disappointed!

Visiting Old Town Square in late November was like stepping into a winter wonderland. The Christmas decorations were up, transforming the square into a magical scene of twinkling lights and festive ornaments. The atmosphere was lively yet cozy, with local stalls selling seasonal treats like mulled wine and gingerbread cookies. It’s a perfect spot to soak up the holiday spirit, whether you’re shopping for gifts or just enjoying the festive vibes. A must-visit spot if you’re in Prague during the holiday season!

Name: Historic Centre of Český Krumlov
short_description: Situated on the banks of the Vltava river, the town was built around a 13th-century castle with Gothic, Renaissance and Baroque elements. It is an outstanding example of a small central European medieval town whose architectural heritage has remained intact thanks to its peaceful evolution over more than five centuries.
formatted_address: nám. Svornosti 2, 381 01 Český Krumlov-Český Krumlov 1, Czechia

reviews.text: One of the most beautiful towns in Europe, with all its buildings and location, creates a wonderful composition of a place that looks like something out of a fairy tale, but built by human hands.

Approach and services that you really need as a tourist in overly touristic place. Right in the city center and with services that the tourists use.
Me and my friend asked for luggage storage, as we wanted to walk at the streets of historical center without out backpacks. The lady behind the cash was very friendly, explained us how does it work, including opening ours of the info-center.
The storage of one bag costs 50 crowns per day. Storage room is outside of info-center main room so the shop assistant went with us to store out luggage and later to pick it up.
One disadvantage is opening time of the place. It would be nice to have the longer times, or to be able to pick the luggage up when we need it to.

We lost our phone with all our tickets while visiting Cesky Krumlov. We were directed to the infocentrum.

The lady who helped us was exceptional! Her name was Lucia if I'm not mistaken. She spoke fluent English, was extremely helpful, went out of her way and called the ticket place and had our bus tickets back to the hotel emailed to her and she printed a copy for us. Ultimately it was a great ending since our phone was returned by a kind gentleman🙂

We cannot thank her enough !

You can keep your luggage here for a very reasonable fee. There are no individual lockers but a locked room to keep your bags. Quite safe.

You can also book your shuttle etc here. Very helpful. Don't forget to ask them about the free English walking tour of Cesky Krumlov. It's an amazing way to explore this town.

The lady sitting at the counter was very helpful. Hailed a cab for me to the hotel. One can also park their luggage @1€ per piece for a day. They close at 1800hrs and open at 900hrs. So plan accordingly.

Name: Historic Centre of Telč
short_description: The houses in Telc, which stands on a hilltop, were originally built of wood. After a fire in the late 14th century, the town was rebuilt in stone, surrounded by walls and further strengthened by a network of artificial ponds. The town's Gothic castle was reconstructed in High Gothic style in the late 15th century.
formatted_address: nám. Zachariáše z Hradce 9, Vnitřní Město, 588 56 Telč, Czechia

reviews.text: Our guide was good, spike Czech and English fluently. Was very knowledgeable!
Small but beautiful town with amazing baroque architecture.
SUPER
AGBAPPCZ

A beautiful historic city with lots of sights and places to explore. Attention, outside the tourist season, this location is really almost deserted and deserted. Most places are closed until March, including restaurants and some accommodation.

Name: Bourges Cathedral
short_description: The Cathedral of St Etienne of Bourges, built between the late 12th and late 13th centuries, is one of the great masterpieces of Gothic art and is admired for its proportions and the unity of its design. The tympanum, sculptures and stained-glass windows are particularly striking. Apart from the beauty of the architecture, it attests to the power of Christianity in medieval France.

reviews.text: The cathedral Is an astonishing example of romanic and gothic architecture. The shape of the cathedral, the entrance sculpted portals, the stained glass painted windows are Simply Amazing. Visit It!!!
Absolutely amazing! Photos cannot come close to describing how incredible this cathedral is, must be visited in person to fully appreciate its magnificence.
Bourges is, in a word, unexpected. Quiet, sunny, with a subtle charm. The cathedral Is simply stunning and the stained glass alone is surely worth a visit.

Gorgeous cathedral, definitely worth making a stop and visiting. The inside is amazing and the immensity is breathtaking. You can buy tickets to visit certain closed areas, definitely will return for those.
Beautiful park next to it. Very calming!

One of the most impressive cathedrals of France.
Tourist hint : it is very fresh inside, so if you are visiting Bourges on a very hot summer day, visit inside the cathedral in the middle of your trajectory.

Name: Mines of Rammelsberg, Historic Town of Goslar and Upper Harz Water Management  System
short_description: The Upper Harz mining water management system, which lies south of the Rammelsberg mines and the town of Goslar, has been developed over a period of some 800 years to assist in the process of extracting ore for the production of non-ferrous metals. Its construction was first undertaken in the Middle Ages by Cistercian monks, and it was then developed on a vast scale from the end of the 16th century until the 19th century. It is made up of an extremely complex but perfectly coherent system of artificial ponds, small channels, tunnels and underground drains. It enabled the development of water power for use in mining and metallurgical processes. It is a major site for mining innovation in the western world.

reviews.text: I had the train tour and the museum. The tour was just in German, but was done in a majestic way. The train is obviously the focal experience of the tour, but also how the life was underground and the tools used is explained wonderfully (also without knowing the language:)). The museum is in 3 buildings, the storage with the history is the main part, and the other 2 is more about the real machines. They all have English explanations.

An amazing experience I would highly recommend! It's rare to get to walk in the shoes and take the same mine train the miners took back in the day, deep into the depths of this mine and UNESCO World Heritage site. The rest of the museum and exhibitions are also interesting but the mine rail tour is a must!

Very impressive! It was for me the first time to visit a mine like this, it feels you go back in time! The groups weren't that big, so you could see a lot of the mine. It was quite cold, so wear warm clothes. The train underground was an amazing experience!

I recently visited the Rammelsberg Ore Mines with my husband and had an incredible experience. We took the guided tour in English, called the Röder Stollen, led by Mr. Christian Etzrodt. He was super friendly and humorous, making the entire journey interesting and engaging. I really appreciate him going out of the way to add fun to the tour.
