The park is well taken care of. Really cool to see all the statues and the museum is well presented with English translations all over the park. Most of it is outdoors which is nice. 3-4 hours to walk everywhere. I really recommend a visit!

Fabulous! So glad we put this site on our list. The park is well laid out and maintained. The artifacts on display are outstanding. Well worth the price of admission. (COP 65,000 each.) We also paid COP 150,000 for an English speaking guide. We found it money well spent. Elveco (sp?) was knowledgeable about the site and the flora and fauna. He also shared knowledge of traditional herbal remedies. We had a great day.

The park is pretty nice and I can recommend it for every tourist who is interested in archeological topics. However, the price of 65k is way too much, compared to other sights in Colombia. It would be nice to have a cheaper ticket option for this park only, because many tourists only stay for one day and are not interested in the other parks that are quite far away.

Wonderful site. The museum is small but very nice. The information is in English and Spanish. They have 40 statues that were removed from where found in earlier times on a walking path. Then there are areas with excavated tombs. Amazing! The ancient culture who created these were fascinating.

Name: Kutná Hora: Historical Town Centre with the Church of St Barbara and the Cathedral of Our Lady at Sedlec
short_description: Kutná Hora developed as a result of the exploitation of the silver mines. In the 14th century it became a royal city endowed with monuments that symbolized its prosperity. The Church of St Barbara, a jewel of the late Gothic period, and the Cathedral of Our Lady at Sedlec, which was restored in line with the Baroque taste of the early 18th century, were to influence the architecture of central Europe. These masterpieces today form part of a well-preserved medieval urban fabric with some particularly fine private dwellings.

reviews.text: St. Barbara’s Cathedral in Kutná Hora, Czech Republic, is a stunning Gothic masterpiece and a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Built in 1388, it was dedicated to St. Barbara, the patron saint of miners, reflecting the town’s rich silver mining history. The cathedral took over 500 years to complete, with various architects contributing to its unique design. Its distinctive tent-like roof, featuring intricate flying buttresses, makes it one of the most remarkable Gothic structures in Europe. Inside, visitors can admire breathtaking frescoes depicting medieval mining life, as well as stunning stained-glass windows and Baroque additions from later periods. One fun fact is that the cathedral was originally planned to be even larger, but funding issues—due to the decline of Kutná Hora’s silver mines—halted its expansion. Another interesting detail is that some of its artwork includes hidden satirical elements mocking the church and nobility, offering a glimpse into the humor of the time. The cathedral remains a symbol of the town’s former wealth and influence, attracting visitors from around the world who come to admire its grandeur and historical significance. Today, it stands as a testament to Gothic artistry and the enduring spirit of Kutná Hora’s mining past.

Always worth a day trip from Prague (50% off on the train for over 65s BTW) even if you just visit the spectacular cathedral and have lunch. The stained glass is some of the most beautiful I have seen anywhere. If you can manage the 84 steps up to the organ loft it is very interesting to look down at the organ mechanism and to see that all the gilded musicians are only gilded on the back!

This cathedral is absolutely stunning and a must-see! The Gothic architecture is breathtaking—every detail is so intricate, we found ourselves just standing there in awe, taking it all in.

What makes this place even more special is the rich history, which is explained in detail on the second-floor gallery. It’s fascinating to learn about the stories behind such a magnificent structure while admiring its beauty.

If you appreciate history, architecture, or just want to experience something truly awe-inspiring, this cathedral is worth every minute. Take your time to soak in the atmosphere—you won’t regret it!
A highly recommended day trip from Prague to Kutna Hora to see this 600+ year old cathedral …in awe of the architecture, design and craftsmanship…

One of the most unique aspects of the cathedral’s decoration is the focus on secular, mining-related themes alongside religious imagery. This blend of the sacred and the everyday makes St. Barbara’s stand out from many other European cathedrals. The frescos, which date from the 15th century, are remarkably well-preserved and provide a window into the life and times of medieval Kutná Hora.

Name: Roskilde Cathedral
short_description: Built in the 12th and 13th centuries, this was Scandinavia's first Gothic cathedral to be built of brick and it encouraged the spread of this style throughout northern Europe. It has been the mausoleum of the Danish royal family since the 15th century. Porches and side chapels were added up to the end of the 19th century. Thus it provides a clear overview of the development of European religious architecture.

reviews.text: Spectacularly beautiful. It's a wonder of Scandinavian design that the cathedral could seem so warm and light-filled on a winter day in Denmark. The many seplechurs and gravestones were... Well, they were as uncomfortable as they were stunning. But what better place than a church to consider our own mortality? Like the other places we visited in Denmark, we were amazed by the access - we could walk right up to the altar, the caskets, into all the rooms, etc; We were also extremely impressed with the free guidebook, which gave a great deal of information.

Beautiful architecture and history of Denmark. Several Viking kings are buried here as well as many generations of royalty. Have visited many times and it always takes my breath away. It is hauntingly beautiful.

Beautiful Cathedral with a fascinating history. Entry includes a guide book which has useful information about each part of the cathedral and the different tombs. Definitely worth a visit and paying to go inside.

A most beautiful church. There is a fee for admission but it is well worth the price to see such an exquisite church and the historical burial places of the Danish monarchs. The sculpture and artwork in this church are breathtaking. You can walk the entire space on ground level and then up to the gallery level. Here there is a museum and some great views of the space. There are also crypts. Each space has the most amazing sarcophagi and reflect the era of the kings and queens. A must-visit in Roskilde.

I would have never been able to see this cathedral if I hadn't done a day trip as it is about 45 mins outside of Copenhagen and not easy to get to. The tombs are so elaborate, and to hear the stories of the kings and queens buried here was fascinating.

Name: Historic Centre of Avignon: Papal Palace, Episcopal Ensemble and Avignon Bridge
short_description: In the 14th century, this city in the South of France was the seat of the papacy. The Palais des Papes, an austere-looking fortress lavishly decorated by Simone Martini and Matteo Giovanetti, dominates the city, the surrounding ramparts and the remains of a 12th-century bridge over the Rhone. Beneath this outstanding example of Gothic architecture, the Petit Palais and the Romanesque Cathedral of Notre-Dame-des-Doms complete an exceptional group of monuments that testify to the leading role played by Avignon in 14th-century Christian Europe.

reviews.text: Beautiful city! Beyond its rich history and stunning architecture, there’s plenty to see and do, whether you're traveling solo, with family, or with friends. Be ready for some walking—there are plenty of stairs, hills, and scenic pathways to explore. If you have the chance to visit, I highly recommend it!

Very nice. Lots of effort to make the experience immersive. The tablets have images of what the place looked like during its original use, as well as many nice facts about the rooms, objects and events that were happening at the specific part of the palace. I saw a group with a guide as well, so I suppose they also offer guided tours. We took the - palace + gardens + the bridge - tickets. They have nice student discounts. The bridge was an amazing experience!

Amazing palace with interesting history. Absolutely breathtaking sitting in the middle of a historical city centre. Definitely recommend going inside, the interactive tablet guide was very entertaining, never seen anything like this before.

The Palace is well preserved, and the garden is also recommended as it is a very quiet place to sit around for an afternoon. You get a nice bird view of Avignon at the top of the Palace. The only thing is that many parts of the place is not easily accessible with narrow and steep staircases, and there are not many things on display.

Unique and extraordinary Gothic palace. It is enormous and the tour is extensive, for once I didn't wish to see the closed off areas too, it was more than I could take in already. The gardens are lovely and worth the extra ticket. The wall paintings in the popes' chambers are incredible.

Name: Messel Pit Fossil Site
short_description: Messel Pit is the richest site in the world for understanding the living environment of the Eocene, between 57 million and 36 million years ago. In particular, it provides unique information about the early stages of the evolution of mammals and includes exceptionally well-preserved mammal fossils, ranging from fully articulated skeletons to the contents of stomachs of animals of this period.

reviews.text:
A tryst with pre-historic era!.
We had visited it during the month of April and took the 1 hour tour (along with the museum - to be paid separately) into the pit. The guide was very friendly, expert in geology and was able to make the tour very interesting. This UNESCO natural heritage site is a must visit, if you’re around the area.
Very well decorated and maintained facilities.

Book a guided tour beforehand. Only very few guided tours in English which is bad. They dont seem to want to have too many tourists as there is little awareness about the site as well as it is not made for non-German tourists. But interesting story and site. Do go visit the museum i. The nearby Messel city, it is more interesting and we got an explanation in English there.
Had a nice tour for an hour and got to see fossils and the pit. No tours in English tho. Museum was nice. We stopped by as we were staying nearby, maybe wouldn’t drive far for this though.

This site holds incredible historical significance, but unfortunately, it suffers from poor management. The staff lack sufficient training, and the guy at the desk struggles with English. He barely explained anything. Tours of the pit are mostly conducted in German, with English tours available only once or twice a month if you're fortunate. Most brochures are also in German, leaving English speaking visitors with limited resources. The museum itself is impressive, yet there’s a lack of knowledgeable guides to enrich the experience. With better management, this site could reach its full potential.

One of the best places I've visited in my life. If you're interested in mammal evolution this is a must see. Definitely book a tour before visiting. The fossils were so good. They were buried in an anoxic layer at the bottom of a lake so not just bones have been preserved. Some insects they dig up you can still see the refractive colours. It's eocene so it's when mammals were really getting established after the dinosaurs. Tells us so much about our evolution. It's so rich. They're only digging an area 2m x 4m but they're finding 2 - 3 thousand fossils per year.

Name: Historic Centre of Siena
short_description: Siena is the embodiment of a medieval city. Its inhabitants pursued their rivalry with Florence right into the area of urban planning. Throughout the centuries, they preserved their city's Gothic appearance, acquired between the 12th and 15th centuries. During this period the work of Duccio, the Lorenzetti brothers and Simone Martini was to influence the course of Italian and, more broadly, European art. The whole city of Siena, built around the Piazza del Campo, was devised as a work of art that blends into the surrounding landscape.

reviews.text:
We recently visited the Palazzo Pubblico in Siena, and it was an unforgettable experience! The highlight of our visit was seeing the famous Allegory of Good and Bad Government, an incredible fresco by Ambrogio Lorenzetti. Located in the Sala dei Nove, this masterpiece gives a powerful visual representation of how good governance can lead to prosperity and peace, while bad governance brings corruption and decay. The details in the fresco are stunning, and it’s amazing to think about how it’s stood the test of time since it was painted in the 14th century.

Aside from the fresco, the building itself is rich in history and offers a deep dive into Siena’s medieval past. The architecture and other artwork throughout the Palazzo are equally impressive. We spent about an hour exploring, but the Allegory was definitely the star of the show.

The gift shop at the Palazzo Pubblico was a pleasant surprise, offering a variety of beautiful souvenirs and art-inspired gifts. It’s a great place to pick up something special to remember your visit. If you’re in Siena, this is a must-see spot that combines art, history, and culture in one amazing experience!
Beautiful town with so much history. Explore the little streets and get a plate of pasta… try to find the spot I posted. It’s a picture !

The Palazzo Publico is situated in the famous Piazza Del Campo and started construction in 1297. Like most buildings on the square it is stunning. Also close by are the Duomo Di Siena and the Torre Del Mangia. A wonderful location to visit, have a coffee or meal, shop or just people watch.
It’s a great city to walk around and maybe even buy a some clothing. But personally I wouldn’t stay more than a day here
Great museum and lots of nice things to see! The old graffiti was pretty cool also.

Name: Historic Centre of Naples
short_description: From the Neapolis founded by Greek settlers in 470 B.C. to the city of today, Naples has retained the imprint of the successive cultures that emerged in Europe and the Mediterranean basin. This makes it a unique site, with a wealth of outstanding monuments such as the Church of Santa Chiara and the Castel Nuovo.
formatted_address: Via Rita Atria, 11, 80139 Napoli NA, Italy

reviews.text: The accommodation itself is very good. The apartment has good beds, air conditioning and good bathroom. However, the breakfast is in a different location, a bar near the b&b. Depending on the time you go for breakfast, the options are limited.
This place is a sit hole

We stayed two days in Naples and chose this room/apartment and had a great time.
Central location, near Spacca Napoli and close to the Metro stop.
The managers are very nice, super attentive to customer needs and very helpful. They also allowed us to leave our backpacks for the entire day of our checkout.
Super recommended, excellent quality/price ratio.

It is the second time I have stayed at the Historical. Miriam and Sergio were very helpful in giving the right directions.
Clean rooms, b&b close to all the main attractions
If I return to Naples I will definitely go to this establishment.

Two courteous, friendly and knowledgeable guys!
Well-kept, clean and super quiet house, you sleep divinely!
Very close to the central station and in the historic center, it allows you to travel around Naples comfortably on foot.
Good luck guys, keep up the good work, good luck!

Name: Crespi d'Adda
short_description: Crespi d'Adda in Capriate San Gervasio in Lombardy is an outstanding example of the 19th- and early 20th-century 'company towns' built in Europe and North America by enlightened industrialists to meet the workers' needs. The site is still remarkably intact and is partly used for industrial purposes, although changing economic and social conditions now threaten its survival.
formatted_address: 24042 Crespi d'Adda, Province of Bergamo, Italy

Name: Ferrara, City of the Renaissance, and its Po Delta
short_description: Ferrara, which grew up around a ford over the River Po, became an intellectual and artistic centre that attracted the greatest minds of the Italian Renaissance in the 15th and 16th centuries. Here, Piero della Francesca, Jacopo Bellini and Andrea Mantegna decorated the palaces of the House of Este. The humanist concept of the 'ideal city' came to life here in the neighbourhoods built from 1492 onwards by Biagio Rossetti according to the new principles of perspective. The completion of this project marked the birth of modern town planning and influenced its subsequent development.

Name: Historic Villages of Shirakawa-go and Gokayama
short_description: Located in a mountainous region that was cut off from the rest of the world for a long period of time, these villages with their Gassho-style houses subsisted on the cultivation of mulberry trees and the rearing of silkworms. The large houses with their steeply pitched thatched roofs are the only examples of their kind in Japan. Despite economic upheavals, the villages of Ogimachi, Ainokura and Suganuma are outstanding examples of a traditional way of life perfectly adapted to the environment and people's social and economic circumstances.
formatted_address: Ogimachi, Shirakawa, Ono District, Gifu 501-5627, Japan

reviews.text: If you like looking into Japan's past this is a great place to visit. I went in winter and loved the cool fresh air and the picturesque scenery. The old style buildings were well preserved and it was interesting to go through one of the main buildings. There were a lot of tourists which is to be expected. There are coin lockers available, but they fill quickly. However there is also a storage facility. Be prepared with cash. All in all I enjoyed my time here. I'd love to come back at another time of year to see the scenery change.

Must visit. One of the highlights of my Japan trip so far. Just breathtaking and so different from anything I’ve experienced yet. See it covered in snow. Lush and green. It doesn’t matter. Breathtaking either way.

Do make sure you buy your bus tickets in advance as they can and do sell out.

I had a lovely time here with my sister. We chose to go in winter when it looks like a winter wonderland and that's exactly what it was.
There is a place to leave your luggage and bags as well as coin lockers. So we walked around and explored without the burden of heavy bags.
The thatched roof buildings looked so out of this world dressed in clumps of snow ❄️🌨️❄️.
It is beautiful and I would recommend people to visit it to get away from city life and experience the peace of the  outdoors.
Adults and children all enjoyed playing in the snow because there is just a lot of it. We also took a lot of pictures..
I want to go back again in spring 🌱

I stayed a night in the area so I don't bother with the crowds. This allowed me to spend more time in the village and enjoy the serene atmosphere without the crowds. The day before, there's heavy snowfall, and it's also Wednesday, which I think is a day off for many, since many paths (including the main road) hadn't been frequently cleared. However, the following day, everything was much neater.

We took a tour here using N Day Tours and it was an amazing place to see! I wish we had been given a little more time, but we had another stop to do.

I’ve been to a few world heritage sites and I can see why this one is so famous during the winter.

There was so much snow and lots of things to do; ice cream, takoyaki, 3 houses, and lots of souvenir stores to see.

I recommend taking a tour here because the roads are next to huge banks of snow.

Name: Town of Luang Prabang
short_description: Luang Prabang is an outstanding example of the fusion of traditional architecture and Lao urban structures with those built by the European colonial authorities in the 19th and 20th centuries. Its unique, remarkably well-preserved townscape illustrates a key stage in the blending of these two distinct cultural traditions.

Name: Schokland and Surroundings
short_description: Schokland was a peninsula that by the 15th century had become an island. Occupied and then abandoned as the sea encroached, it had to be evacuated in 1859. But following the draining of the Zuider Zee, it has, since the 1940s, formed part of the land reclaimed from the sea. Schokland has vestiges of human habitation going back to prehistoric times. It symbolizes the heroic, age-old struggle of the people of the Netherlands against the encroachment of the waters.

reviews.text:
I was a bit disappointed as I thought I was going to visit a ghost town 🐻👻🏚️🙈 beside that, it was pretty cute and beary well maintained. The onsite restaurant seemed popular and there were also great walking trails around 🐾
A pawfect place if you want to learn about the interesting history of the site 🤓📚👍 or if you’re just interesting in birdwatching 🦆🦢🕊️🦤👀

Pretty area.

I thought I was supposed to see the differentiation of where the island ended and they did the land reclamation. But I never really could figure that out. The tourist office is fantastic and the little café there has great service
It’s fascinating to imagine that it was an island once!
Beautiful, quiet. Nice area for a walk.
Yes,  go there !

Name: Rice Terraces of the Philippine Cordilleras
short_description: For 2,000 years, the high rice fields of the Ifugao have followed the contours of the mountains. The fruit of knowledge handed down from one generation to the next, and the expression of sacred traditions and a delicate social balance, they have helped to create a landscape of great beauty that expresses the harmony between humankind and the environment.
formatted_address: W4PM+4WF, Tappiya Falls Trail, Banaue, Ifugao, Philippines

reviews.text: Situated in the Cordilleras of Luzon Island in the Philippines are the Banaue Rice Terraces at an elevation of approximatley 5,000 feet above sea level.  The lfugao people have maintained  this incredible farming technique for over 2000 years.  Mountain sides and hills carved out by hand to build terraced fields combined with a rainforest fed irrigation system is an astonishing demonstration of engineering mastery and environmental sustainability.  Many areas of the rice terraces have been declared a World Heritage Site under UNESCO.  Unfortunately,  some terrace locations have not been maintained due to a dwindling labour force and are slipping into decay.  The rice terraces are a real marvel to be cherished, and I hope that the Government of the Philippines will intervene to preserve and maintain these lands.   (Personal Note:  Photos of the terraces are beautiful, but being there in person opens up an entirely new level of appreciation.)  Hiring a private tour operator in Banaue or a private driver familiar with the region is recommended.
The place is so clean and the air is refreshing it’s must be add one in your bucket list, definitely will be back there!
Very nice place, road is pretty hard, but you need to see this.
Breathtaking view.
One of the eight wonders of the world.Visited the place and amazed how the natives made this rice fields by hand.Enjoy the peace and comforting weather.

Name: Cultural Landscape of Sintra
short_description: In the 19th century Sintra became the first centre of European Romantic architecture. Ferdinand II turned a ruined monastery into a castle where this new sensitivity was displayed in the use of Gothic, Egyptian, Moorish and Renaissance elements and in the creation of a park blending local and exotic species of trees. Other fine dwellings, built along the same lines in the surrounding serra , created a unique combination of parks and gardens which influenced the development of landscape architecture throughout Europe.

Name: Seokguram Grotto and Bulguksa Temple
short_description: Established in the 8th century on the slopes of Mount Toham, the Seokguram Grotto contains a monumental statue of the Buddha looking at the sea in the bhumisparsha mudra position. With the surrounding portrayals of gods, Bodhisattvas and disciples, all realistically and delicately sculpted in high and low relief, it is considered a masterpiece of Buddhist art in the Far East. The Temple of Bulguksa (built in 774) and the Seokguram Grotto form a religious architectural complex of exceptional significance.

Name: Haeinsa Temple Janggyeong Panjeon, the Depositories for the Tripitaka Koreana Woodblocks
short_description: The Temple of Haeinsa, on Mount Gaya, is home to the Tripitaka Koreana , the most complete collection of Buddhist texts, engraved on 80,000 woodblocks between 1237 and 1248. The buildings of Janggyeong Panjeon, which date from the 15th century, were constructed to house the woodblocks, which are also revered as exceptional works of art. As the oldest depository of the Tripitaka , they reveal an astonishing mastery of the invention and implementation of the conservation techniques used to preserve these woodblocks.
formatted_address: 10 Chiin-ri, Gaya-myeon, Hapcheon, Gyeongsangnam-do, South Korea

reviews.text:
This collection of wooden blocks is a true marvel. They are nearly 800 years old and have survived fires at the temple, multiple Japanese invasions, the Korean War, and the ravages of time and nature.

Japan destroyed many historical buildings and artifacts during their invasion of the late 1500's, but this temple and the Tripitaka Koreana was spared. Japan returned to Korea in the early 1900's and destroyed much of what they failed to destroy the first time, but somehow these were spared again. When the Korean War broke out, more historical buildings and artifacts were destroyed. This temple in particular was slated to be bombed during the Korean War, but a pilot disregarded orders knowing there were important artifacts here. Not to mention the various fires that have destroyed other buildings at the temple, but somehow not the building that houses the Tripitaka Koreana.

What makes these even more remarkable is how well preserved they are, nearly 800 years later. Making these wooden blocks ready for carving was an incredibly complicated and labor intensive process that took more than 5 years from the cutting down of the tree to carving the blocks. The blocks were treated with special varnish after being carved to discourage insects and were wrapped in metal to prevent warping. Even the building that housed them was designed to keep these blocks in pristine shape, based on its orientation, the size of its windows, and the materials used on the roofs and floors. They did such an amazing job that a modern building designed to store the blocks in perfect conditions actually caused damage to the blocks, causing them to be returned to their home of 700 years.

Just an incredible piece of history in a country where so much of it was destroyed by war. Even though Haeinsa is a bit difficult to reach, it is absolutely worth visiting.

I didn't know that Koreans printed publications hundreds of years before Gutenberg.

This temple is a storage for 81 258 wooden printing blocks. Beautiful temple and nice country mountain road trip. Nearby restaurants have interesting mountain vegetarian food with close to 20 side dishes.

I can't get closed to treasure 'Tripitaka Koreana' because they only open inside on weekends. But I could see the things through bar, it was still amazing from far distance. And monk pray in the building on the time I arrived.
If you want to see Tripitaka Koreana more close, have to reserve in advance on their website.
Lots of historical meaning to Koreans. It is surprised wooden pallets have kept perfectly.
Amazing history. Roots of Korean culture. 80 000 tablets stored in this location that spread Buddhism to many locations

Name: Jongmyo Shrine
short_description: Jongmyo is the oldest and most authentic of the Confucian royal shrines to have been preserved. Dedicated to the forefathers of the Joseon dynasty (1392–1910), the shrine has existed in its present form since the 16th century and houses tablets bearing the teachings of members of the former royal family. Ritual ceremonies linking music, song and dance still take place there, perpetuating a tradition that goes back to the 14th century.
formatted_address: South Korea, Seoul, Jongno District, Jong-ro, 157 종묘관리소

reviews.text:
The English tour at 12pm on Wednesday was excellent. Our tour guide was very animated.
Some parts are under renovation currently.
Best time to visit is the first Saturday in November this year when the rituals will be performed. Usually they are performed twice a year now on first Sunday of May and first Saturday of Nov. They used to be performed 5 times a year in the beginning.
The exhibition hall offers lots more information about the spirit tablets of the kings and officials as well as the rituals and foods of the ceremonies. Well worth visiting the exhibition hall to understand in greater detail what was explained in the tour.
There is even a Lego model set created by Colin Jin who used 20,000 blocks to create musical instruments and figurines performing Jongmyo royal ancestral ritual.

Jongmyo Shrine in Seoul is a UNESCO World Heritage site and one of the oldest Confucian royal shrines, dedicated to the memorial services for the deceased kings and queens of the Joseon Dynasty. Its serene atmosphere and well-preserved architecture offer a tranquil retreat from the city’s bustle. Guided tours provide insightful historical context, enhancing the visitor experience. While the shrine’s simplicity may not captivate all tourists, it’s a meaningful destination for those interested in Korea’s cultural heritage. ￼Make sure you buy tickets in advance, on certain days you won’t be allowed to go in by yourself but only through a guided tour!

A UNESCO World Heritage site and a wonderfully maintained Joseon Dynasty shrine, this is a must-do if you're into history. Visiting this site can be different depending on the day you go. There are certain days when you have to join a free guided tour to visit (Weekdays according to their website). And there are other days where you can walk around the grounds on your own (Weekends according to their website). However, I visited on a "guided tour only" weekday, but I was able to "free roam," so I'm not sure about that. All that aside, the grounds and the structures are amazing! Like other recent reviews have said, the main shrine building was still under refurbishment when I went. Despite that, the entire site is still worth visiting for the beauty, history, and peaceful atmosphere! If you buy the Palace Pass combination ticket, admission to this is included.

Lovely visit, both culturally interesting and within a beautiful park setting showcasing all the golden colours of autumn.
Registered as a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1995, the shrine dates back as far as 1395 for the main hall, which is currently undergoing some renovation. Other buildings like the Hall of Eternal Peace were added in 1421.
Entrance is free if you're 65+

An old, uncrowded, historical place.

It enshrines the spirits of the kings of Joseon, the last dynasty of Korea, and has been a place of worship for about 600 years. It is designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and the entrance fee is 1,000 KRW. It is worth visiting for its old trees, buildings, and walking paths.

Name: Virgin Komi Forests
short_description: The Virgin Komi Forests cover 3.28 million ha of tundra and mountain tundra in the Urals, as well as one of the most extensive areas of virgin boreal forest remaining in Europe. This vast area of conifers, aspens, birches, peat bogs, rivers and natural lakes has been monitored and studied for over 50 years. It provides valuable evidence of the natural processes affecting biodiversity in the taiga.

Name: Hanseatic Town of Visby
short_description: A former Viking site on the island of Gotland, Visby was the main centre of the Hanseatic League in the Baltic from the 12th to the 14th century. Its 13th-century ramparts and more than 200 warehouses and wealthy merchants' dwellings from the same period make it the best-preserved fortified commercial city in northern Europe.

reviews.text: An incredibly beautiful city. Highly recommended in the warmer part of the year! But is also very nice otherwise.

Name: Old and New Towns of Edinburgh
short_description: Edinburgh has been the Scottish capital since the 15th century. It has two distinct areas: the Old Town, dominated by a medieval fortress; and the neoclassical New Town, whose development from the 18th century onwards had a far-reaching influence on European urban planning. The harmonious juxtaposition of these two contrasting historic areas, each with many important buildings, is what gives the city its unique character.
Country name: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

Name: Gough and Inaccessible Islands
short_description: The site, located in the south Atlantic, is one of the least-disrupted island and marine ecosystems in the cool temperate zone. The spectacular cliffs of Gough and Inaccessible Islands, towering above the ocean, are free of introduced mammals and home to one of the world’s largest colonies of sea birds. Gough Island is home to two endemic species of land birds, the gallinule and the Gough rowettie, as well as to 12 endemic species of plants, while Inaccessible Island boasts two birds, eight plants and at least 10 invertebrates endemic to the island.
Country name: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
formatted_address: Gough Island, St Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha

reviews.text: The remotest island of the world was so magical. You could feel the arctic wind blowing through the gorgeous nature of this beautiful island.
Great Picture and Great Experience become a traveller& researcher scientist🙏🏻💐🥰
Good fun, lovely food. Thanks girlies x
Amazing sunsets and bird life. I'd love to build a condo development on the west side, however, the Chinese have already beat me to it.
Nice animals and trails to walk through

Name: Carlsbad Caverns National Park
short_description: This karst landscape in the state of New Mexico comprises over 80 recognized caves. They are outstanding not only for their size but also for the profusion, diversity and beauty of their mineral formations. Lechuguilla Cave stands out from the others, providing an underground laboratory where geological and biological processes can be studied in a pristine setting.

reviews.text: This can only be five stars. I mean there's only like two or three of these in the world on this scope. Highly suggest going on to the website and reserving your timed entry tickets ahead of time, in addition to supplementary guided tours. SPECIAL NOTE: the $3 online reservation fee is just the reservation. It'll be more money when you get there. I think it was $10 a piece. The lower chamber tours, both of them, were canceled due to Park staffing issues after the latest presidential mandate. That notwithstanding we had a wonderful time took 2 or 3 hours to make it through the entire self-guided walk if you want official merchandise, go to the bookshop not to the gift shop. Two totally different separate entities. The caverns are amazing they speak for themselves and don't need me to. Put it on your schedule and support the National Park system.

As everyone is saying, this place is so worth the time. Incredible. I'll cut the jaw and give a hopefully helpful perspective.
We got to the ticket desk and the friendly park ranger told us the walk down to the caverns (versus taking the elevator) was "strenuous". We laughed at first as we started walking down but the deeper we walked into the caverns the less we laughed -- it was a LONG walk. Just all downhill walking and running for half an hour! Definitely don't do it if you don't have good knees. That being said if you are hesitant, still do the walk! It is SO worth it! God's creation is amazing! Glory be.
Great gift shops, friendly park rangers.

Amazing cave system you get to walk down to the bottom almost 800ft from the top. Easy walk with gradual slope down and it’s well lit and even surface to walk on. Highly recommended to go down by yours self rather than take the elevator. You will get to experience many of the fantastic sights on the way. Then you can take the elevator back up when exiting. Make sure to eat at the cafe which is located at the bottom within a massive cave what a cool experience.

So amazing!!!  Give yourself at least 4 hours for the visit so you can take in the beauty of each area. Audio guides are available to rent if you would like to hear the details about the caverns. The majority of the walk is on a 20 degree grade down to the great room so hiking out is up hill all the way. It’s nice that they have an elevator and bathroom facilities inside but not until the end.

Carlsbad Caverns was an amazing experience! Be sure to reserve a timed entry in advance—it’s just $1 per person, and our total for four was $60. Even outside peak bat season, the caves were stunning.

The 3.5-mile hike down felt longer since we explored a few extra trails inside. Railings line the entire walkway, and while most of the hike is a gentle downhill with some stairs, you do feel it as an entry level hiker. Flashlights are recommended—ones with a long beam would be worth it! We had small ones and our phones, which worked but didn’t fully capture the depth of the darkness. My pictures don’t do it justice—it’s much darker than it looks, so if you struggle to see in low light, bring something extra to illuminate parts of the path.

At the end of the trail, we took the option of 75-story elevator back up. The trails were busy, but people were respectful about photos and passing. There are gift shops at both the top and bottom, plus snacks underground. Just remember—no food or drinks in the cave.

Highly recommend visiting—truly a must-see!

Name: Historic Quarter of the City of Colonia del Sacramento
short_description: Founded by the Portuguese in 1680 on the Río de la Plata, the city was of strategic importance in resisting the Spanish. After being disputed for a century, it was finally lost by its founders. The well-preserved urban landscape illustrates the successful fusion of the Portuguese, Spanish and post-colonial styles.
formatted_address: G4HX+CMW, Calle Exodo, 70000 Col. del Sacramento, Departamento de Colonia, Uruguay

reviews.text: It's a small but beautiful area of Colonia del Sacramento. Just wander. No map required. Shops, bars, restaurants, ruins, churches, gorgeous views - this place has it all and it's free.

Colonia del Sacramento Uruguay 2023.
Old City of Colonia, declared world patrimony by Unesco.
Recommended touring it by walking, since going by car would make you feel odd because there is no access to all the streets.
The architecture keeps the colonial tone mixing Portuguese and Spanish styles, which were the countries that were struggling for these lands for nearly 100 years.
Stone, brick, wood, old lighting on the streets, small windows, enigmatic facades.
You can also visit the protection wall created to protect the city with canons, and  walk along the coast boulevard until the yatch club.
The most beautiful sunsets on the Uruguay river, with the sound of the River Plate river, even a sealion I have seen yesterday and today 20 July!
Quiet place, safe, charming, intriguing, which I come back whenever possible to connect with myself. No matter how small it is, it fills my senses and recharge my energy  with power. Special for weddings, to come with your significant other or to fall in love. Clean air, in winter or in summer is visitable, there are museums to visit with one ticket and the lighthouse can be visited to have a wide view of the city from the sky.
I love this place! Peaceful and good to ride bikes
Lovely small town, historical place

Colonia is a delightful break from Buenos Aires.  The coastline is beautiful, there are beaches along it's shore, sweet posadas and high-end hotels.  People are very friendly, relaxed, and helpful. 2-3 nights and are you are refreshed!  It's old town is charming, but a little expensive compared to Argentina at this time!  Try local wines, Uruguayan hand made items.  Great place to do banking!

Name: Waterton Glacier International Peace Park
short_description: In 1932 Waterton Lakes National Park (Alberta, Canada) was combined with the Glacier National Park (Montana, United States) to form the world's first International Peace Park. Situated on the border between the two countries and offering outstanding scenery, the park is exceptionally rich in plant and mammal species as well as prairie, forest, and alpine and glacial features.

reviews.text: Canada has a much different take on National Parks than the US does. This seems much more like a town than a park, the deer were also pretty friendly like they have been feed. Still a nice stop though if you want to see Canada.

We visited Waterton Lakes and Glacier National Park after Banff and were pleasantly surprised by this hidden gem in Alberta. The beauty of this place is truly breathtaking, with stunning scenery that rivals even Banff. A must-do experience is the cruise ride that crosses the US border into Glacier National Park, stopping at Goat Haunt. The park boasts beautiful waterfalls like Blackiston Falls and Cameron Falls, as well as the unique Red Rock Canyon with its striking red rocks. Don't miss the Bison Paddock, home to about 20 majestic bison. Explore Cameron Lake and other scenic spots for a truly enjoyable day. Fun fact: the first commercially viable oil field in Alberta and Canada was discovered in this park. Visit Waterton Lakes National Park for an unforgettable experience.

Yes! You’ve got to visit, especially if you’re already visiting Glacier National Park in the states. You’ll need your passport to get across the border into Canada, which is also pretty fun getting to talk with the border agents. The entire area is absolutely stunning and it’s a lot of fun getting to take the trail over in Waterton Park up along the waterfall. Make sure to visit the park’s visitor center for some really interesting exhibits and make sure to get your National Park Passport stamped at the front desk!

A must-do experience in Waterton! Boat crew were all knowledgeable about the town and can crack up some humour during the tour. There’s no washroom in the boat, so make sure you used one before boarding. Also, parking can be difficult especially close to departure times so arrive early.

Had an unforgettable hike in Waterton on September 21st! Ran into a mama bear and her two cubs. Huge shout out to the amazing park ranger who was out there keeping everyone safe by scaring the bears out of town. If you see this, thank you! You were a total hero that day!

Name: Caves of Aggtelek Karst and Slovak Karst
short_description: The variety of formations and the fact that they are concentrated in a restricted area means that the 712 caves currently identified make up a typical temperate-zone karstic system. Because they display an extremely rare combination of tropical and glacial climatic effects, they make it possible to study geological history over tens of millions of years.

reviews.text: Did the long tour and booked it in advance. I have been visiting a lot of caves worldwide, and this is one of my favorites. 5.6 kilometers through different types of rock formations and you see nearly all of the other offered tours. I had the luck that our group of eleven people had two guides. So I had a nearly private guide who explained all in English. I really enjoyed the tour
Incredible tour. The tour guide was accommodating to both English and Hungarian speakers! So much information and it was truly fun.

This is a must do thing in Hungary. I drove 3 hrs from Budapest to here to get into the caves in early morning. You can not get in by yourself you have to go with the tour and guide, the tour is about an hour and 1km long. You enter here and get out at different location. The guide takes you through different parts of the caves and explains every thing. It is very cold inside the caves around 10deg C so better to take warm clothes. It extends more than 25.5 km.

Brilliant place for a family visit, but not advisable for small children. The price is fair. We took the short 60 minute tour, but for sure we will be back next year ( or before) for the 100 minute tour, which is 4km drive from the 60 minute tour cave. There is a guide who escorts you through the cave, stopping at certain places to explain the history. It was interesting and quite amazing. We took extra warm clothes in a back pack, just incase we got cold half way through. But there was no need, I was in shorts and a t shirt. Other people in light jackets. Once the tour is over, you have a pleasant walk back over the hills to the beginning. Out side the cave in the surrounding areas (walking) there is souvenir shops and 3 restaurants, well places to eat. Not high class restaurants,  I would rather say , quick food points, but you order and can sit in pleasant surroundings and enjoy your food. The food price was also good value and not your typical tourist resort extortionate price. There is a small play ground, all in all it's a full day program. After the cave you can walk around the Forrest.

Visited on an Educational Trip. Cave tour was an amazing experience. Especially the cinema experience in the caves.

There is a giant stalactite that holds the record for highest stalactite in the world. There's plenty of good food and entertainment around the cave entrance. With a subsided ticket anyone can visit the amazing Aggtelekk caves in Northern Hungary.

Name: Monasteries of Haghpat and Sanahin
short_description: These two Byzantine monasteries in the Tumanian region from the period of prosperity during the Kiurikian dynasty (10th to 13th century) were important centres of learning. Sanahin was renown for its school of illuminators and calligraphers. The two monastic complexes represent the highest flowering of Armenian religious architecture, whose unique style developed from a blending of elements of Byzantine ecclesiastical architecture and the traditional vernacular architecture of the Caucasian region.

reviews.text: A must see destination when visiting Armenia. Aside from the great location and remarkable view, it's a wonderful showcase of religious stone carving art.
Beautiful monastery near the border of Armenia & Georgia with the harmoneously decorated fresco arts

Beautiful monastery, over 1000 years old and protected by UNESCO. Easy to reach from Tbilisi, about 2h with no border crossing delays. Beautiful grounds, very interesting and worth visiting. No entrance fees.

First of all, it is on UNESCO world heritage list... So I think it's of one the most important places in Armenia to visit.
And, I can't tell you about its nature! wondering and excellent.

Perfect view and fresh air. Staff are all very nice, when I told them that I don't have coins for the washroom, they let me use it free. Really grateful to them.
Will pay them next time when I back with coins.

Name: Historic Centre of the City of Salzburg
short_description: Salzburg has managed to preserve an extraordinarily rich urban fabric, developed over the period from the Middle Ages to the 19th century when it was a city-state ruled by a prince-archbishop. Its Flamboyant Gothic art attracted many craftsmen and artists before the city became even better known through the work of the Italian architects Vincenzo Scamozzi and Santini Solari, to whom the centre of Salzburg owes much of its Baroque appearance. This meeting-point of northern and southern Europe perhaps sparked the genius of Salzburg’s most famous son, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, whose name has been associated with the city ever since.

Name: Palace and Gardens of Schönbrunn
short_description:
From the 18th century to 1918, Schönbrunn was the residence of the Habsburg emperors. It was designed by the architects Johann Bernhard Fischer von Erlach and Nicolaus Pacassi and is full of outstanding examples of decorative art. Together with its gardens, the site of the world’s first zoo in 1752, it is a remarkable Baroque ensemble and a perfect example of Gesamtkunstwerk

.

reviews.text: We obtained tickets through Project Expedition for the VIP evening of an after hours palace tour, dinner and Mozart/Strauss concert.  The tour was terrific (automated via a handheld recorded system and in English - a total of 16 languages were available).  The palace is huge with a variety of decor styles! The tour was quite interesting!  Dinner was superbly delicious.  The concept was spectacular! We had (VIP) front row seats for an 8-instrument performance with 2 opera singers.  It was truly amazing!  Well worth every penny!!

Very beautiful palace that had quieter details than the rest of the palaces. It was more contemporary and parallel to the mansion. The fact that someone can see a very large part of them for free is very good. Definitely worth the climb to the Gloriette, the view is amazing.

Schönbrunn Palace in Vienna is an incredible place to visit. The architecture is stunning, and the gardens are beautifully maintained, offering breathtaking views. The palace's interiors are rich in history and elegance, making the tour truly fascinating. The atmosphere is serene, and the whole experience feels like a journey back in time. It's a must-see attraction in Vienna, perfect for history lovers and anyone who appreciates beautiful landmarks!

Amazing visit.  All the good reviews stand up. It's a bit expensive but I can't imagine what the annual upkeep on this Majestic castle and grounds is!

Not only is the castle vast, over 1400 rooms, but the grounds are enormous.  Wear comfortable shoes and be prepared to walk for hours to get the best from your visit.
There are about 5/6 places to eat/drink, but as we went off season, I'm not sure how many places were open.

The palace is impressive and I recommend taking the complete tour because it is worth every penny. There is also an audio guide and that you can start whenever you enter the rooms. If visiting in winter you can also spend some time at the Christmas market which is absolutely wonderful! I recommend buying tickets in advance because the entrance is permitted for a limited amount of people in time slots.

Name: Belize Barrier Reef Reserve System
short_description: The coastal area of Belize is an outstanding natural system consisting of the largest barrier reef in the northern hemisphere, offshore atolls, several hundred sand cays, mangrove forests, coastal lagoons and estuaries. The system’s seven sites illustrate the evolutionary history of reef development and are a significant habitat for threatened species, including marine turtles, manatees and the American marine crocodile.

reviews.text:
Amazing place! Beautiful view
I love the weather
Nice and friendly people
Some of the best snorkeling/diving in the area.
Clear waters calm colors  fishs while scuba diving in yown life is simple and calm searching rewuored to find low cost accomidation for long stays
You need to see it, and you better go soon. The coral are bleaching and dying from warm waters. 🥲#climatechangeisreal. #saveBelizeBarrierReef
I haven't went here before but I live at Belize and I know that it is beautiful

Name: Lushan National Park
short_description: Mount Lushan, in Jiangxi, is one of the spiritual centres of Chinese civilization. Buddhist and Taoist temples, along with landmarks of Confucianism, where the most eminent masters taught, blend effortlessly into a strikingly beautiful landscape which has inspired countless artists who developed the aesthetic approach to nature found in Chinese culture.

reviews.text: This was one of my favorite spots that I've been able to go to in China. Mount Lu is one of UNESCO's World Heritage Sites. Stroll along the path in the mountain is tiring but the sights are worth it. There are temples within the mountain face. Some exciting paths along narrow cliffs but safe enough for all people who are able to walk. Have a lovely stroll in the town which, despite hosting a ton of local tourist, seem to be stuck in time with vintage shops, restaurants, and artisan crafts along the streets. Also visit Chiang Kai-Shek's home at Mount Lushan. The mountain offers a lot of sights and activities.
Great to visit during summer times to get away from hotness, with beautiful waterfalls, great mountain views, beautiful valley, colorful flowers, peaceful lake.

Mount Lushan, in Jiangxi, is one of the spiritual centres of Chinese civilization. Buddhist and Taoist temples, along with landmarks of Confucianism, where the most eminent masters taught, blend effortlessly into a strikingly beautiful landscape which has inspired countless artists who developed the aesthetic approach to nature found in Chinese culture.
🇮🇳
Lushan Mountain in Jiangxi Province has been loved by literati for thousands of years. They don’t know the true face of Lushan Mountain, just because they are in this mountain!
The Immortal Cave in Mount Lushan, the waterfalls in Mount Lushan, and the clouds and mist in Mount Lushan are all beautiful!

Name: Mount Emei Scenic Area, including Leshan Giant Buddha Scenic Area
short_description: The first Buddhist temple in China was built here in Sichuan Province in the 1st century A.D. in the beautiful surroundings of the summit Mount Emei. The addition of other temples turned the site into one of Buddhism's holiest sites. Over the centuries, the cultural treasures grew in number. The most remarkable is the Giant Buddha of Leshan, carved out of a hillside in the 8th century and looking down on the confluence of three rivers. At 71 m high, it is the largest Buddha in the world. Mount Emei is also notable for its exceptionally diverse vegetation, ranging from subtropical to subalpine pine forests. Some of the trees there are more than 1,000 years old.
formatted_address: Emei Mountain, Emeishan City, Leshan, China, 614203

reviews.text:
Takes 1.5 hours from Emei Mountain Station (bullet train) to reach the cable car stop. Then some climbing and walking for 15 minutes from the cable car stop to the cable car queue. There is plentiful of food and drinks along the way to the cable car queue. Depending on the season you are here, the queue can take from 15 mins to a hour. After the cable car ride, expect to walk and climb more stairs to reach the golden peak. Please factor in the travelling time (at least 4 hours round trip. I did it as a day trip from Chengdu. Took the 835am train and reached the bullet train station at 10am. Reached the peak at about 12pm. Departed the peak at 230 and returned to Chengdu at about 7pm.

The view is awesome but so the entry ticket price. Note that the initial ticket purchased at the bullet train station does not include the cable car right to the peak. Remember to top up at the ticketing counter before joining the queue!

Mount Emei Golden Summit, one of the World Heritage Sites for both natural and cultural heritages, is an enhanced combination of lursh forest and monasteries, stunning scenery and profound culture. It's one of the Four Great Buddhist Mountains in China and play an important role in Buddhism.
A great place to visit and hiking as a choice for natural lovers.

A very nice place to visit, and a must go! However, the journey is long and tiring. We took a 1.5 hrs bus up to the mountain, and need to walk 5-10 mins to change to cable car. There are 2 types of cable car, one that carry 6 people (longer waiting time) and the bigger one can carry about 30 paxs at one go. After that, you still need to walk about 15-20 on staircases to reach the top. Very tiring journey, and prepare a whole day there.

2023 December. Once in a lifetime must go place. Not suitable for some as it is quite steep at the last stretch although there are handheld carriages which bring you up with a cost.
One day trip. Bring Passport for foreigners.
Take the earliest high speed train from Chengdu to Emeishan station 620am+-, economy ticket CNY70+-, 1hr 20min+- duration.
Reached the station, go to the official counter and buy entrance ticket, to and fro bus and cable car tickets, approximately CNY400+-.
1st sector, approximately 2hr bus ride, half way through toilet break.
2nd sector, walk approximately 40mins.
3rd sector, cable car approximately 5mins and stroll 10 min to the peak.
Lastly enjoy the scenery.
very steep mountain and mid-to-difficult trails. yet, very rewarding scenes. the mountains, temples, villages, monkeys, all mingled naturally.

Name: Lednice-Valtice Cultural Landscape
short_description: Between the 17th and 20th centuries, the ruling dukes of Liechtenstein transformed their domains in southern Moravia into a striking landscape. It married Baroque architecture (mainly the work of Johann Bernhard Fischer von Erlach) and the classical and neo-Gothic style of the castles of Lednice and Valtice with countryside fashioned according to English romantic principles of landscape architecture. At 200 km2 , it is one of the largest artificial landscapes in Europe.

reviews.text: Very beautiful, even in this season, specially because there are not so many people.

It is indeed a beautifully organised cultural and tourist complex, including not only the palace park complex, but also an organised surrounding infrastructure convenient for tourists.
I was very pleasantly surprised by the shops and restaurants around

The castle itself is not so impressive for me. It's a bit basic neo baroque building and having to pay 4 different tickets for 1000czk altogether seems excessive. If you have to choose I would go with the representation rooms. They were the most impressive for me with some very nice wood carvings.
The surrounding garden is very nice to a long walk. All in all it's a nice option for a day trip.
Fun fact the castle posseses the largest faux deer head collection I have ever seen.

Stunning area, one of the best gardens I've been to, and filled with buildings, lakes, wildlife and history.

Took a boat trip on the river and saw kingfishers, storks, herons and deer.

Lednice village is pretty and easy to stay in woth, bike hire, beer and food in a short walk
Amazing place to take a stroll, good palace gardens, would recommend 100%

Name: Okapi Wildlife Reserve
short_description: The Okapi Wildlife Reserve occupies about one-fifth of the Ituri forest in the north-east of the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The Congo river basin, of which the reserve and forest are a part, is one of the largest drainage systems in Africa. The reserve contains threatened species of primates and birds and about 5,000 of the estimated 30,000 okapi surviving in the wild. It also has some dramatic scenery, including waterfalls on the Ituri and Epulu rivers. The reserve is inhabited by traditional nomadic pygmy Mbuti and Efe hunters.
formatted_address: N4, Democratic Republic of the Congo

reviews.text: It is good, but China's mining activities are steadily destroying it by

A blissfully beautiful piece of paradise completely cut off from mainstream tourism. If you can make it here consider yourself very fortunate!! Untouched jungle, winding rivers, pygmies, okapis, chimpanzees. Just amazing.

Enjoy the Rain Forrest here as it’s an incredible journey just to get here to see the pygmies and the wilderness that they live in.  I was here 40 years ago and life here has not changed much.  Enjoy the Okapi reserve as these animals are rare

Beautiful tropical forest paradise. Want a rich multisensory experience? Visit here and take your time listening to the rushing Epulu River, the cicadas humming and the birds singing. Visit the Mbuti in their forest camps and watch them harvest honey. It's an unforgettable place.
I liked the animals and I went there on a nice day. I think that this is a great experience to see exotic animals.

Name: Verla Groundwood and Board Mill
short_description: The Verla groundwood and board mill and its associated residential area is an outstanding, remarkably well-preserved example of the small-scale rural industrial settlements associated with pulp, paper and board production that flourished in northern Europe and North America in the 19th and early 20th centuries. Only a handful of such settlements survive to the present day.

reviews.text: Beautiful World Heritage site. Signs all over the place provide interesting information. Plenty of places to just sit down and enjoy the view or take pictures of nature.
Great place for photos. We had the chance to get a tour as well. It was worth it if you are  into the way things are made and there was an  option for an English tour too.
beautiful UNESCO site with one of the better espressos in Finland ☺️
A wonderful sight from the beginnings of the plywood industry in the 19th century. Nice brick buildings, a few souvenir shops, a vegetable garden, a beach, sheep and lots of green space.

A really nice milieu with parks. Get a good impression of the buildings, what kind of splendor the factory area had in its time, e.g. With a cartridge. The places were in good condition and restoration was also done. The restaurant and sales points also served.

The museum tour about cardboard manufacturing was worth all the money. The guide was very knowledgeable about history and knew how to answer questions. Visited the destination 3.8.-23.  I definitely recommend visiting.

Name: Canal du Midi
short_description: This 360-km network of navigable waterways linking the Mediterranean and the Atlantic through 328 structures (locks, aqueducts, bridges, tunnels, etc.) is one of the most remarkable feats of civil engineering in modern times. Built between 1667 and 1694, it paved the way for the Industrial Revolution. The care that its creator, Pierre-Paul Riquet, took in the design and the way it blends with its surroundings turned a technical achievement into a work of art.

reviews.text: Great route for cycling, Bordeaux to Narbonne ( jumps about a bit in places but not difficult to get back on track). Shady for much of the route and flat throughout, taking in beautiful towns and countryside.

Canal Du Midi from Toulouse to Narbonne.
By bike September 2019
This is a great experience and very physical intensive.but a lot of joy and a good way to strengthen your body.
The first step from Toulouse to Castelnaudary it's quiet relaxed and the path on the side of Canal du Midi make it easy to get along. But you always hear the high way where the cars making there own sound but still you feel happy peddling along the old Allees beside the water.
The following route to Carcassonne needed more Intension for the path it was paved with little stones, occasionally some roots and wholes make it difficult to bike fast.
The third part till Narbonne was even more difficult and because of some tree disease they had to cut almost all the old trees and planted new once but this couldn't give you an enjoyable feeling. The good part was that the high way was to fare away to hear.
Nevertheless the people you meet on the Canal Du Midi in Bike, Hiking or on a Boot are always very friendly and all in all take as much time you can to be able to explore the villages on the Canal try the good food and the great wine they produce in the area and look out that you have always enough water with you.
A bucket list exsperience and must do. Relaxing holiday by selfdriven boat while enjoying southern France's vinos and old villages.
Lovely view, fantastic French Environment and Atmosphere abundant with fresh Breathing air.. Wonderful place to be in Southern France .
A canal that runs from Toulouse to the Mediterranean sea, many places to visit and stay over ,by bicycle, foot or river boat

Name: Upper Svaneti
short_description: Preserved by its long isolation, the Upper Svaneti region of the Caucasus is an exceptional example of mountain scenery with medieval-type villages and tower-houses. The village of Chazhashi still has more than 200 of these very unusual houses, which were used both as dwellings and as defence posts against the invaders who plagued the region.

Name: Cologne Cathedral
short_description: Begun in 1248, the construction of this Gothic masterpiece took place in several stages and was not completed until 1880. Over seven centuries, successive builders were inspired by the same faith and a spirit of absolute fidelity to the original plans. Apart from its exceptional intrinsic value and the artistic masterpieces it contains, Cologne Cathedral testifies to the enduring strength of European Christianity.

reviews.text:
Make sure not to bring a big backpack, since you will need to put it into paid storage at the back of the cathedral.

The cathedral itself is nice to explore during daytime. There are plenty of details all across its interior and you may even take a look at the throne room museum with more prestigious wall paint etc.

Worth a visit!

A very stunning cathedral with access to inside, there were queues and masses of people which made it hard to actually have time to look properly and take it all in. I think you need to pay once you’re inside the cathedral to enter the middle, I didn’t check it out so not 100% sure. Beautiful stained glass windows and statues. Breathtaking architecture.

This cathedral has been on my bucket list for as long as I can remember and just recently, I finally got the chance to visit it. Stepping out of the train station after having arrived in Cologne and immediately seeing the majestic cathedral towering over the city was a truly incredible sight. It was magnificent to behold from the outside and just as magnificent to behold inside as well. It's a fascinating piece of architecture and holds so much history. A have visited a number of cathedrals across Europe and this one just happens to be my favourite. I'm truly glad that I got the opportunity to visit this cathedral, it's an experience that I'll never forget.
The most impressive building I have ever seen. Make sure to visit the panoramic view from the top of the cathedral- only stairs, no elevator and it costs 8€ but trust me it’s worth every cent !

An absolute landmark and a must-visit. Its size is breathtaking, gigantic and immense, it dominates the city’s skyline in the most magnificent way. The Gothic architecture, stunning stained glass windows, and towering spires make it a true masterpiece. Whether you admire it from the outside or explore the incredible interior, the experience is unforgettable. A visit to Cologne wouldn’t be complete without seeing this absolutely splendid cathedral

Name: Bauhaus and its Sites in Weimar, Dessau and Bernau
short_description: Between 1919 and 1933 the Bauhaus movement revolutionized architectural and aesthetic thinking and practice in the 20th century. The Bauhaus buildings in Weimar, Dessau and Bernau are fundamental representatives of Classical Modernism, directed towards a radical renewal of architecture and design. This property, which was inscribed on the World Heritage List in 1996, originally comprised buildings located in Weimar (Former Art School, the Applied Art School and the Haus Am Horn) and Dessau (Bauhaus Building, the group of seven Masters' Houses). The 2017 extension includes the Houses with Balcony Access in Dessau and the ADGB Trade Union School in Bernau as important contributions to the Bauhaus ideas of austere design, functionalism and social reform.

reviews.text: As a completist, I decided to visit the Bernau site of the UNESCO Bauhaus listing in Germany. From Berlin it’s a simple journey on the regional train or S-Bahn, and a bus ride to the ‘Welterbe Bauhaus’ stop. The architecture is interesting, and the visitor centre is well designed, with a nice exhibition and some materials I wasn’t expecting to come across. The staff were uniformly welcoming and I had an overall good visit. Tours of the school are only available on weekends, and English language tours even more infrequently. It’s perhaps not an essential visit if you only have a passing interest in the Bauhaus. The other sites in Dessau and Weimar are by far richer. However, this was an enjoyable morning excursion from the city.
Very interesting site for understanding the Bauhaus movement.

I had a pleasure to attend a guided tour today. The building is in deed impressive and the tour was really interesting. Really great way to spend your Sunday noon. Many thanks to our super nice guide that show us around today!
Please note, this is just the visitor center for the heritage. To visit the heritage building itself, you must book a tour in advance.
Very special place, worth a visit!

Name: Luther Memorials in Eisleben and Wittenberg
short_description: These places in Saxony-Anhalt are all associated with the lives of Martin Luther and his fellow-reformer Melanchthon. They include Melanchthon's house in Wittenberg, the houses in Eisleben where Luther was born in 1483 and died in 1546, his room in Wittenberg, the local church and the castle church where, on 31 October 1517, Luther posted his famous '95 Theses', which launched the Reformation and a new era in the religious and political history of the Western world.

reviews.text: Nice square surrounded by a selection of interesting buildings, amidst of which you will find two statues within beautifully designed casings.
Really enjoyed my time here. The best place I visited throughout all my time in Germany.
Statue of the great reformator Martin Luther who lived and teached here 500 years ago.
Must see in the Luther's Town Wittenberg!
Icon

Name: Archaeological Site of Aigai (modern name Vergina)
short_description: The city of Aigai, the ancient first capital of the Kingdom of Macedonia, was discovered in the 19th century near Vergina, in northern Greece. The most important remains are the monumental palace, lavishly decorated with mosaics and painted stuccoes, and the burial ground with more than 300 tumuli, some of which date from the 11th century B.C. One of the royal tombs in the Great Tumulus is identified as that of Philip II, who conquered all the Greek cities, paving the way for his son Alexander and the expansion of the Hellenistic world.

reviews.text: We visited this as part of of a tour and our tour guide gave us a detailed description of what was inside. The most amazing thing was the ancient tomb of King Philip that was excavated there and is displayed prominently inside the museum. This dates back to 400BC and it’s amazing how you can see the actual tomb and in displays many of the artifacts.  Even some of the images of frescos can be seen which itself is amazing.

We came to this site without expectations and were more than pleasantly surprised by the Necropolis (museum). The collection was thoughtfully arranged and is just stunning. It is the burial tomb of Phillip II the king of Macedonia who was responsible for uniting its various tribes and consolidating its territory, setting the stage for his son Alexander’s triumphant campaigns. Part of his success came from lessons he learned as a child hostage in Greece. He learned of the phalanx formation and the use of the long spear or pike called a sarissa which he brought to the Macedonian infantry. He also transformed the army with increased discipline and training. Under Phillip the soldiers were provided with the possibility of advancement through the ranks and were rewarded with bonuses and extra wages for exceptional service. All of this is reflected in this tomb of exceptional quality. This may be one of the best memorials I’ve seen of a clearly beloved king and the father of a nation. Phillip not only set the stage for Alexander but for the world to be shaped as it has been by Hellenic values.

Do not trust Google to get you there! Put the museum in as your destination, otherwise you could be driving and then walking aimlessly forever. Start at the museum, which is actually the entrance to the tombs, and yes worth it for the entrance fee (15 E for Americans).  Other area not well signed and hard to figure out where to enter, lots of walking
So nice to pay tribute to your history, just brilliant !
Just wonderful

Name: Millenary Benedictine Abbey of Pannonhalma and its Natural Environment
short_description: The first Benedictine monks settled here in 996. They went on to convert the Hungarians, to found the country's first school and, in 1055, to write the first document in Hungarian. From the time of its founding, this monastic community has promoted culture throughout central Europe. Its 1,000-year history can be seen in the succession of architectural styles of the monastic buildings (the oldest dating from 1224), which still today house a school and the monastic community.

reviews.text: Highly recommend visiting this beautiful spot! Please be aware that the winery requires tickets purchased at least a day in advance - you cannot buy tickets once you’re there. The in-person tours are only in Hungarian but you can purchase an audio tour, which I recommend. I bought a bottle of wine at the gift store and enjoyed it.

I recently visited the Pannonhalma Archabbey in Hungary, and it’s an absolute gem for history, architecture, and culture lovers. Sitting on a hill with stunning views, it’s the oldest school in Hungary, dating back to 996 AD. The Romanesque architecture reflects its Benedictine roots perfectly.

The library was a highlight—full of ancient books and manuscripts. The whole place was surprisingly quiet during summer, which made the experience even better. The main restaurant was closed, but I found a pizza spot nearby. Don’t miss out on their lavender products and the abbey’s own beer—great for souvenirs, the beer was tasty and they have different strength. You can purchase those in the gift shop.

It’s close to the Baroque town of Győr, so definitely worth adding to your trip!

Website said it is open, we checked weeks in advance and a couple days before visiting. When we arrived the abbey was closed due to a music festival, they said the website was updated - that morning. The library could be visited on a tour, so at least we got to see that
Unique location of the monastery and very well preserved interiors including the librery.
Lovely abbey which is a unesco world heritage site. Need to take local bus to get here but well worth the trouble. Lots of history and the view from above the mountains is the best.

Name: Sangiran Early Man Site
short_description: Excavations here from 1936 to 1941 led to the discovery of the first hominid fossil at this site. Later, 50 fossils of Meganthropus palaeo and Pithecanthropus erectus/Homo erectus were found – half of all the world's known hominid fossils. Inhabited for the past one and a half million years, Sangiran is one of the key sites for the understanding of human evolution.
formatted_address: Jl. Sangiran No.Km.4, Kebayanan II, Krikilan, Kec. Kalijambe, Kabupaten Sragen, Jawa Tengah 57275, Indonesia

reviews.text: one of the historical educational tourist attractions that I really wanted to visit since I was a child in elementary school in Lombok, finally I got the nostalgia of studying the history of ancient humans in ancient times, it was really amazing, shuttle transportation is only charged 6 thousand rupiah from the parking lot to the museum, the entrance ticket is quite cheap for domestic 15 thousand rupiah and you can hire a guide to explain the history by paying only 100 thousand rupiah, don't forget to buy souvenirs and rocks because the prices are quite affordable, happy traveling!

Bringing back to high school memories

Take about 50minutes from Solo, if you came by car or motorcycle need to proceed to parking area, after that use public transport cost IDR 3.000 per pax to museum.
At museum, entry ticket cost IRD 8.000per pax, then enjoy either use tour guide or not depent on you.

For me (the one who interested in primordial history) it's worth to visit.
- Arriving from Purwosari, i paid around 85K IDR for gocar.
- Entrance fee 8K IDR (i don't know whether it same for foreign visitor or not).
- Tour guide 75K IDR (the tour itself was generally good but he skip some; probably because of tire).
- From the museum, i walked down to the car parking lot. Pretty near, just around 6 minutes walk. Motorbike or ojek will charge 3K IDR (but it optional).
- From car parkir, i went back to solo using Trans Jateng bus, only 4K IDR. It can be paid by cash or QR payment.
- The bus then stopped at Tirtonadi terminal. Totally i taken around 40'  if not mistaken.
- From terminal, there is a sky bridge connected to solo balapan train station.
- Exit from the station, there is a solo bus transit shelter. I ride a red color bus (corridor 1) and still free at that time. But i was required to tap the payment card (mine was e-money).

PS. If visitor bring their own car, i must be parked at the official car parking lot. From there, visitor can choose to walk to the entrance of museum which less than 10' or ride a black pick-up car. I don't know how much the charge for this car.

It was quite fun to visit Sangiran. We took Trans Jateng bus from Tirtonadi Terminal at 10 AM and arrived about 45 mins to 1 hour later, the fare was quite cheap and the entry to Sangiran was affordable. There were multiple specimens and interactive display at Sangiran. It can be a good destinations for families with children.

This is an excellent place to study, but also suitable for family recreation. One thing to take note is that the 2nd display room was somehow damp, thus making the air smell bad.
Don't worry about buying food in the cafeteria—the prices aren't expensive yet they taste quite good.
To those who bring their own vehicles, please park at the shelter area. Then take a ticket for a short pick up ride to the museum's one and only entrance gate.

Name: Sceilg Mhichíl
short_description: Sceilg Mhichíl is an outstanding, and in many respects unique, example of an early religious settlement deliberately sited on a pyramidal rock in the ocean, preserved because of a remarkable environment. It illustrates, as no other property can, the extremes of a Christian monasticism characterizing much of North Africa, the Near East, and Europe.
formatted_address: Great Skellig, Skellig Rock Great, Ireland

reviews.text: Take medicine before starting the one hour boat to Skellig Michael island even you are not a sea sick. But it’s worth to go. During strong wave we saw many dolphins. 35,000 pairs of Gannets made the little Skellig island as an awe inspiring sight from the boat. My group can view thousand of lovely tamed  puffins on May 28,2024. It’s easy to see closely, much better than in Iceland. I highly recommend to visit Skellig Michael island if you visit South Ireland. Do not afraid even vomiting from seasick I can say it’s worth to go. Don’t miss it

Tricky to reach: not only are there limited slots (max 180 guests per day), it's expensive to get there and your tour might be cancelled due to weather, swells, wind, rainfall.
It's 600 steps up, on uneven stone slabs. It will take you about 15 to 20 minutes of nonstop climbing, with not a lot of spots to catch your breath. Then you'll need to go down again, and your knees will have something to say about that.
