Wonderful views, intricately built monastery with a vivid history. Lots of birds and particular plant life. Quite the experience.

One of the highlights of our trip to Ireland. Unique and full of history.
Preparing for this we read a lot of material that almost scared us out of the trek. Honestly, this is for beginners. Avid hikers will have zero issues. The biggest take away is TAKE YOUR TIME. Steps can be uneven, but watch your feet and catch your breath at each stair landing. Take a camelbak or small backpack for your water, snack, and camera. Nothing else needed. ENJOY!

This is simply a great place. If you are lucky with the weather and the waves you will have a wonderful experience. But be aware that you really have to climb all those steps. The old monastery is a great place to be. The birds on Little Skellig and the seals are great to watch. And in June there are many puffins on Skellig Michael which can be looked at from a short distance.

Awesome trip with Boat "Deva" the crew were just amazing. Booked landing tour, took 5 hours, first we did the tour around the islands, after landing to Great Skellig. Everything on time. This is the toilets in the island. Lots of puffins now in july.

Name: Castel del Monte
short_description: When the Emperor Frederick II built this castle near Bari in the 13th century, he imbued it with symbolic significance, as reflected in the location, the mathematical and astronomical precision of the layout and the perfectly regular shape. A unique piece of medieval military architecture, Castel del Monte is a successful blend of elements from classical antiquity, the Islamic Orient and north European Cistercian Gothic.

reviews.text:
Super interesting octagonal castle from the 1240s built by Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor, Hohenstaufen of Swabia and King of Sicily.
Example of Medieval architecture located on a hill some kilometers away from Andria overseeing a large plain.
The octagonal castle is surrounded by an octagonal tower at each corner.
Mysterious and an almost inhumanly exact geometric shape, some theories claim that the octagon represented the union of the circle and the square.

the environment is beautiful. the parking lot near the castle is small and always full. from the large paid parking lot approx. 20 minutes walk to the castle. the road leads through a pine forest, very beautiful.

The place is not worthy of a visit and shouldn't be the Unesco listed site - it's just an empty shell of a castle that is not typical for the region, doesn't tell any story of the region and the owner maybe even didn't spent time there. What looks nicely from the outside is rubbed inside so you can see only empty walles and holes in the places where supposed to be fireplaces. Go to Matera instead if you are looking for a unique unesco experience.
Don't leave Puglia without visiting this Frederics II castle. Guide is preferred since the stories are more vivid.

Amazing Castle and the views are incredible. Castel del Monte is a remarkable 13th-century fortress in the Apulia region of Italy, known for its unique octagonal shape and mysterious design. Built by Emperor Frederick II. No one knows why it was originally built,  some say for astronomical views, some say Frederick II’s show of money and power.  It’s truly beautiful.

Name: The Trulli of Alberobello
short_description: The trulli , limestone dwellings found in the southern region of Puglia, are remarkable examples of drywall (mortarless) construction, a prehistoric building technique still in use in this region. The trulli are made of roughly worked limestone boulders collected from neighbouring fields. Characteristically, they feature pyramidal, domed or conical roofs built up of corbelled limestone slabs.
formatted_address: Via Monte S. Michele, 37, 70011 Alberobello BA, Italy

reviews.text: Definitely must see!  What a beautiful and unique area!  It's a great time to visit in February/ March as it's less crowded and certainly more relaxing :)
Beautiful place. We came across festival, there was music, delicious food, great weather. I recommend walking around the city without a map - you can find great things!

There are hundreds of Trulli that cascade down the hillside, majority are now souvenir shops or small hotels or B&Bs. It’s one of the most amazing parts of Alberobello in Puglia.
Rione Monti is an old quarter of this beautiful old town which is also a UNESCO world heritage site.
Just a neat place… Fun to see and visit. Makes your imagination roll as you think of how it would be to live in these trullis many years ago. Fun!

Drive around the Itria Valley in southeastern Italy and you’ll discover houses straight out of a fairy tale. Of diminutive size and topped by conical roofs made of stacked limestone, trulli—the traditional structures of Puglia—look like beehives from another planet. Found on almost every country road in the valley, trulli are not idle curiosities; they are actively used as homes, farmsteads, guesthouses, and more.

Name: Early Christian Monuments of Ravenna
short_description: Ravenna was the seat of the Roman Empire in the 5th century and then of Byzantine Italy until the 8th century. It has a unique collection of early Christian mosaics and monuments. All eight buildings – the Mausoleum of Galla Placidia, the Neonian Baptistery, the Basilica of Sant'Apollinare Nuovo, the Arian Baptistery, the Archiepiscopal Chapel, the Mausoleum of Theodoric, the Church of San Vitale and the Basilica of Sant'Apollinare in Classe – were constructed in the 5th and 6th centuries. They show great artistic skill, including a wonderful blend of Graeco-Roman tradition, Christian iconography and oriental and Western styles.
formatted_address: Via San Vitale, 17, 48121 Ravenna RA, Italy

reviews.text: Absolutely beautiful mosaics - so worth going. My tip, if you are planning on seeing the sights in Ravenna, buy a ticket for all 5, as it saves money, and all 5 are worth seeing

Basilica di San Vitale – My Favorite Place in Ravenna!

The Basilica di San Vitale is undoubtedly my favorite place in Ravenna, and it’s easy to see why. This stunning Byzantine church is a true masterpiece, filled with some of the most incredible mosaics I’ve ever seen. From the moment you step inside, you’re transported back in time, surrounded by vibrant colors and intricate designs that seem to shimmer and glow.

The mosaics in San Vitale are absolutely breathtaking, with scenes from the Bible and the lives of saints depicted in stunning detail. One of the most iconic mosaics is the Empress Theodora, who is depicted with such grandeur and elegance, showcasing the opulence of the Byzantine Empire. The mosaic of Emperor Justinian is equally impressive, with his regal presence immortalized in vibrant colors. These mosaics are not only beautiful but also a fascinating glimpse into the historical significance of the church during the 6th century.

The church’s architecture is also exceptional, with its octagonal shape and elegant proportions creating a sense of harmony and balance. The central dome is particularly striking, and the light that filters through the windows gives the entire space a spiritual and ethereal quality.

Why It’s My Favorite:
•	The mosaics are among the best-preserved examples of Byzantine art in the world.
•	The basilica’s historical significance and architectural beauty make it an absolute must-see in Ravenna.
•	It’s a peaceful and reflective space where you can immerse yourself in the art and history without the crowds of some of the more famous attractions.

If you’re visiting Ravenna, San Vitale is a must-visit. The stunning mosaics, combined with the serene atmosphere, make it one of the most remarkable and awe-inspiring sites in Italy.

An absolutely amazing and stunning monument! Absolutely worth visiting if you are in Ravenna and interested in cultural and historical activities! I recommend buying the ticket for 9,50€ and visiting all 5 most popular monuments/museums/churches in Ravenna all together! They all are pretty much near each other so you can reach all of them by foot very fast, enjoying the view of the city and maybe going for a little shopping while walking around. Love Italy!

One of the most beautiful churches I've ever seen. A must see worth doing a day  trip in Ravenna.
Interesting to note that there was a panel for blind people, with braille and some textured images, and all the 5 sites included in the 1 ticket are wheelchair accessible:)

The Basilica is absolutely breathtaking. It's a 5th century byzantine design and despite the plain exterior the inside is just sublime.

Standing there taking it all in is truly a remarkable experience.

Do yourself a favour and buy a combination ticket that let's you visit 5 sites for just €10.

We visited the first weekend in June and didn't have to wait. I cam imagine it would get very busy in summer

Buy your tickets in advance or online. They are valid for 7 days but you can only visit each site once with your combo ticket.

Name: Historic Centre of the City of Pienza
short_description: It was in this Tuscan town that Renaissance town-planning concepts were first put into practice after Pope Pius II decided, in 1459, to transform the look of his birthplace. He chose the architect Bernardo Rossellino, who applied the principles of his mentor, Leon Battista Alberti. This new vision of urban space was realized in the superb square known as Piazza Pio II and the buildings around it: the Piccolomini Palace, the Borgia Palace and the cathedral with its pure Renaissance exterior and an interior in the late Gothic style of south German churches.

reviews.text:
Beautiful place to stop by on the way to Pienza.
In a small wine shop you can buy wine on a glass or bottles. There is also an option to join winetasting program for which we didn't have time.

Really worth the stop, you can even go to the Palazzio and do a wine tasting for 20€ (3 wine and some food). Very cool and charming place.
Not a lot of people, even some lavender fields on the side of the allee.
Visited in February,  not much open and garden in average shape. A few photographic opportunities. Maybe best visited later in the year.
We were on a photography tour so of we stopped here for pictures.
We didn't go to see the mansion but heard to be quite nice. It was our first view of the iconic trees of Tuscany.

Name: Hiroshima Peace Memorial (Genbaku Dome)
short_description: The Hiroshima Peace Memorial (Genbaku Dome) was the only structure left standing in the area where the first atomic bomb exploded on 6 August 1945. Through the efforts of many people, including those of the city of Hiroshima, it has been preserved in the same state as immediately after the bombing. Not only is it a stark and powerful symbol of the most destructive force ever created by humankind; it also expresses the hope for world peace and the ultimate elimination of all nuclear weapons.

reviews.text: The Atomic Bomb Dome in Hiroshima is a must-see with no excuses if you're visiting the city. Once a fabric building, it survived the atomic bomb explosion that detonated 600m above it, standing as a haunting reminder of history. It has been carefully repaired and maintained over the years, preserving its powerful message. The site is deeply moving, full of historical significance, and adds profoundly to the atmosphere of the city. A visit here is a meaningful and unforgettable experience.

My wife and I were on a bus tour across Japan and this was one of the places that I was most interested in seeing. I am a history buff, adore Japanese culture and we wanted to pay our respects to a tragic chapter in human history. We have also been to Auschwitz in Poland and it is important to look the ugly parts of history in the eye, so that we are witnesses and never make that mistake again.

The most important thing that I took away from the Atomic Bomb memorial was the stately crane that was perched upon the dome while we were there. To me that was a symbol that life had returned to the lively, bustling, beautiful city of Hiroshima. If this memorial, and world heritage protected ruin, was not here, you would never know that an atomic bomb was dropped directly above it.

My favourite part of the memorial was the crane statue with the child holding a giant origami crane. The glass displays with all of the thousands of origami paper cranes that children have made to honour the victims was lovely to see. The peace symbols and signs made up of tiny cranes were very touching.

Luckily for us, there were many Japanese school children on a field trip to see the memorial park that day. It was another sign of life reborn. I rang the bell to honour the victims. A truly lovely memorial and a wonderful way to honour the countless lost souls that were lost that sad day.

This structure is very well preserved and a symbol of the resilience of the Japanese people in the face of the horrors of atomic weapons. Surrounded by a beautiful garden, it is indeed a sight to behold with the dome right next to the river and surrounded by a well maintained garden.

You can walk around this garden and site for many hours and have the opportunity to see this site from various scenic points. If you are in the area I also recommend going to the museum and checking out the larger garden site which goes beyond this dome. This is indeed a great educational opportunity to learn about this point in history

A very moving yet peaceful area. The old dome has been well preserved. This attraction is very historical, easy to access, is free of charge. Take the time to walk around and read what it has to say. Give yourself some time to take it all

The Atomic Bomb Dome in Hiroshima is a profoundly moving and historically significant site that left a deep impression on me during my visits. I went to this location twice, both on weekdays, and each time, it was a deeply sobering experience.

Standing near the dome, I felt the weight of history and the immense tragedy of the atomic bomb disaster that unfolded here in 1945. The building, preserved in its ruined state, serves as a stark reminder of the devastating impact of nuclear warfare on humanity. It’s shocking to see the skeletal structure of the dome still standing amidst the vibrant city of Hiroshima, symbolizing both the destruction and resilience of the people who rebuilt their lives after such unimaginable suffering.

The silence around the site is almost palpable, as visitors from all over the world pay their respects. The dome’s presence is haunting yet essential, reminding us of the importance of peace and the urgent need to prevent such tragedies in the future.

I highly recommend visiting the Atomic Bomb Dome if you’re in Hiroshima. It’s not just a historical site—it’s a powerful call for reflection on humanity’s past and a reminder to strive for a more peaceful future.

Name: Itsukushima Shinto Shrine
short_description: The island of Itsukushima, in the Seto inland sea, has been a holy place of Shintoism since the earliest times. The first shrine buildings here were probably erected in the 6th century. The present shrine dates from the 12th century and the harmoniously arranged buildings reveal great artistic and technical skill. The shrine plays on the contrasts in colour and form between mountains and sea and illustrates the Japanese concept of scenic beauty, which combines nature and human creativity.

reviews.text:
It's a very nice and unique shrine, being pretty much in the sea at high tide. As most popular tourist locations it can be a bit busy. It was a bit shocking to see even more people arriving as I was leaving at 15:00.
There's currently work being done to parts of the shrine building and some others nearby which was a shame.

Maybe the best part of my Japan trip! The calm, the sites, the temples, the deer, great people! Visit this place if you can. It is just a short ferry trip away from the train station. It is easy to spend a day here, easy to spend multiple days. On my nest visit I will definitely try to stay a few days in the island itself.

Lot’s of deers, beautiful nature view, town and shrine.

You can spend a day here if you want to go for a more relax pace to fully explore island including hiking. Otherwise come early in the morning to catch the ferry here as last ferry back to mainland departs between 5-6pm.

Okay okay, it is one of the most famous of photos of Japan. It is a nice view when the tide is in. Hard to get a good photo when the tide is out. Get photos from the beach side. Do not waste your time waiting in line for hours to take the photos from the front. Not worth the hype. A cool place to visit.

Very popular place. I came around 11am so it is not possible to go to the 鳥居. Also there is a long queue to take pictures with it. Good to visit if you have time otherwise nothing to loss.
Notes:
1. There are two ferries you can choose. For the JR one, the outbound approaches to the鳥居, so you can take some good pictures. With JR pass there is still 100 yen island tax
2. There is official website you can check tide and ebbing times for that day. Usually the difference is about 4-5 hours. So if you want to see the in the water and above the water scenes of the Torii. You need to time your trip wisely

Name: Ancient Ksour of Ouadane, Chinguetti, Tichitt and Oualata
short_description: Founded in the 11th and 12th centuries to serve the caravans crossing the Sahara, these trading and religious centres became focal points of Islamic culture. They have managed to preserve an urban fabric that evolved between the 12th and 16th centuries. Typically, houses with patios crowd along narrow streets around a mosque with a square minaret. They illustrate a traditional way of life centred on the nomadic culture of the people of the western Sahara.

reviews.text: Excellent visit with local tour in French. The view from the old mosque is very nice. Must visit the well that was extremely protected. The walls and old city ruins still in very good condition and there is fee of 200. Make sure to reach the top where new town starts. Quite a contrast!

A fascinating labyrinth of an ancient abandoned fortified stone village, this village earned UNESCO Heritage status and represents one of the stops on a trade route and the route to Makkah. Of note, you will find a historic mosque with rows of archways that allow light to permeate the ground an inspire faithful Muslims to come and pray. Only Muslims were able to enter the space, but it can be viewed from above at the northern corner. Other key structures are the homes of the three founders or Maisons des 3 Fondateurs. They are in fairly good condition, as is the emergency well that seems to dangle from the rest of the town. In case the fortified town was under siege, this well could be a vital resource for water.
We also explores homes of the scholars and imagined what studies would be like in this ancient Saharan village.
Do use caution when tourinf the site. Many stones are loose and its worth being mindful of where you put your steps.
Worth a visit

Historic old town, ruins, the old trading town of Ouadane. Fascinating quiet place. The old mosque is in a condition worth seeing. The viewing fee is 200 Ou. You can visit the site with or without a guide.

A very interesting and beautiful place to visit. The ancient trading city of Ouadane has existed for centuries. I got a tour from a French-speaking man, he was nice and knew a lot about the city. From the old mosque, to the houses of the founders to the defensive wall, he showed everything. Even a very deep well, so watch your step! I would recommend visiting it either in the morning or in the afternoon. The cost is 200 Ougiya + tip for your guide (unless you want to buy something from a souvenir)

Name: Pre-Hispanic Town of Uxmal
short_description: The Mayan town of Uxmal, in Yucatán, was founded c. A.D. 700 and had some 25,000 inhabitants. The layout of the buildings, which date from between 700 and 1000, reveals a knowledge of astronomy. The Pyramid of the Soothsayer, as the Spaniards called it, dominates the ceremonial centre, which has well-designed buildings decorated with a profusion of symbolic motifs and sculptures depicting Chaac, the god of rain. The ceremonial sites of Uxmal, Kabah, Labna and Sayil are considered the high points of Mayan art and architecture.

reviews.text: This was a wonderful site to visit. Only problem we encountered is that you have to pay two different times. One of the times only accepts pesos so be prepared. The site is very well kept. There is a lot of walking and some climbing.
Love visiting the Mayan pyramids and in aww of their sophistication and intelligence! Uxmal was so peaceful and quiet! Very well maintained with good descriptions of each point of interest.
This is unbelievable!  Just amazing ruins of all shapes and sizes.  Iguanas everywhere.  Not difficult to find.  Just one hour drive from Merida.  It’s a must see if you’re in the area.

Uxmal leaves an impression on visitors. The unearthed expansive remains of a Mayan civic religious and entertainment hub ask us to consider life from well over a millennium ago.  Our guide shared his knowledge and pride as he steered us across the landscape of monumental buildings and up to breathtaking vistas. Symbols abound. Customs seemed both familiar and foreign.  It was a lot to take in for we first time visitors.  Inescapable is the contrast between the beautiful Yucatan blue skies and the warm colors of the stones and carvings.  There is nothing but green hills surrounding this encampment - there are no distractions - and one can easily imagine the presence of the former inhabitants. I was able to retreat and steal a moment by watching and listening to the swallows circling overhead. And I caught a glimpse of a vulture. This visit provided a frame of reference I did not have before. I highly recommend a visit. Dress to stay cool. Come early to avoid the midday sun. Be sure to have a guide with you. Cash is required for a portion of the admission. Food drinks and souvenirs are available. We reached the site using a tour from Merida that also included another archeological site, lunch and a visit to a Cenote.

Unbelievable architecture. Look it up online before you go. Pricey at 561 pesos but they need to maintain it. Good bathrooms and well groomed paths. No vendors on site. Worth the drive and price especially if you add in Kabah which is just down the road and it is only 80 pesos.

Name: Historic Monuments Zone of Querétaro
short_description: The old colonial town of Querétaro is unusual in having retained the geometric street plan of the Spanish conquerors side by side with the twisting alleys of the Indian quarters. The Otomi, the Tarasco, the Chichimeca and the Spanish lived together peacefully in the town, which is notable for the many ornate civil and religious Baroque monuments from its golden age in the 17th and 18th centuries.
formatted_address: Centro Histórico, Centro, 76000 Santiago de Querétaro, Qro., Mexico

Name: Historic City of Meknes
short_description: Founded in the 11th century by the Almoravids as a military settlement, Meknes became a capital under Sultan Moulay Ismaïl (1672–1727), the founder of the Alawite dynasty. The sultan turned it into a impressive city in Spanish-Moorish style, surrounded by high walls with great doors, where the harmonious blending of the Islamic and European styles of the 17th century Maghreb are still evident today.

reviews.text:
Mausoleum of Moulay Isma'il is a historic Islamic funerary complex in Meknes, Morocco. It encompasses the tomb of Sultan Moulay Ismail, who governed Morocco from 1672 until his death in 1727, and is situated within the confines of his citadel. It is a notable historic and religious site in the city.

The funerary complex consists of various courtyards and chambers. The main central courtyard, located on the west side of the tomb chamber, is sparsely decorated except for a central fountain and pavement. The western and eastern sides of the courtyard are occupied by these horseshoe arches.

Behind the courtyard's eastern wall are the mausoleum chamber and adjoining rooms.  An indoor patio or courtyard covered by a high amazingly beautiful cupola ceiling. The pavement and lower walls are decorated with zellij tilework that feature circular or radiating geometric patterns, typical of Moroccan architecture. At the center of the patio is an ornate fountain, and while the cupola ceiling above primarily features painted and carved wood. The wooden cupola ceiling and stucco-carved walls of the patio are remarkably stunning. The cupola is high enough to allow for windows that bring in natural light. Its beauty undoubtedly mesmerizes thousands of visitors.

The mausoleum is a square chamber which holds the tombstones of Moulay Isma'il.  The royal tombstones are made of marble and are richly carved with  Arabic calligraphic inscriptions.

Similar to other Moroccan cultural landmarks, images merely offer a glimpse of its beauty. To experience its beauty in its entirety, an on-site visit is required. Time constraints, such as what I  experienced with my tour group; limited the capture and sharing of only a few essential aspects of The Mausoleum of Moulay Isma'il.
Stunning building. Beautiful majestic walls. Makes a great day trip from Fes.

Incredible that this historic building, with its holy significance, is free to enter. It’s very well maintained and there are lots of people to explain things to you. If you want to enter the room where Moulay Ismail is buried you have to take your shoes off. If you don’t want to do that, you can also view the tomb through a window to the right of the mausoleum entrance, with arguably gives a better view anyway.
Beautifull mausoleum. Worth a visit and not many tourists!

Absolutely beautiful place, definitely worth visiting, stunning architecture and decoration. My own experience marred only by a group of very loud Catalans who seemed to think it was normal to shout to each other and guffaw loudly at their own jokes in another country's religious site. You can understand why mosques and other Muslim sites are closed to foreigners when you see behaviour like this - keep respect, people. 🙏🏼

Name: Dutch Water Defence Lines
short_description: The significant boundary modification of the property first inscribed in 1996 stretches from the IJsselmeer (previously known as Zuiderzee) at Muiden to the Biesbosch estuary at Werkendam. This modification adds the New Dutch Waterline to the existing Defence Line of Amsterdam World Heritage site, to become the Dutch Water Defence Lines World Heritage property and also includes a number of small extensions and reductions to the boundaries of the Defence Line of Amsterdam World Heritage property. In particular, the extension illustrates a single military defence system, which was based on inundation fields, hydraulic installations and on a series of fortifications and military posts stretching over an area of 85 km. It also includes three smaller components: Fort Werk IV, the Tiel Inundation Canal and Fort Pannerden near the German border. Built from 1814 to 1940, they complement the already inscribed site, which is the only example of a fortification based on the principle of controlling the waters. Since the 16th century, the people of the Netherlands have used their expert knowledge of hydraulic engineering for defence purposes. The centre of the country was protected by a network of 45 armed forts, acting in concert with temporary flooding from polders and an intricate system of canals and locks.

Name: Historic Centre of Oporto, Luiz I Bridge and Monastery of Serra do Pilar
short_description: The city of Oporto, built along the hillsides overlooking the mouth of the Douro river, is an outstanding urban landscape with a 2,000-year history. Its continuous growth, linked to the sea (the Romans gave it the name Portus, or port), can be seen in the many and varied monuments, from the cathedral with its Romanesque choir, to the neoclassical Stock Exchange and the typically Portuguese Manueline-style Church of Santa Clara.

reviews.text: Beautiful views from the bridge on both side of Porto. Metro is running on it, on the top, which is so cool, you can drive by car on the bottom, walk on both platforms.   Decent piece of modern engineering as well.

Beauty is here. Omg, even the weather was not that great but the place this is heavenly. It has nice garden area nearby, some viewing point and the best part is train track and pedestrian is at the same time on the bridge. Obrigado!

The Luís I Bridge in Porto, Portugal, is an engineering marvel and an iconic symbol of the city. Spanning the Douro River, this magnificent double-deck iron bridge offers stunning panoramic views of Porto and Vila Nova de Gaia. The upper deck, primarily used for trains, provides breathtaking vistas of the river and the city’s historic center, while the lower deck, for vehicles and pedestrians, allows closer access to the riverside. Walking across the bridge, especially at sunset, is a truly unforgettable experience. It’s a must-see for anyone visiting Porto, showcasing both the city’s rich history and modern engineering.

The Luís I Bridge is an iconic masterpiece in Porto, offering breathtaking views of the Douro River and the city’s colorful architecture. Walking across the upper level is a must, especially at sunset, with a panoramic view that captures the magic of Porto. It’s not just a bridge, but a true symbol of the city’s charm and history. Highly recommended for anyone visiting Porto!

Great bridge. It is a great place to check out the food, wine, walk and a boat ride as well 😀. Two way roads where you can walk all the way across and can even try the rope way which will give you a wonderful scenery of Porto. Boat trips are frequent even and go both ways.

Name: Lake Baikal
short_description: Situated in south-east Siberia, the 3.15-million-ha Lake Baikal is the oldest (25 million years) and deepest (1,700 m) lake in the world. It contains 20% of the world's total unfrozen freshwater reserve. Known as the 'Galapagos of Russia', its age and isolation have produced one of the world's richest and most unusual freshwater faunas, which is of exceptional value to evolutionary science.

reviews.text:
Lake Baikal, the deepest lake in the world 🇷🇺

Lake Baikal is the largest freshwater lake in the world (by volume) and the world's deepest lake. Somewhat crescent shaped, it is in the southern Siberia area of Russia. It is also the oldest lake in the world. It is home to approximately 1,700 to 1,800 endemic plant and animal species🤍

We had a great day out on Lake Baikal and it is not just beautiful but has an astounding history as world’s deepest and oldest freshwater lake and amazingly contains about 20% of the world’s unfrozen fresh water. It is estimated to be around 25-30 million years old and home to thousands of species of plants and animals. We were told that it holds significant cultural and spiritual importance for the indigenous Buryat people.

The place you must go in your lifetime!! Lake Baikal - the deepest, largest, oldest lake in the world!! I joined the trip to this amazing place on 27/2/2024, enjoyed the spectacular view of blue cracked ice texture and even had lunch on the lake at -20 degrees Celsius, just so crazy but awesome! Every single moment in Lake Baikal is precious and memorable!

Lake Baikal, nestled in the heart of Siberia, is a natural wonder of unparalleled beauty and significance. As the deepest and oldest freshwater lake in the world, Baikal boasts a stunning array of superlatives that make it a must-visit destination for any nature enthusiast.

One of the most striking features of Lake Baikal is its crystal-clear waters, which offer unparalleled visibility and a surreal underwater landscape. This pristine environment is home to a unique ecosystem, including thousands of endemic species found nowhere else on Earth. From the enigmatic Baikal seal to the mesmerizingly transparent ice formations that adorn its surface during winter, the lake never fails to captivate visitors with its otherworldly charm.

Beyond its natural allure, Lake Baikal holds cultural and historical significance as well. It has been revered by the indigenous Buryat people for centuries, who consider it a sacred site imbued with spiritual energy. Moreover, the surrounding region is dotted with charming villages and historic landmarks that offer insight into the area's rich heritage.

However, Lake Baikal is not without its challenges. Despite its remote location, it faces threats from pollution, climate change, and unsustainable development. Efforts to preserve this natural treasure are crucial to ensure that future generations can continue to marvel at its beauty and wonder.

In conclusion, Lake Baikal is a breathtaking testament to the power and beauty of nature. Its pristine waters, unique ecosystem, and cultural significance make it a destination like no other. While facing challenges, it remains a beacon of hope for conservation efforts worldwide.

Lake Baikal is a rift lake located in southern Siberia, Russia, between the federal subjects of Irkutsk Oblast to the northwest and the Republic of Buryatia to the southeast. It is the deepest lake in the world, with a maximum depth of 1,642 meters (5,387 feet; 898 fathoms).
Lake Baikal is home to thousands of species of plants and animals, many of which are found nowhere else in the world. It is recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site for its unique natural beauty and biodiversity.
Lake Baikal contains 20% of the world's unfrozen freshwater reserve and is known for its exceptional clarity and purity.

Name: Volcanoes of Kamchatka
short_description: This is one of the most outstanding volcanic regions in the world, with a high density of active volcanoes, a variety of types, and a wide range of related features. The six sites included in the serial designation group together the majority of volcanic features of the Kamchatka peninsula. The interplay of active volcanoes and glaciers forms a dynamic landscape of great beauty. The sites contain great species diversity, including the world's largest known variety of salmonoid fish and exceptional concentrations of sea otter, brown bear and Stellar's sea eagle.

reviews.text:
There are a lot of active volcanoes in the area, lots of bears and bugs. Guides can be hired but it is more fun to sneak around…more dangerous too….Bears….
This volcano is constantly erupting, very difficult to get close to, but worth the trip. Quite a hike to get close to the lava flows. Snow is melted near them and then refrozen into ice….Makes for a fun hike. Stay upwind of the gas coming out of the ground, got a little light headed for a bit. Definitely pack enough gear for this trip and bring the stuff you don’t think you will need. Because you will not want to use any of your gear and there is nothing else around, bring a stick or piece of metal to play with the lava. Make your own unique lava souvenir.

Disappointing. Came expecting a nice view from the top but the sky was blackened for miles on an otherwise sunny day. Also it's difficult hiking here because of all the lava flows. Air quality is poor. I went through three umbrellas that were no use, they kept catching fire.

The highest (active) volcano of the Kamčatka Peninsula and of the entire Eurasian continent, its beautiful symmetrical cone, dominates the wild surrounding landscape.
If interested in making an ascent, watch out for flying lava blocks.

“This is how the planet’s fiery breath looks when the volcano wakes”, a local resident observed to me describing the blazing glow of Klyuchevskaya Sopka.  Considered the tallest active volcano in Eurasia, it is visible from more than 60 miles away.  Klyuchevskaya Sopka is located on Russia’s Kamchatka Peninsula, approximately 60 miles west of the Bering Sea, and towers nearly 16,000 feet at its peak.

While the views from the top were exceptional, and the mountain itself is a gorgeous feat for natural forces. My hoodie got singed by magmic expulsions from this earth pimple.

4/5, please visit with heavy titanium hoodies.

Name: Historic Walled Town of Cuenca
short_description: Built by the Moors in a defensive position at the heart of the Caliphate of Cordoba, Cuenca is an unusually well-preserved medieval fortified city. Conquered by the Castilians in the 12th century, it became a royal town and bishopric endowed with important buildings, such as Spain's first Gothic cathedral, and the famous casas colgadas (hanging houses), suspended from sheer cliffs overlooking the Huécar river. Taking full advantage of its location, the city towers above the magnificent countryside.

reviews.text: After Alfonso VIII of Castile conquered Cuenca, which was under Islamic rule in the 12th century, he built a defensive structure on a hill overlooking the old town of Cuenca. It featured a blend of Islamic and Christian architectural styles typical of medieval Spain. Most of the original building has been destroyed, leaving only the walls and a few defensive structures. Walking along the walls, visitors can enjoy panoramic views of the Huécar River and Casas Colgadas.

I wanted to get out of Madrid for one night and took the train to Cuenca. I was very surprised by the beautiful old town and the clubs with local people were great too. I can recommend taking the train or bus.

Can't really explain how beautiful this city is, and this place in particular it is breathtaking as you can really feel the old times while you walk nearby the castle. You can also park your car and there are bars and restaurants up here, in summer the temperature is below 30 degrees which helps. I would reccomend to come here in early morning.

What an amazing place to be.. I didn't know about this place when in my road to Madrid my girlfriend sawed on the map! From the moment you are visiting the old city you are going 2-3 century's back in time!
Beautiful and historical spot in Cuenca! Worth the climb and there are parkings and restaurants nearby the castle. Excellent views from the castle and surrounding areas.

Name: La Lonja de la Seda de Valencia
short_description: Built between 1482 and 1533, this group of buildings was originally used for trading in silk (hence its name, the Silk Exchange) and it has always been a centre for commerce. It is a masterpiece of late Gothic architecture. The grandiose Sala de Contratación (Contract or Trading Hall), in particular, illustrates the power and wealth of a major Mediterranean mercantile city in the 15th and 16th centuries.
formatted_address: C/ de la Llotja, 2, Ciutat Vella, 46001 València, Valencia, Spain

reviews.text: The place is nice, with a beautiful garden, price for tickets was decent and there was no waiting time. Honestly nothing bad to say about this place because everything was just OK. That's the whole point, just ok, not amazing, not outstanding, not so many things to see or to explore. Everything was fine but we don't consider this to be a 5 star attraction in Valencia because there is nothing that makes this place stand out from our point of view.

For an affordable entry free, you can visit a UNESCO World Heritage site for a glimpse into Valencia’s past. The main hall, with its stunning twisted columns, is undeniably impressive, and the building’s historical significance adds to its charm. While the experience is fairly brief and there’s not much else to explore inside, it’s still a worthwhile stop in the city

La Lonja de la Seda de Valencia is an absolute gem in the heart of Valencia! This UNESCO World Heritage site is a must-visit for anyone interested in history, architecture, or simply breathtaking sights. The Gothic-style building, with its intricate carvings and soaring columns, is a true testament to Valencia’s rich past as a major trading hub.

Walking through the grand Contract Hall, you can almost feel the history of merchants negotiating deals centuries ago. The twisted columns and vaulted ceilings are simply stunning! The Patio de los Naranjos, with its peaceful courtyard and fragrant orange trees, adds to the charm and offers a lovely spot to relax.

The attention to detail in the architecture is mesmerizing, and the entrance fee is very reasonable for such a well-preserved historical site. Whether you’re a history buff or just looking for a beautiful place to explore, La Lonja de la Seda is an absolute must-see in Valencia!
Stunning and quiet at the same time. Do not miss! The entrance fee is only 2 euros!  One of the best monuments in the city.

Arguably the most beautiful site in Valencia. The color contrast between the orange and pale building was gorgeous though the weather is still cold right now. The trading hall is one of the most impressive architectures I've seen.

Name: Church Town of Gammelstad, Luleå
short_description: Gammelstad, at the head of the Gulf of Bothnia, is the best-preserved example of a 'church village', a unique kind of village formerly found throughout northern Scandinavia. The 424 wooden houses, huddled round the early 15th-century stone church, were used only on Sundays and at religious festivals to house worshippers from the surrounding countryside who could not return home the same day because of the distance and difficult travelling conditions.

reviews.text:
UNESCO site for a good reason!  The story behind church towns is something I’d never heard of before. These small cabins were built to use as a place to stay for people from farms too far away to drive to church and back in one day. Compulsory church attendance was the law in Sweden. Today they are still privately owned and people still use them to attend church it have family get together.
The museum explains it all and has great displays and even since film footage from the 1920’s since they were used into the 1950’s for their original purpose. Very cool place!

A must-see when in Luleå. So much history.
I was here at 08:30 hrs on a cold February morning and had the place to myself!

Gammelstad Church Town in Luleå, Sweden, is a wonderful place to visit. The old wooden houses and the beautiful 15th-century church are very interesting. Walking around the village feels like going back in time. It's a great spot for anyone who likes history and old buildings. Highly recommended!

Lulea old town is a must for families visiting Lulea.
The streets are stunning and there is an open air museum with fun activities for the kids.
We had Fika in a nearby small shopping centre before finding the centre of the old town about 1 km away.
We had a great time.
Worth a quick visit to view the wooden houses and stroll around the church if you happen to be in the area.

Name: Laponian Area
short_description: The Arctic Circle region of northern Sweden is the home of the Saami people. It is the largest area in the world (and one of the last) with an ancestral way of life based on the seasonal movement of livestock. Every summer, the Saami lead their huge herds of reindeer towards the mountains through a natural landscape hitherto preserved, but now threatened by the advent of motor vehicles. Historical and ongoing geological processes can be seen in the glacial moraines and changing water courses.

reviews.text:
One of the best places I visited in Sweden.
Very nice exhibition! It's small but if you want you can stay there for hours and read about many interesting things about Sweden, the nature and the culture of the Sami. Absolutely worth a visit!

You can also take a break and drink some coffee or take a nice waffle.

The building and the information exhibit are good but what made it exceptional was the kind and helpful staff. They have good information about hikes and other things to do in the area. You can rent a city bike for free (as long as you return it the same day).

The food was great, they have vegan options available!

Great view from their restaurant! I visited winter time and we were the first visitor that day, the staff - Amanda, was really the warmest person :) she gave us a tour of the place and was really accommodating and helpful in every possible way. Their coffee and food is also good and I would recommended having a stopover here if you’re in the area, you‘ll learn about the falls that fell silent, the sami culture and their 8 seasons, the nature parks and reserve and so much more!

We always love a trip here! We visited with our lively 1 and 3 year old and they came up with engaging games that were nature based and fun. We had a really good lunch of open sandwiches and waffles which were both great. Thank you for chatting and letting our children run around. We'll see you later in the season 😊

The staff is very very friendly and gives you good information for the area. The building has a incredible location! Also the architecture is awesome. You have to take off your shoes when you enter and you get some houseshoes there
They also offer free bike-rental 10-18

Name: W-Arly-Pendjari Complex
short_description: This transnational extension (Benin, Burkina Faso) to the W National Park of Niger, inscribed in 1996 on the World Heritage List, cover a major expanse of intact Sudano-Sahelian savannah, with vegetation types including grasslands, shrub lands, wooded savannah and extensive gallery forests. It includes the largest and most important continuum of terrestrial, semi-aquatic and aquatic ecosystems in the West African savannah belt. The property is a refuge for wildlife species that have disappeared elsewhere in West Africa or are highly threatened. It is home to the largest population of elephants in West Africa and most of the large mammals typical of the region, such as the African Manatee, cheetah, lion and leopard. It also harbours the only viable population of lions in the region.

reviews.text: If you are in Benin, surely worth visiting. Very experienced and friendly guides, affordable prices, high chances of visiting many kinds of animals and birds.

Pendjari National Park is located in the northwestern part of Benin. It covers an area of 480,000 hectares, There are wild animals such as the lion, buffalo, elephant, exotic birds, hippopotamus, warthog and many other wild animals. The site offers wilderness camping, tours, accommodation and other unique experiences for tourists. All you have to do is take a look around and you will be able to experience the wonders of nature.

Pendjari National Park 🇧🇯

Pendjari National Park is a national park located in Benin, West Africa. It is known for its diverse wildlife and beautiful landscapes. The park covers an area of approximately 4,800 square kilometers and is home to a variety of species, including elephants, lions, cheetahs, hippos, and various types of antelope.

Pendjari National Park is part of the larger W-Arly-Pendjari complex, which spans three countries: Benin, Burkina Faso, and Niger. The park is known for its efforts in conservation and protection of wildlife, particularly the West African lion population.

Visitors to Pendjari National Park can enjoy wildlife safaris, birdwatching, and guided tours to see the diverse flora and fauna of the region. The park offers a unique opportunity to experience the beauty of nature and observe animals in their natural habitat.
I'm a safari guide inside i like it as if it was my second home
Nice😊

Name: Heard and McDonald Islands
short_description: Heard Island and McDonald Islands are located in the Southern Ocean, approximately 1,700 km from the Antarctic continent and 4,100 km south-west of Perth. As the only volcanically active subantarctic islands they ‘open a window into the earth’, thus providing the opportunity to observe ongoing geomorphic processes and glacial dynamics. The distinctive conservation value of Heard and McDonald – one of the world’s rare pristine island ecosystems – lies in the complete absence of alien plants and animals, as well as human impact.

Name: Macquarie Island
short_description: Macquarie Island (34 km long x 5 km wide) is an oceanic island in the Southern Ocean, lying 1,500 km south-east of Tasmania and approximately halfway between Australia and the Antarctic continent. The island is the exposed crest of the undersea Macquarie Ridge, raised to its present position where the Indo-Australian tectonic plate meets the Pacific plate. It is a site of major geoconservation significance, being the only place on earth where rocks from the earth’s mantle (6 km below the ocean floor) are being actively exposed above sea-level. These unique exposures include excellent examples of pillow basalts and other extrusive rocks.

reviews.text: Spent a year at Macca and can thoroughly recommend the place - wildlife over summer is amazing. Cruise ships do short stops there over summer. Best way to stay there is as an employee of Australian Antarctic Program or Tasmania Parks

Good holiday destination would recommend, took the wife and two kids they loved the scenic views
Penguin for dinner was a nice addition definitely returning!
God’s creation is Amazing 🤩 and Marvelous to our eyes.
No trees, just tussock grass and lots of seals and penguins. Fantastic place..
The animals were unkind and lazy. They refused to pose for pictures, but just laid there doing nothing. The elephant seals need to get a job and fast.

Name: Hallstatt-Dachstein / Salzkammergut Cultural Landscape
short_description: Human activity in the magnificent natural landscape of the Salzkammergut began in prehistoric times, with the salt deposits being exploited as early as the 2nd millennium BC. This resource formed the basis of the area’s prosperity up to the middle of the 20th century, a prosperity that is reflected in the fine architecture of the town of Hallstatt.

reviews.text: Center(market square) of the marvelously beautiful town Hallstatt. There were lots of tourists and some were really annoying, please be respectful, some people live there. The natural beauty is unmatched. Also there are nice cafes and restaurants too, but most of the things are expensive.

Hallstatt is absolutely beautiful and a must-visit! While it can be very touristy during the day, it becomes incredibly peaceful after 7 p.m. when most places close. If you're looking to take stunning photos, I recommend getting there as early as 7 a.m. to avoid the crowds and capture the serene beauty of the village.

Hallstatt is one of the best places I’ve ever gone on earth.
It’s like a heaven and I can not believe how beautiful it was.
You have to experience it by yourself

This is such a beautiful township to visit. It’s part of the Hallstatt attractions.

As we walking through the town, we stopped by various markets, bake shops, salt shop, ice cream stands, gift shops, while admiring the unique architectures, colorful and floral residential houses, and gorgeous water and mountain views.

Yes, there were a lot of tourists here, the roads are crowded, and we were told of the stories that most of the locals don’t real care for the tourists to be here so we need to be extra polite when not communicating with businesses owners.

This is a must to visit when you are in Hallstatt!

One of the most scenic places ever. Heard it was one of the inspirations for the townhall in the animated movie 'Frozen'. Ideal for fresh fish meals as well as the visit to the Salt Mine. The latter is a MUST GO!

Name: The Sundarbans
short_description: The Sundarbans mangrove forest, one of the largest such forests in the world (140,000 ha), lies on the delta of the Ganges, Brahmaputra and Meghna rivers on the Bay of Bengal. It is adjacent to the border of India’s Sundarbans World Heritage site inscribed in 1987. The site is intersected by a complex network of tidal waterways, mudflats and small islands of salt-tolerant mangrove forests, and presents an excellent example of ongoing ecological processes. The area is known for its wide range of fauna, including 260 bird species, the Bengal tiger and other threatened species such as the estuarine crocodile and the Indian python.

reviews.text: The Sundarbans, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, offer a mesmerizing blend of nature's beauty and mystery. With its lush mangrove forests, winding waterways, and diverse wildlife, including the Bengal tiger, it’s a haven for nature lovers and adventurers alike. The serene landscapes, vibrant ecosystems, and peaceful isolation make it a unique and enchanting destination.

The sundarban is one of the largest mangrove forest in the world. The beauty is to much attractive. It’s a combo package of happiness. Amazing experience with nature. The sundarban is globally famous for its rich biodiversity. It is home to approximately 400 species of animal, birds, fish, invertebrates and thousands of plant species.

The Sundarbans is a breathtaking natural wonder and a must-visit destination in Bangladesh! 🌿🌊 As the largest mangrove forest in the world and home to the majestic Royal Bengal Tiger 🐅, it offers an incredible experience for nature lovers and adventure seekers.

The peaceful rivers, dense greenery, and diverse wildlife create a truly magical atmosphere. 🦜🐊 Whether you're cruising through the winding waterways, spotting rare animals, or simply enjoying the serenity of nature, the Sundarbans never fails to amaze. The fresh air, scenic beauty, and thrilling wildlife make it a perfect escape from city life. Highly recommended for anyone looking to explore Bangladesh’s natural beauty! 🌍💚

Sundarban Is just too tooo toooo muchhh beautiful,while going through the river the feeling I felt was devineeee. It was so beautiful in itself,even if you don't see any animals you'll still say that your trip was amazing.maybe because it was my first time but I felt awesomeeee,like truly awesome. But one thing I'll say,if you are going to sundarban to see tiger or deer then I'll tell you to decrease your expectations. In my trip I saw some birds and manyy jellyfishes and nothing more. But still the experience wass awesome for me, the forest was beauty itself. I'll remember those scenes my  entire life.

A beautiful World Heritage site that is home to many diverse plants and wildlife and vital to our environment. I visited it in Bangladesh through a boat tour that goes through the Bangladesh Forest Department and was a truly amazing experience.

Name: Historic Centre of São Luís
short_description: The late 17th-century core of this historic town, founded by the French and occupied by the Dutch before coming under Portuguese rule, has preserved the original rectangular street plan in its entirety. Thanks to a period of economic stagnation in the early 20th century, an exceptional number of fine historic buildings have survived, making this an outstanding example of an Iberian colonial town.
formatted_address: R. João Vital, 36-48 - Centro, São Luís - MA, 65010-320, Brazil

reviews.text: The historica center gets better restored and more beautiful every time I come here. A magnificent place to wander around and enjoy the beauty of all these different ancient houses, streets, narrow alley’s and cobble stones.
Most historical place of Sao Luis. Old fasihon and colourfull buldings. Main Street has many local stores. There are not so much restaurant , bars or coffiee shops. Mostly local stores.
Buildings and streets are well preserved. Lots of cafe or resto. You can also buy souvenirs. Theres a lot of store there.
Take a walk during the day to see the colonial houses - even of not all of them are un good shape - and come back in the evening as you can run into nice cultural events.
Top

Name: Old Town of Lijiang
short_description: The Old Town of Lijiang, which is perfectly adapted to the uneven topography of this key commercial and strategic site, has retained a historic townscape of high quality and authenticity. Its architecture is noteworthy for the blending of elements from several cultures that have come together over many centuries. Lijiang also possesses an ancient water-supply system of great complexity and ingenuity that still functions effectively today.
formatted_address: V6CP+P8H, Gucheng District, Lijiang, Yunnan, China, 674100

reviews.text:
Huge, pretty, historical, and architecture is just amazing! Super great vibes as well, so lively and happening at night! Took three days to explore the whole area by foot properly. Love this place so much! Views from the top are amazing. So much good food to eat, and sights to explore. 😍

Particularly LOVE taking pics with the tribal costumes! The ladies here are so amazing with their hair and make up skills, transforming me to an ancient princess in an instant hahaha. Had loads of fun and would say this is the main highlight of my Yunnan trip! 🥰👍😊🥰

We enjoyed the vibes here in the Old Town, especially at night. Lots of shoppings and restaurants at the fringe of the old town. Also nice to take photos here with the Jade Dragon Snow Mountain.  A short walk is the Black Dragon Pool, a great spot to take the snow mountain during sunrise

Huge old vibrant ancient city. We stayed within vicinity which made our exploration easy. Do try out flower biscuits as you spent time there, it's quite unique to our taste buds. Do go up to Wenchang Palace if you would like to have a spectacular overview of the city

A particularly nice place to visit at night, this ancient city offers a great mix of local cultures and modern nightlife. Feel free to explore and settle for a cup of locally produced tea before heading towards the bars and clubs for a night of debauchery.

The place also features great retail and F&B options that’s bound to keep your wallets empty and your stomachs filled!

We stayed at the South Gate (Nan Men) and went to 4 different Qing Zhen / Muslim friendly restaurants in the area. During the night, it was lovely and can be pleasantly quiet off the main streets, with some people having night photography sessions. The old palace of Mufu was relatively peaceful too and a good vantage point for views of the town, without climbing all the way up Lion Hill which charges a fee. Bought flower cakes and a fruit wine, all good.

Name: Ancient City of Ping Yao
short_description: Ping Yao is an exceptionally well-preserved example of a traditional Han Chinese city, founded in the 14th century. Its urban fabric shows the evolution of architectural styles and town planning in Imperial China over five centuries. Of special interest are the imposing buildings associated with banking, for which Ping Yao was the major centre for the whole of China in the 19th and early 20th centuries.

Name: Classical Gardens of Suzhou
short_description: Classical Chinese garden design, which seeks to recreate natural landscapes in miniature, is nowhere better illustrated than in the nine gardens in the historic city of Suzhou. They are generally acknowledged to be masterpieces of the genre. Dating from the 11th-19th century, the gardens reflect the profound metaphysical importance of natural beauty in Chinese culture in their meticulous design.
formatted_address: 178 Dong Bei Jie, Gu Su Qu, Su Zhou Shi, Jiang Su Sheng, China, 215004

reviews.text: The Classical Gardens of Suzhou are a group of gardens in the city of Suzhou, in Jiangsu, China, which have been included in the UNESCO World Heritage List. A peaceful place to spend a few hours admiring the classical Chinese architecture of different structures and the abundant covered walkways. Wonderful tour here in Nanjing, China.

I'm sure if you were here at a quiet time, it would be lovely. But since it is one of the most famous places in China for Chinese people, the odds of you being here at a quiet time are slim to none. Expect massive crowds and long queues to just get to specific famous spots for pictures. I found this place extremely frustrating. And I was here on a Monday, not even a weekend or public holiday.

I love Suzhou because the city is beautiful, the city's canals, stone bridges, pagoda and beautiful gardens. Suzhou is like the Venice of China.

Take the gondola, sailing through a narrow waterway and passing stone bridges. Walking around the canals also is my favorite thing to do.

There are so many lovely and beautiful cafes, bookstores, and souvenir shops. All so artistic and pretty. Feel like step back in time.

Suzhou is also one of the top tourist destinations, so it's not easy to take pictures at the certain landmark and popular sites due to overcrowded.

The Classical Garden of Suzhou we're added to the list of UNESCO World Heritage Sites in 1997.

How to get here :I took the high-speed train from Hangqiao Railway station in Shangai, which only took around 30 minutes to reach Suzhou. Alternatively take a coach from West Bus Station, will takes nearly 2 hours.
Beautiful, serene, green gardens. A great attraction in Suzhou.

It was so beautiful there
Lovely place
Must visite

Name: Cocos Island National Park
short_description: Cocos Island National Park, located 550 km off the Pacific coast of Costa Rica, is the only island in the tropical eastern Pacific with a tropical rainforest. Its position as the first point of contact with the northern equatorial counter-current, and the myriad interactions between the island and the surrounding marine ecosystem, make the area an ideal laboratory for the study of biological processes. The underwater world of the national park has become famous due to the attraction it holds for divers, who rate it as one of the best places in the world to view large pelagic species such as sharks, rays, tuna and dolphins.
formatted_address: Cocos Island, Puntarenas Province, Puntarenas, Costa Rica

reviews.text: The island is beautiful and well preserved. The Rangers ensure the protection of the site. It is possible to go ashore with a permit. You should not hesitate. The island is full of waterfalls. You can also see wild pigs.
Wonderful place.  Only park rangers live on island and rotate out once a month.  It is a 36 hr boat ride to the island
My anniversary with Coco's Island 2013-2023

Great spot for diving and wildlife watching.  My son found some cool old coins with crosses on them while wandering in a beach cave underneath a rock overhang that kind of looks like a human face. Great vacation yall.

If you look closely off the coast of the island you shall see a large Underwater Ancient City, with a big Gorilla or Monkey Head structure below and more structures surrounding it, including giant walls, we discovered this a few years ago while talking about treasure.

Derek Kesek
Founder at Hempearth Group

Name: Episcopal Complex of the Euphrasian Basilica in the Historic Centre of Poreč
short_description: The group of religious monuments in Porec, where Christianity was established as early as the 4th century, constitutes the most complete surviving complex of its type. The basilica, atrium, baptistery and episcopal palace are outstanding examples of religious architecture, while the basilica itself combines classical and Byzantine elements in an exceptional manner.

reviews.text: Very beautiful entrance. I’m sure it’s wonderful to visit inside, but the prices are really out of reality, as everything in Croatia…

Very impressive medieval basilica
Excellent visit as you access first various secondary buildings, tower and museum before to reach the incredible mosaic
A must visit for historical lovers
Beatiful and very interesting early Christian basilica and episcopal palace.

Interesting but not outstanding.
Properly done though.
Nice

Name: Historic City of Trogir
short_description: Trogir is a remarkable example of urban continuity. The orthogonal street plan of this island settlement dates back to the Hellenistic period and it was embellished by successive rulers with many fine public and domestic buildings and fortifications. Its beautiful Romanesque churches are complemented by the outstanding Renaissance and Baroque buildings from the Venetian period.

reviews.text: Trogir is one of the most beautiful places in the world, featuring a breathtaking old town filled with narrow streets and historic landmarks. I highly recommend visiting the market on the eastern side of the old town, where you can immerse yourself in the local culture and buy fresh produce. Afterward, enjoy a morning coffee at one of the charming cafes with a stunning view of the sea. It's the perfect way to start your day and soak in the beauty of this enchanting destination.

One of the cutest places in Croatia. Very small, so you won’t need to walk for a long time but you will see a lot of beautiful spots and try very good food. ❤️ Even in November it was just exceptional!
This small town is really nice. We came here while we were island hopping. It's very beautiful and old. You could easily spend 2 hours here. There's also a local market here.
A very unique and beautiful old town, it really stunned me! It really has those old cobblestone narrow streets that you see in photos online, walking around is simply magical.

Beautiful small island with plenty of narrow cobbled alleyways to explore. Most places seem to be cash only. The bus station is just on the mainland and the water taxi to split is just beyond the small island of Trogir with the more modern buildings. Good views from the top of the central bell tower

Name: San Pedro de la Roca Castle, Santiago de Cuba
short_description: Commercial and political rivalries in the Caribbean region in the 17th century resulted in the construction of this massive series of fortifications on a rocky promontory, built to protect the important port of Santiago. This intricate complex of forts, magazines, bastions and batteries is the most complete, best-preserved example of Spanish-American military architecture, based on Italian and Renaissance design principles.

reviews.text: A definite must visit if you go to Santiago de Cuba(This fort is a UNESCO world heritage site for a reason). It's one of the largest forts I have been to in the Caribbean with many levels, stunning views of the Caribbean, and generally a lot to see. You can actually climb all the way down to the sea ( don't do this in the middle of the day because it's super hot here). I would recommend bringing water as their isn't much shade and it can get super hot.
Beautifully restored castle with excellent views of the Caribbean, just 100 cup entry, parking close-by and some souvenir stalls through downtown souvenirs are cheaper.

Beautiful but extremely hot! The whole place is actually quite Big but the exposition inside is unfortunately not impressive! Also choose wisely when you wanna go there cause the afternoon in the summer is not possible or you gonna feel like a meat on a frying pan! Good advice take a Big bottle of water and a hat with you! Beside that it’s a great spot for a photo with a marvellous and literally panoramic view! A bit beneath the main entrance you gonna find a lovely restaurant with as well a spectacular view and some gift shops and a picturesque Light House.

Never enough time to see the whole place!.  This location has much to see, I would suggest to have your own way there. Cause tours do not give your enough time there for a person to see all interesting levels it has. I found it very clean and well organized. One will need to pay 5cuc to take pictures.
Wonderfully restored and maintained. This is a good example of the theory of self defense in the era that it was built. Donald Trump is still trying the same approach with his stupid wall.

Name: Morne Trois Pitons National Park
short_description: Luxuriant natural tropical forest blends with scenic volcanic features of great scientific interest in this national park centred on the 1,342-m-high volcano known as Morne Trois Pitons. With its precipitous slopes and deeply incised valleys, 50 fumaroles, hot springs, three freshwater lakes, a 'boiling lake' and five volcanoes, located on the park's nearly 7,000 ha, together with the richest biodiversity in the Lesser Antilles, Morne Trois Pitons National Park presents a rare combination of natural features of World Heritage value.

reviews.text:
Still one of the best hikes.  It's pretty challenging but equally rewarding to be at one with so much nature.  With determination, almost anyone can make this walk despite their level of fitness.

And then the swim up the titou gorge is a must after that walk.
Amazing!!  There is some rough terrain but so worth the hike. We had a 10 hour day hiking and it was unforgettable! Prepare to be hot & wet! Must put this on your TO DO list while in Dominica!

Morne Trois Pitons was the first national park to be established in Dominica (in 1975). In 1997 it became a UNESCO World Heritage Site. At an elevation of 762 meters, Freshwater Lake in the park is the largest lake on Dominica and the source of the Roseau River. The lake sits in an old volcanic crater at the foot of Morne Macaque.
This place was absolutely stunning. One of the most beautiful things I’ve ever experienced. The guides were awesome. Definitely a bucket list adventure for everyone.

Incredible place, feels like you’re on an episode of National Geographic. I explored with tour guide Peter Green and he was amazing! Find him on Facebook at Peter Green Bushman Tours or get his info at the Discover Dominica office in Roseau.

Name: Historic Centre (Old Town) of Tallinn
short_description: The origins of Tallinn date back to the 13th century, when a castle was built there by the crusading knights of the Teutonic Order. It developed as a major centre of the Hanseatic League, and its wealth is demonstrated by the opulence of the public buildings (the churches in particular) and the domestic architecture of the merchants' houses, which have survived to a remarkable degree despite the ravages of fire and war in the intervening centuries.

reviews.text: The dragons on the walls are incredibly cute, and the architecture will remind you of Disney’s How to Train Your Dragon. Tallinn is a little slice of paradise on Earth — smaller than other Nordic capitals, but so much more welcoming and charming.
Famous Christmas Market at Tallinn Old Town featuring cultural foods, crafts and concerts. Cultural place either winter or summer. Loved visiting it.

Tallinn Town Hall is an impressive medieval building that dominates the Old Town Square. Its Gothic architecture and tall spire make it one of the standout landmarks in the city. Even though we didn’t go inside, the exterior alone is worth seeing, with its intricate details and historical significance. The Town Hall adds a lot of charm to the square, and it’s a must-see when visiting Tallinn’s Old Town.

Tallinn Town Hall is a stunning example of Gothic architecture and a standout landmark in the heart of Tallinn’s Old Town. Built in the early 1400s, it’s the only preserved Gothic-style town hall in Northern Europe, making it a must-see for architecture lovers and history enthusiasts alike. The building’s facade, intricate details, and distinctive dragon-shaped waterspouts give it an iconic medieval charm that fits perfectly with Tallinn’s UNESCO-listed Old Town.
This is not a town hall for civic business.   It's an old town center from approximately the 13th or 14th century.   It's very fascinating to visit.  We've been there twice the last 3 years.

Name: Historic Fortified City of Carcassonne
short_description: Since the pre-Roman period, a fortified settlement has existed on the hill where Carcassonne now stands. In its present form it is an outstanding example of a medieval fortified town, with its massive defences encircling the castle and the surrounding buildings, its streets and its fine Gothic cathedral. Carcassonne is also of exceptional importance because of the lengthy restoration campaign undertaken by Viollet-le-Duc, one of the founders of the modern science of conservation.
formatted_address: 1 Rue Viollet le Duc, 11000 Carcassonne, France

reviews.text:
Fantastic castle with an exciting history!
We visited on a sunny morning in early February. There weren’t many people around, so it felt like we had the place to ourselves. I can imagine it gets quite crowded during peak season. I recommend paying €16 to enter the castle and walk along the wall

Pictures don’t give it justice! You must see yourself because it is magnificent. There is no fee to enter. Tons of shops and restaurants throughout. Best place to purchase a ticket for a self tour of the castle are at the information center. They will provide you with a map to get to the castle tour and throughout the city walls!

Carcassonne Castle is a prime example of medieval European fortresses and is recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage site, gaining international acclaim. It not only frequently competes with France's other famous landmark, Mont Saint-Michel, for the title of the most visited French attraction, but it has also become an inspiration for many creators, including the famous German board game Carcassonne and the popular Japanese anime Attack on Titan.

Carcassonne is situated on a hill far from the city center, and from a distance, its distinctive towering city walls can be seen standing tall on the hill, creating an intimidating sense of awe. However, once you pass through the two high city walls, you are greeted by an unassuming, quaint medieval town. Life within the high walls feels surprisingly ordinary and almost imperceptible—only those guarding the walls or those outside truly realize the fortress's towering, inaccessible presence.

Today, Carcassonne has two main entrances. One is better preserved and features a statue of Dame Carcassonne, offering a clear view of the castle’s double-layered wall structure. This entrance is also the most common one for tourists to enter the town. However, I personally recommend the entrance hidden at the back of the castle. Although the road here is more damaged and rugged, I feel it offers the most beautiful view of the castle and will undoubtedly satisfy the medieval knight spirit that lies deep within us all.

Beautiful Medieval city, located about 30min walk from train station. Amazing architecture well worth a visit! One piece of advice, get a tour guide and you will be amazed of the history of this place

Well, what can I say. This castle is truly impressive on another level. It's possibly one of the most impressive castles I've ever visited, and I've visited 100's, although mostly due to its vastness/size more than anything, but then isn't that what castles are mostly about?

You can actually see so much of this castle for free which is always great but the €13 ticket to see the rest is so worth it, especially if you've got the energy to walk the whole perimeter of the castle walls. Be sure to give yourself plenty of time to see it all properly, maybe even up to 2 hours. If I was a Kid (perhaps I still am?) I would truly love this part.

Great for dogs in all the free access areas as well.

Jan 16th 2025

Name: 18th-Century Royal Palace at Caserta with the Park, the Aqueduct of Vanvitelli, and the San Leucio Complex
short_description: The monumental complex at Caserta, created by the Bourbon king Charles III in the mid-18th century to rival Versailles and the Royal Palace in Madrid, is exceptional for the way in which it brings together a magnificent palace with its park and gardens, as well as natural woodland, hunting lodges and a silk factory. It is an eloquent expression of the Enlightenment in material form, integrated into, rather than imposed on, its natural setting.
formatted_address: Piazza Carlo di Borbone, 81100 Caserta CE, Italy

reviews.text: One of the most impressive royal palaces I have ever seen, and rightfully deserving to be included in the UNESCO World Heritage sites. The grand staircase, the court theatre and the throne room are among the most striking of all the palace, in addition to the stunning Nativity scenes. The palace can be easily reached by train from Naples' central station, and the entrance costs 12 euros. Highly recommended.

The palace is HUGE!!

The gardens are beautiful and worth long walk through, imagining the events that took place in them many many years ago!

The palace architecture and exhibits are wonderful and enjoyable, although I could do without the modern art randomly strewn throughout, along side priceless classics?!

The Palace of Caserta is stunning inside, but the overall experience was extremely disappointing. First, hardly anyone speaks English, and the lack of information is frustrating. The staff were rude when we asked for help, and important details about the site were poorly communicated.

For example, there’s a section with modern art and a theater you can visit—but only if you happen to know they exist. The theater was closed for hours in the middle of the day because the staff member was apparently needed elsewhere in the gardens. This was not communicated anywhere except at the theater itself, making it impossible to plan our visit around it. We loved saving this highlight for the end of our tour. But as a result, we completely missed it.

Parts of the garden were also closed off with no prior notice, so you can’t adjust your route accordingly, which meant we walked unnecessary kilometers. When we finally decided to take the shuttle bus back to the entrance, the non-English-speaking driver gestured for us to sit down but never mentioned it was a paid service. At the entrance, he escorted us to an payment desk and made us buy a return ticket just for the one-way ride we had already taken.

While the palace itself is breathtaking, the disorganization, lack of clear communication, and unhelpful staff made this a very bad experience overall.

Nice place to visit. The two main attractions would be the apartments (stately home) and the park. You can get a combination ticket for both or separate tickets but please note that the park has late entry rules; 2:30pm. We asked for tickets for the park but were sold one for the apartments. The apartments are nice and has some modern exhibits as well. Huge place. If you like renaissance art then this would be a place for you. I think children might find it a bit too boring though!
The park on the otherhand is pretty decent. I have reviewed this separately.
Bought tickets on site; more cost effective.

This absolutely gorgeous palace is worth the effort to visit. I had never heard of it until stumbling upon it through some research related to famous movie locations. It is a hidden gem! Where is the marketing? The public needs to know about it. It is apparent that the facilities are in some need of maintenance and repair, and I'm sure the funds brought in by some good campaigns would make this a sustainable endeavor. It is a treasure that beautifully represents an integral part of Italy's history and is worth preserving.

Name: Residences of the Royal House of Savoy
short_description: When Emmanuel-Philibert, Duke of Savoy, moved his capital to Turin in 1562, he began a vast series of building projects (continued by his successors) to demonstrate the power of the ruling house. This outstanding complex of buildings, designed and embellished by the leading architects and artists of the time, radiates out into the surrounding countryside from the Royal Palace in the 'Command Area' of Turin to include many country residences and hunting lodges.
formatted_address: Via Eros da Ros, 8, 16167 Genova GE, Italy

reviews.text: What a wonderful place! The sea view was very beautiful, the residence was clean, comfortable and perfectly placed near to the sea and the town. The staff are very welcoming and helpful. Highly recommended.
