Ruined furniture, no duvet, noisy heating system not working well in the bedroom. Dirty kitchen and dead insects stuck in pictures (living room). Unfriendly manager.
Website very misleading.
Great relaxation place just a few metres from the costal parade
Beautiful view
Great!

Name: Botanical Garden (Orto Botanico), Padua
short_description: The world's first botanical garden was created in Padua in 1545. It still preserves its original layout – a circular central plot, symbolizing the world, surrounded by a ring of water. Other elements were added later, some architectural (ornamental entrances and balustrades) and some practical (pumping installations and greenhouses). It continues to serve its original purpose as a centre for scientific research.
formatted_address: Via Orto Botanico, 15, 35123 Padova PD, Italy

reviews.text:
I may have not been here during the bloom of most plants, but the ones that are here are amazing, the displays are entertaining and interactive, perfect to get a sandwich out and appreciating the views or picking up a sketchbook and doodle away. Free for students from the university and perfect for multiple occasions. Everything is nice and up-kept.
As a Mexican watching an agave live and from my home was beautiful, but I could feel it’s not on the best conditions, maybe in future visits it will cheer her up seen more Mexicans like me.
University of Padua Botanical Garden is really worth a visit. It is located in the center of town and it has a beautiful old style setting, but also a new and advanced building.

Orto Botanico di Padova – The Oldest Botanical Garden in the World

The Orto Botanico di Padova is not just a beautiful garden—it’s a living piece of history. Founded in 1545, it is the world’s oldest university botanical garden and has been a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1997. Originally established for medical students at the University of Padua, it played a key role in the study of medicinal plants and the development of modern botany.

The gardens are open Tuesday to Sunday from 10:00 AM to 6:00 PM (closed Mondays). Tickets cost 10€ for adults and 5€ for students.

What makes this garden truly special is its original Renaissance design, which remains intact. The circular layout, symbolizing the world, is divided into geometric sections filled with rare and exotic plants. One of its most famous residents is Goethe’s Palm, planted in 1585, which inspired the German writer Johann Wolfgang von Goethe’s studies on plant evolution.

In addition to its historical charm, the modern Biodiversity Garden showcases plants from all climate zones, housed in state-of-the-art glasshouses. The mix of ancient botanical heritage and innovative conservation efforts makes this garden one of the most unique in the world.

A must-visit for plant lovers, history enthusiasts, and anyone looking for a peaceful retreat in Padua. Absolutely worth it – 5/5!

A really different botanical garden experience. It is a historic garden that is built upon its early foundation as a place to study botany and its use in medicine, etc. not too big and very accessible and well looked after. It has a palm that was planted in 1500’s and many other old and new trees, shrubs, herbs, flowers and water plants. A relaxing afternoon.

Paid 10 euro per person, the garden was shallow, tickets expensive for what they offers, the most interesting part, the green house was closed for refurbishment still the ticket price was unchanged. No bar or restaurant inside to buy refreshments, no even  selling machines, just a sad art gallery and an empty depressing terrace. So disappointed.
We usually love visite botanical gardens whatever we travels but this one was absolutely shamble for the price we paid.
An example? Edinburgh Botanic Garden is free, marvellous, full of beautiful blooming plants every time of the year, with bars, restaurants inside and shops with plants and souvenir. Padova orto botanic never again. Plants in my home are kept better.

Name: Portovenere, Cinque Terre, and the Islands (Palmaria, Tino and Tinetto)
short_description: The Ligurian coast between Cinque Terre and Portovenere is a cultural landscape of great scenic and cultural value. The layout and disposition of the small towns and the shaping of the surrounding landscape, overcoming the disadvantages of a steep, uneven terrain, encapsulate the continuous history of human settlement in this region over the past millennium.

reviews.text: Stunning, unexpected, and historically important!
Kayak around the islands of Palmaria, Tino and Tinetto
The smallest of the three islands of the La Spezia archipelago. Little more than a rock but very suggestive as it is uncontaminated.

A dream place to enjoy the sea and the true tranquility of nature, especially in the period from the end of August to the beginning of June when there is no massive presence of pleasure boats and the passage of tourist boats.
On this islet, among other things, there is what remains of the first two-nave church built in Liguria dating back to around the 5th century. Unfortunately, these remains are in a complete state of abandonment, victims of bad weather and the wear and tear of time.
She's beautiful. Crystal clear water and peace. You can visit it for the feast of San Venerio (I think around September 13th)

Name: Cathedral, Torre Civica and Piazza Grande, Modena
short_description: The magnificent 12th-century cathedral at Modena, the work of two great artists (Lanfranco and Wiligelmus), is a supreme example of early Romanesque art. With its piazza and soaring tower, it testifies to the faith of its builders and the power of the Canossa dynasty who commissioned it.

reviews.text: The Modena Cathedral is a breathtaking Gothic landmark and a true symbol of the city. Its towering presence and intricate details make a lasting impression. Stepping inside, you immediately feel the weight of history in the dimly lit, atmospheric interior. The beautifully sculpted decorations and grand arches add to its majesty, while the adjacent Ghirlandina Tower completes the stunning scene. Whether you love architecture or just want to experience Modena’s essence, this cathedral is a must-see.

The Modena Cathedral, or Duomo di Modena, is an awe-inspiring masterpiece and a must-visit landmark in the heart of the city. As a UNESCO World Heritage Site, it stands as a testament to Romanesque architecture and the rich history of Modena.

Built on the burial site of Saint Geminianus, the city’s patron saint since 331 AD, the cathedral is not just an architectural wonder but also a deeply spiritual place. The crypt, where Saint Geminianus is interred, adds a layer of solemnity and historical significance, making the visit feel profound and meaningful.
The Cathedral was so beautiful! It wasn’t very crowded. Definitely worth a visit if you are in the area.

Visited as part of my unesco heritage sites tour. This UNESCO World Heritage site, completed in the 12th century, is a masterpiece of Romanesque architecture. The exterior's intricate sculptures and the interior's beautiful frescoes and stunning rose window are truly captivating. It wasn't too crowded, allowing for a peaceful and reflective experience. I think thus cathedral is very special because its white facade and tower very memorable. Also the architecture within is lovely.
Beautiful Romanesque cathedral, with numerous small details to find. Free entrance.

Name: Archaeological Areas of Pompei, Herculaneum and Torre Annunziata
short_description: When Vesuvius erupted on 24 August AD 79, it engulfed the two flourishing Roman towns of Pompei and Herculaneum, as well as the many wealthy villas in the area. These have been progressively excavated and made accessible to the public since the mid-18th century. The vast expanse of the commercial town of Pompei contrasts with the smaller but better-preserved remains of the holiday resort of Herculaneum, while the superb wall paintings of the Villa Oplontis at Torre Annunziata give a vivid impression of the opulent lifestyle enjoyed by the wealthier citizens of the Early Roman Empire.
formatted_address: 80045 Pompei, Metropolitan City of Naples, Italy

reviews.text: An absolutely breathtaking experience! The Archaeological Park of Pompeii is a must-visit for history lovers. Walking through the well-preserved ruins feels like stepping back in time. The details of the ancient streets, villas, and frescoes are astonishing. The site is vast, so wear comfortable shoes and take your time exploring. Truly one of the most fascinating historical sites in the world!

We had a great time at Pompeii, but feel as though the signs and map could be a little clearer. The site gets very busy and it's absolutely massive, which makes it a challenge to get around in just a few hours like we had. I would recommend giving yourself at least 4-5 hours, if not the entire day to explore as there's lots to see and quite a lot of queues to get into some of the buildings.

This is a MUST DO if you are in Italy. It is easily one of the coolest things you will ever do in your life. It’s a whole entire ancient city you can explore. It’s absolutely gigantic. I suggest getting a tour to truly learn as much as you can about this place, knowing the history is worth it. There is also a bunch of nice cats to pet.

Honestly, I say 2 full days are required to learn and see everything.

A must see. You will remember this for a long time. For the best experience, familiarize yourself with history and some of the most interesting buildings before you even get there. The maps they give you are a bit hard to follow and the place is enormous. It is an entire city after all.

It’s a great place to experience the history of Pompeii. I underestimated the size of this place… It really was an intriguing city. There are a few trip hazards so be careful what you wear. There doesn’t seem to be any toilets inside the park and you need to walk back to the entrance or the exit to find one. This was the only disappointing thing about it besides the lack of  signage for directions. While I understand they probably want to keep some aesthetics of the town I think it’s important to show better directional signage as it’s easy to get lost in there! Unfortunately, the audio guides were disappointing because they talked too much about the family history and not enough about why the paint is still lasting and what the bodies mean,  how it happened. Etc Everything like that. For those who are interested in family history, I guess that’s fine but for me I wanted to know more about the bricks they used and the bodies that were there and how they did things. I also would’ve liked a video room that showed life in those days and the event of the volcano..  some rude tourist guides walking around-from seperate companies. I was taking a photo in the hallway and had one of them pushed me aside and then she went off in Italian at me… I told her I didn’t understand and I was taking a photo. She could’ve waited and be more polite, unfortunately I didn’t get to her company name because I would’ve reported her as I was pushed into the wall!

Name: Costiera Amalfitana
short_description: The Amalfi coast is an area of great physical beauty and natural diversity. It has been intensively settled by human communities since the early Middle Ages. There are a number of towns such as Amalfi and Ravello with architectural and artistic works of great significance. The rural areas show the versatility of the inhabitants in adapting their use of the land to the diverse nature of the terrain, which ranges from terraced vineyards and orchards on the lower slopes to wide upland pastures.

reviews.text: The Amalfi Coast is an absolute dream come true! From the picturesque towns to the breathtaking views, every moment spent here feels like a piece of paradise. The crystal-clear waters, the charming villages, and the stunning cliffs create an unforgettable experience. Whether you're exploring the historic sites, enjoying the delicious local cuisine, or simply relaxing by the sea, the Amalfi Coast offers something magical for everyone. Highly recommend it for anyone looking for a perfect blend of natural beauty and cultural richness.
It should definitely be on one's bucket list. I would recommend to visit in pre-season or post-season. Otherwise it can be crowded. Ine of the most beautiful coasts I have ever seen.
Every town has something unique. Would recommend avoiding peak season (August) and having a clear plan for your holiday as there’s simply so much to see!
A beautiful place to visit, lots of nice shops and restaurants around. We went in February (a very pleasant time) but can imagine it's much busier in the summer season.
Wonderful little town with amazing shops, food, gelato and coffee. Beautiful streets, incredible vibes. Recommend Nino and friends for samples of gourmet chocolate, olive oil, pestos, and balsamic

Name: Archaeological Area of Agrigento
short_description: Founded as a Greek colony in the 6th century B.C., Agrigento became one of the leading cities in the Mediterranean world. Its supremacy and pride are demonstrated by the remains of the magnificent Doric temples that dominate the ancient town, much of which still lies intact under today's fields and orchards. Selected excavated areas throw light on the later Hellenistic and Roman town and the burial practices of its early Christian inhabitants.

reviews.text: After multiple trips to Sicily this year, I finally had the chance to visit this incredible place. Despite a rainy week, the skies cleared, and I arrived early to avoid crowds. The peaceful atmosphere allowed me to fully explore the park in just over two hours. The history and beauty of the site are truly remarkable. Even when I left, it was still quiet. Highly recommend visiting if you get the chance!

Amazing experience. We did not have a tour guide or the audio guide, instead relying on Google and Wikipedia. We still found it amazingly informative and moving. The structures, and the history behind them, we're readily accessible. It made a historical period I'm not super familiar with (Greek colonization of Sicily) come alive.

Breathtaking views to the coastline. The temples are magnificent as well! Place takes less than 2 hours to check it out.

There are a total of 3 temples (hit or miss), it’s pretty cool to walk around the ancients street surrounded by the beautiful olive trees as well as walnut trees while in bloom (February).

The park covers a fairly large area. There are views of the city and the sea. There is a charge for using the car park, which is closed by a barrier. The fee can currently be paid at a ticket machine on the way out. At the entrance to the park there is an airport access system with a security guard. Once you get through you can buy a ticket or show the one you bought online. There is a toilet at the entrance. The park is very warm even in October. There is not much shade. Bring water and a hat! There is no shopping inside, but there is a water tap where you can drink and fill a bottle. You can also bring your dog. If you are passing through, these ruins are well worth a visit.

A huge park area with ancient temples. I felt like I had completely plunged into ancient history. The Temple of Heracles has an incredible energy. There is an Igor Mitoraj’s sculpture near the Temple of Concordia 👏

Unfortunately, we didn’t have enough time to explore the entire park—it’s better to plan for a full day and bring a hat and water

This is truly an amazing historical treasure and a gem of Sicily, a must-visit spot!✅

Name: Villa Romana del Casale
short_description: Roman exploitation of the countryside is symbolized by the Villa Romana del Casale (in Sicily), the centre of the large estate upon which the rural economy of the Western Empire was based. The villa is one of the most luxurious of its kind. It is especially noteworthy for the richness and quality of the mosaics which decorate almost every room; they are the finest mosaics in situ anywhere in the Roman world.

reviews.text: The most beautiful Roman mosaics I have ever seen. We visited in February with a private guide, so there was only us there. It gets extremely busy and hot in the summer. It is stunning!!

This villa is a great visit! I have seen a few Roman Villas around the Med and this is one of the best preserved. The scale of the villa is clear to see which gives a great insight into the owner’s wealth and how they lived. The information is great. They have built a walkway above the rooms/mosaics which was an excellent way to take it all in. Would definitely recommend visiting. We visited on the drive from Palermo to Noto and it was a perfect stop for that drive. We visited in late December in the late afternoon and it was very quiet.

An absolute must see if you are in Sicily and at all interested in archaeological sites. These must have been the best Roman mosaics I’ve ever seen. So many different styles and in wonderful condition. It’s not just the so called ‘ bikini girls’ there are way more impressive mosaics

Villa Romana del Casale in Piazza Armerina is one of the most beautiful places I have ever visited. The mosaics are amazing and show a lot about the culture and lifestyle from over 2000 years ago. They are so detailed that you can clearly imagine how life was in Roman times. The art and design of the villa are impressive and give a unique look into history. It’s a place full of beauty and meaning, and I highly recommend visiting it.

Wonderful place to visit! It is so impressive the condition of the mosaics, really precious that they survived the years.However, I think the place needs a better maintenance and conservation of this heritage. There are leaks on quite a few places directly onto the mosaics and pigeons are nesting and pooping around even though there are some safe nets. The place needs better care so it is preserved for the next generations too!

Name: Su Nuraxi di Barumini
short_description: During the late 2nd millennium B.C. in the Bronze Age, a special type of defensive structure known as nuraghi (for which no parallel exists anywhere else in the world) developed on the island of Sardinia. The complex consists of circular defensive towers in the form of truncated cones built of dressed stone, with corbel-vaulted internal chambers. The complex at Barumini, which was extended and reinforced in the first half of the 1st millennium under Carthaginian pressure, is the finest and most complete example of this remarkable form of prehistoric architecture.
formatted_address: Viale Su Nuraxi, 09021 Barumini SU, Italy

reviews.text: Absolutely breathtaking site. Just imagining that people living in these very building 3,5 thousand years ago. I visited this place in mid January, and there were no peple. I didn't know you are allowed only with a tour guide, but it is totally reasonable + I had an individual tour and was the last person there. Enjoyed the sunset from the ancient tower as well :)

You couldn’t imagine how they built until you went in. Amazing experience to know the history and culture. The guide told us that in other time of the year the spot will be surrounded with colourful flowers.

Great experience if you have the time to explore the island. It's something different and worth it..the tour itself is short but there is waiting time for other groups to allow access, without that would be a max 20 min but add at least 20 min of waiting around. The access in parts it's tricky but I saw people of all ages do it! It's not cheap at 15 euros for a short visit. The tour guide Daniela was lovely.

Su Nuraxi di Barumini is a fascinating site that I thoroughly enjoyed visiting. The ruins are incredibly well-preserved, offering a unique glimpse into history. However, be prepared for some waiting time as only one group is allowed to enter or leave the main structure at a time. While the entry fee is a bit on the expensive side, the experience and the chance to explore a UNESCO World Heritage site make it worthwhile.

Breathtaking complex of former towers surmounting holy wells, built with oversized closely aligned stones in tholos style, with narrow tunnels connecting the towers and going to what were the floors above. Cool with shadow inside with informative tours. Well worth the visit and the long wait wait at the ticket office

Name: Mount Kenya National Park/Natural Forest
short_description: At 5,199 m, Mount Kenya is the second highest peak in Africa. It is an ancient extinct volcano, which during its period of activity (3.1-2.6 million years ago) is thought to have risen to 6,500 m. There are 12 remnant glaciers on the mountain, all receding rapidly, and four secondary peaks that sit at the head of the U-shaped glacial valleys. With its rugged glacier-clad summits and forested middle slopes, Mount Kenya is one of the most impressive landscapes in East Africa. The evolution and ecology of its afro-alpine flora provide an outstanding example of ecological and biological processes. Through the Lewa Wildlife Conservancy and Ngare Ndare Forest Reserve, the property also incorporates lower lying scenic foothills and arid habitats of high biodiversity, situated in the ecological transition zone between the mountain ecosystem and the semi-arid savanna grasslands. The area also lies within the traditional migrating route of the African elephant population.

reviews.text: Had the best experience ever Kwanza mountain climbing was top notch

The best mountain 🏔️ to visit in Africa and being the second highest mountain in Africa that’s stunning .Mount Kenya The mountain features several key peaks, including Batian (5,199m), Nelion (5,188m), and Point Lenana (4,985m), which offer thrilling experiences for hikers and climbers.

Around the mountain, pristine alpine lakes such as Lake Ellis, Lake Michaelson, and Lake Alice provide serene and scenic spots for adventurers. These lakes are not just beautiful; they are also home to a variety of fish species. Rainbow trout, introduced during the colonial era, are the most common fish found in the lakes, offering an additional attraction for fishing enthusiasts.

Mount Kenya is a must-visit destination, blending striking peaks, tranquil lakes, and diverse wildlife to create an unforgettable outdoor experience.

Mount Kenya National Park offers breathtaking landscapes with its towering peaks, lush forests, and diverse wildlife. It's an ideal destination for adventurous hikers and nature enthusiasts seeking an unforgettable experience.
Amazing place. I wish we had taken the hike to crest Mt Kenya.
Such a magical cold place to be.

Name: Lake Turkana National Parks
short_description: The most saline of Africa's large lakes, Turkana is an outstanding laboratory for the study of plant and animal communities. The three National Parks serve as a stopover for migrant waterfowl and are major breeding grounds for the Nile crocodile, hippopotamus and a variety of venomous snakes. The Koobi Fora deposits, rich in mammalian, molluscan and other fossil remains, have contributed more to the understanding of paleo-environments than any other site on the continent.

reviews.text: 🚤✨ Just took a wild ride across the jade waters of Lake Turkana to Central Island, and let’s just say…this island is serving serious volcanic vibes 🌋! The boat ride felt like an adventure out of a movie—wind in my hair, sun on my face, and endless views of Africa’s largest desert lake. Once on the island, it was like stepping into a dream: craters filled with turquoise lakes, rugged lava cliffs, and panoramic views that go on forever. No filter needed when nature’s this breathtaking. 🌊🔥 Who knew the desert could be this magical?
A good day trip from Eliye Springs. Unfortunately, many of the famous crocodiles have been poached. You will need to hire a private boat.

It's a world UNESCO World Heritage heritage, located on Lake Turkana. It has three crater lakes, a crocodile lake, a flamingo lake, and a tilapia lake. It's accessed by a motorboat from either Kalokol or Eliye. You have to pay Kws charges before accessing the park at their Lodwar and Kalokol offices. It's a great place for hiking and picnicking. It's a two-hour boat ride from Eliye depending on the lake currents and 30 minutes, from Kalokol.
Fantastic flamingos volcano crater

It's not worth it. The craters are beautiful to look at. Otherwise there is only a crumbling shelter and a crumbling toilet. The KWS entrance fee is not worth the money, actually an outrage. The boat trip is expensive and doesn't exactly inspire confidence when it's windy, there are no crocodiles due to fishing (in the national park?), and there haven't been any flamingos for a while. The path is partly under water, later there is hardly any passage, you have to fight your way through the thorn bushes. Too bad.

Name: Historic Centre of Riga
short_description: Riga was a major centre of the Hanseatic League, deriving its prosperity in the 13th–15th centuries from the trade with central and eastern Europe. The urban fabric of its medieval centre reflects this prosperity, though most of the earliest buildings were destroyed by fire or war. Riga became an important economic centre in the 19th century, when the suburbs surrounding the medieval town were laid out, first with imposing wooden buildings in neoclassical style and then in Jugendstil . It is generally recognized that Riga has the finest collection of art nouveau buildings in Europe.
formatted_address: Vecrīga, Central District, Riga, LV-1050, Latvia

Name: Hospicio Cabañas, Guadalajara
short_description: The Hospicio Cabañas was built at the beginning of the 19th century to provide care and shelter for the disadvantaged – orphans, old people, the handicapped and chronic invalids. This remarkable complex, which incorporates several unusual features designed specifically to meet the needs of its occupants, was unique for its time. It is also notable for the harmonious relationship between the open and built spaces, the simplicity of its design, and its size. In the early 20th century, the chapel was decorated with a superb series of murals, now considered some of the masterpieces of Mexican art. They are the work of José Clemente Orozco, one of the greatest Mexican muralists of the period.
formatted_address: C. Cabañas 8, Las Fresas, 44360 Guadalajara, Jal., Mexico

reviews.text: If you are in the historic downtown of Guadalajara, this place is a must see. Fabulous ceiling murals as well as a few smaller exhibits. A great place to spend a few hours.

One of the most imposing and beautiful buildings in Guadalajara- originally built as an orphanage and hospital in the colonial era. The murals by Orozco are spectacular and there are additional spaces for rotating art exhibitions. Highly recommend !  Great museum shop as well.

Very scammy practice, beware!

You pay for a building with approximately 25 rooms of art, murales, and more. This is also what the reviews say and why we entered.

However.

The main building is nice, but not special compared to any random murales on the street or church decoration. And besides that, there were four (!!!) rooms open. Out of more than twenty-five!

One room with six or so paintings, one with a small counter with a few pottery things / ceramics, one with maps of Guadslajara and a miniature of this building, and one with papers from a dictionary (seriously).

Presumably you are not at all interested in a dictionary, nor so much in generic ceramics, leaving you with six or so paintings, a map and miniature building, and a main building with some murales.

Of course they don't give you your money back either. So please, I took pictures of everything except for the dictionary, now you can enjoy the building without paying.

If you do decide to go, explicitly ask what they offer before you pay.

What a scam.

Hospicio Cabañas is a beautiful historic site featuring murals by the famed Mexican muralist José Clemente Orozco. Once an orphanage and hospice, it has now been converted into a museum. The architecture is breathtaking and reminiscent of Spanish colonial style. A must-see for anyone sightseeing in Guadalajara.

There are few places I have been to that are like the Museo Cabanas. What was once an orphanage is now a place full of culture and history with a lot to take in.

Currently, they have several art exhibits to come and see, all showcasing different Mexican artists from the 20th century. The art exhibits here are quite lengthy and do take a while to run through. They contain an extensive collection of the artist's works, more than most other art museums I have been to.

The highlights here were the main hall that you can walk into after entering the museum. If you walk past the main courtyard at the entrance, you will find a sprawling hall with enormous murals painted all over the walls and even on the ceiling. It was amazing to see as I have seen very few things like it in the past.

In addition to this, the size of the museum is also impressive and left me surprised. There had to have been at least 12 different courtyards situated throughout the museum, the two biggest ones being at the very entrance of the museum and on the other side of the main hall. They made for a great place to take photos and walk around enjoying the breeze.

Something else I liked was how clean the museum was kept, both in the exhibits and on the outside in the courtyards. I always saw someone walking around with a broom in hand, sweeping up any rubbish they could find.

I really did enjoy coming here though as it was a great place to come and pass the time and see everything the museum has to offer.

Name: Archaeological Site of Volubilis
short_description: The Mauritanian capital, founded in the 3rd century B.C., became an important outpost of the Roman Empire and was graced with many fine buildings. Extensive remains of these survive in the archaeological site, located in a fertile agricultural area. Volubilis was later briefly to become the capital of Idris I, founder of the Idrisid dynasty, who is buried at nearby Moulay Idris.

reviews.text: Worth a visit. Extensive site. A guided tour is worthwhile. Not too many statues but gives a good layout of a Roman town on the edge of the empire. Some very nice mosaics.

I’ve been to most ancient Roman sites in Italy, all of Middle East (including Byzantine empire) and North Africa and this place was the most impressive! Only second best to Pompei and Herculaneum. This former Roman era capital of Morocco is in surprisingly good shape with some gorgeous mosaic floors. You get a real good feel of how this place once has been. The architecture is absolutely impressive and the stroll around the park very pleasant with the beautiful nature and surroundings. It’s been an absolute highlight of our trip. A guided tour of the place is highly recommended to bring the history alive.

This is a very well preserved Roman site which gives a picture of the Phoenician  and Roman influences in the area and some of the local Berger culture. it is well preserved giving you a picture of daily life with mosaics archers temples and a small remain of a basilica. It’s a very big site so you need a bit of time.

Really cool and well preserved roman ruins. Probably the best preserved I've seen outside of Rome, with tile mosaics and still easily made out and the etchings are visible, it is really a remarkable place. I would definitely recommend making a trip out to see these ruins.

World Heritage site.

We had a guide that was arranged for us. He seemed knowledgeable but his English accent was slightly difficult to follow. However, I would not visit here without one or it might just be a pile of rocks.

Excavations began in 1915.

Ruins date back to first century BC then evidence of Roman occupation up until they moved to Tangier and then ultimately the abandonment of the city dates to the 14th century.

The guide explained that this area at one point had 20,000 people. Can see the entry to the areas with the arches standing.  The data says that only 40% of the ruins have been excavated.

There was a main road that had arches along the entire way but only a few remain standing.

Ruins of large wealthy Roman homes built with many rooms and courtyards and you can see the crumbled delineations.

Beautiful mosaics seen.

The mosaics that are roped off are originals and they are beautiful.

This is a must see because the shear size of area, amount of ruins uncovered and to see the mosaics.

Name: Medina of Tétouan (formerly known as Titawin)
short_description: Tétouan was of particular importance in the Islamic period, from the 8th century onwards, since it served as the main point of contact between Morocco and Andalusia. After the Reconquest, the town was rebuilt by Andalusian refugees who had been expelled by the Spanish. This is well illustrated by its art and architecture, which reveal clear Andalusian influence. Although one of the smallest of the Moroccan medinas, Tétouan is unquestionably the most complete and it has been largely untouched by subsequent outside influences.

reviews.text:
Been there multiple times during my stay
I highly advise you to be there with local
Very nice ild city were people still leave there
In the ground there are symbols it guides you to which road you should take and there are maps follow them
Old markets you can find cloth, gold , leather and so one
As well as old building architecture and historical gates Spanish and Moroccan

A loss if you haven’t visited the medinah!

Please get lost in the stunning labyrinth of small paths leading you for hours between worlds of leather, wood, food and artisanal made items!

Drink a Moroccan tea on a roof (stah) at a Riad (Hotel) whilst enjoying the skyline and sunset of this breathtaking town, Tetouane 💜🤲🏻

The Medina of Tetouan is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a true gem of Moroccan heritage. Its narrow, winding streets, whitewashed walls, and vibrant souks create an authentic and enchanting atmosphere. Every corner tells a story, from the beautifully preserved Andalusian architecture to the bustling markets filled with traditional crafts and local goods. The Medina’s unique blend of history and culture makes it an unforgettable destination for anyone seeking to experience the essence of Morocco.

Well, no matter how many words I describe in this city, I will not give it its due praise and splendor, it is truly wonderful, inhabitants,  alleys,  architecture ,  buildings , monuments and activities , all of which must be taken into consideration, each of which has a major role.

Nice medina but it is quite smelly and not clean compared to other Medinas in other Moroccan cities. Mostly stalls selling vegetables, leather products and second hand items.
Wouldn't recommend spending alot of time there

Name: Lumbini, the Birthplace of the Lord Buddha
short_description: Siddhartha Gautama, the Lord Buddha, was born in 623 B.C. in the famous gardens of Lumbini, which soon became a place of pilgrimage. Among the pilgrims was the Indian emperor Ashoka, who erected one of his commemorative pillars there. The site is now being developed as a Buddhist pilgrimage centre, where the archaeological remains associated with the birth of the Lord Buddha form a central feature.

reviews.text: Its a must-visit spot for anyone seeking peace and reflection. The beautiful gardens and sacred pond add to the tranquility of the site. The museum nearby is also informative and offers great insights into the history and significance of this holy place. Highly recommended for a soul-soothing journey.

Lumbini, Nepal, the birthplace of Siddhartha Gautama Buddha, offers a profoundly different airport experience than a large international hub. It's a place where the spiritual significance of the location overshadows the typical hustle and bustle of modern air travel. Let's delve into a review of the Lumbini Airport (Gautam Buddha International Airport).

Gautam Buddha International Airport (LUM) is relatively new and designed to facilitate pilgrimage and tourism to this sacred site. Stepping off the plane, you're immediately struck by the tranquil atmosphere, a stark contrast to the often frenetic energy of larger airports. The airport's design reflects the region's cultural heritage, with subtle nods to Buddhist architecture and symbolism.

The airport is small and manageable, making navigation straightforward. The check-in and security processes are generally efficient, though they may be less automated compared to larger airports. This simplicity adds to the overall sense of peace and tranquility that permeates the location.

The facilities at LUM are basic but adequate. You'll find essential amenities like restrooms, a small cafe, and a few souvenir shops. The emphasis is less on commercialism and more on providing a comfortable and respectful environment for pilgrims and visitors.

The airport's primary purpose is to connect visitors to the Lumbini Sacred Garden, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The proximity of the airport to this significant site is a major advantage, allowing for easy access to the temples, monasteries, and the Maya Devi Temple, the traditional birthplace of the Buddha.

The overall atmosphere at LUM is one of reverence and quiet contemplation. Passengers are often pilgrims from various Buddhist traditions, creating a sense of shared purpose and spiritual connection. The airport's staff is generally friendly and helpful, reflecting the warm hospitality of the Nepali people.

While LUM may lack the extensive amenities and modern infrastructure of larger airports, it excels in its role as a gateway to a place of profound spiritual importance. The simplicity and tranquility of the airport experience complement the serene atmosphere of Lumbini itself.

For travelers seeking a spiritual journey or an immersion into Buddhist culture, Lumbini Airport provides a fitting introduction to this sacred destination. It is a place where the journey itself is as meaningful as the destination. It is a place where you will find peace.

Best place for tourist , there are a lot of temple and many more facilities like free parking, drinking water, taxi . Police are always available for security. Entrance fee is low . So you can go for visit or worship

I've been to Lumbini many times, and each visit feels special. The serene gardens and ancient ruins, especially the Maya Devi Temple, create a peaceful atmosphere for reflection and meditation. It's a must-visit for anyone interested in Buddhism and its rich history.

Lumbini is a truly serene and spiritual destination, and my visit was an unforgettable experience. As the birthplace of Lord Buddha, the site offers a deep sense of peace and reflection, making it a must-visit for anyone interested in history, culture, or spirituality. The Sacred Garden, with its beautiful trees, ponds, and quiet paths, creates a calm and reflective atmosphere perfect for meditation and contemplation.

The main highlight was visiting the Maya Devi Temple, where the stone marking the spot of Buddha's birth is kept. It’s an awe-inspiring moment to stand in such a significant historical location. The surrounding monasteries, built by different countries, offer unique architectural styles and add to the global spiritual significance of Lumbini.

The area is well-maintained, and the staff are friendly and knowledgeable, offering insights into the history and meaning behind the sites. While it can get busy, the spiritual energy of the place remains strong, and it’s easy to find moments of solitude.

If you're looking for a peaceful and enlightening journey, Lumbini is the perfect place to reflect, connect with nature, and experience a piece of world history. Highly recommend!

Name: Mill Network at Kinderdijk-Elshout
short_description: The outstanding contribution made by the people of the Netherlands to the technology of handling water is admirably demonstrated by the installations in the Kinderdijk-Elshout area. Construction of hydraulic works for the drainage of land for agriculture and settlement began in the Middle Ages and have continued uninterruptedly to the present day. The site illustrates all the typical features associated with this technology – dykes, reservoirs, pumping stations, administrative buildings and a series of beautifully preserved windmills.

reviews.text:
This place is worth the visit - not to be missed. The windmills have been nicely kept/maintained from the inside and you’d be in an awe to see how it was used back then. It’s like you have stepped into a completely different era. It was an interesting watch to see how the blades of the windmill are stopped as well.
We reached a little late and to our luck the lady at the ticket counter was nice enough to let us in and quickly guided us where to go so that we can make it to all the places (which we did :)).
There is a boat ride too which you could enjoy but we preferred walking.
Also it’s better to drive yourself to this area because it’s extremely difficult to hire cabs if the time is off. There is a bus stop nearby but depending on where you have to head out to it can be pretty long and slow.

Kinderdijk is a picturesque village in the Netherlands, famous for its iconic windmills. Located in the province of South Holland, Kinderdijk has a collection of 19 well-preserved windmills that were built in the 18th century to help manage water levels and prevent flooding in the region. The windmills are now a UNESCO World Heritage site and a popular tourist destination. The area offers beautiful views, walking and cycling paths, making it a charming spot to visit if you’re exploring Dutch history and culture.

Fantastic day out. Lots to see and learn for all ages. Beautiful windmills and nature reserve. Saw lots of wildlife and there are many joggers and bikers on the trail.
We took the water taxi here from the main bridge. Much cheaper than getting a normal taxi or booking an excursion. You can pre book tickets or scan in/out with your card

What a spectacular visit of the beauty and history of the country of The Netherlands/Holland!  Taking a tour, you can enter a homestead windmill and see how life was back in the day for these early settlers. The photo ops are tremendous, and as we were there, a rainbow suddenly appeared behind one of the windmills, which sent all of us with cameras running at full speed to capture a great shot before it disappeared.

One of a kind experience, this is the UNESCO Heritage site where all the windmills in this area are original and were not moved from somewhere else.

The ticket is value for money since it includes the boat rides, the opportunity to see the e inside of a windmill, watch the well made film and much more.

It’s an eye opener to see how the windmill also served as a home to relatively large families.

Name: Historic Area of Willemstad, Inner City and Harbour, Curaçao
short_description: The people of the Netherlands established a trading settlement at a fine natural harbour on the Caribbean island of Curaçao in 1634. The town developed continuously over the following centuries. The modern town consists of several distinct historic districts whose architecture reflects not only European urban-planning concepts but also styles from the Netherlands and from the Spanish and Portuguese colonial towns with which Willemstad engaged in trade.

Name: Rohtas Fort
short_description: Following his defeat of the Mughal emperor Humayun in 1541, Sher Shah Suri built a strong fortified complex at Rohtas, a strategic site in the north of what is now Pakistan. It was never taken by storm and has survived intact to the present day. The main fortifications consist of the massive walls, which extend for more than 4 km; they are lined with bastions and pierced by monumental gateways. Rohtas Fort, also called Qila Rohtas, is an exceptional example of early Muslim military architecture in Central and South Asia.

reviews.text: The fort is one of the largest and most formidable in the subcontinent. Rohtas Fort was never stormed by force, and has survived remarkably intact. The fort is known for its large defensive walls, and several monumental gateways.

A 16th century marvel located in Dina-Jhelum almost 125 km from Islamabad. The foundation of Rohtas Fort was laid by the Sher Shah Suri of Sur empire. Rohtas Fort is a UNESCO declared world heritage site. It covers an area of 170 acres, 68 bastions, 14 gates, 35-40 feet high walls and is almost triangle in shape. Rohtas Fort is a blended architectural and artistic traditions from Turkey and the Indian subcontinent. It takes almost 2 hours to have a complete visit of the fort. There is a mini shop at the fort where you can get the refreshments. We Pakistani should preserve this historic site by keeping it clean as I witnessed litters on the ground. A must visit historic site.
Amazing place for a historical tour. Definitely reminds you of the kings of Ottoman empire. Well maintained and road is also in good condition.
It's an amazing place for a day trip... Must visit during winters only

Rohtas is beautiful place ...It is a ancient Fort. Rohtas fort remembers the rich history of Shair Shah soori ...Shair shah build this Fort with Heavy stones to protect his army from opponents.It is a unique Fort and beautiful place to visit

Name: Archaeological Site of Panamá Viejo and Historic District of Panamá
short_description: Founded in 1519 by the conquistador Pedrarías Dávila, Panamá Viejo is the oldest European settlement on the Pacific coast of the Americas. It was laid out on a rectilinear grid and marks the transference from Europe of the idea of a planned town. Abandoned in the mid-17th century, it was replaced by a ‘new town’ (the ‘Historic District’), which has also preserved its original street plan, its architecture and an unusual mixture of Spanish, French and early American styles. The Salón Bolívar was the venue for the unsuccessful attempt made by El Libertador in 1826 to establish a multinational continental congress.
formatted_address: 2G47+MW9, Vía Cincuentenario, Panamá, Provincia de Panamá, Panama

reviews.text: Beautiful ruins with tons of history to see, their credit card machine was not working and we had to go through three credit cards before they realize it was their machine. The experience is definitely overpriced at $17 per entry. But it is a very cool experience. There is a tram that will take you from the building to the ruins and back.

Great area to explore. We had a ton of fun just walking the grounds, and there are plenty of things to look at. It seems like it is a quick tour, but you can spend a good amount of time just exploring.

My best friend and I strolled through this amazing section of old Panama. You are able to freely walk throughout the site where the ruins of the Spanish settlers remain. Enjoy the rich history of the area by taking in the thoughtful lessons in the museum. Climb the lookout tower where you can see all of the great city, ocean, and surrounding jungle. This is an absolute gorgeous place to visit.

A nice way to get a taste of Panamanian history. There's a museum near the cathedral tower which I really enjoyed as it had a more full history of Panama Viejo and Panama in general. It's a very touristy place, but worth the visit.

Fascinating UNESCO Heritage site (the original location of the first Colonial settlement) and easy to get to by taxi. Good views, excellent book/gift shop. You’ll find artisans working at The nearby handicrafts center, which has excellent prices.

Name: Medieval Town of Toruń
short_description: Torun owes its origins to the Teutonic Order, which built a castle there in the mid-13th century as a base for the conquest and evangelization of Prussia. It soon developed a commercial role as part of the Hanseatic League. In the Old and New Town, the many imposing public and private buildings from the 14th and 15th centuries (among them the house of Copernicus) are striking evidence of Torun's importance.
formatted_address: Medieval Town of Toruń, 87-100 Toruń, Poland

Name: Castle of the Teutonic Order in Malbork
short_description: This 13th-century fortified monastery belonging to the Teutonic Order was substantially enlarged and embellished after 1309, when the seat of the Grand Master moved here from Venice. A particularly fine example of a medieval brick castle, it later fell into decay, but was meticulously restored in the 19th and early 20th centuries. Many of the conservation techniques now accepted as standard were evolved here. Following severe damage in the Second World War it was once again restored, using the detailed documentation prepared by earlier conservators.

reviews.text: The castle is truly impressive and massive in size. Visitors, be prepared for a long and nice walk. :) The audio guide is well-structured and easy to navigate. While I did not complete the entire tour, as it was quite extensive and some of the spacious rooms felt somewhat similar, the experience was remarkable. Seeing a castle this big was both beautiful and emotional.

Super interesting place. Large castle with lots of cool exhibitions. The audio guide was great, very detailed without being too much. Easy to follow. Well preserved. Could easily spend 3-5 hours inside, depending on how detailed you want your tour.

This was my second visit to Malbork Castle, and I love this place just as much as the first time! This time, I had the chance to bring my family along, which made the experience even more special.

My mom was in a wheelchair, and while navigating the castle was challenging at times, it was still possible for her to enjoy the visit. The staff was incredibly kind and helpful, making sure she had the best experience possible.

The castle itself feels like the dream castle I imagined as a kid—massive, majestic, and full of history. I was amazed by how many areas visitors can explore, and every corner has something fascinating to offer.

Once again, I absolutely loved this place, and I highly recommend it to anyone visiting Poland!

I highly recommend getting the audio guide! It’s available in many languages and provides fascinating insights into the castle’s history, architecture, and hidden details you might otherwise miss. The narration is engaging and well-paced, making the experience even more immersive. It’s worth every cent!

Malbork Castle is absolutely magnificent, with so much to explore and discover. The architecture and history are truly impressive, making it a must-visit for anyone interested in medieval castles. The audio guide is very helpful and engaging, providing fascinating insights into the castle's past and its significance. Plan to spend several hours here to fully enjoy the experience. Highly recommended!
Amazing place! Totally different from other castles that I visited before. Not many visitors during our visit. The exhibitions are very interesting.

Name: Changdeokgung Palace Complex
short_description: In the early 15th century, the King Taejong ordered the construction of a new palace at an auspicious site. A Bureau of Palace Construction was set up to create the complex, consisting of a number of official and residential buildings set in a garden that was cleverly adapted to the uneven topography of the 58-ha site. The result is an exceptional example of Far Eastern palace architecture and design, blending harmoniously with the surrounding landscape.
formatted_address: 99 Yulgok-ro, Jongno District, Seoul, South Korea

reviews.text: Truly stunning. I do recommend doing the secret garden as well. It's incredibly peaceful and beautiful. The tours themselves don't take too long but I could spend hours sitting in the garden and relaxing. Very rich history and well informed tour guides

One of the advantages of visiting Seoul during the Wintertime is that you get to take great pictures without having crowds of people ruining your snapshots. The tradeoff is that you don't get to see the beautifulness of the full bloom of the trees and flowers.
This palace again fell short of my expectations. Needs more TLC.

Changdeokgung Palace and its Secret Garden are a must-visit in Seoul! The palace's elegant architecture showcases Korea's royal heritage, while the Secret Garden offers a serene escape with its lush landscapes, ponds, and pavilions. A perfect blend of history and nature.

A beautiful, historic site in Seoul, known for its stunning architecture and serene gardens. A UNESCO World Heritage site, it offers a glimpse into Korea's royal past. The Secret Garden is a highlight, especially in autumn, with vibrant foliage. A must-visit for history and culture lovers.
p.s : Need to buy ticket for Secret Garden in advance as it sold out quite fast

A much smaller palace than the more popular  Gyeonbokgung but that doesn’t not discount its charm, and I in fact preferred this instead. You will see similar palace buildings and designs but this is less crowded, less rushed and more serene. There is a slight elevation so you get a higher view in some places, but some areas like the Secret Garden required additional cost/ticket to enter. The lake towards the greenhouse was frozen during Dec/Jan and it was beautifully quiet and peaceful. The greenhouse kept a good variety of delicate plants, eg bonsai, which was a nice escape from the cold and period buildings. Overall, this is highly recommended if you have time and want to slow down in Seoul.

Name: Hwaseong Fortress
short_description: When the Joseon King Jeongjo moved his father's tomb to Suwon at the end of the 18th century, he surrounded it with strong defensive works, laid out according to the precepts of an influential military architect of the period, who brought together the latest developments in the field from both East and West. The massive walls, extending for nearly 6 km, still survive; they are pierced by four gates and equipped with bastions, artillery towers and other features.
formatted_address: South Korea, Gyeonggi-do, Suwon, Jangan-gu, 영화동 320-2

reviews.text:
The area is open for the public so it is easily accessible. I had a pleasant walk along the fortress walls and had a good view of the sunset. You can see the juxtaposition between the high rise buildings and the old fortress walls.

There are many cute cafes nearby if you want to rest and chill.

A beautiful historic sight to visit only an hour away from Seoul.
A Unesco World Heritage.

(Pictures taken on November)

For once I seem to agree with a Unesco classification. This is an amazing fortress located around the old city of Suwon. With a few exceptions, you can walk around the perimeter of it all and it is a great walk. We only covered half of it though, but it was the hardest half as it was uphill of the southern gate and with parts covered in sleat, slippery snow which were a bit hard to navigate through, but totally worth it. The view from the highest vantage point was amazing.

Suwon Hwaseong Fortress is a huge and impressive structure that offers stunning views of both the fortress itself and the surrounding city. The fortress spans a long distance, and walking through it typically takes about 2-3 hours. Visitors should keep hydration and snacks in mind, as exploring the entire area can be quite an endeavor.
Alternatively, you can choose to walk only certain sections if you're short on time. Overall, Hwaseong Fortress is a remarkable site that beautifully showcases Korea's historical architecture and provides a fantastic perspective of Suwon.

The (mainly) C18th, UNESCO Suwon Hwaseong Fortress has, in many places, been very well preserved and incorporated into city life.
In one respect it's been well-done... featuring in everyday life of the modern city- bus routes run along it, you pass through its gates whilst cross the roads etc.
But in another way this prevents one from really absorbing its history.
In some places you can almost feel like you're not in the city, but in most places you're standing on a thin ribbon of history that snakes through a noisy, modern city.

Name: Las Médulas
short_description: In the 1st century A.D. the Roman Imperial authorities began to exploit the gold deposits of this region in north-west Spain, using a technique based on hydraulic power. After two centuries of working the deposits, the Romans withdrew, leaving a devastated landscape. Since there was no subsequent industrial activity, the dramatic traces of this remarkable ancient technology are visible everywhere as sheer faces in the mountainsides and the vast areas of tailings, now used for agriculture.

reviews.text: An unique place made by people 2000-2200 years ago. We spent 3h but it is easily can be spent half of a day

Incredible experience! You can discover the gold mines along different trekking. Even you can visit a gold mine inside, by paying a ticket and following some instructions. Get ready to walk, get water with you and enjoy the amazing views. You can also try the traditional food in any of the restaurants in the village.

One of “must see”.
It is area of old Roman gold mine.
They run two aqueducts to flush down entire mount. I think it was great environmental disaster of that times. Fortunately Nature reclaimed this place and rearranged it in great style. I can assure you that walking around you will be astonished. This place is so picturesque that I have had big problems which photos should I publish.
My opinion you can skip one thing. “Lago”, means lake. I could hardly find something interesting about it.
Don’t forget to take a lot of water with you!

Once the largest and most productive gold mine in the Roman Empire, las médulas is a magical place, and well worth visiting. See the excavations and enter inside the tunnels used to excavate the gold. Parking is free and there's no charge to enter. The site is suitable for all fitness levels, but is not very wheelchair friendly.
Beautiful must see. Interesting history.

Name: Palau de la Música Catalana and Hospital de Sant Pau, Barcelona
short_description: These are two of the finest contributions to Barcelona's architecture by the Catalan art nouveau architect Lluís Domènech i Montaner. The Palau de la Música Catalana is an exuberant steel-framed structure full of light and space, and decorated by many of the leading designers of the day. The Hospital de Sant Pau is equally bold in its design and decoration, while at the same time perfectly adapted to the needs of the sick.
formatted_address: C/ Palau de la Música, 4-6, Ciutat Vella, 08003 Barcelona, Spain

reviews.text: A beautiful venue. It’s like €18 for a tour or you can find nightly concerts starting at €20 so enjoy a concert instead. I loved it! There is a wonderful little cafe inside too with a beautiful little courtyard. The stain glass and chandeliers are spectacular

Nestled in the heart of the city, this stunning architectural gem is nothing short of breathtaking. The intricate mosaic designs and the grandeur of the stained-glass windows create an atmosphere that feels almost otherworldly. Every corner you turn reveals a new detail, making it a delight for both the eyes and the soul. The vibrant colors and the fluid forms are a testament to the creativity and passion that went into its design.

Visiting this site is an experience that you won't soon forget. Whether you're attending a performance or simply taking in the artistry, the energy within its walls is palpable. It's a place that beautifully marries history with culture, providing a perfect backdrop for any occasion. Truly, it's a must-see for anyone wanting to immerse themselves in the rich tapestry of local heritage.

One of the most beautiful buildings I have ever seen. My boyfriend and I bought tickets with the audio guide and we both enjoyed it and thought it was comprehensive. There was a group practicing or doing a sound check and it was super cool to hear the acoustics. This is definitely worth a visit!
Highly recommend the tour! Marco was amazing and even let us on stage, it was so much more interesting than I thought and would definitely do it again!

Marvelous architecture! Hard to believe that most of the work was completed in two years time. The glass dome in the center is the real attraction and it uses pieces of stained glasses that are not multicolored but the artist is able to bring the effect of the sun in the center of the room. The color scheme picked and the 40 ladies on the sides makes it’s a masterpiece. On stage you will also see beautiful sculptures and several other stained glass windows all around. Recommend taking the guided tour.

Name: San Millán Yuso and Suso Monasteries
short_description: The monastic community founded by St Millán in the mid-6th century became a place of pilgrimage. A fine Romanesque church built in honour of the holy man still stands at the site of Suso. It was here that the first literature was produced in Castilian, from which one of the most widely spoken languages in the world today is derived. In the early 16th century the community was housed in the fine new monastery of Yuso, below the older complex; it is still a thriving community today.
formatted_address: 26326 San Millán de la Cogolla, La Rioja, Spain

reviews.text: the monastery of the 12th century. I didn't know about him until my husband advised me to go to this place. we walked with heavy backpacks, we were tired, we waited an hour for the opening and all for good reason. a very nice and interesting girl talked about the monastery in English (the girl is local, but speaks English so well that she does not want to leave). from the monastery you can get to Yso by bus, but we did not wait and went on foot, the nature around is very beautiful. there is a copy in the photo. if you can't upload a video with a guide, delete my review. Paulina (I hope I remembered the name correctly), thank you!
Living history of Spain, from the Visigothic era to the Mozarabic and Romanesque periods. What a beauty and what a heritage  🇪🇸😎

Road-trip: La Rioja, Monasterio de Suso - this unesco world heritage site is a short shuttle drive up from the Monastery de San Millán de Yuso. Note: Tickets are required; limited access! Can purchase tickets at the Monastery de San Millán de Yuso ticket office, where you will receive instructions on where to get the shuttle bus up to Suso. Much smaller in comparison to its mighty neighbor Yuso though worth a visit in its own right for its history, surrounding views and general remoteness. Tip: try to coordinate your visit with the timed visit at the Monastery de San Millán de Yuso. If there is a gap between your visits, there are at least two cafes near the main monastery where you can grab a bite or a coffee.

Important to know : You can't go there with your own car, despite what Google Maps says. There's a road but access is restricted.

Tickets need to be bought at the lower level of Yuso monastery and a bus (included in the ticket) will bring you to Suso.

Photo is a 6th century wisigoth altar that's inside the monastery (added mostly to increase visibility of this review because the upper part is relevant unless you like it when Google sends you through dirt roads :D )

We did the tour to the monastery Suso. We were handed out a brochure in our native language (German) at the ticket counter. We were not told that the tour guide for the monastery did only speak Spanish which we don’t speak. While she explained everything to the Spanish visitors in detail we were left out. We felt out of place and disrespected.

Name: Dougga / Thugga
short_description: Before the Roman annexation of Numidia, the town of Thugga, built on an elevated site overlooking a fertile plain, was the capital of an important Libyco-Punic state. It flourished under Roman and Byzantine rule, but declined in the Islamic period. The impressive ruins that are visible today give some idea of the resources of a small Roman town on the fringes of the empire.
formatted_address: Dougga, Délégation de, C6F9+5PH, Teboursouk, Tunisia

reviews.text:
I went there in February during a weekday, I had no line to wait, was easy to find free parking and the ticket was 3-4€ ( can’t remember it exactly) which was very good considering the history and majesty of the place.

I spent there like 3 beautiful hours admiring the site which screams history in every rock. Bring sun cream during a hot summer day.
It’s a easy and short walk from the parking to the site.

Follow me on Instagram for more contents like these: @giuseppecannavoo

I absolutely loved this place! It features a vast area where you can stroll among the remnants of an ancient city, soaking in its history and beauty. There’s even a spot where you can descend into an underground corridor, adding a touch of adventure to the experience.

Although there are a few information boards with descriptions, they are quite limited. We chose to explore without a guide, simply enjoying the stunning views and the charm of this antique site.

I highly recommend this place to anyone visiting Tunisia—it’s truly a must-see!

What can I say about Dougga? It’s an entire city from 2,300 years ago, still there for you to explore: walk through its streets, visit houses, admire the intricate mosaics in the halls, temples, and public baths. Set aside at least 2 hours to visit and be ready to walk. Several temples dedicated to Roman mythology gods like Minerva, Pluto, and Saturn are there. All of this comes with incredible views of the region, with olive trees adding to the atmosphere of the time. And the amphitheater? It’s a spectacle! I suggest starting at the lower part of Dougga and reaching the amphitheater from above for a breathtaking view. Don’t miss the city’s entrance with the two pillars that once supported the gate. Walk through the baths and wander the alleys between still-intact houses. Notice the water collection system that’s still visible. Some English-speaking guides offer their services at the entrance, and I think it’s worth it to learn more about the area’s rich history. By Jupiter, what a place!

An incredible historical site that is truly a journey back in time! This place is vast and filled with rich history, so be prepared to spend a good amount of time exploring it thoroughly. The site has so many fascinating details, with numerous plaques and descriptions to read that bring its past to life. You'll need some physical stamina, as it covers a large area with plenty of walking involved, but every step is worth it.

Nicely preserved Roman ruins. Just an hour away from Tunis. Definitely worth a visit. Plan at the very least hour and a half or even more. The area is huge. Not everything is easily accessible, and there are places with a good elevation or stairs. If you walk Kong enough and pay attention to what happens on the sides, you might notice a few tunnels. Go in and check where it goes. It's fun and absolutely safe.

Name: Maritime Greenwich
short_description: The ensemble of buildings at Greenwich, an outlying district of London, and the park in which they are set, symbolize English artistic and scientific endeavour in the 17th and 18th centuries. The Queen's House (by Inigo Jones) was the first Palladian building in England, while the complex that was until recently the Royal Naval College was designed by Christopher Wren. The park, laid out on the basis of an original design by André Le Nôtre, contains the Old Royal Observatory, the work of Wren and the scientist Robert Hooke.
Country name: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

reviews.text: Great day out for all ages. Well presented displays, spacious and comfortable to walk around. Some internal works being completed meaning some areas are currently closed the only downside. Lots to do in the local area around the museum as well. Easy to spend a whole day at Greenwich between the park, museum, observatory, Cutty Sark, and Queens House.

Great museum with lots of activities for all age groups and welcoming staff. It’s a free museum so you don’t feel you have to see everything in one day, and as it’s in the park there are nearby walks and other museums nearby.

I specifically went to see the Atlantic World gallery, and it’s very good to see that they have begun to address some of the challenges around the problematic interpretation and presentation of the histories of trafficking, enslavement and environmentalism (and more) in the pre and post-colonial Atlantic World. This is such an important part of all of our history, and I can’t wait to see the gallery develop further.

Outstanding museum with something for everyone. Great interactive displays for children.  We were lucky to hear a lovely short talk by Lee today all about Frank Hurley, Ernest Shackleton’s photographer. Lee went through Frank’s photographs bringing to life the bravery and commitment behind each one. It makes you look at them differently. Of course the Tudor room is brilliant too full of incredible maps and models. There is major construction work going on at the museum to replace the courtyard roof. Some displays closed until Summer 2025 but it’s still worth visiting in the meantime. All the staff and volunteers are friendly and knowledgeable. Highly recommended.

Been here many times - it's absolutely amazing! Recently I attended the tour about the treasures of their collection with Simon, who was absolutely amazing and even though I thought I have a decent knowledge about many things I was still enriched with more valuable fun facts (it was really fun). Highly recommend, especially given the fact the ticket is less than a cup of coffee
Superb place. So interesting, well laid out. Welcoming and helpful staff. Great cafe. Lovely setting in Greenwich park. Astronomy photo exhibition. a highlight.

Name: Pyrénées - Mont Perdu
short_description: This outstanding mountain landscape, which spans the contemporary national borders of France and Spain, is centred around the peak of Mount Perdu, a calcareous massif that rises to 3,352 m. The site, with a total area of 30,639 ha, includes two of Europe's largest and deepest canyons on the Spanish side and three major cirque walls on the more abrupt northern slopes with France, classic presentations of these geological landforms. The site is also a pastoral landscape reflecting an agricultural way of life that was once widespread in the upland regions of Europe but now survives only in this part of the Pyrénées. Thus it provides exceptional insights into past European society through its landscape of villages, farms, fields, upland pastures and mountain roads.

reviews.text: Beautiful Place… I Hiked up the Mountain from the North( French Face )  in the Winter it’s prettymuch  impossible to do in the winter, almost died on several accounts. BE CAREFUL IF YOU ATTEMPT THIS IN THE WINTER. Aside from that it’s beautiful. Highly recommend. I will be coming back :)

I absolutely love this place. It has all the ingredients for an optimal encounter between yourself and nature at its best. No matter your age, as long as you can open your eyes, the views and the landscape will take your breath away. Pure oxygen will enter into your lungs with every single step you take while contemplating the creation god has given to us. There are trails for amateurs as well as experience hickers.
If you happen to be near this area please do take the time to endulge in nature.
Super gorgeous. Easy to park and you can easily hike all day here.
This is one of four Base of UFO/UAP around the world, one is in Mount Zeil in Australia, Mount Nyangani in Zimbabwe, And Mount Hayes in Alaska, US

This outstanding mountain landscape, which spans the contemporary national borders of France and Spain, is centred around the peak of Mount Perdu, a calcareous massif that rises to 3,352 m. The site, with a total area of 30,639 ha, includes two of Europe's largest and deepest canyons on the Spanish side and three major cirque walls on the more abrupt northern slopes with France, classic presentations of these geological landforms. The site is also a pastoral landscape reflecting an agricultural way of life that was once widespread in the upland regions of Europe but now survives only in this part of the Pyrénées. Thus it provides exceptional insights into past European society through its landscape of villages, farms, fields, upland pastures and mountain roads.
UNESCO WORLD HERITAGE SITES

Name: Semmering Railway
short_description: The Semmering Railway, built over 41 km of high mountains between 1848 and 1854, is one of the greatest feats of civil engineering from this pioneering phase of railway building. The high standard of the tunnels, viaducts and other works has ensured the continuous use of the line up to the present day. It runs through a spectacular mountain landscape and there are many fine buildings designed for leisure activities along the way, built when the area was opened up due to the advent of the railway.

reviews.text: Nicely clarified the history of the region and the railways.  A big and fine monument and an old electric locomotive?

Beautiful place, only 50 munutes to 1h away from Vienna center and you can experience the glorius mountains and forests of Austria dressed in white with scenes like from a postcard! I loved the place and i'm certainly going to visit it again.

Beautiful landscape on the mountain from the train... But it's worth taking trip and then you can see the winding train from several points as it goes into the tunnel and then goes along the viaduct....
The 20 schilling blick offers a scenic view. Only 10 minutes of walk from the Skulpturenpark, where you can leave your car.
Absolutely beautiful village in the mountains, with classic 19th century architecture.

Name: Flemish Béguinages
short_description: The Béguines were women who dedicated their lives to God without retiring from the world. In the 13th century they founded the béguinages , enclosed communities designed to meet their spiritual and material needs. The Flemish béguinages are architectural ensembles composed of houses, churches, ancillary buildings and green spaces, with a layout of either urban or rural origin and built in styles specific to the Flemish cultural region. They are a fascinating reminder of the tradition of the Béguines that developed in north-western Europe in the Middle Ages.

reviews.text: Calm, serene and silent. Once home to the beguines and women who were less privileged, now this UNESCO heritage site hosts nuns. Great place to just take a walk and introspect!

You are able to walk around the grounds of this Beguinage - which happens to also be a UNESCO World Heritage Site. It is just asked that you are quiet and do not walk on the grass. Lovely white buildings adorn the perimeter and then there is the church where they run services.

A coven of women who emancipated and lived in solitude amongst themselves. The beautiful white house still lodge women of Bruges to this day. The house are all lined around a beautiful garden. There are signs everywhere to keep silence and be respectful.

Such a quiet place ! I went there with a friend because my mom recommended to, we appreciated walking there. It's free, there's some explanation at the entrance, I didn't know about this place before so I'm glad for having been there. There's not a lot of noises, just nature and silent walking. It was great !
(and there are ducks and goose next to it !!!)
Nice to walk around and enjoy the quiet, beautiful unique artictecture and courtyard.

Name: The Four Lifts on the Canal du Centre and their Environs, La Louvière and Le Roeulx (Hainaut)
short_description: The four hydraulic boat-lifts on this short stretch of the historic Canal du Centre are industrial monuments of the highest quality. Together with the canal itself and its associated structures, they constitute a remarkably well-preserved and complete example of a late-19th-century industrial landscape. Of the eight hydraulic boat-lifts built at the end of the 19th and beginning of the 20th century, the only ones in the world which still exist in their original working condition are these four lifts on the Canal du Centre.
formatted_address: Rue du Port de Plaisance 1, 7070 Le Rœulx, Belgium

reviews.text:
We came by bike.

Lift No. 4 of the Old Canal du Centre is a remarkable piece of industrial heritage in Belgium. Built in the late 19th century, this hydraulic boat lift is part of a UNESCO-listed series of lifts designed to navigate a 66-meter elevation difference.
Amazing place of engineering heritage. Both the hundreds year old infrastructure and the impressive modern day construction. Pleasant walk along the channel. Take your family there for a stroll!

Arrived on my boat went through the ecluse/lock and whilst we were waiting an engineer came on his bike to confirm details of our intentions and then invited us to see his machine room. What an experience the lifts work on water power such a wonderful 100 year old invention. The machinery was kept in immaculate condition. Well worth the visit.

beautiful place for whole family rest, parking is available near the harbour, can walk to Strépy-Thieu boat lift, can go up and see lift from upside, paths are very good for skating, bikes, scooters, silent place for long walkings, the lift is extraordinary
Amazing engineering construction. Worth to stop and visit. I would like to be on a boat and being lifted sometime.

Name: La Grand-Place, Brussels
short_description: La Grand-Place in Brussels is a remarkably homogeneous body of public and private buildings, dating mainly from the late 17th century. The architecture provides a vivid illustration of the level of social and cultural life of the period in this important political and commercial centre.

reviews.text: It's so beautiful, especially Brussels Town Hall! This building is full of Gothic architect, like Cologne Cathedral, it was built meticulously down to tiniest pieces. Wonderful!

Grote Markt/Grand Place draws lots of tourists. It's an impressive town square with some very attractive architecture. After dark, when it's lit up, it can feel a bit garish. Folks enjoy the town hall and other historical buildings to take pictures of and post them on Google maps ... There's lots of chocolate, waffles & street food, too.
Where did all the wealth to pay for these buildings come from?

This iconic spot is as grand as its name suggests! The Grand Place is truly stunning—majestic, royal, and full of charm. The intricate architecture and golden details are breathtaking, but when the lights and music come on, the atmosphere becomes absolutely surreal.

It’s a magical experience and undoubtedly a must-visit when in Brussels!
Great views surrounded with historical buildings and architecture. I recommend you to get a local tour guide so that they can explain to you all the histories hidden behind it.

This was part of our walking tour in Brussels. This square deserves it's fame. It's like an intricate tiara crafted in stone. Statuettes of merchants mix with gods and goddesses as they overlook one of the oldest market squares in Europe.

It's a quirky delight.

Name: Fuerte de Samaipata
short_description: The archaeological site of Samaipata consists of two parts: the hill with its many carvings, believed to have been the ceremonial centre of the old town (14th–16th centuries), and the area to the south of the hill, which formed the administrative and residential district. The huge sculptured rock, dominating the town below, is a unique testimony to pre-Hispanic traditions and beliefs, and has no parallel anywhere in the Americas.
formatted_address: Bolivia, Fort Samaipata, サマイパタの砦
