Cuenca's architecture, much of which dates from the 18th century, was 'modernized' in the economic prosperity of the 19th century as the city became a major exporter of quinine, straw hats and other products.
formatted_address: Centro histórico de Cuenca, Cuenca, Ecuador

Name: Bronze Age Burial Site of Sammallahdenmäki
short_description: This Bronze Age burial site features more than 30 granite burial cairns, providing a unique insight into the funerary practices and social and religious structures of northern Europe more than three millennia ago.

reviews.text:
Interesting and mysterious how prehistoric people handled their deceased. Signs provide good description, and there are paper maps as well. Bathroom on site is greatly appreciated.

I worry about the numerous logging activities though, one tree cut down was even used as a signpost. :(

It was a peaceful forest walk in a sunny spring day. 1.5h. Looking at the dozens of bronze age burial places. Guided by a super good guide Ulla. After the walk take a lunch at Kivikylä meat store restaurant. A stylish place.
Be aware you cant bring any trash to the forest. Stay on a road. Keep the Unesco sight clean.

Graves of kings, priests? Places of worship? Other purposes what the massive rock formations served as?

The area itself is very fascinating and historically interesting. But if you're not interested in ancient history at all, the rock formations aren't really anything else but mere piles of rocks to you.

What disappointed me most is that there are no single information desks in sight (except the on the parking lot). There should be more specific info desks spread around the area. After all, the site is UNESCO world heritage site!

If you are seeking pure nature, lonelyness and silence, you are at the right place... I was more or less by myself. Only 2 people crossed my way in an hour time - very recommandable to take a stop when you're around Rauma 🥰
Great ruins, but there are no signs around to help navigate the area. Remember to take pictures of the map and text by the entrance for a better experience.

Name: Jurisdiction of Saint-Emilion
short_description: Viticulture was introduced to this fertile region of Aquitaine by the Romans, and intensified in the Middle Ages. The Saint-Emilion area benefited from its location on the pilgrimage route to Santiago de Compostela and many churches, monasteries and hospices were built there from the 11th century onwards. It was granted the special status of a 'jurisdiction' during the period of English rule in the 12th century. It is an exceptional landscape devoted entirely to wine-growing, with many fine historic monuments in its towns and villages.

Name: Museumsinsel (Museum Island), Berlin
short_description: The museum as a social phenomenon owes its origins to the Age of Enlightenment in the 18th century. The five museums on the Museumsinsel in Berlin, built between 1824 and 1930, are the realization of a visionary project and show the evolution of approaches to museum design over the course of the 20th century. Each museum was designed so as to establish an organic connection with the art it houses. The importance of the museum's collections – which trace the development of civilizations throughout the ages – is enhanced by the urban and architectural quality of the buildings.

reviews.text: It’s truly a must visit place for every tourist coming to Berlin. On the another side of the Spree you can see groups enjoying Salsa on every evening in summers.
Berlin’s Museum Island, a UNESCO site, houses five iconic museums. Rich in art, history, and culture, it’s a must-visit for every traveler and history enthusiast.

There, many museums are located near each other. If you are interested in museums,  you may need one day for it. The most important one is which contains the iconic old Egyptian Nefertiti queen statue.

I have been living in berlin for a few months now and this place never stops to amaze me, in fact it’s my favourite place in berlin. Definitely worth a visit and i suggest just walking around in a sunny day (very rare lol) or during the night.

Soooo many museums

Perfecto if you love history or art

Name: Wartburg Castle
short_description: Wartburg Castle blends superbly into its forest surroundings and is in many ways 'the ideal castle'. Although it has retained some original sections from the feudal period, the form it acquired during the 19th-century reconstitution gives a good idea of what this fortress might have been at the height of its military and seigneurial power. It was during his exile at Wartburg Castle that Martin Luther translated the New Testament into German.

reviews.text:
Ancient castle with long amazing history.

I liked the fact that we were free outside the castle to wander around and enjoy the views.

If you want to visit inside the castle, book a tour ahead of time.

There is a shuttle (black car in one of the photos) that can take you up the hill to the castle.

Wartburg Castle near Eisenach, Getmany, is one of many beautiful castles you can visit and enjoy in Germany. Located on a hill close to a town this amazing and well preserved structure offers amazing views and tells many stories from the rich history of this region.

The castle was grand and the history important. Really glad that I took the tour! We walked there from Eisenach, and it was challenging!

The cafe on site served good food, reasonably priced. And the brats from the food truck were great, too.

10/10 experience, especially for a history buff.

Some logistical data:
there is parking at the top of the hill, it is however limited so make sure to arrive early in the day or later in the evening. Parking is also not that expensive. Depending on the vehicle you drive, it ranges between 2€ and 10€. But you could also park at the bottom and walk up. This will take a while, maybe like 30-45 minutes. Wither on the street or through the path in the woods.

Once parked, you can either walk up the rest of the hill (20-30 minutes), or you can take the bus or the taxi to the top. The bus runs on a schedule, and the taxi costs 3€ per person one-way.

At the castle: you can explore the grounds of the castle for free, but get access to the inside of the castle you need to pay. It ranges from 9€ to 13€ and has a tour included.
You can choose to do the guided your that takes about 2 hours or do a self guided tour. For the self guided tour, you get a little device that places different bits of information depending on the room you are in.

The grounds and the castle are breathtaking and definitely worth the trip. Plan a day or at least several hours for the visit, there's lots to see and the grounds are rather large. I can definitely see why Martin Luther decided to hide out here while he translated the bible.

Great experience. One of the walking routes was closed, so I got some extra KMs in that day, but the hike from the HBF was well worth the views! Walking through the woods to get there was a splendid bonus!

Name: Archaeological Sites of Mycenae and Tiryns
short_description: The archaeological sites of Mycenae and Tiryns are the imposing ruins of the two greatest cities of the Mycenaean civilization, which dominated the eastern Mediterranean world from the 15th to the 12th century B.C. and played a vital role in the development of classical Greek culture. These two cities are indissolubly linked to the Homeric epics, the Iliad and the Odyssey , which have influenced European art and literature for more than three millennia.

reviews.text: The ruins of Mycenae were quite disappointing, except for the museum and the Lion Gate. Almost nothing is left standing, making it hard to visualize the ancient city. I bought an audio guide but didn’t have time to listen to it fully, as too much had to be imagined. I recommend arriving in the morning, as visiting after lunch doesn’t leave enough time to explore before closing. Overall, it is an important historical site, but not as impressive as expected
Extraordinary place full of history and mythology, dating some 1,000 years before classical Greece in a superb setting. Beautiful museum. A must go when visiting the Peloponnese.

My visit to Mycenae was a great experience. The Lion Gate and the Cyclopean walls are impressive, and the "Treasury of Atreus" gave me a real sense of the importance of this ancient site. The museum offers useful information, and the view from the hill is stunning. Definitely worth a visit if you're into history and archaeology.
Just magical. Best to go when it is not the summer season. The views are spectacular and standing at the top of the palace complex you can almost see and hear the  Mycenaean civilization around you!

Just an absolute magnificent site of one of the oldest ruins in the world, with lots of history and mythological connections. Sure, there’s no more standing structures other than the tombs. But the view from the top! And imagining the ancient city from what’s left over is not hard to do. And the giant cyclops boulders. Absolutely incredible. An archaeologist’s dream.

Name: The Historic Centre (Chorá) with the Monastery of Saint-John the Theologian and the Cave of the Apocalypse on the Island of Pátmos
short_description: The small island of Pátmos in the Dodecanese is reputed to be where St John the Theologian wrote both his Gospel and the Apocalypse. A monastery dedicated to the ‘beloved disciple’ was founded there in the late 10th century and it has been a place of pilgrimage and Greek Orthodox learning ever since. The fine monastic complex dominates the island. The old settlement of Chorá, associated with it, contains many religious and secular buildings.

reviews.text: This was part of a half day tour. The views are beautiful. Church is beautiful. You have an opportunity to light a candle and say a prayer. You will need to get the candle when exiting the church and there is an area to light and say a prayer behind you after exiting. Lots of history. We did with a guide and she kept us informed of the history and such.
Superb, even though visitors are only allowed in a small section of the monastery.- walking in the footsteps of history.
It's a beautiful, peaceful and prayerful place. I recommend a visit if you are looking for spiritual rejuvenation.

A magnificent monastery built in 1088 sits high upon the hill overlooking Patmos.  The museum is the best place to understand its history.  The cave of St. John is not far and is the place where he wrote the book of revelations.  Photos are not allowed in the cave.

5* Beauty
5* Medieval Atmosphere
5* View
#NoAccessibility though

Amazingly beautiful and very well preserved castle and monastery with a fantastic view over Patmos town and harbour. To get here you have to cross the winding narrow streets of Chora town, sometimes with stairs. The final path to the monastery is made of stairs, and inside the monastery there are mainly small stairs to get around.
If you have a chance to walk around outside the walls of the monastery, you will feel the power of huge stones from which the castle is built, its height and majesty!

Name: Hortobágy National Park - the Puszta
short_description: The cultural landscape of the Hortobágy Puszta consists of a vast area of plains and wetlands in eastern Hungary. Traditional forms of land use, such as the grazing of domestic animals, have been present in this pastoral society for more than two millennia.

reviews.text:
Very interesting park and the surrounding area.
First of all, it is worth going to the information, where they will tell you what you can see and do in the area.

You can go down the river by boat or kayak, ride horses, visit two parks where you can admire animals, as well as places where animals are treated and, if possible, released.

Where you can see wolves, foxes, horses, buffaloes and countless birds.
Very different park, vast plains, beautiful swamp areas, and lakes to hike and bike around

Wonderfull place to visit in Hungary. Such a lot of wide open space wit fantastic wildlife and a great sense of space. Watching the horsemen working with the horses, including standing on the backs of two at a time, is pretty spectacular and world famous. I had a little ride on just the one and I was sitting down, not standing on it's back! But i still felt pretty spectacular and got some photos to prove it! I recommend a visit.
Fantastic place to visit with family and friends. Lots to see and do and definitely book for the horse drawn tour of the Great plain 😢
beautiful NP with a big variety of animals from reptiles such as pond turtules to birds such as burrowing owls. I recommend visting it very much

Name: Mountain Railways of India
short_description: This site includes three railways. The Darjeeling Himalayan Railway was the first, and is still the most outstanding, example of a hill passenger railway. Opened in 1881, its design applies bold and ingenious engineering solutions to the problem of establishing an effective rail link across a mountainous terrain of great beauty. The construction of the Nilgiri Mountain Railway, a 46-km long metre-gauge single-track railway in Tamil Nadu State was first proposed in 1854, but due to the difficulty of the mountainous location the work only started in 1891 and was completed in 1908. This railway, scaling an elevation of 326 m to 2,203 m, represented the latest technology of the time. The Kalka Shimla Railway, a 96-km long, single track working rail link built in the mid-19th century to provide a service to the highland town of Shimla is emblematic of the technical and material efforts to disenclave mountain populations through the railway. All three railways are still fully operational.
formatted_address: Rajeev Gandhi Circle, Mysuru - Ooty Rd, Kathadimattam, Ooty, Tamil Nadu 643001, India

reviews.text: On arrival I felt a little bit disappointed as there didn’t seem to be much of the old Ooty left. But after a few days of exploring you can still find some of the old Ooty and the town grew on me in the end.

Udagamandalam AKA Ooty is called queen of hills. Its in Nilgiri mountain and cold climate for ennoy mountain view, so many tea estates, Tea factories and gardens. But Now the places are very crowded. Many roads are less width and congested. Plastic water and other drinking bottles banned in ooty. So dont bring any bottles. Soft drinks are CAN only. Water is big bottles only.

Udagmandlam Railway Station, often known as Ooty Railway Station, is renowned for its picturesque setting and historical charm. Situated in the Nilgiri Hills, it offers a unique blend of colonial architecture and scenic beauty.

Udagamandalam, commonly known as Ooty railway station, exudes a charming old-world ambiance. This small but picturesque station serves as either the terminus or the starting point for the famous British-era toy train. The station itself is a delightful throwback to a old era, with its quaint architecture and serene surroundings.

The toy train journey from Ooty is a must-experience for anyone visiting the region. This historic train ride takes you through lush landscapes and rolling hills, offering breathtaking views and a unique glimpse into the region's colonial past. Whether you're starting your journey from Ooty or arriving there, the experience is bound to be memorable.

Overall, Ooty railway station and the toy train ride are integral parts of the region's charm, providing a nostalgic and scenic experience that should not be missed.

First of all those guys who are planning to ooty trip must check the tickets to the toy train before 2 months at most because on site tickets are less if you are travelling from mysuru or else any place

Take tickets from UAM to Coonor It is better to get tickets before 1 month or else go to the station in the early morning at 5 am so you can get the tickets to train off on that day.

Name: Lorentz National Park
short_description: Lorentz National Park (2.35 million ha) is the largest protected area in South-East Asia. It is the only protected area in the world to incorporate a continuous, intact transect from snowcap to tropical marine environment, including extensive lowland wetlands. Located at the meeting-point of two colliding continental plates, the area has a complex geology with ongoing mountain formation as well as major sculpting by glaciation. The area also contains fossil sites which provide evidence of the evolution of life on New Guinea, a high level of endemism and the highest level of biodiversity in the region.

reviews.text: Lorentz National Park is the largest national park in Southeast Asia. One of beautiful national park I’ve been seen. It’s only 40 minutes from Wamena City by 4WD car. You can rent the 4WD around 2.5-3 millions rupiah for oneday trip. Highly recommended!

Lorentz National Park is a stunning UNESCO World Heritage Site located in the Indonesian province of Papua. It covers a vast area of almost 2.4 million hectares, making it one of the largest national parks in Southeast Asia. The park is home to a wide range of flora and fauna, including some of the rarest and most exotic species in the world. Visitors to Lorentz National Park can expect to be awed by the park's towering mountain peaks, breathtaking waterfalls, and crystal-clear rivers. The park is also home to several indigenous communities who have lived in harmony with the natural environment for centuries.

The diversity of the natural landscape in Lorentz National Park is truly remarkable. Visitors can explore dense tropical rainforests, majestic mountain ranges, and vast wetlands, all in one place. The park is home to a wide range of endemic plant species, including orchids, carnivorous plants, and the famous Rafflesia flower. Wildlife enthusiasts will also be impressed by the park's rich animal life, which includes tree kangaroos, cassowaries, and several species of bird of paradise. Visitors can explore the park's various hiking trails, which offer stunning views of the surrounding mountains and valleys.

Lorentz National Park is a unique destination that offers visitors an opportunity to experience the natural beauty of Papua in all its glory. The park's conservation efforts have helped to preserve this unique ecosystem for generations to come. Visitors to the park are reminded to respect the local culture and traditions of the indigenous communities who call Lorentz National Park their home. Whether you're a nature enthusiast, a wildlife lover, or simply looking for a peaceful escape from the hustle and bustle of city life, Lorentz National Park is the perfect destination for you.

Lorentz National Park is located in Papua, Indonesia formerly known as Irian Jaya (western New Guinea). With an area of 25,056 km2 (9,674 mi2), it is the largest national park in South-East Asia. In 1999 Lorentz was declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO.

An outstanding example of the biodiversity of New Guinea, Lorentz is one of the most ecologically diverse national parks in the world. It is the only nature reserve in the Asia-Pacific region to contain a full altitudinal array of ecosystems ranging through marine areas, mangroves, tidal and freshwater swamp forest, lowland and montane rainforest, alpine tundra, and equatorial glaciers. At 4884 meters, Puncak Jaya (formerly Carstensz Pyramid) is the tallest mountain between the Himalayas and the Andes.

Birdlife International has called Lorentz Park “probably the single most important reserve in New Guinea”. It contains five of World Wildlife Fund's "Global 200" ecoregions: Southern New Guinea Lowland Forests; New Guinea Montane Forests; New Guinea Central Range Subalpine Grasslands; New Guinea Mangroves; and New Guinea Rivers and Streams.

Lorentz Park contains many unmapped and unexplored areas, and is certain to contain many species of plants and animals as yet unknown to Western science. Local communities' ethnobotanical and ethnozoological knowledge of the Lorentz biota is also very poorly documented.

The park is named for Hendrikus Albertus Lorentz, a Dutch explorer who passed through the area on his 1909–10 expedition.
You should come and see for yourself. Highly recommend
Best tropical National Park in the world

Name: Villa Adriana (Tivoli)
short_description: The Villa Adriana (at Tivoli, near Rome) is an exceptional complex of classical buildings created in the 2nd century A.D. by the Roman emperor Hadrian. It combines the best elements of the architectural heritage of Egypt, Greece and Rome in the form of an 'ideal city'.
formatted_address: Largo Marguerite Yourcenar, 1, 00010 Tivoli RM, Italy

reviews.text: Such an underrated attraction that should be so better known and visited! This is a top attraction for anyone interested in the Roman period. More than a villa, it feels like a city! Totally recommended, a must see if in Tivoli. Very comfortable parking area just outside the main gate. No waiting to buy tickets. A five-star experience.

Great roman villa complex of Hadrian. Some buildings are really impressive. Some parts are not in good condition any more but still you can understand the overall structure of the villa. The parking lot is large and reasonably priced (3€/day). Be prepared to spend two hours and walk outside a few kilometers.

During our recent visit to Italy, we visited here and walked the entire property. (Wear comfortable shoes). Simply amazing. The history, architecture and grounds were just breathtaking. Well maintained and safe paths to cover as you move about. Far less people than say in more popular touristy areas of Centro Roma. Which yes we toured as well. But the elevation here is cooler temps and lots of trees and shade so you can take your time, sit and relax and take it all in. Highly recommended!!!

Easy to access by car and the parking lot is big. Probably not some place to visit for first time Rome visitors. But if you are into archeology and history, then this place is still worth a visit. Information plates are in front of all major sites and you can check the info. A small indoor area exhibits orginal sculptures. The place is quite empty with very few visitors around. No need to buy tickets in advance.

One of the best archeological sites outside of Rome. So much to see and you get a true sense of the grandeur of the place. Only negative is,  when we visited in October there was no cafe or food/drinks available,  except for  vending machines (cash only)  located on the right in a wooden hut at the top of the hill, just before you enter the main entrance to the villa. Last time we came in July we saw a mobile catering van, serving food and drinks. So it's best to take a snack and water just incase.

Name: Shrines and Temples of Nikko
short_description: The shrines and temples of Nikko, together with their natural surroundings, have for centuries been a sacred site known for its architectural and decorative masterpieces. They are closely associated with the history of the Tokugawa Shoguns.

reviews.text: Majestic,  spectacular,  marvelous,  there are just not enough words to describe the beautiful architecture for this world heritage.  The only downside is that the important buildings require the visitors to take off their shoes, and during winter, it's freezing as hell... u may either purchase the ticket upon arrival, or you may purchase it online and enter smoothly.

This is one of the best shrines we have seen while we are in Japan for 2 weeks! This beautiful complex is massive in size and it takes hours to get through it all! It is so beautiful with all the gorgeous Landscaping! All the architectures just amazing how they build everything and it is so well preserved! I was just taking pictures Non-Stop and I can't even post everything that we saw! I would simply love to go back here and see this again because there has to be a lot of statues and artifacts that we probably missed!

Amazing world heritage with rich cultural and historical value. However, the security is quite disrespectful and impertinent. Overall, a sacred place, worth the visit! The entire tour includes the mountain takes about 30-45 minutes, and a lot of stairs. Nice decoration on the ceiling and roof, the sleeping cat is also famous above a gate.

Not much to review at this temple—unless you’re a fan of peace, silence, and an abundance of spiritual energy. It’s the kind of place where the only noise is the sound of your thoughts (and maybe the occasional bird). But hey, that’s kind of the point, right? Sometimes the best experiences are the ones that don’t require a review at all—just quiet reflection and a lot of inner zen!

Amazingly built shrine and surrounding landscapes. Very popular with the tourists. To enter the shrine, you have to buy a ticket. It is about 3 hours from Tokyo. You have to go to the Shinjuku bus terminal on the 4th floor to purchase your ticket. You can also buy it in advance and select your seats.

Name: Historic Fortified Town of Campeche
short_description: Campeche is a typical example of a harbour town from the Spanish colonial period in the New World. The historic centre has kept its outer walls and system of fortifications, designed to defend this Caribbean port against attacks from the sea.
formatted_address: Centro Histórico, 24000 San Francisco de Campeche, Camp., Mexico

reviews.text: Lots of lovely old buildings painted yellow, pink, blue and green. Very walkable and includes many sights and restaurants.
Very chill and great for families. The city is peaceful, colourful and authentic. I also recommend to visit Edzna which is 1h away by colectivo ! A weekend in Campeche is always relaxing :)
This City is very lovely. The old City is the most beautiful place we visited. Colored houses, small street, the sea. I advise a stop by

A gorgeous historic city! The historic center is really a gem. Well kept up, clean and restored, its really a pleasure to behold, just not at midday because it is hot as Hades so you'll want to tuck yourself into one of the restaurants or watering holes that, luckily abound in the city.
Love this historical town!

Name: Archaeological Monuments Zone of Xochicalco
short_description: Xochicalco is an exceptionally well-preserved example of a fortified political, religious and commercial centre from the troubled period of 650–900 that followed the break-up of the great Mesoamerican states such as Teotihuacan, Monte Albán, Palenque and Tikal.
formatted_address: Carretera Federal Xochicalco, Tetlama S/N, 62609 Miacatlán, Mor., Mexico

reviews.text:
Must see. Very impressive archeological site.

So much to see and explore, if you find yourself in Cuernavaca this along with the historic downtown are a must visit.

Lot of sloped walking, not really wheelchair accessible.

Highly recommended.

You have no idea what awaits you here. Yes, getting to Xochicalco isn’t exactly easy, but trust me—it’s absolutely worth it!

The museum is quite large and packed with fascinating artifacts. The locals here clearly loved shells and starfish—so many were found! Some of the starfish sculptures even look like car wheel covers. 😆

Alongside the usual small figurines and ceramics typical of central Mexico, there are some unique pieces I’ve never seen anywhere else—like a crescent moon with its horns facing up, a ceremonial crown, and what appears to be sculpted ceremonial attire. There’s also a model of Ehecatl’s temple pyramid.

Entrance to both the museum and the pyramids is 100 pesos, and you can pay by card. A win!

By the way, the museum is about a kilometer away from the main archaeological site, and the path is uphill—if you can, drive up instead of walking.

Now, about Xochicalco itself—where do I even begin? Is it the breathtaking view from the mountain, stretching across the valley from edge to edge? The mirror-like lake? The distant towns? The rugged peaks? Truly stunning. Eagles soar overhead, adding to the dramatic scenery.

Climbing the monuments is no longer allowed, though some structures, like the Temple of Quetzalcoatl, are partially accessible. This temple has unique panels with incredibly high relief carvings that are beautifully preserved—you can see every detail.

We kept wandering through the ruins, and they just never seemed to end. Temples, pyramids, overgrown paths, piles of stones with trees growing on them, a ball court with two preserved stands, and in the center, two rings still in place for the game. I could go on and on, but just trust me—this place is worth it.

Xochicalco is way more impressive than Templo Mayor, and I’d rank it right after Teotihuacan—maybe even on par with it. The site is peaceful, with no noise, no pushy vendors, and barely any other visitors.

Highly recommended! Just a heads-up—if you plan to visit Cuernavaca and Xochicalco in one day, be prepared for a fast-paced trip and an early start. While they look close on the map, driving through the mountains isn’t quick, especially on the way back to Mexico City. Splitting the trip into two days would be ideal.

But let’s be honest—the real highlight isn’t the museum (as great as it is) but the archaeological site itself!

One of the greatest archeological sites in central México, built atop a mountain, it's huge size and sheer magnitude will blow you away , also the Feathered serpent pyramid is an absolute must see

it is said that Ce acatl Quetzalcoatl reformed the calendars while living here , and depending on your sources, something truly magical dwells here

don't miss it if near Cuernavaca as it's just 40 minutes away
This is an amazing archaeological site. Very well maintained with lots of interesting things to see. Highly recommended.
Some of the best reserved ruins I’ve ever visited. The Quetzalcoatl temple at the top was breathtaking. Amazing expressive and with the hike

Name: Droogmakerij de Beemster (Beemster Polder)
short_description: The Beemster Polder, dating from the early 17th century, is is an exceptional example of reclaimed land in the Netherlands. It has preserved intact its well-ordered landscape of fields, roads, canals, dykes and settlements, laid out in accordance with classical and Renaissance planning principles.

Name: Sukur Cultural Landscape
short_description: The Sukur Cultural Landscape, with the Palace of the Hidi (Chief) on a hill dominating the villages below, the terraced fields and their sacred symbols, and the extensive remains of a former flourishing iron industry, is a remarkably intact physical expression of a society and its spiritual and material culture.

reviews.text: A hidden gem in the Mandara Mountains, the kingdom of Sukur is a breathtaking place to experience with so much history and preservation. The climb up the 1050m top wasn’t easy, took about 2hrs from the foot of the mountain, thanks to carefully placed footpaths that guided you up. November was cold up there so enjoyed the weather. The people are so welcoming and helpful and are intrigued by you as you are with them. It’s a trip of a lifetime and one to be in every travelers bucket list.
The best place for indegineus cultural heritage  of southern Borno and Northern Adamawa

Sukur is a Cultural Landscape in Nigeria.
According to Wikipedia Sukur or Sukur Cultural Landscape is a UNESCO World Heritage Site located on a hill above the village of Sukur in the Adamawa State of Nigeria. It is situated in the Mandara Mountains, close to the border with Cameroon. Its UNESCO inscription is based on the cultural heritage, material culture, and the naturally-terraced fields. Sukur is Africa's first cultural landscape to receive World Heritage List inscription
Great ancient tradition that was preserved for more than 600years
kitocoLeYor

Name: Historic City of Vigan
short_description: Established in the 16th century, Vigan is the best-preserved example of a planned Spanish colonial town in Asia. Its architecture reflects the coming together of cultural elements from elsewhere in the Philippines, from China and from Europe, resulting in a culture and townscape that have no parallel anywhere in East and South-East Asia.
formatted_address: H9CQ+FFP, Crisologo, Vigan City, Ilocos Sur, Philippines

reviews.text: 4 hours ride if you're from Baguio city. This is a must go place if you're into historic shiz. Although some of the walls were covered with cement making it look modernized (even some of the houses don't look old anymore) Still a good place to take pictures and buy souvenirs

The Vigan Heritage Site is a UNESCO world heritage site.
The structure dates back perhaps from the 17th century Spanish colonial era.

A living history museum that showcases the lifestyle and culture of the Ilocano people during the Spanish colonial period. Streets are lined with well-preserved Spanish colonial houses, shops, and restaurants. It offers a better look at night and is bustling with tourists and horse carts. Awesome experience, really felt authentic (and it was!)

A street turned to museum, the other streets have old houses too but this particular street has really preserved its long strip. Tourists flock here and aside from the heritage houses, you can also find restaurants and souvenir shops here. This is the gem of Ilocos Norte.

Travel back in time and be in the Spanish era, when streets are made of cobbled stones and windows are made of capiz shells. The place invokes sentimental emotions, as it echoes days of a distant past. I do hope they remove all stores and signages there and make it a real heritage village. That will preserve it longer for future generations.

Name: Puerto-Princesa Subterranean River National Park
short_description: This park features a spectacular limestone karst landscape with an underground river. One of the river's distinguishing features is that it emerges directly into the sea, and its lower portion is subject to tidal influences. The area also represents a significant habitat for biodiversity conservation. The site contains a full 'mountain-to-sea' ecosystem and has some of the most important forests in Asia.

reviews.text:
Spectacular views driving, sailing and in the caves itself. Monkeys and monitor reptiles can be seen. Be careful and do not try to pet or feed them.
Highly recommend to book a private trip to the caves with a driver/tour guide and take the trip early in the morning. This way it is less crowded, busy and noisy.
Staff is polite but tired of the crowds. They really do their best but there are just too many people.

Our family recently visited the Subterranean River in Palawan, and it was an unforgettable experience that highlighted the importance of environmental conservation. From the moment we arrived, we were captivated by the stunning landscape of lush greenery and towering limestone cliffs. The boat ride to the cave entrance was filled with the sounds of nature, making us feel connected to the environment. Our knowledgeable guides passionately shared insights about the ecosystem and the need to protect this unique habitat, which was both educational and inspiring for our children.

Inside the cave, we marveled at the breathtaking rock formations and the serene beauty of the subterranean river. The reflections on the water and the impressive stalactites and stalagmites left us in awe. It was a wonderful opportunity for our family to bond while learning about geology and the importance of sustainability.

What stood out most was the eco-friendly approach to tourism; the careful management of the site ensures its preservation for future generations. Knowing that our visit contributed to conservation efforts made the experience even more meaningful.
Overall, the Subterranean River is a must-visit for families, offering a perfect blend of adventure, education, and appreciation for nature. We left feeling inspired to advocate for environmental conservation and cherish the natural beauty of our world. This experience will stay with us for years to come!

Brilliant! But DON’T prebook it.
Tour groups get held up and delayed by cruise ships etc.
we just turned up and got our own boat which had multiple advantages - no queues, asked to stop at the zipline on the way back - and cost the same as a shared boat.
You will share a boat when you get to the underground river anyway- it’s about 20min trip to get there - and it’s awesome in side. The audio is mandatory and well worth it. It adds to the experience that everyone is quiet and listening to the narration, plus it’s interesting and you have all the formation pointed out.
And we saw monkeys and monitor lizards as we walked across to the river.
Highly recommended!!!

Highly recommended!! It is unbelievable to see and to hear how nature can still surprise us - this place has been discovered only couple of decades ago!! Maybe not the best place if you are claustrophobic or overly heavy (it simply might be uncomfortable for you, no harsh feelings). But if you love to connect with nature, escape the busy world for couple of hours, you should definitely give it a go! Overall score: 5 stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

Thankfull we got out on this trip, low pressure coming in caused the boats to be cancelled the day before. We waited at the docking bay for around 2 hours for our turn to get a boat to cross part of the sea to the beach to the cave. This area is very well maintained. The audio guide provided in 13 different languages really adds to the experience. Very beautiful and informative journey. The boat guys do an amazing job getting everyone safely on and off the boats in the choppy waves. There is no dry dock, you hop off the boat into the sea and depending on the waves will depend how wet you get lol wear shoes that can get wet and bring a change of clothes if you prefer to stay dry. I didn't bother changing in the end. We took the opportunity and went zip lining too while visiting, great day out. Highly recommend.

Name: Kalwaria Zebrzydowska: the Mannerist Architectural and Park Landscape Complex and Pilgrimage Park
short_description: Kalwaria Zebrzydowska is a breathtaking cultural landscape of great spiritual significance. Its natural setting – in which a series of symbolic places of worship relating to the Passion of Jesus Christ and the life of the Virgin Mary was laid out at the beginning of the 17th century – has remained virtually unchanged. It is still today a place of pilgrimage.

reviews.text: Definitely worth a visit! You can see there is much care put into the church and grounds. A lively parish, with a large group attending a weekday noon mass.

Beautiful place with some fantastic views.
1. Try to visit when there is not a mass.
2. You can park along street all the way up to the top of Hill.
3. They have a main information window to the right of main entrance if you come up and enter from the bottom of the hill with statues above wall.
4. They also have tours at the information booth.
5. Remember to silence cell phone.
6. Bathroom is located directly behind (Rear entrance) in separate building in court yard. From rear entrance look to the right corner of courtyard you will see WC sign. Cost is 4 ZL cash and no credit card.

This chapel is an important stop for pilgrims to visit places important from the context of Pope John Paul II's life. On a hill, the view from the church lets you see miles into the beautiful landscape. The church built centuries ago is imposing and the frescos on the ceilings and walls are artistically done. There are showcases of the former Pope's visits and most of the content printed is in Polish. The confession boxes are wooden and interestingly crafted for privacy. The church premises are undergoing renovation and wheelchair and stroller accessibility can be better.

I had a very bad experience here. To start with, you have to pay for WC without (as they said) drinking water to refill. When we were trying to pray in church, the priests were vacuming the floor all the time and disturbed a lot. When I wanted to do confession, I was declined just because they didn’t speak english.
But I have to say the place is really beautiful.

Absolutely stunning place! Kalwaria Zebrzydowska park is a Mannerist architectural and park landscape complex plus a pilgrimage park, built in the 17th century as the Counter Reformation in the late 16th century led to prosperity in the creation of calvaries in Catholic Europe. The park was added in 1999 to the UNESCO list of World Heritage Sites. The site is also one of Poland's official national Historic Monuments (Pomnik historii) and tracked by the National Heritage Board of Poland.

This place is just mesmerising and you can fell something divine in the air, it’s truly a special place. They have also a some gastronomy there so you’ll never get hungry hah.

P.S. Read about a history and fix your purpose before you go there!

Name: Laurisilva of Madeira
short_description: The Laurisilva of Madeira is an outstanding relict of a previously widespread laurel forest type. It is the largest surviving area of laurel forest and is believed to be 90% primary forest. It contains a unique suite of plants and animals, including many endemic species such as the Madeiran long-toed pigeon.

reviews.text: The ride by car is beautiful. You should open your car’s windows to enjoy the smells. They’re some stops with ouf nic tables which are wonderful. You need to park your car next to souvenirs shop. The trails are starting there and not exactly at google point ping.

An amazing place covered with clouds.  Unfortunately, we couldn't spend much time in Madeira Natural Park because the weather was bad. We also went to a souvenir shop and bought some interesting things as a memento. It was really fun.  🤗
Madeira Island is magical. Must see
Big fan of the forest here ! Really in love with this waterfall ! For more picture on Instagram : eyesofbelga
The whole of Madeira is just stunning. Such a lovely clean and friendly place. So glad we went

Name: Historic Centre of Sighişoara
short_description: Founded by German craftsmen and merchants known as the Saxons of Transylvania, Sighişoara is a fine example of a small, fortified medieval town which played an important strategic and commercial role on the fringes of central Europe for several centuries.
formatted_address: Cetatea Sighișoara, Piața Cetății, Sighișoara 545400, Romania

Name: Wooden Churches of Maramureş
short_description: These eight churches are outstanding examples of a range of architectural solutions from different periods and areas. They show the variety of designs and craftsmanship adopted in these narrow, high, timber constructions with their characteristic tall, slim clock towers at the western end of the building, either single- or double-roofed and covered by shingles. As such, they are a particular vernacular expression of the cultural landscape of this mountainous area of northern Romania.

reviews.text: Beautiful antic wooden church (UNESCO protected) with XVI paintings. Opened Mon-Sat 9am-12pm and 1pm-5pm. Sun 1pm to 5pm. You have to call and someone will open for you: 744811899 -Entry fee: 6 Lei/ Adult and 3 Lei for kids.
Nice wooden church. Whole this area between Poienile Izei an Botiza is picturesque. Could be done by a MTB.

We tried to call the keeper twice. Once she hanged right away. Calling again, we explained in Romanian we were tourists at the church, she yelled at us something in Romanian and hanged again. Very rude behaviour, unlike other people we met in Maramures.

To reach this place you need to leave the main road behind. It's adorable small village surrounded by hills and meadows. The church is very spacious. I was expecting that the whole church will be covered with the scenes showing the hell but those paintings can be found only close the entryway (quite dark). Anyway, it is worth to visit.
Unfriendly key holder, but the church is nice.

Name: Dacian Fortresses of the Orastie Mountains
short_description: Built in the 1st centuries B.C. and A.D. under Dacian rule, these fortresses show an unusual fusion of military and religious architectural techniques and concepts from the classical world and the late European Iron Age. The six defensive works, the nucleus of the Dacian Kingdom, were conquered by the Romans at the beginning of the 2nd century A.D.; their extensive and well-preserved remains stand in spectacular natural surroundings and give a dramatic picture of a vigorous and innovative civilization.

reviews.text: Disappointed. Just a few stones and not so friendly. You are allowed to step on the grass but have been told of you line down on the grass 🤣🤣.
A very historical place for Romania. The dividing line between free and conquered Dacia. (Completely destroyed by the Romans) now restored to its former glory
It is the third time he visited this energetic, vibrant and ancient place. A lot of knowledge hidden in every corner. Grande Dacia and the Dacos.
This wonderful place is definitely worth a visit
The banks of the Sarmizegetusa Regia fortification, the most important political, military and religious center for the Dacian people. recommend

Name: Western Caucasus
short_description: The Western Caucasus, extending over 275,000 ha of the extreme western end of the Caucasus mountains and located 50 km north-east of the Black Sea, is one of the few large mountain areas of Europe that has not experienced significant human impact. Its subalpine and alpine pastures have only been grazed by wild animals, and its extensive tracts of undisturbed mountain forests, extending from the lowlands to the subalpine zone, are unique in Europe. The site has a great diversity of ecosystems, with important endemic plants and wildlife, and is the place of origin and reintroduction of the mountain subspecies of the European bison.

Name: Brimstone Hill Fortress National Park
short_description: Brimstone Hill Fortress National Park is an outstanding, well-preserved example of 17th- and 18th-century military architecture in a Caribbean context. Designed by the British and built by African slave labour, the fortress is testimony to European colonial expansion, the African slave trade and the emergence of new societies in the Caribbean.
formatted_address: Island Main Road, Sandy Point Town, St Kitts & Nevis

reviews.text:
This is a must-see destination on St Kitts. The fort and surrounding fortifications remain intact or are being restored and it must have been quite the impressive location and endeavor to build.
The museum has several informative exhibits in the buildings inside the main fortress and the views from the gun terrace are magnificent.
Be sure to check out the Artillery Officers quarters. No slumming it for them!
There is an introductory film shown in the building below the ramp to the fortress that is worth watching.
There are toilet facilities, a gift shop, handicapped parking and it looks like more facilities are in progress.
The road up is very narrow in parts and the gates are very tight, so be sure to use your horn to alert others coming up or down. It would be helpful to remind people of this as they pay to enter, although there are signs.

Well kept historical place with an interesting backstory. Spectacular scenery abounds at the top level of the fortress. Somewhat steep climb to get up to the lower level but it's not too bad. Great place to visit if you travel to St. Kitts

Went back to Brimstone  Hill Fortress National Park after many years.   Indeed, the rock of Gibraltar  of the Caribbean.  If you're a history buff and you're in St. Kitts then this a spot you should definitely  visit.  Please be sure to listen to the video briefing.  Lots of history!!!
Very impressive! Had a great time exploring the fortress and area. The views from the top are extraordinary. Please note… if you have mobility issues, this might not be for you.
Extremely interesting place. Not to hard to climb around. Give yourself at least 2 hours to tour all the grounds, about 1 hour for Fort

Name: iSimangaliso Wetland Park
short_description: The ongoing fluvial, marine and aeolian processes in the site have produced a variety of landforms, including coral reefs, long sandy beaches, coastal dunes, lake systems, swamps, and extensive reed and papyrus wetlands. The interplay of the park's environmental heterogeneity with major floods and coastal storms and a transitional geographic location between subtropical and tropical Africa has resulted in exceptional species diversity and ongoing speciation. The mosaic of landforms and habitat types creates breathtaking scenic vistas. The site contains critical habitats for a range of species from Africa's marine, wetland and savannah environments.

reviews.text: We took a boat tour with a group and saw several hippo families. The wetlands are beautiful. The guides were good.  Well worth the trip.

Nice park with massive lake in the middle. Great for relaxing drives and sun downer stops. We had a stunning stop for sundowners close by the lake. Make sure you don’t miss that. Probably most noteworthy is Cape Vidal as a point of interest in the park.

We recommend the boat cruise instead of the game drive. The park is massive and the game viewing is okay. Somewhat difficult to find animals other than Antilopes, zebra and small game or birds. Hence the boat ride might be more exciting for visitors with limited time at their hands.

It was quite rainy the day that we went but wow, wow, wow! We still saw some beautiful animals and even had elephants in the road (we had to wait about 2 hours until they went off tue road and we could pass). Truly magnificent to have the bush, wetland, and beach experience!

The views whiles driving through park, just  breathtaking! The sounds if animals, snakes as we passed the thick bushes on either side of the stretch of road. The climax was when we drove up to Cape Vidal beach! It just felt like we weren't in South Africa! We were in a foreign country. The mood is relaxed, not full despite the fact that it was Jan 1st 2025! The beach has no life guards, it's a beach to relax & have a picnic by the beach. Swimming is at one's own risk! We passed a few chalets and a camp site located within the wetlands. Driving through the park at the max speed of 50 in places 30 & in some places 20km/h took us roughly 2hrs. We enjoyed our drive & the scenery we don't have in Jhb

What an amazing private beach.
I will surely visit again.

Name: Fossil Hominid Sites of South Africa
short_description: The Taung Skull Fossil Site, part of the extension to the site inscribed in 1999, is the place where in 1924 the celebrated Taung Skull – a specimen of the species Australopithecus africanus – was found. Makapan Valley, also in the site, features in its many archaeological caves traces of human occupation and evolution dating back some 3.3 million years. The area contains essential elements that define the origin and evolution of humanity. Fossils found there have enabled the identification of several specimens of early hominids, more particularly of Paranthropus, dating back between 4.5 million and 2.5 million years, as well as evidence of the domestication of fire 1.8 million to 1 million years ago.

reviews.text:
This is an incredible conference venue. Stunning views, peace & tranquility.

We are looking forward to having our conference here next week.

The staff go above & beyond for the client effortlessly. I felt like royalty during my site visit.

Highly recommended for all your conference needs.

Very interesting exhibit that explains several humanoid species and how they came to be and end.  The exhibit is a bit oriented to a school trip, but does have in depth explanations.  A bit dark making it hard for us old folk to read all the text, but worthwhile nevertheless.
A very interesting visit to better understand the beginning and evolution of human kind. Do get a guide to accompany you during the tour, it’s much more worthy.
Great fun.  Unexpected boat ride that was fun. Museum was fun. Wish my company allowed me to read every exhibit.

interesting place for grown ups as well for children. Education for all ages how it all began. The environment around the museum is as well pretty and invites you for having a trip around. I recommend this before the weekend starts to avoid to many people.

Name: Robben Island
short_description: Robben Island was used at various times between the 17th and 20th centuries as a prison, a hospital for socially unacceptable groups and a military base. Its buildings, particularly those of the late 20th century such as the maximum security prison for political prisoners, witness the triumph of democracy and freedom over oppression and racism.

reviews.text: We took a boat ride to the island and then toured by bus with a guide who shared some historical insights, which was great. However, the part we were most looking forward to - the prison visit - was disappointing. Instead of a proper tour, we sat through a one-hour political speech from a former inmate, which felt unnecessary and even put some people to sleep. When it finally ended, we only visited three rooms of the prison, and some of the "facts" we were told turned out to be inaccurate. We would have loved to explore more of the site

What better way to understand living conditions on the infamous Robben Island than to hear it from an actual prisoner. Tours of the island are very thorough from the narrated Bus Tour of the island itself to the Prisoner guided section of the physical confines of the buildings. Bathroom breaks are before and after the tour. The ferry ride was smooth as pie. A break is provided for patrons during the bus tour. Picture opportunities are limited of the surrounding area on the bus tour but one location is setup for the Instagram tags. More pics can be taken of the prison premises during the guided tour. Guides are very knowledgeable and super friendly. As a part of the tour you will get a chance to see Mandela's cell. The Gift shop is located on the dock. Tickets can be purchased online or at the booth. Parking in available at paid garages on the V&A Waterfront.

Worthwhile and historically significant tour at a UNESCO world heritage site!

All-in tour took over 4 hours from showing up at meeting point to get on ferry until returning  to CapeTown waterfront.

Two phase on the tour: bus and walking tour. Really enjoyed the history provided by the wonderful tour guides.

Recommend highly as a learning experience for all ages. Unity for All.

Solid tourist experience, would recommend doing. BUT - be sure to budget a solid 5 hours and go on a clear/ not too windy day. Also bring cash to tip your guide and/or purchase anything on the island, as there were no credit card readers. The boat ride was honestly my favorite part, it was great to get such unique views of Table Mountain and the city from the water. The fact that actual former prisoners are tour guides there is baffling and makes it hit home a bit more. First part of the tour was a bit boring, as you are on a bus for a little over an hour and mostly viewing the village outside the prison. They talked a bit about Mandela, but I wish they spent more time on that history.
tremendous experience of seeing the jail where Nelson Mandela was for 17 years . a place also known for being the military base of the southern Africans in the second war .

Name: Ibiza, Biodiversity and Culture
short_description: Ibiza provides an excellent example of the interaction between the marine and coastal ecosystems. The dense prairies of oceanic Posidonia (seagrass), an important endemic species found only in the Mediterranean basin, contain and support a diversity of marine life. Ibiza preserves considerable evidence of its long history. The archaeological sites at Sa Caleta (settlement) and Puig des Molins (necropolis) testify to the important role played by the island in the Mediterranean economy in protohistory, particularly during the Phoenician-Carthaginian period. The fortified Upper Town (Alta Vila) is an outstanding example of Renaissance military architecture; it had a profound influence on the development of fortifications in the Spanish settlements of the New World.
formatted_address: Via Romana, 31, 07800 Eivissa, Illes Balears, Spain

reviews.text: Ive never left a google review but i was so impressed with my visit i felt the need to. Upon arrival we were greeted with air conditioning (which was highly needed and very appreciated) and very friendly staff. The actual museum itself is very clean, easy to understand and has a beautiful collection of Roman , Punic and Phoenician history. We took our time looking around but staff was always seconds away if we had any questions. Also wanted to mention that there are kids tables with colouring activities to keep little ones occupied, but the artefacts are interesting enough by themselves in my opinion. After we toured the inside of the museum, we headed outside to see the necropolis, but my favourite part had to be the underground section where you could climb down into and see the tombs. Heading back inside , we were greeted by the same lovely staff (who i forgot to mention speak great English) and not only did they call a taxi for us, they also provided us with water while we waited. The souvenirs here are some of the cheapest and nicest ive seen out of the European countries ive visited and there really is something for everyone. The staff also refused to take any sort of tip or donation. They seemed genuinely happy to do their job and have people enjoy and learn history. Ontop of everything else, it was all completely free. Its a real shame it was so empty (we were obviously grateful to have it all to ourselves though) because it really is worth visiting. It was a perfect way to end our week in ibiza and would highly recommend.
What an interesting place. Thoroughly enjoyed our visit. Amazing to learn that a lot of our funerary customs started centuries ago. Staff helpful and kind enough to explain. Well worth a visit.

Great and interesting little museum and archaeological site with very friendly staff and a nice museum shop. My girlfriend and I enjoyed our visit a lot and can definitely recommend a visit to people interested in history or archeology. Admission is free. The museum uses audio-visual exhibits and all signs are available in Spanish and English.

Very good organized museum, great hospitality. Follow the arrows to keep the narration, you will learn a lot about history of Ibiza and not only. Real skeletons,  you can enter most of the graves. Must see, and it's for free!

This was such a great museum, the staff was so friendly and helpful, and it is free! After watching a short video covering the basic history of the island (available in multiple languages), you can go upstairs in the museum to see the artifacts recovered from the burial site and go outside to see the excavated grounds. It was very interesting to see 3 different eras and people buried in the same grave, with separate preparations from the era and culture and to go underground to see the layout of the graves as well as see the shafts from above. Very interesting check-in with history while in Ibiza

Name: San Cristóbal de La Laguna
short_description: San Cristóbal de La Laguna, in the Canary Islands, has two nuclei: the original, unplanned Upper Town; and the Lower Town, the first ideal 'city-territory' laid out according to philosophical principles. Its wide streets and open spaces have a number of fine churches and public and private buildings dating from the 16th to the 18th century.
formatted_address: San Cristóbal de La Laguna, Santa Cruz de Tenerife, Spain

Name: State Historical and Cultural Park “Ancient Merv”
short_description: Merv is the oldest and best-preserved of the oasis-cities along the Silk Route in Central Asia. The remains in this vast oasis span 4,000 years of human history. A number of monuments are still visible, particularly from the last two millennia.

Name: Heart of Neolithic Orkney
short_description: The group of Neolithic monuments on Orkney consists of a large chambered tomb (Maes Howe), two ceremonial stone circles (the Stones of Stenness and the Ring of Brodgar) and a settlement (Skara Brae), together with a number of unexcavated burial, ceremonial and settlement sites. The group constitutes a major prehistoric cultural landscape which gives a graphic depiction of life in this remote archipelago in the far north of Scotland some 5,000 years ago.
Country name: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
formatted_address: Maeshowe, Visitor Centre, Ireland Rd, Stenness, Stromness KW16 3LB, UK

Name: Hoi An Ancient Town
short_description: Hoi An Ancient Town is an exceptionally well-preserved example of a South-East Asian trading port dating from the 15th to the 19th century. Its buildings and its street plan reflect the influences, both indigenous and foreign, that have combined to produce this unique heritage site.

Name: My Son Sanctuary
short_description: Between the 4th and 13th centuries a unique culture which owed its spiritual origins to Indian Hinduism developed on the coast of contemporary Viet Nam. This is graphically illustrated by the remains of a series of impressive tower-temples located in a dramatic site that was the religious and political capital of the Champa Kingdom for most of its existence.
formatted_address: Thánh địa Mỹ Sơn, Duy Xuyên District, Quảng Nam, Vietnam

reviews.text: My family and I came here to visit the beautiful Champs historical national park. We were enjoyed viewing many beautiful ancient concrete Champs buildings. We had a great time visiting this national park. The staffs were very helpful and professional. They do have a restaurant where you can enjoy dining champs authentic foods and gift shop inside the national park.

Absolutely incredible to see. There was a lot which had been rebuilt which is important to a degree so you can see the buildings grandeur but they have rebuilt everything a bit. Only one ruin hasn't been rebuilt a bit. Recommend going last thing of the day, we arrived for 3, but people were still allowed in up to 5pm. You'll want a couple of hours, not including transport there.

Very beautiful location in dense forests. The temple structures were very badly damaged when found. Has been partly restored with the help of the Archaeological Survey of India. Still excavation is going on. Worth a visit,

Beautiful spot. The smell of jasmine will blow your mind. It was flattened by the Americans in the Vietnam war  & has been rebuilt with the help of the Indian, French & German governments. A guide isn't needed but will give you more information about it's history. I  tagged along with a guide with a group & got it for free.

Visiting My Son Sanctuary in Vietnam is like stepping back in time. This UNESCO World Heritage site, nestled in a lush valley about an hour from Hoi An, showcases the incredible ruins of the Champa civilization, dating back over a thousand years.

The site is breathtaking, surrounded by misty mountains and dense jungle, which adds to its mystical charm. The ancient Hindu temples, built between the 4th and 14th centuries, feature intricate carvings and impressive brickwork that have withstood the test of time. Despite some damage from war, many structures still stand, offering a glimpse into Vietnam’s rich history.

A guided tour is highly recommended to truly appreciate the historical and cultural significance of My Son. The knowledgeable guides provide fascinating insights into the architecture, religious symbolism, and the rise and fall of the Champa Kingdom.

For the best experience, visit early in the morning to avoid crowds and enjoy the serene atmosphere. The combination of history, nature, and cultural heritage makes My Son a must-visit destination for anyone exploring central Vietnam.

Name: Belfries of Belgium and France
short_description: Twenty-three belfries in the north of France and the belfry of Gembloux in Belgium were inscribed in 2005, as an extension to the 32 Belgian belfries inscribed in 1999 as Belfries of Flanders and Wallonia. Built between the 11th and 17th centuries, they showcase the Roman, Gothic, Renaissance and Baroque styles of architecture. They are highly significant tokens of the winning of civil liberties. While Italian, German and English towns mainly opted to build town halls, in part of north-western Europe, greater emphasis was placed on building belfries. Compared with the keep (symbol of the seigneurs) and the bell-tower (symbol of the Church), the belfry, the third tower in the urban landscape, symbolizes the power of the aldermen. Over the centuries, they came to represent the influence and wealth of the towns.

reviews.text: Nice town centre with historic buildings. The cathedral and surrounding buildings are very well kept. Nice bars and restaurants to enjoy too.
One of lives pleasures is sitting having a coffee and listening to the bells here.
Nice surrounding, just sit down and enjoy a Belgian beer and listen to the " beiaard "

In this busy student city, the market place offers a peaceful place to enjoy a coffee or meal in one of the many taverns. Statues, art, children's playground, lots of nice shops, something for everyone to enjoy

I believe this is St Martins Church adjacent to the Grote Market.
Kortrijk is quite a pleasant place and easy to walk around.  There is a lot of interesting architecture to admire in the area of the Grote Market and lots of places to eat and snack and watch the world go by.  I believe that the area has frequent antiques markets outdoors also.   The square also hosts live music and performances.  Worth checking beforehand whats on.

Name: Ischigualasto / Talampaya Natural Parks
short_description: These two contiguous parks, extending over 275,300 ha in the desert region on the western border of the Sierra Pampeanas of central Argentina, contain the most complete continental fossil record known from the Triassic Period (245-208 million years ago). Six geological formations in the parks contain fossils of a wide range of ancestors of mammals, dinosaurs and plants revealing the evolution of vertebrates and the nature of palaeo-environments in the Triassic Period.

reviews.text: My friends and I went on a road trip from CABA to Talampaya. We bought an entrance and an excursion on a mini van to go inside the park. It looks like Mars on Earth. Resembles Petra, Jordan but is also very unique and charming in its own way. There were 5 stops and we also had a picnic with white wine and local snacks.

Beautiful landscape. Definitely worth a visit to see the gift from the mother nature.

However, for foreign tourist, the total cost including entrance ticket with a bus ride is about US$40. Visitors are restricted to 4 stop points inside the park and  following a park guide.

Basically all is fine, but not justified for a 2 hours 15 minutes visit inside the park for paying US$40!! Visitors should allow to stay longer and more stop points.
Must see national park in Argentina, with impressive canyon and cathedral like erosion-made stone shapes

This off the beaten, in the middle of nowhere Nacional Parc is certainly worth a visit! Beautifull rock formations, bright colors,  and interesting history explained by professional guids. During the tour they also provide cold water and a little snack. Our tourguide Nadia was very friendly and open for question. They don't speak English here.

Wow, just wow! This experience was so much fun for us.

I have to be honest, it didn’t start off amazing. The host was a bit cold to me (an English speaker) and the bus was a bit stinky but once we got over that, we had a phenomenal trip. Our host warmed up, the places we were shown were beautiful (and so was the knowledge!) we enjoyed the snacks they provided during our excursion, which even included alcohol to our surprise! The only negative thing? As a tourist (AMERICAN) I paid 3 x’s the amount to enter the park than locals but they only have some of the plaques with English. In order to understand everything, my partner had to translate for me.  But overall, super impressed.

We paid $8000 pesos each for the excursion plus the park entrance fees ($20,000 total).

You CANNOT fly a drone here without obtaining a permit from the government. (This can be easily done with you permit from the USA but needs to be done before hand).

They do not offer sunrise or sunset tours because of the predators in the area.

photos taken by @alejandroseveriniph

Name: Jesuit Block and Estancias of Córdoba
short_description: The Jesuit Block in Córdoba, heart of the former Jesuit Province of Paraguay, contains the core buildings of the Jesuit system: the university, the church and residence of the Society of Jesus, and the college. Along with the five estancias, or farming estates, they contain religious and secular buildings, which illustrate the unique religious, social, and economic experiment carried out in the world for a period of over 150 years in the 17th and 18th centuries.

reviews.text: A very knowledgeable and friendly tour guide that urges you to ask questions of your own interest. Our tour lasted about an hour. It is advisable to understand spanish if taking the tour, even without the information it is still a beautiful place.
One of the best estancias (World Heritage Sites)  Amazing back story of Jesuit industry and evangelization

Only the church is open, and only for guided tours. Church is very well maintained and interesting, considering how old it is.
The property is owned privately. Long dirt road to get here.
A really beautiful and relaxing place to visit and learn about a fascinating part of Argentina's history.
Very isolated, beautiful location and wonderful history. Thoroughly enjoyed the tour. Had a wonderful meal at the Rancho, prepared and hosted by Sebastian.

Name: Monastery of Geghard and the Upper Azat Valley
short_description: The monastery of Geghard contains a number of churches and tombs, most of them cut into the rock, which illustrate the very peak of Armenian medieval architecture. The complex of medieval buildings is set into a landscape of great natural beauty, surrounded by towering cliffs at the entrance to the Azat Valley.

reviews.text: Beautiful architecture and view from the temple. Since the temple is on a mountain, the drive and the view is beautiful. Once inside the temple, its a completely different feel. Its so quiet and religious, with option of lighting a candle. Small lake also flows by inside this temple and it makes the whole ambiance so divine.

Geghard Monastery is perched on the edge of a mountain, is a breathtaking architectural masterpiece. Its remarkable construction, seamlessly integrated with the cliff, gives the impression that it emerges directly from the mountain itself a truly inspiring sight.

The structure, composed of multiple buildings connected by beautifully arched doorways, showcases intricate carvings & detailed masonry that have stood the test of time. The craftsmanship of the arches & wall carvings reflects an extraordinary level of skill & dedication, leaving one in awe of how such detailed work was achieved in ancient times.

The fusion of natural & man made elements, coupled with the sheer resilience of the structure, makes this site an unforgettable experience. It’s a must visit for architecture enthusiasts & anyone who appreciates the wonders of ancient ingenuity.
What a monastery, beautiful covered in snow and magical in summer. A gorgeous site to visit in all different parts of the year. Lovely women selling traditional sweets all around.

Beautiful place, when we went they had a wedding there so we could not go inside to see everything but the place was very nice and peaceful. The caves looked interesting.

We heard a guide sing there since the acoustics of the place is amazing it was a very nice experience

More than 1200 years old Monastery.
One of the unesco heritage site.
Great place.
Not a huge place.
You require 40 minutes to visit the whole place.
Lot of road side stalls to buy cheap bread and gifts.
Must visit place.

Name: Cathedral and Churches of Echmiatsin and the Archaeological Site of Zvartnots
short_description: The cathedral and churches of Echmiatsin and the archaeological remains at Zvartnots graphically illustrate the evolution and development of the Armenian central-domed cross-hall type of church, which exerted a profound influence on architectural and artistic development in the region.

reviews.text: Even with the scaffolding and not being able to enter the church the site is beautiful and worth a visit if in the area. It’s free to enter and seeing the ceiling of the frescoes at the main entrance is really quite stunning the restoration work is clearly very important and timely due to the intricacy of the work. Definitely impressive.

I was waiting for the renovation of the cathedral to be finished for many years already and I was happy to know that it was finally over and that it matched my visit to Armenia.

It is really beautiful and is worth visiting. Knowing that it is the oldest cathedral makes it extra special.

Most of the complex is now open (28th September 2024) and the restoration is coming to an end. Definitely worth visiting but I don't think it's worth paying for a day tour from Yerevan.

If you are staying in Yerevan it's very easy to get here. Take minibus 203 from the main street (download Yandex for bus routes). Start of the bus route is on the main street by Matenadaran
Մատենադարան ( 40.1903684, 44.5205699).

There is a bus stop close by the entrance where the bus starts and terminates ( Vagharshapat Central Bus Station). If the bus is not fuhopfrom Yerevan you might need to hop onto another 203 at the yerevan bus station which will take you all the way. On the way back, the bus does not go into the bus station! Stops opposite bus station at the bus stop.

One way ticket in September was 300 amd which you pay just before you exit the vehicle at your final destination. When the minubus stops just hop on and take your seat.

You can explore the complex on your own instead of paying for an expensive tour for as listtle as 600amd. There are free toilets at the complex as well marked on google maps. You can find water fountain just before the cathedral on left, past the souvenir shop.
A wonderful experience even for non-religious people. The exhibition of the treasury is particularly worth the time.

Beautiful church, filled with history, lots of places to sit and contemplate the architecture, the park is filled with drinking water fountains, the church has been going threw a long and intensive renovation, the interior was closed off so we weren’t allowed in.

Name: Greater Blue Mountains Area
short_description: The Greater Blue Mountains Area consists of 1.03 million ha of sandstone plateaux, escarpments and gorges dominated by temperate eucalypt forest. The site, comprised of eight protected areas, is noted for its representation of the evolutionary adaptation and diversification of the eucalypts in post-Gondwana isolation on the Australian continent. Ninety-one eucalypt taxa occur within the Greater Blue Mountains Area which is also outstanding for its exceptional expression of the structural and ecological diversity of the eucalypts associated with its wide range of habitats. The site provides significant representation of Australia's biodiversity with ten percent of the vascular flora as well as significant numbers of rare or threatened species, including endemic and evolutionary relict species, such as the Wollemi pine, which have persisted in highly-restricted microsites.

reviews.text:
A Breathtaking Escape into Nature

⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

Blue Mountains National Park is nothing short of a natural wonder! From the moment you enter, you're greeted by stunning vistas and the serene sounds of nature. The iconic Three Sisters rock formation is a must-see, offering breathtaking views that leave you in awe.

The hiking trails cater to all skill levels, with options ranging from leisurely walks to challenging hikes that lead to hidden waterfalls and lush forests. Each step reveals the park's rich biodiversity, with unique flora and fauna around every corner.

Don’t miss out on the scenic viewpoints—each one offers a new perspective of the dramatic landscapes. The park's well-maintained facilities make it easy to enjoy a full day of exploration. Whether you're an avid hiker, a photography enthusiast, or just looking for a peaceful retreat, Blue Mountains National Park has it all.

Plan your visit; you won't regret it!

A must-visit when in Sydney! I'd recommend spending a few days in the Blue Mountains. There are many accommodation options available around the Blue Mountains area.

If you opt to stay in central Sydney, expect a 2 hour drive at minimum per trip. I suggest starting the day early to make the most out of it. There are various lookouts with terrains of different difficulty level. Do Google and research prior to going. Some are not wheelchair-friendly.

Do remember to put on sunscreen if you are visiting in the summer. Hats, sunglasses and insect repellent are highly recommended especially if you have young kids. Wear comfortable shoes as there will be a lot of walking, climbing up and down the steps and walking on uneven surfaces. Do stock up on drinks and snacks/light bites as most places do not have shops. There are grocery markets and cafes/restaurants within the small towns though they do close early.

Check-out online if the places you intend to visit has a picnic area/waterfall area for a quick swim. Do be cautious of snakes and spiders as you are in the mountainous area.

Overall, the Blue Mountains is definitely an experience for all. We couldn't enjoy it enough and will definitely return again.

Absolutely stunning views and nature so close to Aurstralia's largest city. The region was initially exploited as a coal mining area and relics of that heritage can still be seen as you drive around the park. The name Blue Mountains arises from the natural emissions of the eucalyptus trees cladding the mountainside which scatter sunlight in such a way as to make them appear blue from a distance.

Beautiful scenery with small towns in between.  I stayed in the town of katoomba. Small antique shops, bars and restaurants are the main attractions in town. My hotel was in town with a complimentary full breakfast in the morning. The room was very modern with all the amenities, compared to the rest of the hotel that preserve that classic look. The hotel was at walking distance of restaurants, shops and a Cole's supermarket. Love the place

Honestly, I didn’t enjoy it as much because it rained that day. When it rains, the clouds block the view, so you can't see much. However, the trolley rides were fun, and the Dinosaur park was quite good. Unfortunately, I couldn’t experience the scenic views due to the weather.

Name: Wachau Cultural Landscape
short_description: The Wachau is a stretch of the Danube Valley between Melk and Krems, a landscape of high visual quality. It preserves in an intact and visible form many traces - in terms of architecture, (monasteries, castles, ruins), urban design, (towns and villages), and agricultural use, principally for the cultivation of vines - of its evolution since prehistoric times.

reviews.text: The wachau valley is beautiful and even in autumn. The vineyards are going golden and the sunlight on the steep sides is dramatic.

Serenity

Captured in the warmth of summer, this picturesque spot nestled along the Danube in Austria’s Wachau Valley offers a peaceful retreat. Lush green hills, charming riverside villages, and scenic views make it perfect for relaxation, walks, and unwinding.
