Nice central square with beautiful old buildings from different architectural periods (atleast so i think and so it looked like) and there's also a pretty gothic church

Name: Archaeological Ensemble of Tárraco
short_description: Tárraco (modern-day Tarragona) was a major administrative and mercantile city in Roman Spain and the centre of the Imperial cult for all the Iberian provinces. It was endowed with many fine buildings, and parts of these have been revealed in a series of exceptional excavations. Although most of the remains are fragmentary, many preserved beneath more recent buildings, they present a vivid picture of the grandeur of this Roman provincial capital.
formatted_address: Archaeological Ensemble of Tárraco, 43003 Tarragona, Spain

Name: Palmeral of Elche
short_description: The Palmeral of Elche, a landscape of groves of date palms, was formally laid out, with elaborate irrigation systems, at the time the Muslim city of Elche was erected, towards the end of the tenth century A.C., when much of the Iberian peninsula was Arab. The Palmeral is an oasis, a system for agrarian production in arid areas. It is also a unique example of Arab agricultural practices on the European continent. Cultivation of date palms in Elche is known at least since the Iberian times, dating around the fifth century B.C.
formatted_address: Passeig de l'Estació, s/n, 03202 Elx, Alicante, Spain

reviews.text: Really nice place to visit and you wouldn’t think you was right in the city as it’s so quiet and peaceful

It is a huge park in the city centre. Free entry. There is also playground for children. Very nice atmospheres,hive some time to sit down and enjoy the nature,air and these beautiful creatures. Good program with kids as well.

My last visit dates back when I was very young. Returning after many decades, the Palm Garden is impressive as ever. Lush palm trees, nice walkways and so peaceful be surrounded by century old trees. Nearby car park available.

Must. Visit. Place. Whole city is one of the greenest cities I've ever seen. Air is amazing, no pollutions, beautiful view, lots of places to walk around, chill out and hang out with people. One of the biggest if not biggest palm park in the world. The experience is really beyond unique. Must visit for everyone!

A wonderful park in the center of Elche! Very well-maintained and so beautiful! There's a park for kids, an area for live events, and lots of lovely landscaping. The tourist center is located just in front where you can acquire information about the free train tour that takes to around town. Super interesting and totally worth it!

Name: Roman Walls of Lugo
short_description: The walls of Lugo were built in the later part of the 3rd century to defend the Roman town of Lucus. The entire circuit survives intact and is the finest example of late Roman fortifications in western Europe.

reviews.text: Very picturesque walled city with an interesting mix of old and new buildings

Built in the 3rd century, this wall is a fascinating historical sight. It circles the old center of Lugo and has many exit staircases so you can quickly travel to different parts of the city. It's a pleasant walk to the cathedral and has spectacular views if the weather is nice.

UNESCO 🇪🇦Roman Walls of Lugo
The walls of Lugo were built in the later part of the 3rd century to defend the Roman town of Lucus. The entire circuit survives intact and is the finest example of late Roman fortifications in western Europe.

Roman Walls of Lugo, a city in the Autonomous Region of Galicia in north-western Spain, are an exceptional architectural, archaeological and constructive legacy of Roman engineering, dating from the 3rd and 4th centuries AD. The Walls are built of internal and external stone facings of slate with some granite, with a core filling of a conglomerate of slate slabs and worked stone pieces from Roman buildings, interlocked with lime mortar.

Their total length of 2117 m in the shape of an oblong rectangle occupies an area of 1.68 ha. Their height varies between 8 and 10 m, with a width of 4.2 m, reaching 7 m in some specific points. The walls still contain 85 external towers, 10 gates (five of which are original and five that were opened in modern times), four staircases and two ramps providing access to the walkway along the top of the walls, one of which is internal and the other external. Each tower contained access stairs leading from the intervallum to the wall walk of town wall, of which a total of 21 have been discovered to date.

The defences of Lugo are the most complete and best preserved example of Roman military architecture in the Western Roman Empire.

Despite the renovation work carried out, the walls conserve their original layout and the construction features associated with their defensive purpose, with walls, battlements, towers, fortifications, both modern and original gates and stairways, and a moat.

La Muralla dates back to the 3rd century.  Built by the Romans, it is mostly intact. The views on the wall aren't the greatest but walking this wall leaves anyone impressed with the labor of those who completed this construction so long ago. A must see Lugo.

The Roman walls that enclose the historical part of the city are super wide on top and you can stroll or even jog around them. I'm told that they it's three kilometers or so to get back to where you started but I'm yet to complete a full circuit!!

Name: Catalan Romanesque Churches of the Vall de Boí
short_description: The narrow Vall de Boí is situated in the high Pyrénées, in the Alta Ribagorça region and is surrounded by steep mountains. Each village in the valley contains a Romanesque church, and is surrounded by a pattern of enclosed fields. There are extensive seasonally-used grazing lands on the higher slopes.
formatted_address: Carretera de Taüll, 31, 25528 Boí, Lleida, Spain

reviews.text:
**Review of Sant Joan de Boí** 🌄

Hey there, traveler! If you’re looking for a charming getaway, Sant Joan de Boí is a hidden gem you won’t want to miss. Here’s why it’s so special:

- **Stunning Scenery** 🏞️: Nestled in the Pyrenees, the views here are breathtaking! Perfect for hiking, photography, or just soaking in the natural beauty.

- **Rich Heritage** 🏰: Don’t miss the Romanesque churches! They’re UNESCO World Heritage Sites and absolutely stunning. The architecture will leave you in awe.

- **Outdoor Activities** 🥾: Whether you love hiking, skiing, or just strolling through picturesque trails, this place has it all. The trails are well-marked and vary for all skill levels.

- **Food & Drink** 🍽️: Treat yourself to local cuisine! Try out some traditional Catalan dishes at the cozy restaurants. Local cheeses and cured meats are a must!

- **Chill Atmosphere** ☀️: It’s a small village vibe, so you can relax and escape the hustle and bustle. It feels like stepping back in time.

- **Local Events** 🎉: Check out any seasonal festivals or events. They’re a great way to soak in local culture and meet friendly faces.

In short, Sant Joan de Boí is perfect for a peaceful retreat, adventure lovers, and culture enthusiasts alike. Pack your bags and enjoy this beautiful spot! 🌟

This church is one in the group of romanesque churches that are listed as UNESCO World Heritage Site - El Romànic de la Vall de Boi. Others are:  Santa Eulàlla d'Erill la Calle, Sant Climent de Taüll, Santa María de Taüll, Sant Feliu de Barruera, La Nativitat de Durro. Two churches are not accessible every day. Santa Maria de Cardet is opened every weekend in July and August. The church Assumpció de Cóll was not opened in 2019.
Excellent location to start our hiking in the beautiful Pyrenees.
Beautiful
The best romanic church i saw..

Name: Archaeological Site of Atapuerca
short_description: The caves of the Sierra de Atapuerca contain a rich fossil record of the earliest human beings in Europe, from nearly one million years ago and extending up to the Common Era. They represent an exceptional reserve of data, the scientific study of which provides priceless information about the appearance and the way of life of these remote human ancestors.
formatted_address: Cam. del Pajarillo, 09198 Ibeas de Juarros, Burgos, Spain

reviews.text: An amazing experience indeed, the tour of the archaeological site is outstanding, the staff is knowledgeable and helpful, the visit to the CAREX is incredibly educational, try on your own to create stone tools, fire and shoot arrows or lances! This tour is a must for anyone interested in archaeology, sciences or outdoor live in general. I just wish the CAREX tour lasted some more time to have more opportunities to practice these techniques.
Nice view. Good to sit and relax. Sunday there is nobody. Free
A must visit if you like archeological sites

It is a guided trip to one of the active excavation sites in the region.   The valley has been inhabited by earliest hominids and animals and they are discovering evidence to put the history of human evolution together.

Very interestingand amazing to See this important excavation site ! Unfortunately, we couldn't do a guided Tour in English (only Spanish) but with some Preparation via the Museum of Human Evolution in Burgos, the tour was great also in Spanish

Name: Central Suriname Nature Reserve
short_description: The Central Suriname Nature Reserve comprises 1.6 million ha of primary tropical forest of west-central Suriname. It protects the upper watershed of the Coppename River and the headwaters of the Lucie, Oost, Zuid, Saramaccz, and Gran Rio rivers and covers a range of topography and ecosystems of notable conservation value due to its pristine state. Its montane and lowland forests contain a high diversity of plant life with more than 5,000 vascular plant species collected to date. The Reserve's animals are typical of the region and include the jaguar, giant armadillo, giant river otter, tapir, sloths, eight species of primates and 400 bird species such as harpy eagle, Guiana cock-of-the-rock, and scarlet macaw.

reviews.text: I went to Raleighvallen, which is absolutely gorgeous. Couldn’t do the Voltzberg hike, but would recommend it for the adventure hiker which will take most of the day to get to the top so bring water and light snacks e.g. granola bars and sandwiches. The accommodations are very rustic so don’t expect a luxurious cabin, because you are very deep into the jungle and there is no reception so you will have the ultimate experience of taking everything in. Reservations could either go via STINASU or a tour operator.

The Central Suriname Nature Reserve (Dutch: Centraal Suriname Natuurreservaat (CSNR)) is a conservation unit in Suriname. It preserves an area of tropical rainforest.

just like heaven

Name: Agricultural Landscape of Southern Öland
short_description: The southern part of the island of Öland in the Baltic Sea is dominated by a vast limestone plateau. Human beings have lived here for some five thousand years and adapted their way of life to the physical constraints of the island. As a consequence, the landscape is unique, with abundant evidence of continuous human settlement from prehistoric times to the present day.
formatted_address: Аграрен район на Южен Йоланд, 386 64 Degerhamn, Sweden

Name: Three Castles, Defensive Wall and Ramparts of the Market-Town of Bellinzona
short_description: The Bellinzona site consists of a group of fortifications grouped around the castle of Castelgrande, which stands on a rocky peak looking out over the entire Ticino valley. Running from the castle, a series of fortified walls protect the ancient town and block the passage through the valley. A second castle (Montebello) forms an integral part of the fortifications, while a third but separate castle (Sasso Corbaro) was built on an isolated rocky promontory south-east of the other fortifications.

reviews.text: Love that we stopped on our way to Lugano from Zurich. Will need to go back to explore more of the compound. It was so peaceful and captivating that we decided to explore slowly, to take it in, rather than rush to see it all. It was beautiful, surrounded by natural beauty, and wow, it provided for stunning photographs. History buffs would love the audio tours.

The Bellinzona Castles are a UNESCO World Heritage Site featuring three magnificent medieval fortifications: Castelgrande, Montebello, and Sasso Corbaro12.
Visiting Castelgrande.

Visitors can access the main castle in multiple ways, including a convenient elevator from Piazza del Sole or walking from the city center.

The castles are not just beautiful but historically significant, having played a crucial role in defending strategic alpine routes during the Middle Ages. Whether you're a history enthusiast or simply seeking spectacular views, the Bellinzona Castles offer an unforgettable experience.
Beautiful place with wonderful views and many interesting areas to visit. Worth visiting.

We stopped in the famous Bellinzona for lunch and to explore its three UNESCO World Heritage castles. Castelgrande, Castello di Montebello and Castello di Sasso Corbaro and the town wall formed an ancient defense system that controlled the route to two important alpine passes. The castles themselves are partly in ruins, but still impressive. Castelgrande has interior parts that you can explore. The castle walls offer wonderful views of the surrounding valley. The old town of Bellinzona is small, compact and worth a visit too.

An absolute must if you are not the area. Easy to get to. So well maintained with gorgeous views of snow capped mountains. There is no entrance fee. For those that may need assistance there is a lift which takes you up into the castle area, for those that like to walk there are a couple of entry points. Such a well preserved heritage site.

Name: Historic Town of St George and Related Fortifications, Bermuda
short_description: The Town of St George, founded in 1612, is an outstanding example of the earliest English urban settlement in the New World. Its associated fortifications graphically illustrate the development of English military engineering from the 17th to the 20th century, being adapted to take account of the development of artillery over this period.
Country name: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

reviews.text: The most incredible 360 degree views of St. George’s Island and the entire East End of Bermuda. This is the highest point on the Island.

Name: Blaenavon Industrial Landscape
short_description: The area around Blaenavon is evidence of the pre-eminence of South Wales as the world's major producer of iron and coal in the 19th century. All the necessary elements can still be seen - coal and ore mines, quarries, a primitive railway system, furnaces, workers' homes, and the social infrastructure of their community.
Country name: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
formatted_address: Church Rd, Blaenavon, Pontypool NP4 9AS, UK

reviews.text: It was good if you like trains. Was a bit disappointing. We paid £22 for two adult tickets (kids were free on this occasion). The journey seemed to go back and forth, rather than from point a to point b, but there wasn't anything to do at any of the stops. Journey lasted about an hour's and about 15-20 minutes of this was stationary to have pictures of the kids in the engine itself if you wanted to. Appreciate totally it's a volunteer run thing but we were just expecting something else after looking at the website and having done these trips before. Not saying don't go by any means, just don't expect too much

Great community center with amenities  for all ages including a cafe, computer room, and a beautiful museau with one of the best interactive display sets that I have ever seen. I must do to start off your visit of the Great town.
We visit the cafe regularly,food is absolutely gorgeous and very well priced great atmosphere very friendly

The food is delicious. Coffee and tea are excellent. The atmosphere is great. I have been there now 5 times this month and it has been busy every day.
Next to it is a little museum about the history of the iron workers.
It also has a gift shop with reasonable prices. It also entails the Blaenavon library, which has cute programs for little kids.
All the personnel I interacted with were super friendly.
I highly recommend this place.

Epicentre of large scale industrial sites arising from the 1780s with iron foundries, leading onto the development of Bessemer steel production. One can see how the site began, understand the importance of Wales and it's claim to be the first industrial nation. The BBC TV series 'coal house' set in 1927 and 'coal house' at war set in 1944 were filmed here. Nearby are 'The Big Pit' and walks that explore the development of industrial sites from The Iron Age, the middle ages and the Industrial Revolution.

Name: Stone Town of Zanzibar
short_description: The Stone Town of Zanzibar is a fine example of the Swahili coastal trading towns of East Africa. It retains its urban fabric and townscape virtually intact and contains many fine buildings that reflect its particular culture, which has brought together and homogenized disparate elements of the cultures of Africa, the Arab region, India, and Europe over more than a millennium.

Name: Historic Centre of Shakhrisyabz
short_description: The historic centre of Shakhrisyabz contains a collection of exceptional monuments and ancient quarters which bear witness to the city's secular development, and particularly to the period of its apogee, under the rule of Amir Temur and the Temurids, in the 15th-16th century.
formatted_address: 39°03'00.0"N 66°49'60.0"E, O‘zbekiston ko‘chasi, Qarshi, Qashqadaryo Viloyati, Uzbekistan

reviews.text: The historic centre of Shakhrisyabz contains a collection of exceptional monuments and ancient quarters which bear witness to the city's secular development, and particularly to the period of its apogee, under the rule of Amir Temur and the Temurids, in the 15th-16th century.

The historic center of the city of Shakhrisabz is a UNESCO heritage site and is worth a visit even if many tourists do not stop there, there are many monuments among which the ruins of the Ak Sarai palace and Tamerlane's tomb stand out but I also recommend a visit to the Chor-su Bazaar.

A very impressive site, all in relief, well preserved.
Absolutely worth discovering!

Name: Ciudad Universitaria de Caracas
short_description: The Ciudad Universitaria de Caracas, built to the design of the architect Carlos Raúl Villanueva, between 1940 and 1960, is an outstanding example of the Modern Movement in architecture. The university campus integrates the large number of buildings and functions into a clearly articulated ensemble, including masterpieces of modern architecture and visual arts, such as the Aula Magna with the "Clouds" of Alexander Calder, the Olympic Stadium, and the Covered Plaza.

A beauty 😍😍😍 The restoration is turning out excellent, I hope it continues like this and they also equip it with cutting-edge technology in all areas 🙏🏾🙏🏾🙏🏾

Immense and dynamic, it is being reactivated: new initiatives, projects and learning every day.
The most beautiful city within the most hostile city

Name: High Coast / Kvarken Archipelago
short_description: The Kvarken Archipelago (Finland) and the High Coast (Sweden) are situated in the Gulf of Bothnia, a northern extension of the Baltic Sea. The 5,600 islands of the Kvarken Archipelago feature unusual ridged washboard moraines, ‘De Geer moraines’, formed by the melting of the continental ice sheet, 10,000 to 24,000 years ago. The Archipelago is continuously rising from the sea in a process of rapid glacio-isostatic uplift, whereby the land, previously weighed down under the weight of a glacier, lifts at rates that are among the highest in the world. As a consequence islands appear and unite, peninsulas expand, and lakes evolve from bays and develop into marshes and peat fens. The High Coast has also been largely shaped by the combined processes of glaciation, glacial retreat and the emergence of new land from the sea. Since the last retreat of the ice from the High Coast 9,600 years ago, the uplift has been in the order of 285 m which is the highest known ''rebound''. The site affords outstanding opportunities for the understanding of the important processes that formed the glaciated and land uplift areas of the Earth''s surface.

reviews.text: I had very good 1 day tour there. It was worth renting car and spending whole day there. Very beautiful nature, silence, and clean air. No one was there, like you are in abandoned empty place all alone. All the service places were closed during my visit, so better to prepare your own necessities if u visiting in winter. Didn't see the uplifted lands and many small lakes because it was winter and everything covered by snow. I will come back in summer again.

It’s no surprise that this site is identified as a UNESCO world heritage site ! It is as beautiful during winters as it is during summer time. It takes you back in time with those red / yellow fisherman’s houses for boats and other things.

Nearby walking trail leads you to Watch Tower in the shape of Salt Pepper dispenser and thus its name.

There is also a place to do the grilling and a cafe nearby to enjoy the views.
is beautiful!
Cool place

The weather was unfortunately very bad, wind, light rain, a lot of melting snow and therefore a lot of ice, but the environment is very special. When the weather is nice or when there is fresh snow, it is undoubtedly even more beautiful here.

Name: Maloti-Drakensberg Park
short_description: The Maloti-Drakensberg Park is a transnational property composed of the uKhahlamba Drakensberg National Park in South Africa and the Sehlathebe National Park in Lesotho. The site has exceptional natural beauty in its soaring basaltic buttresses, incisive dramatic cutbacks, and golden sandstone ramparts as well as visually spectacular sculptured arches, caves, cliffs, pillars and rock pools. The site's diversity of habitats protects a high level of endemic and globally important plants. The site harbors endangered species such as the Cape vulture (Gyps coprotheres) and the bearded vulture (Gypaetus barbatus). Lesotho’s Sehlabathebe National Park also harbors the Maloti minnow (Pseudobarbus quathlambae), a critically endangered fish species only found in this park. This spectacular natural site contains many caves and rock-shelters with the largest and most concentrated group of paintings in Africa south of the Sahara. They represent the spiritual life of the San people, who lived in this area over a period of 4,000 years.

reviews.text: Be warned the drive is shocking. Mostly sand/mud roads and then miles of potholes on very sketchy road. Not able to drive more than 10mph. Good views of the Drakensberg but there are better places.
Extremely beautiful and there are so many places to stay to enjoy various areas of the Drakensberg.
I climbed Mafadi, and it was an incredible experience. I would be prepared with ropes for safety. The bath house is clean and there is a tub to bathe.

Cobham

This is a great campsite to get away from technology. The campsite has no electricity and you can camp anywhere there is space. So if you find a spot that you like with an amazing view, camp. Safe place for the children to ride bikes and throw stones in the river.

There are a lot of great hikes from there for all different skill levels, novice walks to day hikes to caves to sleep in.

If you want to get away then this is the place to go and switch off.
Beautiful park with many hikes for all abilities.

Name: Curonian Spit
short_description: Human habitation of this elongated sand dune peninsula, 98 km long and 0.4-4 km wide, dates back to prehistoric times. Throughout this period it has been threatened by the natural forces of wind and waves. Its survival to the present day has been made possible only as a result of ceaseless human efforts to combat the erosion of the Spit, dramatically illustrated by continuing stabilisation and reforestation projects.

reviews.text: Might be unique wonder of nature, but human touch (ferry service capacity from and to mainlaind) makes the experience of getting there uniquely painful and nightmarish. 5 hours(!!) waiting in car at the ferry terminal (back and forth) to have 2 hours in the Sea museum (as there was no time left for anything else). All thumbs down for (de)organized logistics here.
it looks like heaven

This 40-foot sundial stands atop the Parnidis Dune, one of the scenic highlights of Curonian Spit, a UNESCO World Heritage Site shared by Lithuania and Russia. Built in 1995, the sundial was damaged by a hurricane a few years later and rebuilt in 2011. It accurately tells time by creating shadows on the steps, with notches for hours and half hours, as well as months, equinoxes, and solstices.

March 20 marks the spring (or vernal) equinox in the Northern Hemisphere, meaning that for the next six months daylight hours will outlast nighttime darkness. When it's winter in the Northern Hemisphere, those of us above the equator are tilted away from the sun, giving us shorter days and longer nights. In summer, we're tilted toward the sun, but the equinox is right in between. It's the moment during Earth's annual revolution around the sun when its axis is neither tilting away nor tilting toward the sun, giving everyone on the planet an equal split of day and night. This phenomenon happens twice a year—in March and again in September. In the Southern Hemisphere, everything's flipped. There, it's the autumnal equinox today — and, yes, winter is coming.
I am very pleased to have visited this place. With a visa you can walk from Europe to Russia.

Was very disappointed, there where sign's all over the place saying keep off sand dunes before I got onto the beach then I walked onto the beach and there was no sand and only a puddle of water. I was ready to go the the beach and everything. I brought my beach chair and sunscreen and just wanted a nice peaceful day at the beach but there was no beach for me to be at.

Name: Historic Centre of Vienna
short_description: Vienna developed from early Celtic and Roman settlements into a Medieval and Baroque city, the capital of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. It played an essential role as a leading European music centre, from the great age of Viennese Classicism through the early part of the 20th century. The historic centre of Vienna is rich in architectural ensembles, including Baroque castles and gardens, as well as the late-19th-century Ringstrasse lined with grand buildings, monuments and parks.

reviews.text: In to look at souvenirs for the folks back home. Found several items within the price range I was willing to pay. The store lower level was clean and well stocked. Did not make it to the second level. Check out was quick and amiable.
Nice place we had a nice walk in the city and the Anker Uhr was so beautiful and the music to was perfect.

Anchor House
Big souvenir shop
The city center itself.

Name: Tsodilo
short_description: With one of the highest concentrations of rock art in the world, Tsodilo has been called the ''Louvre of the Desert''. Over 4,500 paintings are preserved in an area of only 10 km2 of the Kalahari Desert. The archaeological record of the area gives a chronological account of human activities and environmental changes over at least 100,000 years. Local communities in this hostile environment respect Tsodilo as a place of worship frequented by ancestral spirits.

reviews.text: It was a wonderful experience and awesome moments
We found it to be very interesting and well preserved.

Name: Historic Centre of the Town of Goiás
short_description: Goiás testifies to the occupation and colonization of the lands of central Brazil in the 18th and 19th centuries. The urban layout is an example of the organic development of a mining town, adapted to the conditions of the site. Although modest, both public and private architecture form a harmonious whole, thanks to the coherent use of local materials and vernacular techniques.

reviews.text: Goiás testifies to the occupation and colonization of the lands of central Brazil in the 18th and 19th centuries. The urban layout is an example of the organic development of a mining town, adapted to the conditions of the site. Although modest, both public and private architecture form a harmonious whole, thanks to the coherent use of local materials and vernacular techniques.
Beautiful town, I really enjoyed. Old houses, churches ....

Muitos prédios e calçamento preservado. Cada rua é uma surpresa agradável, seja na arquitetura das construções quanto na decoração externa das casas. Muitos moradores embelezam suas portas com flores, e a rua acaba ficando com um belo vidual.  Vale a pena fazer um tour, com o próprio carro, se familiarizar com o lugar, escolher um bom local para estacionar e explorar a pé o lugar.  Merece uns dois dias de caminhada e ainda uma noite para ver a iluminação das ruas.

Indescritível! Uma cidade histórica muito bem preservada em todos os seus detalhes, inclusive naturais, visto que o rio que cruza o centro é tão límpido que parece ser de um tempo onde não existia poluição. Museus funcionando. Bons restaurantes a preços justos. A visita guiada pelo antigo Palácio do Governo é uma aula de história!  Parabéns e muito obrigada ao povo da cidade de Goiás.

A cidade parece bem cuidada e preserva suas tradições. Não há (ainda) uma exploração turística intensa, como em Pirenópolis, e isso dá uma charme a mais. Não deixem de visitar a casa de Cora Coralina e o Museu das Bandeiras e de apreciar os doces locais e a vista do rio Vermelho a partir das pontes da cidade.

Name: Brazilian Atlantic Islands: Fernando de Noronha and Atol das Rocas Reserves
short_description: Peaks of the Southern Atlantic submarine ridge form the Fernando de Noronha Archipelago and Rocas Atoll off the coast of Brazil. They represent a large proportion of the island surface of the South Atlantic and their rich waters are extremely important for the breeding and feeding of tuna, shark, turtle and marine mammals. The islands are home to the largest concentration of tropical seabirds in the Western Atlantic. Baia de Golfinhos has an exceptional population of resident dolphin and at low tide the Rocas Atoll provides a spectacular seascape of lagoons and tidal pools teeming with fish.
formatted_address: Fernando de Noronha, State of Pernambuco, 53990-000, Brazil

reviews.text: a paradise with warm waters… the island with the most beautiful beaches in Brazil!!! however, everything is very expensive, there is a fee for staying on the island to be paid daily, there is a bus that runs around the island (riding a Bug is expensive). But every sunset on the island is worth it ✨✨✨✨

I went to this Paradise island in 1988 and it was magical. I returned and it has become an artificial, overrated, overpriced place for new money. I just read that part of the Island has been closed for the vulgar wedding of a new billionaire. They sold their soul.....

Fernando de Noronha, located in the State of Pernambuco, is a beautiful and wonderful place, although the cost to go there is a little high, it is worth going and getting to know the island and learning about the marine life that lives there.
Unbelievable experience. The whole island works as a whole. Government and locals unified.
Come for impressions, we'll come to fernando de noronha

Name: Cerrado Protected Areas: Chapada dos Veadeiros and Emas National Parks
short_description: The two sites included in the designation contain flora and fauna and key habitats that characterize the Cerrado – one of the world’s oldest and most diverse tropical ecosystems. For millennia, these sites have served as refuge for several species during periods of climate change and will be vital for maintaining the biodiversity of the Cerrado region during future climate fluctuations.
formatted_address: Rod. GO-239, Km 36 Vila de - São Jorge, Alto Paraíso de Goiás - GO, 73770-000, Brazil

reviews.text: Awesome park with beautiful views and waterfalls. Your need to reserve all day to see them all, but it's worth. Crystalline water and lot of plants. Great place

Absolutely great park with massive waterfalls and rapids (in rain season begin april).

Both yellow (Salto 2.5 hour) and red (Canion 3 hour) is very doable in 1 day if your above average fit (4.5km/h).

Add extra time for pictures and swimming.

18km in total mostly flat terrain some parts with rocks.
Beautiful place. I did the yellow trail. Was very easy! Possible on flip flops, but shoes are recommended. No hiking shoes needed. Unfortunately the red trail is closed due the rain.

Tha parque nacional is extremely well organized, quite cheap and certainly worth the visit if y are around here.
Different routes with very different extensions and difficulty's are very well marked

Gorgeous incredible hiking. Friendly, professional staff. Several waterfalls to see and excellent plant life. You will want to be in reasonable shape.

Name: Yungang Grottoes
short_description: The Yungang Grottoes, in Datong city, Shanxi Province, with their 252 caves and 51,000 statues, represent the outstanding achievement of Buddhist cave art in China in the 5th and 6th centuries. The Five Caves created by Tan Yao, with their strict unity of layout and design, constitute a classical masterpiece of the first peak of Chinese Buddhist art.

reviews.text: It's an amazing place,  showing the spread of Buddhism across China. I'm comparing this to the Mogao Grottoes in Dunhuang, and preferring that over this.  The colors in Mogao are much more brilliant,  perhaps because of better preservation n stricter management of tourists.  At this Yungang Grottoes site, some of the old carvings are actually within reach of the public,  and I clearly see children having a go at them while their parents click away. Still a good experience to see some amazing relics.

A jaw-dropping masterpiece of ancient Buddhist art. Carved into the cliffs over 1,500 years ago during the Northern Wei dynasty, these caves house thousands of intricate Buddha statues, from towering 17-meter colossi to delicate, finely detailed carvings. The craftsmanship is mind-blowing—some figures still have traces of their original paint, giving you a rare glimpse into their former vibrancy.

Absolutely breathtaking. I’m amazing at what humans were able to achieve this many years ago. I still get emotional thinking back to the visit. Grateful that these gems exist and are open for the world to see
Visit only if you wish to ustd by the China dynasty history and how it developed and their believe in Buddhism and respect over different dynasties and the rich.

Buddism grattoes and statues created between 470-550 AD. Some are well preserved. Royal and nobleman spent their wealth trying to recreate the Budda Land discribed in Buddist scripture.
- World heritage site

- Nice modern new musem inside the site
- Sourvernier and book shop at last bus stop
- Allow 2hrs for a brief visit, allow 4+ hours for a guided/detailed visit
- !!! Avoid local public holidays, this apply to all tourist destination in China.

Name: Alejandro de Humboldt National Park
short_description: Complex geology and varied topography have given rise to a diversity of ecosystems and species unmatched in the insular Caribbean and created one of the most biologically diverse tropical island sites on earth. Many of the underlying rocks are toxic to plants so species have had to adapt to survive in these hostile conditions. This unique process of evolution has resulted in the development of many new species and the park is one of the most important sites in the Western Hemisphere for the conservation of endemic flora. Endemism of vertebrates and invertebrates is also very high.

reviews.text: Beautiful nature, endemic plants and animals. Flora and fauna there is amazing. Also opportunity to cool down swimming im the natural pools.

One of the most spectacular natural places in Cuba. Incredible endemism (ie. lots of the animals and plants in this National Park are found no-where else in the world, not even in other parts of Cuba). With a good guide, you can find the Monte Iberia eleuth here, the Northern Hemisphere's smallest frog at 9mm fully-grown (it's gorgeous). Admittedly we visited shortly after Hurricane Matthew hit Baracoa, but there are very few tourists here compared to the more major tourist sites in Cuba. You can arrange tours from Baracoa with most of the tourist offices, or they will point you in the right direction. Our guide on a 3 hour walk through the park was biologist Wisdenilde Navarro Mendez ("Indio") and he was amazing - pointed out a lot of interesting plants and animals, found the tiny frog, managed to get a camoflaged lizard to jump onto my hand and was generally very knowledgeable about the biology of the forest.
One of the most important places in terms of endemic biodiversity in the Caribbean. Very impressive!
Charming park in a beautiful country
Good for bird warching

Name: Tugendhat Villa in Brno
short_description: The Tugendhat Villa in Brno, designed by the architect Mies van der Rohe, is an outstanding example of the international style in the modern movement in architecture as it developed in Europe in the 1920s. Its particular value lies in the application of innovative spatial and aesthetic concepts that aim to satisfy new lifestyle needs by taking advantage of the opportunities afforded by modern industrial production.

reviews.text: I couldn’t understand why UNESCO included Villa Tugendhat on its protection list. I read that it represents the early features of modern architecture. The garden is nice, but I’ve seen much more beautiful ones in other places I’ve visited. The villa is surrounded by glass, maybe it has the distinction of being the first of its kind. It could also be because it hosted many historical meetings, including the agreement for the separation of Czechoslovakia. However, I don’t think it’s under UNESCO protection just because it's a glass-walled villa. Perhaps UNESCO should protect all of Europe, as every street in Europe is historical, and nearly every building has a painting or sculpture on it.
Must see marvel of functionalism in Brno. It’s great that the house and surrounding parks are open to public. And if you don’t manage to get tickets - just walk in the garden for free.

a true architectural masterpiece.
also recommended the beautiful film The Glass Room, a fiction and exciting version of the story of the wonderful Villa Tugendhat

When I visited the waiting list for the house itself was months long. However, the non-waiting list tour was interesting and enthusiastically delivered with  almost no real need to enter the excluded areas which were clearly visible through the window.

Beautiful. Soo timeless. The garden is not the nicest I've ever seen but its ok for English type of park walk. Main point is the villa anyway. We did not go for a tour as you need to book in advance . Few months 😮

Name: Provins, Town of Medieval Fairs
short_description: The fortified medieval town of Provins is situated in the former territory of the powerful Counts of Champagne. It bears witness to early developments in the organization of international trading fairs and the wool industry. The urban structure of Provins, which was built specifically to host the fairs and related activities, has been well preserved.

Name: Zollverein Coal Mine Industrial Complex in Essen
short_description: The Zollverein industrial complex in Land Nordrhein-Westfalen consists of the complete infrastructure of a historical coal-mining site, with some 20th-century buildings of outstanding architectural merit. It constitutes remarkable material evidence of the evolution and decline of an essential industry over the past 150 years.

reviews.text: Great place with lots of history to walk around. Interesting architecture and very well preserved. Free ti park and visit for a walk around. If you want an optional tour (necessary to enter some of the buildings) book in advance as they often may not have availability, and tours don't run everyday.

amazing history and beautiful old industrial buildings. Ruhr museum is
word the visit.

i would have liked to see more info about certain buildings, the machines inside and everything else. it’s and interesting place wich will raise questions that will stay unanswered

Zollverein is an impressive, massive site that feels like stepping into a dystopian film set. Almost as if you're walking through the backdrop of a Robocop movie. The industrial, gritty vibe, with towering structures and sprawling grounds, gives the place an almost surreal, futuristic atmosphere.

Be ready to stroll a few kilometers, as the area is enormous. Despite its size, the layout makes it easy to navigate, and there are plenty of spots to take in the scenery or grab a break.

Parking is hassle-free, with enough spots to accommodate visitors, even during busy times. One of the best parts? Entrance is free, making this an ideal place for anyone interested in industrial history or simply looking for a unique walk.

Very interesting site that is free entry to the public, you do have to pay to visit the museum aspect and the roof but this is super cheap! If you want a guided tour you should pre book but if you’re happy to self guide then you’ll have a great day!
Museum details all the local history and how Zollverein came to be the site it is today. Huge area to walk around that has cafes, restaurants and a swimming pool!
Definitely do a research on what to visit inside the compound before you come. It's a huge place.

Name: Masada
short_description: Masada is a rugged natural fortress, of majestic beauty, in the Judaean Desert overlooking the Dead Sea. It is a symbol of the ancient kingdom of Israel, its violent destruction and the last stand of Jewish patriots in the face of the Roman army, in 73 A.D. It was built as a palace complex, in the classic style of the early Roman Empire, by Herod the Great, King of Judaea, (reigned 37 – 4 B.C.). The camps, fortifications and attack ramp that encircle the monument constitute the most complete Roman siege works surviving to the present day.

reviews.text:
One of my favorite National Park in Israel. No trip to Israel is complete without visiting this place. It is filled with so much history with a breathtaking view of the Dead Sea. The best time to visit is sunrise. This is a place that is usually very busy on weekends so it is advisable to schedule your arrival during the week.
There are a few ways to get up:
1. Snake path - This is the long path up to the mountain.
•Length: The route climbs to a height of 350 meters, and is 2.7 Km long.
•Opens for ascent every day one hour before Sunrise and closes for descent one hour before closing time.
•On very hot days the Snake Path ascent closes at 09:00AM and the descent closes at 10:00AM. When heat is extreme, the Snake Path ascent closes at 08:00 and the decent closes at 09:00. The descent via the Roman Ramp is open as usual.
2. The Roman ramp path - This is the short path.
Starting point: West entrance.
•Length: 0.7 Kilometers
3. Cable car - A round trip by cable car will cost 23$.
• You need to make a reservation!
•Starts working at 8AM!

Visiting Masada National Park was an awe-inspiring experience that left me deeply moved by the rich history and breathtaking views.

One of the highlights was witnessing the awe-inspiring sunrise from the fortress walls. The vibrant colors dancing across the Dead Sea, coupled with the peaceful silence of the desert, created a truly magical atmosphere. It was a moment that will forever be etched in my memory.

Exploring the site, we marveled at the well-preserved structures, including the ancient synagogue, bathhouses, and the imposing palaces. The views from the summit were simply breathtaking, offering a breathtaking panorama of the desert landscape and the Dead Sea in the distance.

Masada National Park’s commitment to preservation and conservation is evident throughout. The efforts to protect and restore this historical gem are commendable, allowing visitors to step back in time and appreciate the remarkable heritage that unfolds within these ancient walls.

I highly recommend visiting Masada National Park to anyone with an interest in history, nature, or simply seeking a unique and memorable experience. The combination of historical significance, stunning landscapes, and a well-organized visitor experience make it a must-see destination.

A trip to Masada National Park is an unforgettable journey that will leave you with a profound appreciation for the resilience of the human spirit and the natural beauty of the Israeli desert. Don’t miss this gem on your travels!

Great national park to learn about the history of Masada! You can either hike up or take the cable car to the top from the visitor center. Signed placards around the area tell you about the history. There’s also a museum on the premises to learn even more. Also a gift shop and food in the visitor center. Very cool visit!

Of all the stops I've made on my 10 day trip to Israel thus far, I think that the Masada National Park has been a standout experience. Everything about this location is fascinating to me, from the history shared through stories, the picturesque scenery with the Dead Sea and Jordan in the distance, to the clear archeological relevance of this site (and including the research center that studies living in harsh conditions). This National Park is, to me, definitely worth taking the time to visit!!

It was hot but well worth the visit. Lots of amazing history, fantastic views, and a store with an extensive variety of cold drinks. Cable car ride to the top was exciting, although each gondola was crammed full of passengers so wear a mask if you wish to protect yourself.

Name: Old City of Acre
short_description: Acre is a historic walled port-city with continuous settlement from the Phoenician period. The present city is characteristic of a fortified town dating from the Ottoman 18th and 19th centuries, with typical urban components such as the citadel, mosques, khans and baths. The remains of the Crusader town, dating from 1104 to 1291, lie almost intact, both above and below today's street level, providing an exceptional picture of the layout and structures of the capital of the medieval Crusader kingdom of Jerusalem.

Name: Villa d'Este, Tivoli
short_description: The Villa d'Este in Tivoli, with its palace and garden, is one of the most remarkable and comprehensive illustrations of Renaissance culture at its most refined. Its innovative design along with the architectural components in the garden (fountains, ornamental basins, etc.) make this a unique example of an Italian 16th-century garden. The Villa d'Este, one of the first giardini delle meraviglie , was an early model for the development of European gardens.

reviews.text: We visited Villa d’Este in May last year, and it was absolutely wonderful. The gardens are breathtaking, with stunning fountains and beautifully maintained greenery. The atmosphere is peaceful, and the historical charm of the villa adds to the experience. A must-visit for anyone in the area!

Place is extremely well preserved, especially the palace with many amazing frescoes. The garden is nice, the only negative is the fountain with the music….expectations are high but it is just a piano playing under a fountain, with no extra attractions.
Price is 15 EUR (2025)….so not cheap for Italy, but maintenance of the site is very well done. You can also find some drinking water at some fountains. Not easy moving for wheelchairs. No parking close to the palace, but Tivoli is not big and you can easy walk through the city centre

A Renaissance masterpiece located in piazza Trento, Tivoli, easily accessible and close to several parking areas. Be aware of the limited traffic zones (ZTL) in the historic center. The gardens are spectacular, with unique fountains and water features. There are public restrooms within the park, conveniently located near the main attractions. Entrance is paid, but it's truly worth it. A visit is a must for anyone who loves art and history. Leave a like and follow me for more reviews!

There is a cost to get in. 2024 was $12 for the basic visit. If you get there early enough in the day you can do the Philip pass and if you're going to see three or more villas it definitely pays for itself. But just visiting this one is definitely well worth it. It is lovely to look in the gardens. Be aware if you're there too close to closing the Italians don't mean closing at a specific time. They mean they are already locked up, cleaned up and going home at that time. So they will walk you out of the gardens 15 minutes early and just push you straight on out of the house. So you are out of the house before 5. :00. Even though that's supposedly the closing time. That was the only negative part of our experience. The garden's really were lovely to go see. Many of the features were not working in November, I don't know if that's because of the cold planning for winter or if they're just broken. But many of the big features definitely were working and there is some great views and pictures to be had in this place

These historic buildings and gardens were a dream! So many beautiful things to see in one place. I would love to go back. If it’s hot, take lots of water! There are lots of places to sit and rest and take in the surroundings.

The organ fountain is timed, so if you want to see it, make sure you know what time it plays.

Name: Lamu Old Town
short_description: Lamu Old Town is the oldest and best-preserved Swahili settlement in East Africa, retaining its traditional functions. Built in coral stone and mangrove timber, the town is characterized by the simplicity of structural forms enriched by such features as inner courtyards, verandas, and elaborately carved wooden doors. Lamu has hosted major Muslim religious festivals since the 19th century, and has become a significant centre for the study of Islamic and Swahili cultures.

Name: Vat Phou and Associated Ancient Settlements within the Champasak Cultural Landscape
short_description: The Champasak cultural landscape, including the Vat Phou Temple complex, is a remarkably well-preserved planned landscape more than 1,000 years old. It was shaped to express the Hindu vision of the relationship between nature and humanity, using an axis from mountain top to river bank to lay out a geometric pattern of temples, shrines and waterworks extending over some 10 km. Two planned cities on the banks of the Mekong River are also part of the site, as well as Phou Kao mountain. The whole represents a development ranging from the 5th to 15th centuries, mainly associated with the Khmer Empire.

reviews.text: It is ruins of the ancient Angkor civilization. The monument has degraded over time and restoration work has not been paid attention. The architecture is unique because it was built from stone, a few remaining reliefs show very high stone craftsmanship, and the work is very beautiful and detailed.

This is a beautiful temple complex that predates Angkor Wat.
You need 1-3 hours, depending on how much time you want to spend going in and out of the buildings in the main complex, whether you want to hike up to see the crocodile rock, the elephant rock and Buddha's footprint.
It's 55k kip/person to enter (currently about $2.50 usd), and there's an electric shuttle that takes you from the ticketing area to the temple complex.
I'm very glad that we decided to come to southern Laos and see this complex.  Definitely a great addition to our trip.

Beautiful scenery of Lingaparavata and the temple building. Tickets and parking aren't expensive and they even provide a free ride on electricity cars to the temple. However, it's quite hot so you should prepare an umbrella or hat. I wish there were tour guides too.

Such amazing ancient Khmer temple on the mountain n good view to see from the top. Undoubtedly, the must visit place in Pakse. Don't miss to see the museum or exhibition hall where you can learn more about the temple n the region.

Visiting Wat Phou was an unforgettable experience! The snake-scale path leading up is unique and gives such a mystical feel as you climb. The view from the top is amazing, especially in the afternoon when the light hits just right – you can see the full layout of the temple structures below with the village in the background, perfectly framed by the golden sunlight. It’s incredible to see this ancient place with so much detail and history, including the old sacrificial area. Such a magical and inspiring spot – a must-see for anyone visiting Laos!

Name: Royal Hill of Ambohimanga
short_description: The Royal Hill of Ambohimanga consists of a royal city and burial site, and an ensemble of sacred places. It is associated with strong feelings of national identity, and has maintained its spiritual and sacred character both in ritual practice and the popular imagination for the past 500 years. It remains a place of worship to which pilgrims come from Madagascar and elsewhere.

reviews.text: A must visit if you are near the capital. UNESCO heritage protected. Traditional kings building next to more modern (18c) queens palace. Still favourite with the followers of the old traditional religion where one wants to talk to ancestors and offer a sacrifice!  Amazing experience. The entry gate to the sacred hill is worth a visit too

Although very far from Antananarivo city centre if you have to visit one historical site in Antananarivo then make this Rovan' Amohimanga Palace a priority visit.Declared a UNESCO Heritage site this Palace complex has most of its original structure intact.Also the view of Antananarivo from this Palace Watchtower is breathtaking.

It is a UNESCO world heritage. It is the king's palace from 1800s and has queen's summer house from 1900s. The summer house has gifts from different countries such as mirrors from Queen Victoria of England, french cristal ware and wallpaper from Japan. The ticket for foreigners costs 10000 and for local costs 400. I recommend visiting the place with a guide as there are not many written explanation. Has nice panoramik view at the top.
A surprisingly simple Palace, in tact from before the French Colonozation and thankfully kept. UNESCO sites are always great. No pics allowed inside buildings

Rovan' Ambohimanga (also known as Royal Hill of Ambohimanga) is a historic site and royal palace located near Antananarivo, the capital of Madagascar. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and holds significant cultural, historical, and spiritual importance for the Malagasy people.

Here are some key details about Rovan' Ambohimanga:

1. Historical Significance: Ambohimanga was once the residence of the Merina kings and queens, particularly during the 17th and 18th centuries. It served as a royal settlement and spiritual center, playing a central role in the history of the Merina Kingdom, one of the most influential kingdoms on the island.

2. Royal Hill: The site is situated on a hill, offering spectacular views of the surrounding area, and it includes a combination of a royal palace, tombs, sacred places, and a fortified town. The hill itself is considered a sacred site and a symbol of the royal heritage of Madagascar.

3. Cultural Heritage: The palace complex at Ambohimanga includes traditional Malagasy architectural features, such as wooden palaces and stone walls. It is an excellent example of pre-colonial architecture and represents the culture and governance of the Merina people.

4. Religious and Spiritual Importance: The site is not only a royal residence but also a place of deep spiritual significance. The tomb of King Andrianampoinimerina, who unified much of Madagascar, is located here, and many Malagasy people still consider Ambohimanga a holy place.

5. UNESCO World Heritage Site: Ambohimanga was designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2001 due to its outstanding cultural value, as it is one of the best-preserved royal sites in Madagascar, offering insight into the island's royal history, architecture, and traditions.

6. Tourism: Today, Ambohimanga is a popular tourist destination, offering visitors the opportunity to explore the royal palace, the surrounding sacred forests, and the historic ruins. It is often visited as a day trip from Antananarivo.

Rovan' Ambohimanga is a must-visit for those interested in the history and culture of Madagascar, providing a glimpse into the island's royal past and spiritual traditions.

Name: Medina of Essaouira (formerly Mogador)
short_description: Essaouira is an exceptional example of a late-18th-century fortified town, built according to the principles of contemporary European military architecture in a North African context. Since its foundation, it has been a major international trading seaport, linking Morocco and its Saharan hinterland with Europe and the rest of the world.

Name: Churches of Peace in Jawor and Świdnica
short_description: The Churches of Peace in Jawor and Świdnica, the largest timber-framed religious buildings in Europe, were built in the former Silesia in the mid-17th century, amid the religious strife that followed the Peace of Westphalia. Constrained by the physical and political conditions, the Churches of Peace bear testimony to the quest for religious freedom and are a rare expression of Lutheran ideology in an idiom generally associated with the Catholic Church.

reviews.text: I visited the Church of Peace in Swidnica today, and it was absolutely breathtaking! The stunning architecture and peaceful atmosphere made me feel so grateful to be able to experience such beauty. I couldn't help but smile the whole time I was there, surrounded by such a sense of tranquility. If you ever get the chance to visit, I highly recommend it - it's truly a magical place.

We visited this church as part of a guided tour. We parked outside of the church complex for free and there was plenty of parking. The church is built of wood and the majority of the fittings are wooden. You are given an old school guide of your choice which you need to return. The interior of the church is fantastic and was being refurbished when we were there. Outside of the church is an oasis of calm with a cemetery and a tall bell tower. The church is a UNESCO site and is a must visit.

The exquisite murals and sculptures, the dome mural design that is perfectly integrated with the exterior windows of the building and the internal carvings make people feel solemn instantly. The oil paintings on the four walls depict the progress of history. Some of the paintings are ingeniously conceived, such as the one with rain on one side and sunny on the other side. You can see the painter's thinking method. The very beautiful angels are vivid. The painting in the middle of the dome allows you to feel the difference when you look up. It is really amazing!

This all wooden Lutheran church is a must see if you are in the region. Though it made not  seem like it, but this Church's core is wood, There is so much beautiful art every where you turn within this structure, The grounds are peaceful and free to enter, The church has a fee to enter, but it is certainly worth it. #SeeTheWorld @ChuckDiesal

The Church of Peace in Swidnica is the truest diamond of the Christian architectural heritage, where splendor, the coziness of wood and magical longevity are combined. This is a must-visit, must-see and must-feel UNESCO protected site while being in Silesia. I regret only one thing - we did not appreciate that more time should be spent for the visit.

Name: Historic Centre of Guimarães
short_description: The historic town of Guimarães is associated with the emergence of the Portuguese national identity in the 12th century. An exceptionally well-preserved and authentic example of the evolution of a medieval settlement into a modern town, its rich building typology exemplifies the specific development of Portuguese architecture from the 15th to 19th century through the consistent use of traditional building materials and techniques.

reviews.text: Lucas was our guide and he was outstanding.  He has a passion for the history and for Portugal.  Great insights and you really get value for your money.  Also he is very helpful and made some great recommedations on how to save money.
Recommend to visit when you are in Porto. It's easy to get there by train. Old center is fabulous! If you like ancient architecture,  you will love Guimaraesh!

We needed a little break from the wonderful wineries of the Douro Valley so we took a little day trip to the Beautiful historic town Guimaraes. The castle and the cathedral are the main attractions but we fell in love with the small streets and buildings. It was fun to walk without purpose, enjoy ice-cream in a street corner and just explore.

So worth a couple of hours strolling through their impressively maintained medieval village, full of charming shops and cafes for lunch or dinner, after visiting the Castelo de Guimarães and not-to-be-missed Palace of the Dukes of Braganza w/ amazing interiors and furnishings.

A really quaint old town with lots of history.  Very clean.
Many restaurants and cafés.  Don't miss this!

Name: Alto Douro Wine Region
short_description: Wine has been produced by traditional landholders in the Alto Douro region for some 2,000 years. Since the 18th century, its main product, port wine, has been world famous for its quality. This long tradition of viticulture has produced a cultural landscape of outstanding beauty that reflects its technological, social and economic evolution.

reviews.text: One of the best stays we had in Portugal! Incredibly friendly owners that tell you everything you want to know about the rich history of the Douro valley and agriculture. You are allowed to enter the whole area and the 2 dogs of the owner will gladly work as your gps and guide you through the fields. We've only stayed one night, but we could spend weeks there without hesitation. Great food and hospitality as well!

We had an amazing night here with wine tasting and dinner.
The host and his staff were great. We learnt a lot about the winery and the Douro Valley.
The views were amazing especially at sunset. The pool area was good for a relax at the end of a hot day.
We enjoyed walking the vine yards at our leisure.
The only low point was the heat in our room on a day that was over 40 degrees it was nearly impossible to sleep without a fan or air conditioning.
We had an amazing time at Quinta da Estrada. The people were very nice, the food and wine was amazing. It's a great place to have a great time. Muito obrigado 🍷🍇

We came here for 3 nights and didn't want to leave. Luis made us feel very welcome and home. The garden and views are amazing. We enjoyed staying in the loft with our private terrace to enjoy breakfast with an awesome view. The homemade food and wine was delicious too. An all in all fantastic and authentic experience in the Douro Valley ☺️

Wonderful experience of wine tasting with dinner in the picturesque place in Douro valley.

Through the wine tasting we knew from Luis a lot of interesting facts about wineries n Douro, how they produce it and all about history behind it.

Luis was so friendly and very hospital. Highly recommend this place. It is possible to stay and deep dive in history!

Name: Central Sikhote-Alin
short_description: The Sikhote-Alin mountain range contains one of the richest and most unusual temperate forests of the world. In this mixed zone between taiga and subtropics, southern species such as the tiger and Himalayan bear cohabit with northern species such as the brown bear and lynx. After its extension in 2018, the property includes the Bikin River Valley, located about 100 km to the north of the existing site. It encompasses the South-Okhotsk dark coniferous forests and the East-Asian coniferous broadleaf forests. The fauna includes species of the taiga alongside southern Manchurian species. It includes notable mammals such as the Amur Tiger, Siberian Musk Deer, Wolverine and Sable.

reviews.text: Really beautiful animals

During a solitary Christmas I immersed myself in reading Arsen'ev, your photos conveyed to me the wonder and uniqueness of those places
Thank you

A real miracle. After V. Arsenyev’s books on the Ussuri region and Dersu Uzala, I look at these fabulous places with the help of a smartphone and the Internet. Thanks to Google, thanks to the people who posted these photos. I would like to know what brought each of you here?
Like the person writing the first review, my phone brought me to this place, with the help of Google, driven by the curiosity that reading Dersú Uzalá entails.
I also watch it while reading Arsenyev. God willing, one day I will see these places too.

Name: Aranjuez Cultural Landscape
short_description: The Aranjuez cultural landscape is an entity of complex relationships: between nature and human activity, between sinuous watercourses and geometric landscape design, between the rural and the urban, between forest landscape and the delicately modulated architecture of its palatial buildings. Three hundred years of royal attention to the development and care of this landscape have seen it express an evolution of concepts from humanism and political centralization, to characteristics such as those found in its 18th century French-style Baroque garden, to the urban lifestyle which developed alongside the sciences of plant acclimatization and stock-breeding during the Age of Enlightenment.
formatted_address: Pl. de Parejas, s/n, 28300 Aranjuez, Madrid, Spain

reviews.text: Beautiful place and town. Well maintained and when we were there it hosted the wedding dresses of the Royal Family. It’s worth the train journey from Madrid. The palace is not as crowded as others and they have a tour guides who are very good. The forest around is very quiet and well kept. There are centenary trees. There are a few restaurants 10-15min walk from the palace that serve traditional food

Took a guided tour.  Enjoyed learning the history of the palace and surrounding city.  The large trees by the river were the most pleasing part of the palace and gardens to me. There were some aspects that were less overwhelming including the fountains       Also the garish style of decoration is historically of much interest, but not very pleasing to this modern eye.

Absolutely Gorgeous.  Surpasses Versailles. Without the hype or crowds. The carpets are bright and clean the furniture is inviting.  The chandeliers are large and brilliant.  Every painting and piece of decor are worthy of a day of reflection.  It was a gorgeous day - the gardens were inviting.

Beautiful palace and gardens (the gardens are free to visit). You have the option to either do the tour on your own (you can download their app and pay for an access code if you want an audible guide, but every room has a small description in Spanish and English), or as part of a group with a tour guide. The visit takes between 45-90 minutes depending on how interested you are (I always take my sweet time just to annoy my family and because I enjoy visiting palaces) and it's worth going there first thing in the morning as it gets busier later on. I can't remember if there's a café there, but there's definitely a restaurant or café opposite the garden entrance and there are people with flyers trying to advertise their restaurant.
Quite a long wait to gain entry despite pre-booking and paying online. However, it was worth the visit. The route around from room to room flowed well. Beautiful decor

Name: Mining Area of the Great Copper Mountain in Falun
short_description: The enormous mining excavation known as the Great Pit at Falun is the most striking feature of a landscape that illustrates the activity of copper production in this region since at least the 13th century. The 17th-century planned town of Falun with its many fine historic buildings, together with the industrial and domestic remains of a number of settlements spread over a wide area of the Dalarna region, provide a vivid picture of what was for centuries one of the world's most important mining areas.

reviews.text: Such a interesting experience!! The guide we’ve had was friendly and knew a lot of the mine en it’s history. There were also lots of quotes from people way in the past about working in the mine and other stories. When our guide turned out all of the lights, the darkness of the mine was kinda scary. Hope the lady of the mine doesn’t follow us back home!

A can’t miss UNESCO site in Sweden. The guided tour in the mine was well worth it! Friendly for children over 4 .. beware lots of stairs but it was an amazing visit. The museum was also a great informative visit. Lots of great historical information and a inique experience for all.

English tours are limited so book in advance,
Visit musium also.
It won't be that cold inside the mine but wet and water dripping so wear clothes according
A very interesting and amazing place. I recommend a guided tour of the mine underground to everyone. I will put only few photos because You have to go there personally. Highly recomend.

We first visited in April 2022 but that was a brief visit(only the mine tour), we merely took a glance at the museum. We were quite impressed even during that short visit, and decided to revisit.

Today, we spent an entire day there:
- Reached early(0950), and viewed the sites like Creutz shaft, hoist, etc.
- Visited the museum, viewed  partially but thoroughly.
- Lunch at the cafe. We avoided the restaurant this time as the menu didn't suit us but based on our 2022 visit, I would say the restaurant is decent and reliable.
- Guided tour in English at 1330. We actually had booked a Swedish tour as the English one at 1200 was full. During our interaction with reception, they informed us that there would be an additional English tour at 1330 due several visitors.
- Revisited and covered the remaining part of the museum.
- Left around 1600.

The museum is the best part, followed by the 1h guided tour. They have taken utmost efforts to provide information on English. The guides and the staff provided some interesting information apart from the tour as well. The kids also enjoyed a lot.

Overall, it is a must-visit sight if you are in Sweden even for a brief period.

Name: Swiss Alps Jungfrau-Aletsch
short_description: The extension of the natural World Heritage property of Jungfrau - Aletsch - Bietschhorn (first inscribed in 2001), expands the site to the east and west, bringing its surface area up to 82,400 ha., up from 53,900. The site provides an outstanding example of the formation of the High Alps, including the most glaciated part of the mountain range and the largest glacier in Eurasia. It features a wide diversity of ecosystems, including successional stages due particularly to the retreat of glaciers resulting from climate change. The site is of outstanding universal value both for its beauty and for the wealth of information it contains about the formation of mountains and glaciers, as well as ongoing climate change. It is also invaluable in terms of the ecological and biological processes it illustrates, notably through plan succession. Its impressive landscape has played an important role in European art, literature, mountaineering and alpine tourism.

reviews.text: Incredible place highly recommend walking as much as possible. Amazing people and views. Mürren was a very special place. If you have the time to walk the trails it is totally worth it.
This is a continuation of my other posts of Switzerland...our bus driver drove past the beautiful twin lakes - Brienz and Thun - near Interlaken on the way to and from our hotel in Wilderswil.
Very nice hike alongside a glacier, that is actually the combination of 3 glaciers. Not very difficult but also not trivial.

What can I say - it's a miracle that's slowly but surely  melting away. Standing next to this gigantic field of ice made me think about how lucky I am to be able to see it still. Hope we can preserve this for future generations.
The glacier is stunning! And is easily reachable Fiesch - Fiescheralp lift - tunnel - glacier, ~2 hours walk.

Name: Tombs of Buganda Kings at Kasubi
short_description: The Tombs of Buganda Kings at Kasubi constitute a site embracing almost 30 ha of hillside within Kampala district. Most of the site is agricultural, farmed by traditional methods. At its core on the hilltop is the former palace of the Kabakas of Buganda, built in 1882 and converted into the royal burial ground in 1884. Four royal tombs now lie within the Muzibu Azaala Mpanga, the main building, which is circular and surmounted by a dome. It is a major example of an architectural achievement in organic materials, principally wood, thatch, reed, wattle and daub. The site's main significance lies, however, in its intangible values of belief, spirituality, continuity and identity.

reviews.text: Not a great photograph for scale but the Royal Burial Grounds are an Unesco world heritage site for their creativity in both conception and execution. You could probably go around it in thirty minutes but there was only four people in my tour group so we got to ask loads of questions and were there nearly two hours. Women are given sarongs to cover their knees. Definitely worth US$ 20.

Enjoyable tour of a newly reopened World Heritage Site. It was closed for 14 years after the fire and reopened 4 months ago. Tour guide Fred did a amazing job explaining the history to us. Ticket price is USD$20 per pax plus extra tips for the guide

Very serene and calm place a UNESCO world heritage site. Primarily the last 4 kings have been buried there. The place has quite some unique history and the construction is very unique. They charge entrance fee as well.
Must visit place.

Great history of the Baganda kingdom and its existence to date
It’s a great honor to be here
Very good guides who give you all the information, prices are reasonable for all
Bravo Uganda 🇺🇬

I recently visited the Kasubi Tombs in Kampala, and it was a truly unique and enriching experience. The site, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is the burial ground for four Buganda kings and an important cultural symbol for the Baganda people.

The moment I entered, I was struck by the rich history and spiritual significance of the place. The architecture is distinct, with traditional grass-thatched huts that symbolize the rich cultural heritage of the Buganda Kingdom. The guides were incredibly knowledgeable and gave in-depth explanations about the history of the kings buried here, the importance of each structure, and the cultural rituals still practiced today.

However, it’s worth noting that the site is undergoing restoration, following a tragic fire that damaged the main building a few years back. While this is important for preserving the site, it might limit some areas for exploration. Despite this, the visit remains impactful, offering a glimpse into Uganda’s royal history and cultural practices.

If you’re interested in learning about Uganda’s heritage and history, I highly recommend visiting the Kasubi Tombs. It’s a serene place, perfect for reflection and gaining a deeper appreciation of Buganda culture.

Name: New Lanark
short_description: New Lanark is a small 18th- century village set in a sublime Scottish landscape where the philanthropist and Utopian idealist Robert Owen moulded a model industrial community in the early 19th century. The imposing cotton mill buildings, the spacious and well-designed workers' housing, and the dignified educational institute and school still testify to Owen's humanism.
Country name: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
formatted_address: New Lanark Rd, Lanark ML11 9DB, UK

reviews.text:
We visited today.  Parked on the New Lanark Top Car park and walked through the woods, then followed the trail (unfortunately due to flooding unable to use the boardwalk) to the Falls of Clyde. Great information boards on route about the hydro power.
We then visited the Cafe and shop in the old Mill buildings. These  are dog friendly, providing water and treats.  Great food and service.

Visited with family today to see a local attraction close to my wife's family home. I was astounded at the beauty of the village and the fantastic job the trust has done in restoring and saving these wonderful buildings. I was so happy to have seen the buildings from where they were derelict to the amazing condition they have been restored to.
The tourist attraction is reasonably priced at £32 for a small family, but guides you on the history of the Mills and through the eyes of a young girl, Annie Mcleod.being an engineer I loved the working mill machinery still operating and making wool for use in the making of garments.
The tour of the mill brings you into a fantastic canteen with a varied menu for snacks and drinks. Onto the gift shop and it is a mixture of historical gifts, woolen merchandise and locally made beers and gins!
All in all the visit to New Lanark was wonderful, a mix history, manufacturing and seeing wonderfully restored buildings in beautiful surroundings. I would highly recommend a visit, be prepared for the steep walk from the top car park down to the village and back up. There is a bench for the weary half way!

Fantastic place. UNESCO HERITAGE. It was quite a surprise for me. It has a spectacular walk along the river bank.many waterfalls and some animals of the forest. I don't know how I didn't visit it before... it's shocking.
Instagram @javisa47

amazingly beautiful places. So much history and the most incredible walks. Small people had a fabulous time. Unfortunately lunch was very expensive and no one liked the hot dogs. Staff were all just lovely and helpful. We will def be back to soak in the change of seasons. Added bonus catching the little electric bus back up the hill at the end of the day. The driver was such a friendly chatty and informative man who really engaged with the wee people.
Fantastic for a day out, very interesting and great for walks along the Clyde to see the Falls

Name: Saltaire
short_description: Saltaire, West Yorkshire, is a complete and well-preserved industrial village of the second half of the 19th century. Its textile mills, public buildings and workers' housing are built in a harmonious style of high architectural standards and the urban plan survives intact, giving a vivid impression of Victorian philanthropic paternalism.
Country name: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

Name: Dorset and East Devon Coast
short_description: The cliff exposures along the Dorset and East Devon coast provide an almost continuous sequence of rock formations spanning the Mesozoic Era, or some 185 million years of the earth's history. The area's important fossil sites and classic coastal geomorphologic features have contributed to the study of earth sciences for over 300 years.
Country name: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

Name: Derwent Valley Mills
short_description: The Derwent Valley in central England contains a series of 18th- and 19th- century cotton mills and an industrial landscape of high historical and technological interest. The modern factory owes its origins to the mills at Cromford, where Richard Arkwright's inventions were first put into industrial-scale production.
